PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation by honourable senators as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Honourable Senators to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a refusal of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 24 citizens), Calvert (from 34 citizens), Knowles (from 97 citizens), Parer (from 14 citizens) and Vanstone (from 37 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patenting
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Australian Senate.
The undersigned citizens of Australia oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would:

compromise animal welfare, allow genetic engineering companies to appropriate the fruits of centuries of selective breeding, reduce biodiversity, and further concentrate ownership of breeding stock. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and without your intervention they may soon be approved.
Therefore, please take all possible steps immediately to ensure that:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more.
2. The Senate amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We urge the members of the Australian Senate to act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of Australia. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that 219 hectares of reserved forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest in the Otways Rainforests, Victoria has been set aside as a flora reserve, but the rest of this catchment may be cleared for logging.
Your petitioners humbly pray that this catchment may be wholly set aside as a National Estate to protect this unique rainforest.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1 (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in the Parliament assembled, should:
1. By Act, ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. Take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security: Employment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
Your petitioners oppose the Social Security (JobSearch and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, and ask that you prevent it from becoming law.

Were it to become law it would further intimidate, humiliate and impoverish the unemployed who are already suffering because of the state of the economy. There are not enough jobs. The government needs to tackle the economy, not attack the unemployed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(a) the constitutional arrangements governing superannuation;
(b) the taxation arrangements which apply to superannuation;
(c) the adequacy of prudential control arrangements applying to superannuation funds;
(d) the implications for the financial system of the expected growth in superannuation fund assets;
(e) the investment of monies by superannuation funds;
(f) the ownership of surpluses in defined benefit superannuation funds;
(g) the level of fees charged in relation to superannuation fund membership and asset management;
(h) the information available to members of superannuation funds;
(i) the representation of fund members in trustee structures of superannuation funds;
(j) the dispute resolution mechanisms available to members of superannuation funds;
(k) the rules for the vesting and preservation of benefits;
(l) the adequacy of superannuation awards to provide universal superannuation coverage;
(m) the rate of employer non-compliance with superannuation awards;
(n) the ability of employees to make contributions to superannuation funds established pursuant to superannuation awards;
(o) the desirability of providing improved benefits to superannuation arrangements in lieu of increased contributions under superannuation awards in appropriate circumstances; and
(p) any other relevant matters, including superannuation arrangements existing in other countries.
(2) That provision for the composition and powers of the committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with concern the answer given on 29 May 1991 by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in which he suggested that Australian wheatgrowers would not be disadvantaged by the Federal Government's decision to write off almost $200 million owed by Egypt for wheat deliveries;

(b) notes the confusion and possibly unplaced optimism that this statement is likely to cause wheatgrowers, given that it is contrary to usual arrangements for uninsured portions of overseas loans; and
(c) calls on the Minister to clarify the situation, so that wheatgrowers may know exactly in what financial position the Federal Government has placed them over the Egyptian sales.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED STATES ARMED FORCES RADIO AND TELEVISION SERVICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the push by the US Armed Forces Radio and Television Service to directly broadcast their programs to areas around the US base at Nurrungar in South Australia;

(b) notes, too, that this proposal is supported by the Department of Defence and, if permitted, would undermine the main pillars of Government broadcasting policy by allowing an unlicensed foreign-owned free-to-air service to operate in the area of Australian-licensed operators and, because it would not be licensed under the Australian Broadcasting Act, the service would not be subject to any of the usual constraints or sanctions;

(d) calls on the Government to make it quite clear to the US military that such a proposal is totally unacceptable to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a very brief comment about this motion. General Business time is an important time for members of both the Senate and the other place. It is one of the very few times that we have to bring forward matters which are not necessarily on the agenda of the Government or the official Opposition. It is really an infringement of the rights of individual senators for General Business time to be unduly constrained or abandoned, as this motion suggests.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a number of matters on the Notice Paper. For the last eight years, I have not had an opportunity to put these matters forward in the time made available in General Business time. That is partly my fault because I have not insisted upon my rights in this regard. I hope that people understand that I have accumulated some goodwill in this area and I hope that when and if I introduce a Bill it will get some priority in General Business time at some stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The speeches read as follows-
EXPORT CONTROL AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the Export Control Act 1982. The amendments do not reflect major changes in policy by the Government.

The Export Control Act sets up a regime for the export inspection of prescribed goods. These goods include meat, fish, fresh fruit and vegetables, dairy produce and grains. The purpose of the inspection is to ensure that the goods which are to be exported meet the strict requirements set out in the orders made pursuant to the regulations under the Act. These requirements are aimed at ensuring fitness for human consumption, quality and accurate trade description of the goods.

The Government takes a serious view of malpractice in the export food industry. Any malpractice that may endanger the reputation of our export industries and jeopardise overseas markets for Australian goods must be strongly deterred.
Accordingly these amendments include the introduction of two new offences into the Act.

Clause 6 of the Bill introduces an offence of falsely representing, at the time of entering goods for export, that conditions or restrictions applicable to those goods have been complied with. The representation is made to an authorised officer who is usually an officer performing inspection services. The phrase `enter for export' is defined in Clause 3 of the Bill.

This offence is introduced because many goods which are controlled by the Act are prepared without the direct supervision of an authorised officer. The exporter of those goods may only enter the goods for export if the goods have met the conditions or restrictions that were applicable to the preparation of those goods.

The offence has three elements. First prescribed goods must be presented to an authorised officer for the purpose of the authorised officer performing his function under section 10 of the Act. That function is to ensure that the conditions or restrictions applicable to the goods have been complied with. A presentation to an officer at that officer's request will be a presentation for the purposes of this element.

The second element is that the presentation must occur at a prescribed stage of the preparation of the goods. Given that there are different inspection processes for different commodities it will be necessary to prescribe stages of preparation that are suitable for each commodity. Hence there are particular stages of preparation at which goods which exporters wish to enter for export must have complied with the conditions or restrictions applicable to those goods.

The third element is that there is a false representation that the conditions or restrictions applicable to the goods at or before the time the goods were entered for export, have been complied with. This need not be an express representation. It is sufficient that it is by necessary implication because in the normal course of inspecting goods it is not common for the exporter to expressly state that the goods have complied with prior restrictions or conditions.

The second offence created by this Bill is set out in Clause 15. That clause amends section 24 of the Act by inserting an offence of authorised officers receiving goods or services from the owner of a registered export establishment without written permission of the secretary. Section 24 of the Act currently prohibits an exporter providing goods or services to an authorised officer. This amendment complements that provision by prohibiting the receipt of goods or services by authorised officers. I must particularly stress the importance of the integrity of inspection staff in the food industry. Lack of integrity on their behalf will jeopardise valuable export markets for Australian exporters.

Clause 14 of the Bill introduces a new section 23 into the Act. Section 23 provides for the secretary to issue health or fitness for human consumption certificates. Such certificates are usually required to be provided by the exporter to the importing country before that country will allow goods to be imported. In addition the certificates are also used for commercial purposes by the exporters even where there is no importing country requirement, for example to obtain payment for their goods. Accordingly, to facilitate export trade, this amendment makes it clear that such certificates may also be granted where the certificate relates to requirements of the Act or to other matters concerning goods of the kind that are to be exported.
An express power to cancel such a certificate is included where the secretary becomes aware that the information attested to in the certificate is incorrect in a significant respect.

Other amendments in this Bill follow current criminal law policy by omitting references to monetary penalties where terms of imprisonment are provided for. Section 4B of the Crimes Act 1914 will operate and for each 12 months of imprisonment provided for in the Export Control Act, a court may impose a monetary penalty of up to $6,000.00 for individuals or 5 times that amount for corporations. This obviates the need to amend the Act when policy as to the relativity between gaol terms and monetary penalties changes.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
NATIONAL FOOD AUTHORITY BILL 1991

This country has a long history of food legislation. According to the Times of London in 1914, ``Australia was the first of the dominions of the British Empire and probably the first country in the world to enact pure food legislation and to establish standards to which manufacturers of food must conform''. That newspaper reported that there was ` `a pure food Act of the amplest description in force in Australia before the Bill for the American Act came before Congress.''

The need to establish food legislation in Australia was recognised as early as 1838, when the colony of New South Wales passed its Adulteration of Bread Act. In 1863, a Melbourne newspaper published lists of common adulterations in food and then went on to expose practices such as colouring sweets with lead chromate. In 1896, New South Wales passed its Public Health Act, which made it an offence to sell unwholesome or adulterated food or food which was falsely described. Adulteration was seen as both a health safety problem and a fair trading issue.
States retained the right to make food laws after federation and in 1905 Victoria passed its Pure Food Act and was followed over the next five years by the remaining four States.

Changed conditions after World War II made a new approach essential. In the late nineteen forties, the industry established food technology associations in each State and through their Federal body, the Australian Food Technology Association, these associations approached the Government with an offer to undertake preliminary work towards developing uniform regulations.
In 1953 the Federal machinery to develop uniform food regulations was set up within the National Health and Medical Research Council.

The NH&RC had been established much earlier, in 1938, to advise governments on public health matters. Food fell within its interests and when moves were made towards uniform regulation it was considered to be the obvious body with the scope of interests and expertise to guide the regulation process.

Despite substantial reforms to food industry regulation since then-most notably, an agreement by the Commonwealth and States for the joint development of standards-the need for reform remained evident both because of the impact of the food regulation system, the growth of the processed food industry and the capacity of the regulatory system to respond swiftly to public health and safety issues which are of increasing interest to consumers. And much more needs to be done to ensure that the public have a better opportunity to contribute to the framing of standards.

The food processing industry is a very important industry to all Australians. Not only is it a major contributor to our health and well-being through the production of safe and nutritious food, it also provides employment for many.

The food processing and beverages industry represents the largest sector of our manufacturing industries. It accounts for approximately 20%-in excess of $30 billion a year-of manufacturing turnover and employs some 173,000 people.

Australia is a major exporter of food. Our exports amount to over $8.5 billion a year which is over 20% of total Australian exports. Most of these are, however, low value added products. The opportunities are there to expand our exports of the processed foods- Austrade believes that our exports of processed foods to the Asian region could be doubled- but a number of studies have shown that there are continuing difficulties with achieving our full export potential.
The industry was examined by what was then the Industries Assistance Commission in October 1988.

The IAC's final report agreed that the current system of food regulation was a significant impediment to the development of an efficient and competitive industry in Australia-that is to the development of our export industry. Similar conclusions have been reached in a series of reports by the then Business Regulation Review Unit.

The IAC concluded that current administrative mechanisms were costly in terms of time and resources and had reduced the efficiency and competitiveness of the Australian food industry through increased costs and impediments to product innovation and adoption of new technologies.
Moreover, difficulties with the current standards and their administration were impeding gains in public safety and consumer protection sought by the community.

It is also the case that in recent years consumers have become increasingly conscious of the significance of food for health and are rightly concerned at a range of potential issues affecting its safety. They are also concerned about the levels of residues from pesticides and naturally occurring heavy metals that find their way into our food chain and about the type of additives and processing aids used in preparing the food for the supermarket shelves.

Despite the commitment and dedication of a large number of people, the current arrangements for developing domestic food standards are cumbersome and time consuming. Under these arrangements new and revised food standards are developed through a cooperative arrangement with the States and territories. At the Federal level, responsibility is split between the National Health and Medical Research Council and its various expert committees under the Community Services and Health portfolio and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs under the Attorney-General's portfolio. Standards are then implemented through State and Territory legislation.
The major problems with the current regulation system can be attributed to:-
* a lack of clearly defined objectives for food regulation, together with the lack of a single body with responsibility for driving the system and developing standards
* complexities and rigidities which render the present system ineffective at responding swiftly to public health problems and innovations in food production technology, and
* deficiencies in the mechanisms for setting and reviewing food standards.
We also believe that there needs to be more openness in the system with real opportunities for interested parties to contribute to the process.

The current approach to State implementation could also be improved. While some States now adopt food standards by reference to the standards formulated by the National Health and Medical Research Council system, there are delays in States drafting their own regulations and differences in drafting between States increase the difficulty in ensuring uniform interpretation. Also there are differences between State approaches in areas such as food hygiene and food recalls.

Against the background of the IAC report, the Government agreed that a revised mechanism for setting food standards was necessary and should be developed jointly by the Commonwealth, States and Territories. This position was endorsed by the Australian health Ministers' conference in June 1990.

In close consultation with States and Territories we have developed a reformed process for setting food standards which addresses the problems of the current arrangements. In October 1990 the direction of these reforms was agreed by the heads of all governments at the Special Premiers' Conference on Commonwealth-State relations.

And now after such an impressive history in food regulation originally led by the States and then bringing on board the industry, scientists and consumers, for the first time, the Federal Parliament is to have the opportunity to debate the issues and to contribute to the reforms.
The basic principles of the reforms being proposed are:-
* to consolidate responsibility for domestic food standards development with a minimum number of decision making layers
* to ensure uniformity between jurisdictions;
* to establish objectives for food standards;
* to promote coordination of domestic and international food standards;
* to ensure an open and publicly accountable arrangement which would allow input by interested parties and provide for public hearings where appropriate;
* and, importantly, to retain the involvement of the States and Territories in standards development and administration.
These principles are to be adopted by the Commonwealth, States and Territories through the Bill before the Senate and a formal agreement between all heads of government.
Let me first describe the Commonwealth State agreement.

Under the existing agreement each State and Territory adopts the food standards that have been developed by the National Health and Medical Research Council and agreed to unanimously by members of the National Food Standards Council.
The National Food Standards Council comprises the responsible Ministers from all jurisdictions in Australia.

The existing agreement also allows for each State to make unilateral variations to those food standards. It is now necessary to revise that agreement to take account of the decision of the Special Premiers Conference that uniform national food standards should apply across the nation and be regulated by a national food authority.
Under the revised agreement presently being considered by States and the Territories, they would adopt food standards that have been:-
* recommended by the National Food Authority, and
* agreed to by the National Food Standards Council by majority decision.
Now let me turn to the Bill before the Senate.

This Bill will establish the National Food Authority as an independent statutory authority, and make provision for its membership, staffing, functions and objectives. It will also prescribe the process by which food standards are to be developed so as to ensure that all interests-consumers, industry and scientific experts-are involved in the development of standards by providing adequate information about proposals and an opportunity to contribute.

The Authority is to comprise a full time chair supported by four part time members. One of the part time members would be an officer of a State or Territory health authority with a good knowledge of the food regulation system. The Bill requires that the members of the Authority are to have experience or expertise in relevant fields such as public health, food science the food industry or consumer advocacy. The members are however not representatives of the various interest groups.

The Bill requires the proposed National Food Authority to pursue set objectives in making recommendations for the introduction, removal or amendment of food standards. The Authority will be required to have regard in priority order to:-
* the need to protect public health and safety;
* the provision of adequate information relating to food to enable consumers to make informed choices;
* the promotion of fair trading in food;
* the promotion of trade and commerce in the food industry; and
* the promotion of consistency with standards applied to food in international trade.

The fifth objective referring to the requirements for international trade, is likely to be of increasing relevance. The food standards recommended by the food Authority apply to all food sold in Australia-to imported food as well as to domestically produced food. And of course the producers who produce to meet domestic standards would be advantaged if these standards were consistent with overseas requirements.

The role of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-or GATT-negotiations is also relevant. Those negotiations have identified the need to avoid food standards being used as barriers to trade. The GATT goal is to ensure that national standards should be based upon the standards developed by the Codex Alimentarius Commission or where they differ, they do so on a scientifically justified basis. The National Food Authority will contribute to the decision making on Codex standards and, in turn, harmonise our domestic food regulations, where appropriate, with Codex. This harmonisation would remove the potential for accusation that Australia was using food standards as a non-tariff trade barrier.

The principal function of the Authority as set out in the Bill is to develop and review the standards relating to food available in Australia. Food standards prescribe a range of matters that relate to food composition, the use of additives, production, storage, maximum levels of environmental contamination including heavy metals and pesticides residues, labelling and packaging.
The Bill also gives the Authority a range of functions which are ancillary to the development of those standards. Generally, these relate to working with the States and Territories to:-
* conduct surveys of the food available,
* arrange the recall of unsafe food, and
* conduct food safety awareness and education programs.

The Authority will also develop and publish recommended codes of practice and guidelines to assist industry in maintaining hygienic production and handling procedures to ensure the safety of the food.

The Bill goes into considerable detail to prescribe the process to be followed by the Authority in relation to its principal function-the development of standards. The Bill requires the Authority to notify interested organisations, including all State and Territory health authorities and the National Health and Medical Research Council, and to place notices in the Commonwealth Gazette about all proposals to develop or amend a food standard and to invite submissions on the proposals. The New Zealand Government will also be advised, so as to ensure a continuing exchange of information and consistent approach to food regulation between ourselves and our close trading partner.

After considering any submissions, the Authority will draft a standard and once again notify interested parties and the public and invite comment on the draft. When considering the more significant of proposed standards, the Authority will be empowered to hold a public hearing to give interested parties the opportunity to debate the issues in open forum.

This requirement for an open and public process is an essential element of the reform and, I believe, that it will become a model for the approach to making regulations in many other areas. In order to avoid the process itself becoming a barrier to necessary swift action the Authority may simplify the process where issues are of minor significance and has a ``fast track'' available to it there is an exceptional public health risk.

There are limited review processes included in the legislation. An applicant for development of a standard may seek review of the NFA's decision by the AAT where the Authority rejects an application without having developed a draft standard. The final recommendation of the NFA and the decisions of the NFSC are not subject to review.

One of the complaints about the present system is that it can take far too long to consider an application and process it through the complex National Health and Medical Research Council committee structure. The reforms proposed in this system will overcome this by imposing a time frame within which the Authority must complete its scientific assessment of a proposed standard and make a recommendation to the National Food Standards Council. This period is first established as a maximum of 12 months and it may be reduced by regulation.

The Authority will employ scientists over a range of disciplines whose expertise will be supplemented as needed by experts either called on an ad hoc basis to advise on individual standards or employed as consultants.

At the end of this process the Authority will present a draft standard and recommendation to the council of State, Territory and Commonwealth Ministers responsible for food regulation-the National Food Standards Council.

Obviously, under our federal system whereby the Commonwealth will provide the facilities and processes to develop the standards which are to be implemented by States and Territories, it is essential that the States and Territories are fully involved. As I have already mentioned they will be represented on the management of the Authority and will be advised of all proposals coming before the Authority, thus having the opportunity to make submissions.
In addition, the Bill provides a mechanism for States and Territories to be involved in the broader issues such as the development of the policies within which food standards are set.

This involvement will be through a high level advisory committee which would be established by the Bill. This committee would comprise the chairperson of the Authority, a representative of each State and Territory, a representative of the departments of Community Services and Health and Primary Industries and Energy and a representative of the New Zealand Government. Provision is also made for the chairman to appoint other members for specific purposes such as to provide advice on industry and consumer issues.

This is not a committee to routinely examine proposals for food standards. It is intended as a top level policy advisory body to assist the Authority in setting its broad policy guidelines and directions. It would only become involved in consideration of an individual standard when the chair of the Authority believes that top level policy advice is needed-the development of that standard would remain subject to the fixed time scales.

The procedures set out in the Bill represent the best thinking of people working within the present system and have been developed to ensure that the principles of the reforms that I mentioned earlier are carried through into practice. However, with such a major change to industry regulation, we must keep the system under review to ensure that the reforms actually achieve the efficiencies that they were designed to achieve. The Government will therefore instruct the Authority to review its operating procedures after they have been in place for two years to assess any changes that may be necessary to improve efficiency.

The Government also proposes that within its first eighteen months of operation the food Authority should review the policy for setting food standards and prepare a timetable for the review of each existing food standard.

Public confidence in the food supply is essential to protect the marketability of agricultural produce and processed foods. Both Commonwealth and State governments have responsibility, complementary to the role of industry, to promote quality and hygiene and this can be effectively provided through a National Food Authority. The establishment of such a body, together with the proposed Heads of Government agreement, will be a major achievement in removing regulatory impediments to the development of the Australian food industry and establishing an effective mechanism for responding to food safety concerns. The proposed approach is strongly supported by the food industry.

The Bill before the Senate ensures that consumer groups have the opportunity to contribute to food standards and recognises the need for all of us to be able to be confident that food we purchase is safe and wholesome and that the information about that food is comprehensive and adequate. The Bill also recognises the significance of the food industry and the need for interstate and international trade means that the process for setting food standards should be efficient and dynamic.

The bringing together of the administrative responsibility for food standards and imported food risk assessment policies into one body will bring about some efficiencies of operations. However the tight time frames for finalising applications for new standards and the need to review all existing standards for conformity with the objectives set out in the Bill will involve a modest additional resource commitment.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The following message has been received from the House of Representatives:

INTERJECT.PARA: MR PRESIDENT,
The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:
That the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations be amended to read:
(1) That a joint committee, to be known as the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, be appointed to inquire into and report upon:
(a) regulations made or proposed to be made under the Migration Act 1958;
(b) all proposed changes to the Migration Act 1958 and any related acts; and
(c) such other matters relating to the Migration Act 1958, regulations or reports as may be referred to it by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

(2) That the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee elect a Government member as its Chairman.

(5) That the committee elect a non-government Senator or Member of the House of Representatives to be the deputy chairman who shall act as chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee the members present shall elect another member to act as chairman at that meeting.
(6) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(7) That 4 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(8) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to any subcommittee any matter which the committee is empowered to examine.

(9) That the committee appoint the chairman of each subcommittee who shall have a casting vote only and at any time when the chairman of a subcommittee is not present at a meeting of the subcommittee the members of the subcommittee present shall elect another member of that subcommittee to act as chairman at that meeting.
(10) That the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the members of that subcommittee.
(11) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a subcommittee may participate in the public proceedings of that subcommittee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(14) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to move from place to place.
(15) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(16) That the committee or any subcommittee have power to consider and make use of the evidence and records of the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations appointed in the 35th Parliament.
(17) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by the effluxion of time.
(18) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
Ordered that consideration of the message be an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 May, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue for a moment a matter I raised at the Estimates hearing in respect of disclosure of test results. I now have got a copy of the advice that the Secretary to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has received from the senior General Counsel, counsel 3 unit of the Attorney-General's Department, in respect of the privacy provisions contained in section 67 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act. I ask the Minister what in particular invited the opinion and what are the consequences of the opinion in respect of the operation of the Act?
—Can I ask Senator Crichton-Browne to ask the next question. I have someone checking outside. There are plenty of officers out there and apparently one of them knows.

—The only other matter I raise is about the status of the Australian Sports Drug Agency in respect of Australian athletes at events conducted by the International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) in Australia? Who is responsible for the testing and who carries out the testing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian agency has an absolute authority to test all Australian athletes. It can do so at International Amateur Athletic Federation (IAAF) events but that body also has the right to test athletes. As I understand the situation, there is no guarantee that there would only be one set of testers; there might be two.

—Has that process been working satisfactorily or is there some conflict between the two? It seems to me that is the prospect we would be facing, with the IAAF claiming to have the right to test all athletes, but the Australian Sports Drug Agency not having the right to test all athletes unless it is subject to an agreement between Canada, I think, and the United States or the United Kingdom. Other than that agreement, the Australian Sports Drug Agency would only be able to test Australian athletes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that, while Australia is quite happy with the arrangement, the IAAF has expressed concern not simply about what it might term Australian interference but the interference by national bodies at large. I understand that we will be having some further talks with the international body to see whether we can unruffle its feathers. The other question the honourable senator asked was whether the arrangement is working well and the answer to that is yes. In so far as the agency is concerned there have been no problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask it particularly because the object of setting up this Australian Sports Drug Agency, presumably, was to have an independent agency divorced from both the administration and officials of the sports. If they insist themselves on choosing who are the athletes to be tested, the testing process is eliminating the Australian Sports Drug Agency from participating in a primary role in events which are taking place in Australia. This fundamentally undermines the purpose for which we passed legislation in this place last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I did ask at the Estimates hearing whether or not somebody could discover for me what part Mr Rowe played. I asked that for a particular reason. As I understood it, Mr Rowe is associated with the IAAF drug doping agency and he is also in some way associated with Athletics Australia. What concerned me, without making judgment about it, was that Mr Rowe sprang very vigorously to the defence of Mr Plant, who was also associated with the IAAF. He did not defend his role in the substitution incident long past but was at pains to point out that he had not committed any technical offence.

I would have thought that, if he were to have a view at all, he should have been saying that it was an unsavoury practice and not one that is looked upon favourably by the Association with which both he and Mr Plant in some way are associated. To the extent that he is an Australian and to the extent that Athletics Australia claims that it had no contact with the IAAF over the appointment of Mr Plant, I rather wonder what the relationship between Mr Plant and Mr Rowe is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the situation with Mr Plant is a matter of concern for us. Mr Rowe is a member of what is called the Technical Officials Panel of the IAAF; that is his position. So far as Mr Plant is concerned, I am advised that Athletics Australia has banned him from any managerial position with Australian teams, so he does not have an official position of that kind. But I understand that he still looks after a number of Australian athletes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Richardson. I will not labour the point, but it is not too subtle a point. We have the IAAF insisting that it be responsible as the primary body for drug testing in Australia for events conducted by Athletics Australia. For instance, in respect of the Australian national championships the IAAF would claim to be the primary testing body and responsible for that testing, and not Mr Haynes's body. To that extent there is not a separation from the officials and from the events. That would not concern me, except that Mr Nebiolo and his group have a pretty unsavoury past. I take honourable senators back to the Rome world championships as a classic example, when Mr Nebiolo at that stage was also the head of the Italian amateur athletics association, and it is a pretty sordid and sorry history that took place at that time. That body now claims to have control of the testing of Australian and overseas competitors in Australia in events conducted in what might be the Australian championships.

SPEECH.PARA: Mixed up with that body is Mr Rowe, who is associated with dope testing, defending Mr Plant, who is one of the commissioners of the grand prix circuit who was involved in an attempted substitution. Frankly, it does not give anybody much encouragement that there will be a hands-off approach. That is why I ask whether Mr Haynes's agency, the Australian Sports Drug Agency, will be able to test all athletes whenever it likes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered that part of the question a little earlier, but just to finalise the matter for Senator Crichton-Browne, I would inform him that later today the Australian Sports Commission will be discussing with Athletics Australia its program. As Senator Crichton-Browne knows, the Commission approves these programs before approving the very considerable funding that it gives all sports. Because, as I acknowledged earlier, the points that Senator Crichton-Browne raises are a matter of concern, they will be raised today with Athletics Australia as part of those discussions that the Commission is having with that body. The Commission will be endeavouring to get some sort of satisfactory response from Athletics Australia as to how we will do this in future. But whatever happens, so far as Australian athletes are concerned the Australian Sports Drug Agency will continue to test them.
—Whatever the event.
—Whatever the event, we will not be resiling from that.

—I understand that the Department, by way of a memorandum dated 24 January 1991, wrote to the Attorney-General's Department concerning the disclosure by officials of the Australian Sports Drug Agency to parliamentary committees of information obtained under the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act of 1991.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is happening. Perhaps if we could just move on and, whenever the relevant officer returns with the answer, I will interrupt whatever else I am doing and provide the honourable senator with the answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask some questions concerning Ravenshoe. Am I correct in my understanding that the Minister signed an assistance agreement on behalf of the Government on 29 June 1988?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I signed the agreement on behalf of the Government. Somebody will no doubt check whether it was on 29 June 1988, but I suspect that it was.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 2(1) (b) of the agreement refers to operational subsidies being paid on 1 July 1990. This payment was made before then. How could it have been made before the due date under the terms of the agreement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware, there is no term in the agreement to which I could refer to say that that power is given. Nonetheless, the decision was taken given that the money was payable under the agreement anyway and that the purpose of the exercise was to keep the Ravenshoe Mill open, functioning and employing. The company operating the mill produced evidence considered sufficient by those in the Department who were administering the agreement that it required an advance payment because of a number of seasonal factors to which I think I referred in an answer to a question in the Senate a few weeks ago, including a supply of logs because of wet weather and a few other factors. The company had a short term cash flow problem which an advance would assist.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the Commonwealth was liable for the money anyway, the decision was taken after examining the evidence presented by the company that an advance should be payable. What then occurred was an adjustment to the total requested because of interest forgone. I think the original request was for slightly more than $1m, and the end amount paid was just under $970,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer Senator Richardson to clause 2(1) of the agreement, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to compliance by the Company with the provisions of this agreement, the Commonwealth will, in accordance with and subject to the provisions of this Agreement, provide to the company-
(a) an interest free loan of $4.5 million on or before 30 June 1988; and
(b) a subsidy for each of the years 1989, 1990, 1991 and 1992, payable by advance on the first day of July of each such year . . .
Given that payment was authorised under this agreement only to occur on 1 July 1990, how could the payment made in January 1990 be authorised under the terms of the agreement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already acknowledged that under the agreement there is no term which says it can be varied. However, the Commonwealth signed an agreement for the purpose of keeping a mill open, functioning and employing. If a short term cash flow problem were to arise which was going to bring the mill undone and have it closed, then the Commonwealth has a choice to stick rigidly to the terms of the agreement and allow the mill to close or make an advance payment in an attempt to keep it open, functioning and employing. That is what the Commonwealth determined to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This agreement between the Commonwealth and Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd was signed by the Minister on behalf of the Commonwealth. As a result of his signature, it was a ministerial agreement. Is the Minister now telling us that the Plywood mill could ring up the Department and say, `We are having cash flow problems because of the weather'-or whatever- `and we need a cheque for $1m quickly' and the Department would not refer that matter to the Minister as the responsible Minister at the time? If that is the case, then I suggest the agreement has not been adhered to. Could the Minister direct his thoughts to that?

SPEECH.PARA: I will repeat the matters for the Minister: the agreement between the Commonwealth and Plywood and Plastic was signed by the Minister for and on behalf of the Commonwealth. That agreement was to make payments on 1 July. It seems, though, that the mill has rung up and said, `We have cash flow problems' and the Department, without access to the Minister, has signed a cheque for $968,841.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prepared to table some correspondence on this matter. It was not a question of someone from the company ringing up and saying, `Listen, we want some money early' and someone in the Department saying, `That sounds like a good idea, here it is'. Rather, there was a letter to the Department. It may have been addressed to me-I am not certain-but there was a letter to the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: In that letter the company set out the reasons why it considered that an advance payment was necessary. The Department then examined that request to see whether it concurred and, as well, referred the matter to Price Waterhouse to look at. There is correspondence from Price Waterhouse on this matter. There are a number of letters here, which I am prepared to table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister very much for his undertaking to table the documents and I would be very grateful also if a copy could be provided. Did the Minister actually see the letter of request from the company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not see the letter. I did find out about it subsequently. I cannot recall what date I would have found out about it. I may have found out about it weeks or years ago, but I did not see the letter; nor was I consulted about the payment at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department had taken the view-and I am not saying that the Department is incorrect-that payments were authorised by the agreement which had been signed by me. The administration of that agreement in the making of the payments was the responsibility of the Department and it accepted that responsibility. So a payment was made as a consequence of that administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister now says that he saw the letter subsequent to the payment. I ask the Minister: on what date, roughly, did he see the letter and in what context was it brought to his attention? Also, in the course of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories approving the payment, what financial information was provided to the Department by Plywood and Plastic? Did the Department have in its possession audited financial statements, or did it have other financial information? If it had financial information which was not audited, what tests were applied to the veracity of that financial information at the time at which the payment was made? The Minister says that the company said it had short term cash flow difficulties, but if the cash flow difficulties are indeed short term, it would be appropriate for the Department to sight the proper financial statements and, I suggest that they should be audited financial statements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that waiting for audited statements would have been possible. Had the Department decided to wait for audited statements, then I think that time would have run out for the mill to continue to operate. I do not think that would have been very sensible. This was a short term cash flow problem, and so an examination was undertaken by the Department and Price Waterhouse into the circumstances that gave rise to the problem to determine the extent of it, and whether or not the extent of it justified an early payment. In the view of those who made that investigation, both from the Department and from Price Waterhouse, the circumstances did justify the making of an early payment.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of when I sighted the letters that I will table-and if Senator O'Chee does not mind, I will table them as soon as this is over because the problem is that if I give them up I cannot work from them while we are speaking-I first sighted them about two weeks ago, I am informed. That is several years after the event.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The payments were decided upon departmentally. This means that an officer of the Department approved some $968,000 which, I think everybody here would agree, was not strictly authorised under the terms of the agreement. I note that the Minister is nodding and I thank him very much for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst everybody accepts that the Commonwealth had a future obligation to make the payment, my concern is that within the letter of the law the payment may have been unlawful because it was not made on the due date. In fact, it was made in the preceding financial year. It is not the calendar year which is relevant here, it is the preceding financial year. The financial year in which this payment was to have been made began on 1 July 1990-that is, the 1990-91 financial year. The payment was, in fact, made in the 1989-90 financial year.

I also refer Senator Richardson to clause 2(1) (b) of the agreement, which I have already quoted, in which it is said that the subsidy is for the 1990 year and is payable in advance on the first day of July. In other words, not only was it not made within the terms of the agreement in that it was on the wrong date, and not only was it made in the wrong financial year, but also the payment was in effect a subsidy for the 1989-90 financial year when it was meant to be a subsidy for the 1990-91 financial year. Upon that basis, I ask the Minister to advise how the payment was lawful and the basis on which the Department arrived at that conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain that there is much I can add to the answers that I have already given on this question. The Department believed that the payment was made in the context of the agreement and that it was the Government's policy, as determined by the agreement, to try to keep the mill open and to pay quite considerable sums to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Had I been consulted at the time that this payment was made, my view is that, provided the examination by the Department and Price Waterhouse suggested that there was sufficient reason to keep the mill open, I would have agreed. The object of the exercise-the only purpose of this exercise-was to keep the mill and, many people would say, the town of Ravenshoe functioning.

Had we taken a decision not to make an advance payment a couple of years ago and had that resulted in the closure of the mill, I am quite certain that I would have been attempting, in an Estimates Committee, to justify why we had so cruelly closed the mill, taken employment away from all those people and caused great hardship in the town. It is one of those situations in which Ministers and public servants earn their money. We had to make a decision on the evidence we had before us.

Perhaps on the strictest possible legal interpretation, we could have said, `Well, the agreement says the money will be paid on 1 July. We will not vary that. That's it. If you close down between now and then, too bad'. But I take the view that the Commonwealth has already invested considerable sums of money-and it had already made a couple of very large payments-and the view was that, to keep the show on the road, we had to make an advance payment. Had I been consulted, I would certainly have said yes. I do not seek simply to pass the buck and say, `Blame the Department'. In terms of the decision to make the payment, had I been consulted at the time, I would have said yes and, having been in a position to review that decision, I still say yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister indicate to us what letters he is going to table? In advance of having a look at them, could he indicate the sort of investigations that Price Waterhouse made when considering the request from the company for an advance payment? I also ask the Minister whether he might also table the internal memorandum, advice slip or payment that he mentioned in answer to a question a month or so ago when he said he had ticked the payment authorisation at the time. Would the Minister table that at the same time as he is tabling these documents?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I said at the time that I was speaking in the abstract when I said, `When one of these things happens, a Minister would give it a tick' or I think I said, `You'd give it a tick'. Because I was not consulted, I did not give it a tick. So there is no document which I have ticked. There is a document which shows authorisation of payment, however, and I am quite happy to table that. I do not think that that is a problem. It would show that an assistant secretary authorised the payment. I will give that to Senator Macdonald.

SPEECH.PARA: I will summarise the two letters which I will seek to table. The first letter is on Timbertech letterhead, which is a fairly important name these days. The letterhead says that Timbertech is a division of National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd. It is written to Dr Turner, who at the time was the Assistant Secretary of the Natural Heritage Branch, but I do not think he is any more. The letter begins by saying:
The purpose of my letter is to bring to your notice problems we have encountered over the past 12 months and . . . the effect these problems have had on cashflow . . .

The letter then goes on to talk about operations, manning levels, good mill practice, timber extraction, retooling and so on. It goes on to the fourth page setting out the problems that the company was encountering. I will allow the honourable senator to analyse that in whichever way he wishes.

The other two letters which I table are from Price Waterhouse. The first letter-the letter from the company-was dated 13 December 1989. The two letters from Price Waterhouse are dated 21 December 1989 and 28 December 1989. These letters contain an examination of the company's position. They go through each of the company's suggestions and complaints. It is in fact in the Price Waterhouse letters that one sees the suggestion that if a payment is to be made there should be a commensurate reduction for interest foregone. As I understand it, the Price Waterhouse letters do not recommend either way; they simply set out the facts for the Department's consideration. The Department considered those facts, as well as its own investigation of them, and then made the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister indicate what additional investigations the Department made at the time and whether any of them included any investigations into the financial standing of the Timbertech group?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Macdonald's question, I am advised that there was no financial investigation of the group as a whole, just an examination of the situation at the mill.

—I note that the first letter Senator Richardson intends to table is a letter dated 13 December 1989, the letterhead of which is `Timbertech A division of National Associated Plywood Proprietary Limited'. When the Department received this request, did it note the fact that National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd was not the party with which the Commonwealth had an agreement and, moreover, that that party had no authority or right to make a request for a payment under an agreement with Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd? How did the Department subsequently agree to the payment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —We may as well get a couple of things out into the open, so perhaps Senator O'Chee can bear with me.
—Confession is good for the soul.
—I have none to make-not to Senator Boswell, anyway.
—Father Boswell.

—I do not look upon him as a father figure. There is a complex web of companies here, interwoven as company webs can be. It is probably not in the Spalvins class, but it approaches it. The person with whom the Department dealt on many occasions was a Mr Macdonald. I assume that he is no relation to Senator Macdonald. As I understand it, this Mr MacDonald over a period sent a number of letters from Timbertech-this was not the only one. So the Department continued to deal with letters from Mr MacDonald that were on a Timbertech letterhead. I am not certain whether that happened on every occasion but it certainly happened on several occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: The payments that had been made prior to the third advance payment were made out to the company which is referred to in the agreement. On the third occasion, once the investigation to which I have referred had been carried out, a senior officer delegated to another officer-a more junior one-the task of drawing the cheque.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a monumental task!
—It is not a monumental anything; that is the normal practice.
—Paying $1m to the wrong company is the wrong practice!

—It is not a question of the wrong company. I will get to that. Senator Boswell may be having fun barking up the tree, but it is the wrong one as usual. The officer made a mistake, working from the Timbertech letterhead and referring to that in drawing up the cheque. He made an error. Having said that the cheque should have been made out to another entity within the same group, the Department's legal officers believe that that does not present any legal complication for the Commonwealth or any diminution of our chances of success in any legal action we may wish to take.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the reason why I have not yet answered Senator Boswell's question from a couple of weeks ago is that the Attorney-General's advice is being sought on this question so that I can provide a complete answer to Senator Boswell. I think that is the right thing to do. I would like to have the view of the Department's legal officers confirmed or otherwise, so we have requested that. That is the crux of the matter and I do not think there is any point in talking about which officer might have done this. The situation is that the officer is no longer with the Department or the service.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister asking us to believe that a cheque for $968,041 was paid illegally on 9 January, without audited accounts, to a company that went broke three months later, that the cheque was made out to a company that it was not entitled to go-in other words, that the cheque went to National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd, a company that owned a mill in Kyogle, when it should have gone to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, a company that owned a mill in Ravenshoe-and that the Minister was responsible at the time? Is that what the Minister is telling us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —That may well be the interpretation that Senator Boswell puts on it, but it is obviously not what I am telling him. Nothing illegal was done. If the Commonwealth were to refuse the request and the mill had closed immediately, Senator Boswell would have spent the next 12 months pursuing me for doing that.
—It closed three months later.

—I said `immediately'. Senator Boswell would have been pursuing me and blaming me for the collapse. At least it is pretty hard to blame the Government or the Department for the collapse. It is important for the people of Ravenshoe to know that the Government was prepared to go to great lengths to make sure that the mill stayed open, functioning and employing people. Even in retrospect, we were justified in doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already said that, even in reviewing this two years on, had the information that was available to me then been presented to me, I would have authorised the payment. Once a payment is authorised, be it by myself, as it sometimes might have been in other circumstances, or by a senior officer and the Assistant Secretary in this circumstance, one would expect that the right name would be put on the cheque. In this case a wrong name was put on the cheque. But, on the basis of the advice I have received, I do not believe that this in any way diminishes the Commonwealth's legal position. As I said, I am seeking an opinion to have that confirmed, but that is what I am advised by the Department.

As far as the Department is concerned, while the name was wrong, it was sent to the company whose letterhead was on the top of the page for all the agreed purposes that had been put in the letter of the company. That being the case, the Commonwealth's legal position is protected. I am not pretending for a second that this is a perfect exercise. However, I am suggesting that nothing illegal was done and, in my view, nothing improper.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has mentioned a few times that the legal position of the Commonwealth has not been prejudiced by the cheque being issued to the wrong company. Has any legal action been taken or is any legal action being contemplated?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been able to answer those questions for the last three months, six months or however long I have been getting them.
—Seven.

—For the seven months I have been getting these questions. I still cannot answer them. The Attorney-General's Department does not wish to prejudice anything that the Commonwealth might do. While I would love to tell Senator Spindler what the Attorney-General's Department thinks about this issue and what future directions it might take, it is something that I am advised I cannot do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not really wish to get into what recovery action the Commonwealth may or may not take. The question of the diminution of the Commonwealth's legal rights is in some way a red herring, although I do note Senator Spindler's concern that it has been seven months now and there still has not been any action pursued, despite many claims that we will have the information or the report within a couple of days or a couple of weeks. I flag that point.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is still the legality of the payment. Senator Richardson has accepted already that, within the strict letter of the law, the payment was unlawful because it was within the wrong financial year and outside the terms under which it was authorised by the agreement. We now have the situation where the cheque was not only paid outside the terms of the agreement in terms of the date but the cheque was also paid to a company that could not give an acquittal of the Commonwealth's potential obligations to pay to the correct company at a subsequent date. In effect, the payment did nothing to relieve the Commonwealth's future obligations. Senator Spindler would agree that that is a cause for grave concern about recovery actions. We now have the second basis on which this payment is unlawful. The first basis is that it was made outside the terms of the agreement and was early.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not unlawful.

—I do not intend to get into whether it was politically right. We are talking about the legality of the payment. We now have the second basis of illegality, which is that the payment was to a party which could not give acquittal for the debt. I do not care whether it happened by accident or not. It is almost $1m of taxpayers' money. The Commonwealth should not be frivolous with the taxpayers' money; goodness knows, we all pay enough of it. I am very concerned that we now have two bases upon which the payment was illegal.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to raise a third basis upon which the payment may have been illegal. Senator Richardson said that the payment was for the purposes in the agreement. The agreement is headed `Wet Tropical Rainforests of North-East Australia Nominated World Heritage Area-Rainforest Conservation Structural Adjustment Package', from which I assume that the payment is a part of the $75m structural adjustment package for the wet tropical rainforest area. The payments are authorised under clause 2(1) and (2) to be for assistance to the mill.

Under clause 5(1) the subsidy is to be used to continue the operations of the mill and a number of other things. Senator Boswell draws to my attention that the cover sheet of the agreement is marked `In relation to the provision of financial assistance to re-equip the company's mill at Ravenshoe'. Will the Minister accept that, by the payment going to the wrong company in Kyogle, the money was not applied within the ambit of the agreement and was not applied or paid by the Commonwealth within the terms of the agreement to assist the company to which it was due? Can the Minister give an indication of the seriousness of making a payment of almost $1m which, quite clearly from the date the cheque was written, was never going to serve the purposes for which it was intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go into the motives of those who were associated with the company and the mill who were spending the money, the subsequent allegations of what they did with it or the events. If what Senator O'Chee is saying were correct in respect of what was done with the money, it could well amount to a very serious breach of the agreement-not by the Commonwealth but by the company. That is something we may find out later. Senator O'Chee may be right about there being a breach, but not by the Commonwealth. While we are speaking of Timbertech, it should also be pointed out that it is not a Kyogle address-it is an address a long way from Kyogle-but an address in Smithfield in Sydney.
—That's even further away.

—It is a long way away. A lot of companies that operate in north Queensland or rural parts of Australia come out of Sydney, so that is not too unusual. Senator O'Chee has missed quite a few points. I did not say, nor do I accept, that in any way the payment was unlawful. I have already said that, had I been consulted about the making of this payment on the basis of what has been presented to me, I would have said yes, because I would have been very concerned to keep the mill going. That was the undertaking that the Government had made to the people of Ravenshoe. To deny the money, if that were to cause the closure, would have been the most serious breach of that undertaking possible, and I would never have countenanced that. I do not believe that the payment was unlawful.

SPEECH.PARA: I have at no stage said that the making of the cheque out to Timbertech in any way prejudices whatever legal position the Commonwealth might have because of what I would refer to as the purposes. It was not the purposes of the agreement that I referred to; it was the purposes set out in the letter for making a payment which was made in the context of the agreement and made early.

In that letter, as I said, a whole list of circumstances is set out where the cash flow problems are explained. They were examined by Price Waterhouse and they were also examined by the Department. I am not sure how good a lawyer Senator O'Chee is-although I am getting an impression-but I would have thought that any reading of the letter signed by Mr Macdonald would suggest that if a payment is made to Mr Macdonald on the basis of the claims that he has stated in the letter, then he would have to stick to them. Of course, he was a principal of quite a number of the companies in the complex web that I referred to earlier. I think that lawyers with a little more clout than the honourable senator accept that view. Nonetheless, that view cannot and will not be decided in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all-because Senator Richardson mentioned this in a very honest way-I should make it clear that Fergus Macdonald, who the Minister referred to, is absolutely no relation of mine. In fact, I have never met the gentleman, but I have heard quite a bit about him from the people of Ravenshoe. My concern in this matter has always been not only the loss of Commonwealth money but the fact that that money should have gone to Ravenshoe, been spent in Ravenshoe and been used by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd at Ravenshoe to pay the creditors of Ravenshoe who extended credit to the mill because they believed that the Government was financing the mill.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems from information that has been tabled in this Senate that the money did not go to that company and did not go to Ravenshoe; it is being suggested that it went to New South Wales and has been used there. In that way I am very concerned that the Commonwealth has not properly overseen large amounts of taxpayers' money given for a particular purpose which have been used for other purposes. That has caused enormous hardship in the town of Ravenshoe.

This has been raised for over a year now. On 16 October Senator Richardson indicated that, at last, the Government thought there might have been something a little smelly about it, and the Minister was referring the matter to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). That was on 16 October, which is almost seven months ago. Since that time we have been trying to find out what has been happening. In the Estimates Committee hearing on 19 April I asked what was happening and I got no response. On 10 April Senator O'Chee asked the same question. I remind Senator Richardson of his answer at that time. He said:

I understand that some recommendations on this matter will be going to the Attorney-General within a matter of days. I can assure . . . the Senate that we will endeavour to make the information public at the earliest possible opportunity.
Questions have been asked since, but we just do not get any answers. I put a question on notice on 7 March which was answered on 9 April in which I asked:
When is it likely that the Senate will be advised of the results of the investigation.
The answer came back in writing:
I will keep the Senate advised of progress on this matter, as appropriate.
At that time I also asked:

What avenues are available to Senators to monitor the action which is being taken by the Government in relation to the approximately $7m of government funds which appears not to have been used for the purposes for which it was allocated.
The answer to that question came back:
Normal Parliamentary avenues.
