I do not know what normal parliamentary avenues are. If I keep asking the Minister what is happening, how are the investigations going and when is it likely that something is to be done, and I cannot get an answer, what are the parliamentary procedures that I can take?

Mr Chairman, you will be aware, as Senator Richardson will be aware, that I am currently pursuing a motion before the Senate asking that this whole matter be referred to an inquiry by a committee of the Senate. While he was answering a question from one of my colleagues yesterday, in response to my interjection Senator Richardson indicated that he would have no hesitation about an inquiry proceeding. I interjected on Senator Richardson saying that probably we should have a royal commission into this matter, and I think Senator Richardson said, `I would have nothing to hide; it would not worry me', or something like that.

My questions to Senator Richardson are these: when can we find out what is happening with this money? If the Minister will not give me an answer, what are the normal parliamentary avenues that I can pursue to get an answer? Would he confirm his comment to me in response to my interjection yesterday that he would have no objection to a standing committee of the Senate-probably the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts-looking at all aspects of what has happened in Ravenshoe? Aspects such as what has happened to employment opportunities in the town; what has happened to the social fabric of that society; what has happened to the mill; and what has happened to the money-where has it gone, who got it and what should have happened to it. I wonder whether Senator Richardson would be kind enough to give me an indication of his feelings on those three particular matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of things clear first. When I was answering a question from Senator O'Chee earlier I talked about questions over the past seven months on this matter and I went on to elaborate on various matters; I was not referring to the cheque, I was referring to the circumstances of the mill, its closure and how the money was spent.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the questions of Senator Macdonald, I have to operate within the constraints that the Attorney-General's Department has given me. That has been a complicated and difficult matter. As honourable senators would be aware, a receiver has been appointed. I do not believe it has been very easy for the Department to collate the kind of information necessary for it to make its decision promptly. My understanding is that opinion has been sought from senior counsel on a number of matters, but I am not able to go into that. Whatever action is to take place, I am strongly advised by the Attorney-General's Department that I am not at this point able to comment because it might prejudice our legal position. So I cannot do it, much as it would make my life much easier at this time if I could, and I shall decline to do so.

In terms of what Senator Macdonald wishes to do for the people in Ravenshoe, the Government is still negotiating with three potential purchasers of the mill for a further injection of Commonwealth funds in an attempt to keep the mill going. Obviously, I also would not want to do anything that would prejudice that. Those discussions are continuing. I am hopeful that they will result in a decision which keeps the mill going. That ought to be everyone's aim in the exercise. That is why all the Commonwealth money was spent in the first place.

As to Senator Macdonald's question about an inquiry and what it might do, I did say yesterday that in so far as I was personally concerned I had no problem with such an inquiry, and I had nothing to hide on the matter. Given that I have just revealed everything that I know about the matter, I think that honourable senators now know as much as I do and I believe that I have nothing to fear personally from the tabling of the documents or the discussion this morning. Whether the Senate wishes to pursue such an inquiry would be entirely up to it. Of course, if legal action is taken it will be difficult for the Senate to proceed with an inquiry if it affects those court actions. We have arguments about that in here, so I am not prepared to comment on who prevails in these circumstances. That is something we will sort out later.

My view would be that absolutely everything that has happened in this saga will be in the public arena over the course of the next 12 months. If any inquiry is to take place, not just into this matter but into Ravenshoe more generally, because the honourable senator just widened the terms of reference somewhat in his question, I would have thought it far better to wait until that information is properly put into the public arena without prejudicing the Commonwealth's legal position and, when the information is out, the Senate can make any choice that it likes. We will all still be here and those opposite can obviously do it then.

I would advise that, in advance of any action being taken, there will always be the possibility that it could prejudice the Senate inquiry and the Commonwealth's legal position. In any event, I am not sure what documents the Attorney-General's Department would be prepared to make available at this stage. That is something the honourable senator will have to sort out with his colleagues. I would advise that, because there is an inevitability about all of this becoming public, there is probably a better place for it to come out than here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to the Minister specifically on the issue of whether the payment was lawfully made. Is the Minister saying that the delegated authority of the senior officer who authorised the payment, which was made at a time which was in contravention of the text of the original agreement, extending amending, in effect, the terms of that agreement so that the payment could be made in a financial year other than the one specified by the agreement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already explained, the departmental officers who examined this question-and that goes beyond the person who authorised the payment-took the view that the payment was being made in the context of the agreement; that there was a clear Government policy to keep the mill open; and that if the payment was not made the danger was that the mill would close immediately. That is the position they took and they made the payment accordingly. I do not believe that that is unlawful, given that the Commonwealth was obligated under the agreement to make the payments in any event.

SPEECH.PARA: It does change the dates because obviously it must do that if it is given in advance. Giving an advance payment on an agreement is not normal but it is also not rare. It is not rare either in government or commercial circles. Obviously it is only done if one is satisfied that circumstances demand or require it. That is the decision that the Department came to after its examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the Minister has not addressed the direct question that I asked as to whether that officer had authority to vary an agreement that was initially signed by the Minister? There must have been delegated authority vested in that officer to vary an agreement signed by the Minister; is that the case?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am able to, I actually did answer the question but I will do it again so that the honourable senator will understand. The view was taken by the Department that the payment to be made was within the ambit of the agreement. Given that the Department had responsibility for administering the agreement, which is the normal course of events, I do not believe that the officers at the time thought that they needed any other specific authorisation to take the action which they did. They believed that because it was within the ambit of the agreement they could continue on with their administration of it. Whether they made the $1m payment in July or January, it was still going to be within the ambit of the agreement. If an officer in the Department starts on that basis, he is of the view that he does not need any further or specific authorisation.

—The Chair is having some difficulty here. I cannot find any additional expenditure set aside in relation to the matters that are being raised at the moment. I have gone back through the explanatory notes and that seems to confirm my suspicions. I have also had a look at Hansard for that particular day and I notice that there was a great deal of discussion there. But the fact that there was discussion there does not necessarily mean it was in order. I am not ruling it out of order at the moment. I am saying that my suspicions are that we are not quite in order. That being the case, I would like those who are participating in this debate to keep that in mind.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman, I shall do so. I note that my colleague Senator Macdonald made a reservation in respect of this matter.

—Certainly there was a reservation, but the fact that there is a reservation does not necessarily mean that the reservation is in order. I am not ruling at this stage that it is not, but I think that it may not be. I ask honourable senators to keep that in mind as we are debating this matter.

—I certainly shall and, in fact, I only have one or two more questions, anyway. These questions relate to the manner in which funds appropriated by the Department are spent and, in particular, the manner in which funds which were due to be spent in the next financial year are spent in a preceding financial year without an appropriation. My question to the Minister is really quite simple. If Senator Richardson owed money to Bill O'Chee Pty Ltd and paid the money to Ron Boswell Pty Ltd because both companies were owned by the National Party Pty Ltd--
—Is this a hypothetical case?

—Hypothetical at the moment but the Minister may decide to give us some money, anyway. Would the Minister consider that the payment of the money to Ron Boswell Pty Ltd discharged the Minister's obligations to Bill O'Chee Pty Ltd? I ask for the Minister's thoughts on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going around in a circle here. I have answered this question, in so far as I am able to, several times. I am not sure there is much point in going over it, but I will say it one more time just so that we understand. The Department received a letter on Timbertech letterhead which referred to a payment due to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd. That letter contains information as to what was wrong at the company and a request that a payment be made early.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the letter refers to a payment due to Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd and the circumstances of the mill at Ravenshoe, according to the company as set out in that letter, I am advised that the view of the Department's legal officers is that the Commonwealth's position is not prejudiced by the cheque having been made out to Timbertech. Senator O'Chee is obviously of a different opinion. I cannot help the fact that he has got a different opinion, but that is it.

Senator O'Chee must remember that after that letter, prior to a payment being made, the Department examined the request, as did Price Waterhouse. It seems to me from a reading of these letters that the Department has followed the suggestions of Price Waterhouse, with one exception, that being that the Department reduce the amount from $1,062,000 to $968,000; and Price Waterhouse thought that the Department should obtain a deed of release from the company for that reduction as a full discharge of the obligation. The Department did not consider that to be necessary. Beyond that the Department would appear to have followed the thrust of what Price Waterhouse had to say.

On that basis the payment was advanced. When one has an agreement, especially an agreement with a company about the Commonwealth giving money-and it must be remembered here that the Commonwealth agreed to give money, and that part of it was loan, part of it was a gift-it will always be possible that money can be used for purposes that one did not have in mind at the time. It is fortunate for the whole debate that we are having on the Commonwealth's legal position, in any event, that a late decision was made to give part of the money as loans and not all as gifts. It is that fact that enabled the Commonwealth still to be able to protect its position and perhaps, depending on advice, take further action. One wonders how much could have been taken at all if there had been simply a gift.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one last question, and I know that my colleague Senator Boswell has one last question; we do not wish to detain the Committee. Senator Richardson says that the Department was advised to obtain a deed of discharge from Plywood and Plastics.
—Deed of release.

—I thank the Minister-a deed of release in respect of payment obligations which were supposedly to be met by this early payment. The Department did not take that advice. If the Department had taken the advice, it would have been able to secure the discharge of its payment obligations. By not taking the advice it has prejudiced its position. Does the Minister believe that in light of this the payment in question discharged the Commonwealth's payment obligations on 1 July?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the deed of release the suggestion was made by Price Waterhouse that one be sought from the company to say that the reduced payment was a full discharge of the obligation, even though it was a reduction on what the Commonwealth was due to pay on 1 July. The Department's view was that that deed of release would not add anything to the Commonwealth's legal position, so it did not take up that suggestion. It took up the suggestion to reduce the payment by the requisite amount, but not the suggestion to get a deed of release. I do not consider myself expert enough to be able to give an opinion on what effect that might have.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the officers of the Department take any legal advice as to whether they could make the advance payment under the agreement before making it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without wishing to labour the point, the Department sought accounting advice, not legal advice, because it considered the payment was being made within the ambit and context of the agreement.

—If I may go back to Senator Richardson's answer to my previous question or questions some time ago, could I ask the Minister: in the course of normal parliamentary avenues of making these inquiries, when is it likely that the Senate will be advised on what is happening? Could he put a time limit upon it-a week, a month, a year, a decade, a century?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any information now to be able to tell Senator Macdonald when. But in view of the interest shown I will contact the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) myself rather than leave it to the Minister who is currently administering the Department. I will try to seek from the Attorney-General his undertaking to talk to his Department about expediting whatever action there is to be taken, if there is any and, if there is not, to announce that there is not. I will try to do that with the Attorney-General, and hopefully after he has consulted his officers I could give an answer on that matter on Monday or Tuesday. Certainly on Monday or Tuesday I will tell Senator Macdonald what the Attorney-General tells me that I can make public.

—There is one problem that I have of a procedural nature, Mr Chairman, which relates to whether or not appropriations are made against which issues such as this can be raised properly in Estimates committees. I draw your attention to section 3 of the explanatory notes for this Department, page 34, at the top of the page in division 135, where under the heading `Administrative departmental running costs' there is an allocation of $255,000 not allocated to program. As I sense the burden of your remarks, Mr Chairman, it would suggest to us that, because these are not program-specific, we are denied the opportunity of discussing an expenditure of $250,000 because it happens to be non-program-specific. I submit to you in your consideration of this matter-because obviously you were intending to consider the position and perhaps felt that it was inappropriate for this debate to have proceeded or for the matter even to have been raised at Senate Estimates-that, where one has an amount that is not allocated to a program, it raises an opportunity for a general expenditure to be discussed in the sense that presumably, because it cannot be made program-specific, it ranges across matters which may well include issues of this nature. If, for example, there were a wage rise or something of that order, it seems to me that it would relate to anything in the Department. I am raising this as something that could be considered in your determinations about what is appropriate to be raised in the Senate Estimates committees.

—Yes, Senator Baume, I will certainly have a look at that, and you might note that I said that I suspected we were out of order. I did not go so far as to say that we were. It is probably a matter that will not raise itself so much in the Estimates for the Budget, but for Additional Estimates it might be a little difficult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume asked a question yesterday which I undertook to answer before the end of the proceedings. With your indulgence, Mr Chairman, I seek to do so now. Yesterday Senator Baume asked questions about the purchase of Australia II in 1984. The response is as follows: on 4 November 1984, the Chairman of the Council of the Mus- eum of Australia, Mr Alex Dix, announced that the Commonwealth had agreed to buy Australia II for the Museum of Australia. On 4 February 1985, an agreement was signed between the Mus- eum and The America's Cup Defence 1987 Ltd under which Australia II was sold to the museum for $2m to be paid in four instalments over the period to mid-1987 when the boat was to be delivered to the museum. The Department files show that all Council members agreed to the purchase.

SPEECH.PARA: I also have a reply to a question asked by Senator Crichton-Browne. I will struggle with this one, but I will do my best. The Department sought the Attorney-General's opinion because section 67 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act provides for imprisonment for wrongful disclosure of athletes' names. The Department wanted to know whether this had implications for parliamentary committees. The Attorney-General's opinion in summary is as follows:

. . . officials of the Agency could not be required to divulge that information to a Committee. Moreover, if such a Committee is empowered to require the production of documents or the answering of questions it is prohibited from requiring an official to divulge that information to it.

On the advice of the Privacy Commissioner, the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act restricts release of names to the athlete concerned, to the national sporting organisation and to the Australian Sports Commission where Commonwealth funds are involved. At the time the Bill for the Act was debated, Senator Crichton-Browne sought an amendment to allow the release of names to Parliament, and that amendment was defeated. The Government supports the need to protect privacy and therefore believes there is no need to amend the Act at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say at the outset that my amendment was a declaratory amendment. It did not seek to vary the Bill. It was simply restating a fundamental principle, and that is that under section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act there is an obligation upon witnesses to provide information so requested of them by a committee of the Parliament, and immunity from prosecution is provided to witnesses for giving evidence which may be claimed under any other circumstance to be a criminal offence. The claim that would be put would be this: if the head of the Minister's Department provided evidence that under section 67 it was a criminal offence, it would be a defence and an immunity from prosecution under section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. Therefore, the secrecy provisions do not prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: Presumably, if Mr Tony Blunn came before the Committee and refused to give evidence to us, he would be refusing on the basis that he would be breaching section 67 and therefore committing a criminal offence. Section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act provides a defence. Under section 16, it is not a criminal offence. Therefore, there is no defence for not giving the evidence. I find it a remarkable proposition put to us by the Solicitor-General, who I notice in his opinion says that it `probably' would not be an offence for Mr Blunn to give evidence. If it is not an offence, the secrecy provisions do not prevail.

My declaratory amendment was simply to reinforce the fact that section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act prevails with respect to the hundreds of clauses and the hundreds of Bills that contain secrecy provisions. I continue to argue, as do most sensible people, that no offence is being committed by any witness giving evidence before a committee of the Parliament. That is why I find the opinion of the Solicitor-General remarkable, particularly when he uses the word `probably'.

With your indulgence, Mr Chairman, I wish to table a response that I received from the Clerk with respect to this matter in which he puts a view which sits comfortably with my own, and that is that section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act prevails. He states:

The opinion concedes that, because of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, a person `probably' could not be punished for giving evidence to a Parliamentary committee contrary to the secrecy provisions.

That is the very point I am making. For instance, if Mr Blunn cannot be punished, therefore the secrecy provisions do not prevail because he is covered by immunity under section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. I find it a remarkable situation that we find ourselves in when the Solicitor-General is suggesting that they cannot give evidence.

I was not wishing for any unreasonable disclosure, but I find this remarkable when we have an Australian Sports Drug Agency set up under an Act of Parliament to give it both discretion and autonomy so that it is not subject to any influence from any other body and is able to test athletes in Australia. At the end of the day-to give a very bad example-if it found that eight of the Canberra Raiders had been using banned substances, eight players would be missing from the team the next time it played and their absence would continue to be a great mystery to everybody, because under the secrecy provisions nobody would be allowed to know that the eight players tested positive. We would have to assume that they had all come down with some terrible disease at the same time, which I find an absolutely bizarre situation.

I acknowledge the secrecy concerns in this matter. However, one of the deterrents, as Ben Johnson will tell anybody, of testing positive to a banned substance is the public humiliation that goes with being found to be a cheat. In my view, at the end of the day that is a greater sanction than any other penalty, not the least being of a pecuniary nature. There is a great deal of persuasion to be had, with respect, in having a disclosure of that nature. I also find it bizarre that, as I understand the current ruling, where an athlete is tested and is found negative that cannot be disclosed. Unless I am wrong, it is not possible for the agency to disclose that Mal Meninga has been tested and found negative. Surely there is some virtue in demonstrating that the athletes are clean and that the Australian Sports Drug Agency is doing its job. I seek leave to table the opinion from the Clerk.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give a brief response. First, the Government is looking at an amendment to cover the last point raised by Senator Crichton-Browne, that of disclosing the names of those who do not test positive. In response to the rest of what he had to say, all I can say is that the current Minister does not share his view. The honourable senator should think about that.
—I defend her right to be wrong!

—It is because it is acknowledged that there is a problem that the opinion was sought. It is the Attorney-General's opinion, not the Solicitor-General's opinion. That ought to be made clear on Gavan Griffith's behalf, so I correct that matter for the record. Obviously, it is a very difficult point.

SPEECH.PARA: I am told the Attorney-General's Department was aware of the Clerk's view in the preparation of its opinion and specifically referred to it during the course of that opinion. So it had taken that into account. It obviously has a difference of view. I have been called upon far too often to give legal opinions here, contrary to Standing Orders, this morning and I would not seek to give a further one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was seeking to table both opinions. I was listening carefully when Senator Richardson said, `Think about that'. The present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories once made the observation, in the midst of a speech, that she thought we had gone over the top with this drugs in sport business. People have been dying ever since from drug abuse. I do not know what the quantum judgment is on the meaning of `over the top'. As long as we have the continuing levels of abuse, I do not believe we have gone over the top.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure there is nobody who would stand up and argue with me that power-lifting in Australia has cleaned up its act. That includes the drug free group, which these days seems to test positive as often as-I was going to say the non-drug free-the other body as well. That is why I kept out of that debate on that matter at that time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D
Motion (by Senator Richardson) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee D be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now consider the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services.

—In keeping with the reservations on Estimates Committee D, I refer to some of the unanswered questions that were raised in the Estimates Committee and subsequently answered. I refer to a question I asked on the consultancies given to external board members of the Department of Administrative Services and the quite extraordinary amounts of money apparently paid to one of the board members, Mr Cowley. He operates a consultancy organisation called Palmer Cowley Consultants International. Who is the Palmer of Palmer Cowley?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will find out and let Senator Parer know.
—I wanted to confirm that it was not one of the other board members.
—No, it is not.

—Another question involves the sheer volume of work. The response is that it is no longer a requirement to automatically call public tenders for Commonwealth purchasing, and I understand that. The total of $118,497 on its own would not be a problem, but where it involves board members of the Department of Administrative Services does the Department consider that it is ethical for a board member to be given consultancy work without the requirement to go to tender-although in some cases tenders were called?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Parer is suggesting any impropriety here. It is fair to say that Mr Cowley is a professional in his own right. Unless there is a suggestion of impropriety, we do not think there is anything improper in the way he has been used and selected for the work that he has been involved with.
—Senator Parer, I am having a little difficulty knowing where you are.
—It is the unanswered question `Contracts to DAS Board of Management members'.
—If I can follow that up, there are procedures in place to ensure that everything is above board. If Senator Parer would like some more information on those, we will provide it for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Minister that, in the answer given to me, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is no longer a requirement to automatically call public tenders for Commonwealth purchasing.

The answer refers to the `principles of value for money; open and effective competition; specifications; ethical behaviour and fair dealing'. If a person is a board member of the Department of Administrative Services, is it considered ethical for a board member to be given consultancy work when there are other consultants out there who should be given the opportunity to do the same?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Many other consultants get work from the Department of Administrative Services. One person should not be excluded because he or she has qualified sufficiently to be on the board of DAS. I do not think there is anything unethical about what has happened with Mr Cowley. Unless Senator Parer has any concrete allegation to make, we should not be making such inferences.

—It is not a matter of allegations and inferences; it is a matter of whether it is ethical that someone appointed to the board of a government department should be given consultancy work within the Department without tenders being called.
—I have answered.

—I do not believe the Minister has answered. Is it an ethical practice? Is it something we can see going on? How extensive is it? Is it not improper for someone on the board who knows the operations of the Department to be given jobs? Some of those jobs are not small jobs, although some of them certainly went for tender. Surely, the propriety that is required for a department of the nature of the Department of Administrative Services is such that board members should be excluded from consulting their own Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the answer provided to Senator Parer is worth restating for the record. The DAS board is far removed from the selection process for consultancy contracts. Written instructions were promulgated to senior management in DAS concerning the guidelines to be followed in dealing with external members of the DAS board, including the separation of business dealings with individual DAS board members from their board membership.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer is talking of an enormous organisation-Administrative Services-with a quite diverse and widespread range of functions. It is a body which is moving from the traditional Public Service structure to a much more commercially orientated one. In the process, it is using the expertise of a whole range of personnel, Mr Cowley being one, both inside and outside the public sector.

As I say, the first part of the answer to Senator Parer states the Government's position in that the DAS board is removed from the selection process and structures are in place to ensure that there is no unethical behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have already covered the Palmer Cowley Consultants International matter, but could the Minister tell me who Customer Satisfaction Pty Ltd is?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is a private sector company and Mr Cowley is on its board. Since we are pursuing the Cowley matter, let me also say that I am advised that he does leave the board if there are any indications that a consultant will be employed on a particular task. Let me also remind the Committee that, when we are talking about the board of management, we are talking about a body which is advisory to the Secretary. We are not talking about one that controls the Department. It is advisory in that it consists of a diverse range of personnel from private and public enterprise and the trade union movement. It is, as I say, an advisory body to the Secretary-one which has worked quite remarkably well, in fact.
—Could the Minister advise me what the board members are paid?
—I am advised that it is approximately $15,000 per annum.

—The fact that a board member is paid $15,000 per annum and then picks up another $111,000 in consulting fees to the Department, the advisory board of which he is on, certainly explains the concerns we have. The other question I ask is: what is the Bowden Sexton Consulting Group? Is it related to Mr Cowley as well?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it is, but I am not advised at this stage as to the relationship they have.

—I wonder whether the Minister could get confirmation, because it appears to me that we have four groups involved here. We have Mr Cowley, Palmer Cowley Consultants International, Customer Satisfaction Pty Ltd and now we have the Bowden Sexton group. Could the Department give me information on those people?
—Can Senator Parer be somewhat more specific as to what information he wants?
—I want information on company structure, who controls the companies and the ownership of them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —They are private companies. We will attempt to obtain the information as soon as we can and provide it to Senator Parer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question on unanswered question No. 19, which was asked by Senator Parer. It appears at page D29 1 of the transcript of Estimates Committee D and concerns overtime payments from July 1989 for members' and senators' staff and electorate telephone bills. I certainly was not a party to his asking this question nor was I very interested in it until I saw the results that were distributed to all honourable members and senators. Obviously, the figures got much further than that because I believe that they have been published in some newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: Against my name for the period from 1 July 1990 to 28 March 1991 there is a figure of $4,490.68 for overtime. In my office I am pretty conscious of overtime and I run my office exactly as I run my private office. I know that staff are entitled to overtime, but I have only one full timer and the other two jobs are taken up by four part timers, so I expected to see a nil figure against my name. When I picked up the results I saw the figure of $4,490. As I said earlier, I did not particularly want this information but, as this is the information that went out, I presumed that it would be correct. Can the Minister give me any reason why it would not be correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that Senator Panizza has already taken this up with the Department and has been advised that the point he makes is right. There was a mistake.
—How many more mistakes?

—We could not do without Senator Walters, could we? I am trying to answer the question. There is a mistake in that respect and Senator Panizza has been advised accordingly. No other mistake has been brought to our attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made a phone call to the Department, as the Minister has pointed out, and I did receive a letter saying that there was a mistake, but there was not a hint of an apology nor have other honourable members been advised that there may be mistakes. I asked at the time whether I was the only one complaining and I was given the answer no, I was not the only one complaining.

SPEECH.PARA: I had certain suspicions and I made some inquiries in my office as to whether staff members had been signing their own overtime forms or something like that. I did not seriously think about it, but I asked what had gone wrong and when I made the phone call to the Department I was told. I received no hint of an apology, nor has a corrected version of these figures been sent around. As Senator Walters has pointed out, how many more mistakes can be expected? Can I expect that the Department will go through the results again and send around a corrected version?

When querying this figure I also asked whether, as this year's figure was wrong, last year's figure was also wrong. When I have had overtime paid in my office in previous years, were the figures right or wrong? I have had no advice yet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: (12.01 p.m.) I am further advised that there was one other complaint, and that was from Mr Bruce Lloyd. That case has been corrected as well, leading to his amount being reduced by $30,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply, but I would like to know whether there is going to be a correction. This is not the first time that something like this has happened. It happened with the figure for my spouse's travel to Canberra a couple of years ago. Figures were published in one of the newspapers in Western Australia in relation to spouse's travel. I received notification asking for the information-I know that I am getting away from the subject, but I want to use it as a case in point-I did not have the time to check it, and I know that it was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, these figures have gone out beyond this place. I suppose there is no reason why they should not go beyond this place, because they are public knowledge and the public is entitled to know about what is going on, and nothing has been corrected. Can I expect an answer from the Minister as to when all honourable senators will be advised that there has been a check on this answer, and when they will be advised of any mistakes, just as the Department has advised how much has been spent by each office to date?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: (12.04 p.m.) I think the most appropriate way of rectifying the record is by this discussion we have just had. It will obviously appear on the record that the corrections have been made with respect to Senator Panizza and Mr Bruce Lloyd, whose overtime expenditure has been reduced from $84,000 to $54,000 for the financial year in question. By placing that on the record in this discussion, honourable senators and members will be advised of the corrections in the way that they received the first supply of information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer but I believe that that is not a satisfactory way to go about it. It is satisfactory to me, because my bill will be sorted out. I want it to be sorted out for the previous two years to find out whether the bill for those previous two years is correct. I did ask the Department about that by telephone and I have not heard back from it. I did get a letter but there was no hint of an apology. I take it that that will settle my case, but it still leaves other senators and members up in the air as to whether theirs is correct or not.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move on to telephone costs. I think I asked the Department to check that my electorate telephone costs were correct. I presume-and no doubt the Minister will tell me-that this is the figure only for the electorate office, not for the private home. I would like a comment on that. What led me to believe that the telephone costs may have been wrong was when I ran through everyone's bills to see how my office was averaging and whether mine was above or below those of other members and senators. I looked at the bill for my old friend and colleague Senator P.A. Walsh and found that he had $42 against his electorate telephone for the year 1.7.89 to 30.6.90. Either he has been very inactive or something could be wrong there. Bearing that figure in mind, could I have an indication as to how accurate the telephone bills are?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the telephone accounts are accurate. In respect of Senator Walsh, it should be remembered that no-one is trying to suggest that he was out of contact with people. For most of that period, he was a Minister. It is probably a fair assumption to make that his telephone bill would have been paid by his then Department, the Department of Finance. What we have here are electorate telephone costs paid by the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take that as an explanation that a different department may be paying for his account. I would still like an indication as to whether the Department is going to check the telephone costs that have been billed against each office. No doubt I will hear from the Minister on that in time.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to a personal telephone account which gives an example of what I am on about. In some cases accounts from some exchanges, certainly the main ones around Australia-and Senator Patterson raised this privately-show the details of telephone calls on the back. I would like to know whether these detailed accounts go to the Department. I have nothing against detailed phone accounts. I can see the Minister is smiling because he is worried about who I may be ringing. If the details of all our phone calls go to the Department, I believe that that is not right. As I have said, I believe in having detailed accounts so that when a senator is running an office, whether it be an electorate office or a private office, that senator can keep an eye on how things are going and can use the accounts to allocate costs of calls to certain items. That is useful in private business. In the case of electorate business, I find it rather disconcerting that the Department is getting a list of all the numbers that I ring. There are no worries about that when it comes to my private office. I tell the Minister that I will sit down as long as he understands the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got the question. I addressed this issue some time ago when the supply of those full accounts was going to be made available by Telecom. We have decided to ask Telecom not to provide the Department with any details of phone accounts of members of Parliament. The issues that Senator Panizza raised were important. Of course, he would not want anyone using the freedom of information provisions to obtain details of the telephone accounts of some of our colleagues. So we have decided that itemised accounts should not be made available. In the past, there was a practice whereby details of trunk calls were provided to the Department, but the request now is that, in the interests of privacy, no details of phone calls of members of parliament should be made available to the Department.

—I have one final question on that matter. Could the Minister give me an idea as to when he gave that instruction and whether those instructions are retrospective? It does not worry me if the details on the back of that phone account relate to my office. But it does worry me that there may be some phone accounts that show, for instance, that I rang the Minister or that I rang someone in the Department, as I did when I was complaining. That is certainly material that can be used in a way other than for which it was intended.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that, if the record shows that Senator Panizza rang me, he would be in real trouble. I gave that instruction something like three or six months ago. I do not have the precise details as to when it was, but it was in response to correspondence from Mr Scholes who was concerned about this issue as well. In response to that we made a decision to ensure that records would not be made available. I can get Senator Panizza precise details of the date of the decision.

—I will wind this up. We appreciate the fact that the details of phone calls should not go through the Department. This matter has been raised with me by a number of senators and members on both sides. To enable members to check that nobody is coming in from outside and using their phones, I recommend that Telecom provide direct to the member a detailed account, which seems to be a fairly simple way to do things.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will attempt to work with Telecom to see whether that can be done. What may be simple to us may not be simple to Telecom, but we will try to get that arranged.

—This practice concerns me doubly because on many occasions in this chamber I have asked about the practice of keeping a record of telephone calls that are made from members' and senators' offices in this building. Previously I have been given assurances that this does not occur. But indeed, there is a system of keeping a record of calls that are made here, and I was informed that snippets of conversations were stored as well. To find now that in fact lists of telephone calls which members and senators make are made available to the Minister and to his Department--
—The answer is that they are not.

—Were made available to the Department; I put that in exactly the same category. I ask the Minister very specifically on what date the practice of forwarding that information to his Department began. On what date did it cease? What is done with the records that are already within his care and control? Will the Minister give me an assurance that those records will be destroyed without any copies being made or kept and that no other person has had access to them so that they could keep a private list of telephone calls that have been made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that details only of trunk calls have been provided since the 1950s or thereabouts.
—I am not asking about those.
—Senator Bishop will get a full answer. That practice has occurred since the 1950s or thereabouts when the Department first started paying bills of members of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of itemised accounts, my understanding is that, although that practice was going to begin, we stopped it before it had started. I will check that. I will also provide for Senator Bishop details of the date of the decision. The moment this matter was brought to my attention by Mr Scholes I was concerned about it and took action as soon as possible thereafter. My understanding is that fully itemised accounts were never provided. Trunk call accounts have been provided since the 1950s, but we managed to stop fully itemised accounts being provided before the practice started. There might be some further elaboration on that because some accounts might have got through, but I am advised that they did not. If any records are available I will take steps to see whether we can destroy them as the honourable senator requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. We must have a problem over the definition of `practice' because I am holding in my hand an itemised account concerning Senator Panizza's calls. When did this nonpractice begin? How many members and senators were affected? I am pleased that the Minister will give me an assurance that if any such records exist they will be destroyed. I should also like the assurance that no third party has had access to them or will have access to them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have obviously not seen that account; nor can I speak here for any member's or senator's telephone accounts that go through this building. I would like to see at least the date of that account, if the honourable senator removes from it all of the itemised numbers and so on. I will double check to ensure that the practice has not been in place, as I am advised that it has not. If records exist they will be destroyed as the honourable senator requests. I also give the assurance that neither anyone in my office nor I have seen any details of accounts.

—I thank the Minister. As this line of questioning has related to telephone calls from the electorate office, I would also like to ask similar questions and receive similar assurances with regard to telephone calls which are within the residence and which the Department of Administrative Services deals with in a manner similar to the way in which it deals with our electorate office phones.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —From my recollection the decision was that the practice would apply to both residential and office accounts. We will now obviously go back and give the honourable senator the date and details of the decision in respect of those as well, but the answer is that they were to be treated in the same way as electorate accounts.

—The Minister has given the assurance that any records which he holds will be destroyed and that the practice, if it has indeed been in operation, has now desisted and will never again be introduced; is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that, from my first being made aware of it, I was of the opinion that the practice should not be allowed either to commence or to continue. That is still my position and I have no intention at all of reactivating the practice. The only thing I would be inclined to do is take up Senator Parer's suggestion and see whether we can make the accounts available to individual members and senators. If there are any records about, they are not ones which I or my officers know about. But if they are about, we will make sure that they are destroyed.

—With regard to Senator Parer's suggestion, if that is to be introduced it might be a good idea if it were at the request of the member or senator requiring the information because the whole thing smacks of 1984 all coming a bit late, does it not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —That suggestion is also a valuable one. We would obviously want to be sure that if an account is made available to a member or senator provisions are in place to ensure that copies of that account do not go anywhere else within the system. That would be the main factor that would dictate whether Telecom Australia can in fact make those accounts available to members and senators. I think there are also dangers in having Telecom run off our accounts. That is something we will have to look at as well.

—I was just going to raise that point. The Minister clearly does not have responsibility for Telecom, but I think it raises the question of how secure Telecom's records are and who has access to those records. I am one of those who are of the opinion that once records and volumes of information are created they are attractive to someone, and once they are attractive to someone somebody else will make them available. That seems to be the experience no matter how allegedly secure databases are. The fact is that once they exist somebody gets access to them and they will be used in a way in which they ought not to be used.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bishop makes a very valid point. We will refer this part of the transcript to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) to see whether he can take an interest in it as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a general comment about the large number of questions on notice that we have before us. I also have a particular question relating to some matters that I put on notice, the answers to which have now been supplied. It was very clear in Estimates Committee D that the Minister adopted a very restrictive approach to the sorts of questions which could be answered on the Additional Estimates. That caused quite a deal of debate in the Committee and, in the end, a large number of questions which, in my view, could have been dealt with in a very expeditious manner were referred to the Department on notice. There are some problems associated with that. One is that we did not get answers that could have been quickly followed up at the time. Perhaps matters of apparent concern to members of the Committee could have been dealt with in a very quick manner. But that was not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to you, Mr Chairman, that in a number of other committees-in particular, Estimates Committee A-a very wide range of questions were permitted during the Additional Estimates hearings. For example, I recall that in Committee A Senator Schacht and Senator Coates were allowed by the President of the Senate to put a very wide range of questions to the Clerk of the Senate. I noticed that the Clerk did not worry about that and neither did the President or the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Childs, and I think that is fine. But I put it to you that if those rules apply to Labor senators in particular committees it is quite intolerable for coalition senators to find when they go to their committees that the responsible Minister has decided that there will be a very restrictive interpretation of which questions may be asked.

This caused particular problems because in this Committee there was a desire to get through the material as quickly as possible, and there were general agreements to that effect. I cannot speak for my colleagues, but in future when we are faced with the Additional Estimates I shall be very loath to make any general agreements with anyone about cutting down the time in which hearings are to take place, when those views and that cooperative spirit are in no way reciprocated by the Minister at the table.

I ask you, Mr Chairman, to look very closely at the situation where Senator Bolkus in Estimates Committee D took an exceedingly restrictive approach to the questions which were able to be asked, whereas Senator Childs in his Committee took a very open and, in my view, very appropriate approach to the questions which were able to be asked. I think it is important that some ruling be made or some view be given. As I said, I find it extraordinary that Labor senators were able to range far and wide over a wide range of topics with not a hint of protest, while Liberal and National Party senators on the Committee of which I was a member were constantly prevented from asking questions by the Minister at the table. That is the general comment I wanted to make and I hope the Minister will take it on board. I hope that you, Mr Chairman, in your role will also take those comments on board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to those comments, I think it is fair to say that we do not suffer from an overdose of consistency in Parliament. In the Estimates Committee I took the view that we were talking about Additional Estimates and that is where the questioning should have been directed. Senator Kemp makes the point that other senators in other committees were allowed to stray far and wide from that. In another part of this Committee I had to raise points of order against questions asked by the Chairperson because I felt that they were not going to the Additional Estimates. I understand the problem Senator Kemp would have had in trying to ask questions from his side when I was trying to keep the Committee on course in terms of the Standing Orders. I was heartened to hear Senator Kemp refer to Estimates Committee A and Senator Schacht and Senator Walsh asking questions. In respect of Senator Schacht asking questions, our colleague Senator Bishop stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, with respect, Senator Schacht just asked the Clerk whether this was being paid out of the Additional Estimates. He answered that, no, it was coming out of existing appropriations. Therefore, presumably it is not relevant to this inquiry.
Senator Bishop was taking the same line in Estimates Committee A that I was trying to pursue in Estimates Committee D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that make it right?

—I think it is a strange coalition for a start. Both of us appreciate that we are talking about Additional Estimates. What I was trying to do with this Committee was to steer it on to Additional Estimates, as Senator Bishop was trying to do with Committee A.

—I will respond to the suggestion that Senator Kemp has just made. Although I am called Chairman of Committees, I do not have any authority in relation to Estimates committees. The word `Committees' refers to the various committees that are formed in this chamber. As the honourable senator probably realises, I do go round and look at how some of the committees are operating, which makes my job a bit more meaningful when the matter is considered in the Committee of the Whole. I do know a little of what happened in Estimates Committee A, but I am not sure of what happened in Estimates Committee D as I do not know that I got there at the relevant time. I hope that Estimates committee chairmen will make sure that any debate is on the actual estimates before them-in this case the Additional Estimates, or in the Budget Estimates-because it makes my job a little difficult if I find out in the Committee of the Whole that debate has ranged over matters which are not relevant to the Additional Estimates. I think that Senator Kemp's comments probably have been taken on board. In some of the informal meetings I will mention them to the chairmen of the committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I thank you for your helpful comments. Senator Bolkus missed the general thrust of what I was saying. I was saying that there was a difference between the approach taken at the particular committees. He quoted an extract from Hansard and Senator Bishop, but he did not actually read the Chairman's ruling. The Chairman's ruling, if I recall it correctly, was that in some general way there should be an attempt to relate the matters to a particular item. It was a very general ruling, and was not a bad one. I think that, as a follow-up, it was decided that virtually anything was to do with the salary appropriation; hence a very wide range of questioning was allowed to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it is a bad thing to have rules-I am disposed to a position where matters should be debated widely, nonetheless, I accept the need for rules-but the point is that, in Estimates Committee A, Labor senators were given a very wide range of chances to pose questions. I make it quite clear that I was not opposed to that. It has to be said that the Minister's colleagues who adopted that approach were a very weighty group. Our very distinguished President was the Minister responsible, Senator Childs was the Chairman of the Committee and the Clerk of the Senate was being questioned. It was a very distinguished group of people. I would have thought that, if the precedent is established that a wide range of questions can be asked, it should apply to all committees. Senator Bolkus mentioned that Senator Bishop raised a point of order. In my view, it was quite appropriate for Senator Bishop to do so. I think that a very general ruling was given to that point of order. But if the Minister continues to read the Hansard, I think he will find that the ruling did not inhibit in any way the wide range of questioning which took place.

I now turn to a matter relating to a question on notice. The Minister provided me with some figures on the number of staff and consultants employed by Ministers. I appreciate the Minister providing such comprehensive figures. I wish to put a couple of questions to him. The figures that he has provided show there has been a very sharp expansion in expenditure on staff employed by Ministers since 1982. The figures show that in 1982 the total amount expended for ministerial staff was $4.5m; whereas in the current year it is forecast to reach $15.4m. Can the Minister tell me what amount is forecast to be expended this year on consultants as well as staff?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp made a point about increasing staff numbers. Since taking office in March 1983, the Government has increased the Opposition staff resources by 53 per cent-from 43 to 66 staff-compared with the staff allocated to the previous Opposition by the then Government. The Government in the same period has increased its own staff resources by 55 per cent-from 204 to 316 staff-which includes ministerial consultants. Given the changes in public administration over that time and the reorganisation of the public sector, that is quite an appropriate increase.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that in the same period the average salary mix of the Opposition has also improved substantially. In 1983, it was 60 per cent of average Government staff salaries; it now stands at something like 78 per cent. So there has been an enhancement in the range of salaries. In fact, as a result of the changes in the last eight years and the level of salaries paid, the Opposition can now get better staff.

However, it should be noted that in August last year the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) requested an increase of 30 positions, with an enriched salary mixture to rectify what he claimed was an imbalance between Government and Opposition staffing numbers. We agreed to an additional eight positions, maintaining the relativity with Government staff increases since 1983. It is important to keep that in mind by way of background. One should also keep in mind the fact that there is a major difference between being in government and being in opposition. In government one has to administer departments as well as participate in the parliamentary and other processes that opposition demands.

Senator Kemp asked specifically about overall salary payments consultants for this financial year. We only have an estimation of $1.6m for this financial year for consultants. I will get that checked and provide any more definite figure for Senator Kemp, if that is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister is able to supply the figure, I ask him to supply the figure for the moneys paid to consultants in 1982-just for comparative purposes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that we will try to get that figure, but Senator Kemp knows full well that there has been a change in the staffing structures and levels within ministerial offices and there has been an enhanced role for consultants over that period. However, we will provide the figure for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. I do not know whether the Minister implied it, but it is clear from the salaries paid to consultants and the number of them that they provide a very valuable addition to Ministers' staffs. I do not think there would be any doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister quoted some figures and comparisons in relation to the staff employed by Opposition leaders and noted the trends over the last seven or eight years. Just to be clear, I ask whether the Minister could indicate the total increase in the number of additional ministerial staff that the Government has put on since 1982-I think he may have quoted this figure-and whether the people employed in the two media units that the Government has established are included in that figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given the figures. The figure I gave to the Senate was an increase from 204 staff to 316 which, as I said, was an increase of 55 per cent over that period compared to 53 per cent in Opposition staffing increases. I also made the point that the salary mix was increased quite substantially from 60 per cent of average Government staff salaries to about 78 per cent. I am advised that within those figures we have included the actual media advisers to Ministers and media advisers to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp would know that, in respect of organisations such as the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) and the preceding organisation which operated under the Fraser Government, those figures have been, and are now, kept separate by both governments. Senator Kemp has not asked for them this time. If he has not, I am surprised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I did, actually.

—He did, and they are available. In that respect, it should be recognised that the staff level of the NMLS at the moment is somewhere below the actual staffing level that a similar organisation had in February-March 1983. I do not have the precise figures on that, but my understanding is that there has not been an increase in the number of staff in government media units over that time. In fact, there may have been a decrease in the numbers, though it might be marginal. But we will also get that figure checked out for Senator Kemp.

—Just to get it clear, Senator Bolkus said he thought that in relation to the various media units the numbers in the NMLS, compared with what existed before, had gone down. In the figures that he has included for his Government, has he also included figures for the Ministerial Media Group? I note from the figures he has given us that there are eight positions in that unit. In the comparison between the NMLS and the media unit which existed in the Fraser years, Senator Bolkus mentioned that the figures were either about the same or slightly diminished.
—I am advised that they are within that overall figure of 306 or so which was provided to you.

—The point the Minister was making was that the numbers of people employed by the Government in media had, if anything, declined. He has been a bit selective in the figures he is quoting because he has not included the Ministerial Media Group. Those figures have been supplied to me, but in the figures the Minister is quoting before this chamber they are not included.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take Senator Kemp's point. If one were to continue a comparison with 1982-83, one would find that staff were employed in 1982-83 by the then Government to conduct media functions. At the same time, that Government maintained a unit called the Government Information Unit. I have just come across an article in the Bulletin of 15 August 1989 by Laurie Oakes entitled `People in Glass Houses'.
—The apologist.

—I would not call Laurie Oakes an apologist for anyone, as we find out quite consistently when we dare to go on the Sunday program. He made the point that, when one compares the media units of previous and current governments, this Government does not shape up too badly.

—I suggest that, if the Minister adds the numbers of staff that the Government employs in the ministerial media unit to those of the NMLS, he will find that this Government has been particularly generous to itself in the number of special media advisers provided. If one adds on the 100 or so additional positions which the Minister quoted have been supplied to the Government since 1982 for ministerial staff and compares that with the extra eight or nine positions provided for the Opposition, one can see that he has again been particularly generous to the Government. If one compares the three part time consultants with the 30-odd consultants who are also employed on the ministerial staff by the Government, I again suggest that the Minister has been extremely generous to the Government over this period.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to those points. One would expect in a place such as this that one would make assessments on the basis of evidence and information. For Senator Kemp to ask questions, to go through this process, to get information showing that the numbers of Opposition staff have increased almost at the same level as Government staff but that their salaries have increased with something like a 20 per cent enhancement over what they were in 1983, and then to make those claims about the Government being generous to itself-political cheap shots-does not really help the level of debate in this place. It is really a shocking performance. We expect someone like Senator Kemp, with his reputation and his background, to participate on a higher level of discussion, but we have been let down again.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 12.45 p.m., pursuant to order, I call on matters of public interest.
