SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I want to mention the thirtieth anniversary of the formation of Amnesty International. In May 1961, when Amnesty was formed, the world was a very different place. The Berlin Wall had not yet been built; the first manned spaceship had circled the earth a month before; Marilyn Monroe was still alive; Castro proclaimed Cuba a socialist nation and abolished elections; racial violence was particularly ugly in the south of the United States of America; Sir Robert Menzies was the Prime Minister of Australia; and the general attitude to human rights and especially to the treatment of prisoners of conscience was that torture and summary execution were really quite appalling but, if they happened in another country, there was really nothing that one could do about it short of war. One had no right and certainly no power to interfere in the internal affairs of another country.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Peter Benenson, a British lawyer, read a newspaper article about two young men who were gaoled for toasting freedom in a public place and he decided to try to do something to help political prisoners. His newspaper appeal, `The Forgotten Prisoners', was published worldwide on 28 May 1961 and brought in more than 1,000 offers of support for the idea of an international campaign to protect human rights. Within 12 months the new organisation had sent delegations to four countries to make representations on behalf of prisoners and had taken up 210 cases. Amnesty International members had organised national bodies in seven countries.

The principles of strict impartiality and independence were established. The emphasis was on the international protection of human rights. Amnesty International members were to act on cases worldwide and not become involved in cases in their own countries.

The movement of Amnesty International in Australia began as a result of two broadcasts on Australian radio of the British Wilfred Thomas Show in 1961. The first, on 3 August, told of the formation of an organisation, called Appeal for Amnesty 1961, in Britain by Peter Benenson. Wilfred Thomas explained that its proposed worldwide campaign was to publicise cases of men and women in all countries who were imprisoned for their political and religious beliefs.

On 24 August, Wilfred Thomas interviewed Peter Benenson. He urged listeners to write to Peter in London. Fifty-five Australians responded immediately, asking what they could do to help. By the end of 1961 some 100 members of Amnesty International Australia had written to about a dozen prisoners of conscience around the world.

Since 1961 Amnesty International has adopted or investigated more than 42,000 cases. Each case may involve one individual or many. Of these cases, over 38,000 are now closed. At the end of November 1990, Amnesty International was working on more than 3,000 cases, involving more than 4,500 individuals from countries worldwide. Indeed, 1,296 cases were closed in the first 11 months of 1990.

The Australian Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International has a lot to be proud of. Two-thirds of Australian parliamentarians are members of the Group. We have members of all political parties and Independents, and the Group's patrons are the leaders of all federal political parties. In the company of thousands of people around the world, I am proud to say that I hold a position of significant power and influence: I am a member of Amnesty International.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to talk about the problems being experienced by the Disabled Workers Union in Western Australia. A lot is said about the rights of disabled workers under the Disability Services Act of the Hawke Labor Government, yet a situation has arisen where their most effective voice in Western Australia is now under grave threat. This Government and the Department of Community Services and Health are standing by while the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia serves an ambit log of claims upon the providers of sheltered employment in Western Australia. In effect, this large federal union is seeking to represent the hundreds of handicapped workers, most of them intellectually disabled, for whom the Disabled Workers Union has provided since 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am talking about is a small, specialist union that has fulfilled a need when, for 26 years, major industrial unions could not be induced to take an interest in the disabled workers. This is a union unique to Western Australia, with 2,400 members paying $5 a year in fees. Whenever I have visited sheltered employment facilities in my State it has been quite clear what an effective job the Disabled Workers Union has done. It really is a fine example to the rest of Australia.

In accordance with the wish of the union membership, the award does not contain any wage clause. This reflects the fact that many employees work less than 38 hours. The value of allowances has been reached by mutual agreement. The allegations made against some sheltered workshops during the course of the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs into employment of the disabled as to inadequate remuneration and poor conditions certainly do not apply in Western Australia.

Led by Gloria Cassidy as secretary, this union has displayed a practical approach, appreciating the mix of pay and conditions that its members need and that the institutions can afford to pay them. Members of the union are increasingly tired of having their chosen mode of employment denigrated as repetitious or institutional. It is very sad that there are people who, without knowledge of the way in which sheltered workshops operate, simply say that we must push disabled workers out into open employment, that doing the same job two or three times in a day is demeaning, when it is those workers who choose to do the same job.

We now have an ambit log of claims running to 12 pages from a big union with a new-found concern for the disabled. Allowing for the nonsense of ambit claims in our industrial system-a tradition that does Australia no good-I have a real concern that the Miscellaneous Workers Union will adopt a confrontationist approach that will ultimately destroy the sheltered employment facilities upon which disabled workers will continue to depend.

The log of claims starts with a demand for a weekly wage rate of $1,000 with extra allowances of $100 which are scattered around like confetti. The hours are not to exceed 30 per week. There is to be treble overtime; eight weeks annual leave; 100 paid days of sick leave each year; half an hour's washing time before an hour's lunch break; first class air fares for the whole family after three months work; and free board and lodging.

Among many other things, the number of days off that one can get under this ambit log of claims is just remarkable. Across Australia, there are approximately 250 working days in a year. This log of claims contains an allowance for 40 days annual leave, which is eight weeks annual leave; an additional eight public holidays, somewhere along the line, to those which everyone else gets in this country; and 100 days sick leave. I quote from the log of claims:

Employees who are unable to attend work for reasons of illness or accident shall be entitled to 100 days paid sick leave per year. Unused sick leave shall accumulate from year to year and shall be paid out on death or termination or at any time beforehand at the employee's request.

That is a pretty attractive way to pick up an extra 100 days. The log of claims is seeking an entitlement to 10 days bereavement leave per year, 50 days compassionate leave per year and 50 days of special--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you shouldn't really take too much notice of these logs of claims. Nobody else does, you know.

—I am interested in the comment that the Minister has just made because that is really the point I am getting at: that this is just an absurdity. But what is happening is that a union that has been looking after people in sheltered workshops is now being pushed into a position of having to fight for justice in order to maintain its position. Mr Acting Deputy President, to demonstrate what I am saying, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the log of claims.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE FEDERATED MISCELLANEOUS WORKERS UNION OF AUSTRALIA
SUPPORTED AND SHELTERED EMPLOYMENT INDUSTRIAL ENTERPRISES AWARD
LOG OF CLAIMS
1 WEEKLY WAGE RATES
A minimum of $1,000.00 per week shall be paid to all employees.
2 SERVICE PAYMENTS
In addition to all other payments, employees shall receive $100.00 per week extra for each year of service. This shall be payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award.
3 EXTRA PAYMENTS

In addition to the minimum weekly wage rate, $120.00 per week payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award shall be paid as a composite amount for duties of a special nature or requiring additional knowledge and/or special skill or experience.
4 SITE AND/OR ESTABLISHMENT ALLOWANCE

A minimum of $220.00 per week payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award shall be paid in addition to all other payments as a composite amount in lieu of special Site and/or Establishment Allowances to compensate for disabilities in connection with various sites and establishments.
5 DISTRICT AND DIVISIONAL ALLOWANCE

A minimum of $120.00 per week payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award shall be paid in addition to all other payments as a composite amount to compensate for climatic conditions, work in remote areas, isolation and similar disabilities in lieu of specific allowances.
6 INDUSTRY ALLOWANCE
A minimum of $80.00 per week payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award shall be paid in addition to all other payments to compensate for special features of the industry.
7 REIMBURSEMENT ALLOWANCE
A minimum of $200.00 per week payable to employees to compensate for expenses incurred.
8 SPECIAL RATES
$100.00 per week payable for ``all purposes'' of the Award shall be paid in addition to all other payments to compensate for extra duties required of employees.
9 HOURS
A maximum of thirty hours per week shall be worked between the hours of 9.00 a.m. and 4.00 p.m., Monday to Friday inclusive.
10 MEAL BREAK
All workers shall be entitled to a meal break of not less than one hour after each four hours worked; such meal break shall be counted as time worked and paid for at the appropriate rate.
11 SHIFT WORK

Treble time shall be paid for all shift work performed Monday to Friday, both days inclusive. Treble time and a half shall be paid for all shift work performed on a Saturday, Sunday or a holiday. Shift workers who are rostered off on a public holiday shall be paid for such day at double the rate they normally would have been paid had they been at work or have a day added to the period of Annual Leave.
12 OVERTIME
All overtime to be paid for at treble the rate payable for the day or shift on which such overtime is worked.
13 MEAL ALLOWANCE
An employee required to work overtime shall be paid $20.00 for each meal.
14 ANNUAL LEAVE

Eight weeks' annual leave shall be granted within each twelve months' service. Employees shall be paid for such leave at the rate they normally would have been paid had they been at work, together with a further loading of 50% for each week of Annual Leave. The Annual Leave Loading shall be regarded as a continuously accruing entitlement so that an employee terminating prior to the full 12 month accrual period, shall receive prorata payment of accrued Annual Leave Loading.
15 PUBLIC HOLIDAYS
Twenty days in each year shall be granted as paid public holidays, one of which shall be a Union Picnic Day.
Employees shall be paid for such public holidays at double the rate they normally would have been paid had they been at work.
16 SICK LEAVE
Employees who are unable to attend work for reason of illness or accident shall be entitled to 100 days paid sick leave per year.
Unused sick leave shall accumulate from year to year and shall be paid out on a death or termination or at any time beforehand at the employee's request.
Employees falling ill or injured during a period of authorised leave shall be able to avail themselves of any accumulated sick leave standing to their credit.
17 REST PAUSES
Every employee shall be entitled to a rest pause of thirty minutes' duration in the employer's time in the first and second half of his or her daily work.
18 ATTENDANCE AT HOSPITAL, ETC

An employee suffering injury or a health problem necessitating his or her attendance during working hours on a doctor, chemist or trained nurse, or at a hospital or other medical centre, shall suffer no deduction from his or her pay for the time so occupied, and shall be reimbursed by the employer all expenses incurred in connection with such attendance and travelling.
19 BEREAVEMENT LEAVE
Employees shall be entitled to 10 days leave without loss of pay, on the death of a relative of the employee.
20 COMPASSIONATE LEAVE
Employees shall be entitled to 50 days leave without loss of pay, because of personal circumstances or the illness of a family member requiring absence from work.
21 JURY SERVICE
Employees shall be entitled to leave without loss of pay for any time spent on Jury Service.
22 COMMUNITY SERVICE
Employees shall be entitled to leave without loss of pay for any time spent on a Community Service.
23 CLOTHING
Employees shall be supplied with all work clothing and footwear free of charge; such clothing to be cleaned, replaced and repaired free of cost to the employee.
24 PUBLIC HOLIDAY, SATURDAY AND SUNDAY WORK
Treble time and a half shall be paid for all work performed on Saturday, Sunday and public holidays. Provided that one additional day's leave with pay shall be allowed for each public holiday worked.
25 PAYMENT OF WAGES
All wages, including current overtime and other payments, shall be paid each week in the employer's time. Full details of wages paid shall be supplied weekly prior to pay day.
An employee kept waiting for wages shall be paid at treble time during the waiting period.
The employer shall make such deductions and remittances from an employee's pay as are requested, including such items as Union dues and health fund contributions.
26 MOTOR ALLOWANCE
An employee required to use his/her own vehicle shall be paid $5.00 per kilometre travelled.
27 TOOLS

The employer shall provide and keep in efficient condition all tools and equipment which he/she requires the employee to use, or alternatively where an employee uses his or her own tools he/she shall be paid a Tool Allowance of $50.00 per week. The employer shall insure tools supplied by his/her employees.
28 INTRODUCTION OF CHANGE

An employer shall notify employees and their unions as early as possible of all proposed changes which will affect the performance or organisation of work and shall consult fully with each relevant Union about all aspects of the changes at least 2 years before the changes are to be introduced.
29 TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT AND REINSTATEMENT DISMISSED EMPLOYEES
(a) An employer shall not dismiss any employee (whether or not such dismissal takes place before the making of any award or industrial agreement made in settlement of the log of claims);
(b) An employer shall reinstate forthwith all employees dismissed (whether or not such dismissal takes place before the making of any award or agreement made in settlement of the log of claims).
30 DISCIPLINE OF EMPLOYEES

An employer shall give reasonable warning to an employee of unsatisfactory performance or misconduct and a reasonable opportunity to improve the performance or conduct before taking any action against the employee.
An employer shall notify an employee in writing of a decision to discipline him/her and provide a written statement of the reasons for such discipline.
31 NOTICE OF TERMINATION
An employee shall be entitled to terminate his/her employment by giving one day's notice of termination.
An employer shall give an employee twenty weeks notice of termination for each year of service of the employee or payment in lieu thereof.
An employer shall provide to an employee a written statement of the employee's employment record upon termination.
32 REDUNDANCY

At least two years before any decision with redundancy implications is taken, an employer shall consult and reach agreement with the Union. For the purposes of the consultation, the employer shall provide the Union with all relevant information relating to the decision to be taken.
All efforts shall be made by an employer to avoid terminations of employment due to redundancy.
Union members shall be accorded preference over other employees in retention in employment and in respect of all other benefits or opportunities accorded by an employer in a redundancy situation.
Where the Union agrees that terminations of employment due to redundancy are unavoidable, an employer shall
(a) determine together with the union the criteria to be applied in the selection of employees for termination;
(b) notify all relevant public authorities of the impending terminations;
(c) provide an employee whose employment is to be terminated with
* at least two years' notice of termination or payment in lieu thereof
* redundancy pay of twenty weeks' pay for each year of service
* payment in full for all leave entitlements or potential entitlements
* income maintenance payments calculated by reference to the wage rate of the employee
* payment of all relocation expenses incurred or likely to be incurred by an employee and his/her dependants in finding new employment
* assistance in finding suitable alternative work and training and
re-training as part of this assistance; and
(d) accord preference in re-employment with continuity of service to employees whose employment is terminated due to redundancy.
Where an employee is transferred to other duties due to redundancy, an employer shall:
(a) provide income maintenance payments calculated by reference to the previous wage rate of the employee;
(b) pay all relocation expenses incurred by the employee and the employee's dependents in respect of taking up the new duties; and
(c) provide training and retraining for the employee where appropriate.

An employee shall be entitled to the above-mentioned benefits and payments in full notwithstanding that the employee leaves his/her employment during the period of notice of termination given by the employer.
During the period of notice of termination an employee shall be allowed up to six weeks' time-off without loss of pay to seek other employment.
33 RIGHT OF ENTRY
Any officer or employee of The Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia properly accredited, shall have the right to interview employees at any time at their place of employment.
34 NO REDUCTION IN WAGES
Nothing shall operate to reduce the rate of pay of any classification or other entitlement in existence at the commencing date of the Award or Agreement.
35 WORKERS' COMPENSATION
Employees shall be paid full pay whilst absent due to accident or illness occasioned in or in connection with or in the course of employment.
Employees whilst so absent shall receive full accrual of rights and entitlements.
36 PREFERENCE OF EMPLOYMENT
Absolute preference of employment shall be given to financial members of The Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia and a ``closed union shop'' shall apply.
37 NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING WORKERS
Non-English speaking workers shall be entitled to attend English language classes without loss of pay, in the employer's time.
Where non-English speaking employees are employed, interpreters shall be provided for the use of such employees.
38 WASHING TIME
All employees shall be allowed a half-an-hour before the meal break and finishing time for washing and showering.
39 UNION BUSINESS

Employees shall be paid at the rate they would normally have received had they been working for time spent attending Union meetings or other Union business, conferences or Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hearings.
40 FIRST AID
In addition to providing a First Aid Box suitably equipped and maintained, a First Aid Allowance of $30.00 per day shall be paid to employees qualified as First Aid Attendants.
41 SHOP STEWARDS

Any employee appointed as a Shop Steward shall be recognised as the accredited representative of the Union and shall be allowed the necessary time during working hours to carry out Union business without loss of pay.
42 PARENTAL AND SPECIAL FAMILY LEAVE

All employees shall be entitled to leave from work and be paid full pay for all absences from work for up to two years in regard to the birth or adoption of a child with the right to return to the same job or job of similar pay and conditions.
All employees shall be entitled to 50 days leave from work without loss of pay to care for a sick child or meet with the child's school requirements and school closure periods.
43 CHILD CARE
The employer shall provide free child minding facilities for the children of employees, and meet the full cost incurred by employees for the minding and care of their children.
44 TRAVELLING
The employer shall pay an employee for the time spent on travelling to and from work at double time rates.
Where the work is outside the ordinary hours of work the travelling time payment shall be at treble time rates.

The employer is to pay all costs incurred in travelling from the place of interview, trade testing and/or engagement to the place of employment and the costs incurred on termination back to such place of interview, trade testing and/or engagement. The employer shall also pay such costs incurred by the employee on moving his or her family and belongings on such occasions.
The employer shall provide transport or meet the cost of transport to and from work for all employees.
45 ORGANISATION OF WORK
The organisation of work and work practices shall be subject to review and alteration by the Union.
Supervisory positions shall be a matter for determination by the Union.
Staffing levels, classifications and workload shall be subject to review and alteration by the Union.
46 INFORMATION AND SEARCHING RECORDS
All information considered by the Union to be necessary in the pursuance of employment security, health or the general protection of its members shall be provided by the employer.

The Union or its accredited representative(s) shall be afforded the necessary facilities to inspect all accounts, books and other documents considered by the Union to be relevant to its members' interest.
47 PAID STUDY LEAVE
Employees shall be paid at the rate they would normally have received had they been working for all time spent attending Trade Union Training and Education Courses.
Employees shall be entitled to be paid for all time involved attending or studying recognised educational courses and for all costs incurred by the employee.
Employees shall be provided with the opportunity to upgrade their skills or acquire new skills without loss of pay and pay for all costs incurred by the employee.
48 LONG SERVICE LEAVE
All employees shall accrue Long Service Leave at the rate of 2 months per year of service or part thereof plus a loading of 50%.
Pro-rata Long Service Leave shall be paid after one months employment.
Public holidays falling during a period of Long Service Leave shall be added to the period and leave and shall attract a loading of 50%.
49 RETIREMENT
Provision shall be made for the payment of a Retirement Benefit on the basis of four weeks pay for each year of service or part thereof.
50 SUPERANNUATION

The employer shall participate in a superannuation fund deemed suitable to the Union, and shall make weekly contributions of $300.00 per week (such amount to be adjusted to reflect CPI movements) to such fund on behalf of all employees eligible to become members of the Union employed by the employer.
51 AIR FARES
The employer shall grant to each employee and his or her family a return First Class air fare to any city in Australia at the expiration of each period of three months of employment.
The employer shall also pay a travelling allowance of $1,000 for the employee, $1,000 for the employee's spouse and $500 for each child.
52 BLOOD DONORS
Employees shall be entitled to leave without loss of pay for all time spent donating blood.
53 OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
(a) No employee shall be required to work where a potential health or safety hazard arises in the course of their duties. An employee shall suffer no loss in pay due to such inability to work.
(b) An employee shall be appointed as Health and Safety Delegate by the employees and shall be allowed the necessary time during working hours to carry out his or her duties without loss of pay.
(c) There shall be created a Health and Safety Committee made up of employee and employer representatives.

(d) Both the Health and Safety Delegate and the Health and Safety Committee shall have the power to override Management in respect of Health and Safety matters. No new process, equipment, machinery, chemical or substance shall be introduced without the approval of the Health and Safety Committee and the Health and Safety Delegate.

(e) An official of the Union or a person nominated by the Union shall have the right to enter the employer's premises, or the premises at which the employees of the employer are working, at any time, to examine records and, if necessary, make copies of such records, machinery and/or work practices or processes and undertake any inspection relating to the occupational health and/or safety or the employees.
(f) The employer shall immediately supply to the Union and all employees all information, reports, studies and documents in relation to health and safety matters involved in the work process.
(g) The employer shall consult with the Union on all occupational health and safety matters; the Union may review and alter any work practices or processes for health and safety reasons.
54 FATALITIES AND INJURY AT WORK

Where an employee dies or is permanently incapacitated as a result of work, the employer shall pay an amount of $500,000 to the employee's spouse and $100,000 to each child. Provided that these payments shall not be offset against any workers compensation or common law settlement.
55 BOARD AND LODGING
The employer shall provide free board and lodging for all employees.
56 MEDICAL EXAMINATIONS
The employer shall meet the costs of a medical check-up for each employee every three months.
57 MEDICAL AND HOSPITAL COSTS
The employer shall meet all medical and hospital costs, and full insurance incurred of the employee and his/her family.
58 EDUCATION
The employer shall meet the full costs of educating the children of employees.
59 REMOVAL EXPENSES
The employer shall meet the full costs of removal expenses of the employee and his/her family occasioned by the move of the employee to any other location.
60 AMENITIES

(a) The employer shall provide all amenities for each employee including seating, accommodation, heating in winter, airconditioning in summer, dining room with table and chairs, cutlery and crockery, refrigerated drinking water, boiling water at meal times and during rest pauses, wash hand basins, hot and cold showers, soap, towels, change rooms, individual full-length lockers, facilities for heating food, refrigerators and victuals and beverages.
(b) Adequate and proper toilet facilities shall be provided by the employer and shall include the supply of a clean towel each day to the employee.
(c) An employer shall provide separate adequately furnished rest rooms for male and female employees.
(d) Each place of work shall be adequately lit and air-conditioned and shall have installed adequate refrigerated equipment to provide drinking water to employees during normal working time.
61 HANDLING OF CASH
An employee required to handle cash and/or cheques shall be insured at the expense of the employer against any error or loss occurring.

An employee required to carry cash on behalf of his/her employer between his/her place of employment and any other place shall be insured by his/her employer against injury or death for a sum not less than $1,000,000 and shall be provided with an escort and a taxi on each occasion cash is so transferred.
62 INSURANCE

The employer shall obtain and keep current a life assurance policy on behalf of each employee, which would return to the beneficiaries in case of death of the employee, or the employee in case of injury, the equivalent of twenty (20) years income at the rate the employee would have earned had he or she continued to work. On retirement, the said policy shall be transferred to the employee at no cost to the employee.
The employer shall ensure that all premises on which work is carried out are insured for public liability for a sum not less than $10,000,000.
63 EQUAL OPPORTUNITY
Equal opportunity shall be afforded to all persons for engagement and promotion to higher paid work.
64 NO SEXUAL HARASSMENT
The employer shall take positive steps to ensure that no employee is subjected to sexual harassment of any kind whatsoever in the work place.
65 SPECIAL LEAVE
All employees shall be entitled to up to 50 days a year special leave without loss of pay to attend to any of the following matters:-
1. Where the spouse or child of the employee is ill;
2. To attend to matters relating to social security payments;
3. To attend to personal matters of pressing necessity.
66 INCIDENCE

This Award shall govern the wages and conditions of employment of all persons engaged in the performance of all work in or in connection with, or incidental to a ``prescribed service'' ``eligible organisation'' or ``eligible service'' as defined by the Disability Services Act 1986 (as amended) which operates a small business enterprise which employ both able body workers and people with disabilities in either a workshop, or work crew, in a supported employment setting.
The work of such employees shall be those industries occupations and callings covered by the constitution of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the supporters of militant unionism will say that this log of claims is not to be taken seriously, it does, nonetheless, represent an extension of the kinds of demands that hamper and wreck conventional businesses in less sensitive areas. I repeat that at a time when disabled people would have little chance of gaining jobs in open employment, with unemployment in Western Australia soaring over the 11 per cent mark, the last thing they need is aggressive union coverage that threatens the viability of the institutions that employ them. Disabled workers with families and mortgages know this only too well.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many disabled workers and their families in the community who are becoming increasingly concerned about being pushed out into open employment with the possibility of the de-funding of sheltered workshops hanging over their head. They know that able-bodied people simply cannot get jobs these days. How on earth can the disabled compete with able-bodied people in an ever decreasing employment market?

I fear very much that it would suit this Government nicely to see the Disabled Workers Union eliminated as a voice for the disabled. In standing up for the rights and wishes of its members, it has forthrightly defended the continued funding of sheltered workshops and activity therapy centres, which have fallen out of favour with the predominant ethos of the Disability Services Act.

At no stage am I trying to indicate that everything is wrong with the Disability Services Act; that is not so. But I am trying to show that there is a grave danger of disabled people being put on the scrap-heap, and that is surely not a desirable objective. The Act is too often administered in a spirit of knowing what is best for the disabled and stigmatising those who bring forward inconvenient facts as to the continued need for sheltered employment as the best means of ensuring meaning and dignity in the lives of disabled people.

I think people have probably forgotten the old saying, `If it ain't broke, don't fix it'. If we have a situation where disabled people are gainfully employed and where they and their families are happy and the service providers are happy, why do we have to change it? Why do we have to say, `Take all of those people out of there and try to find a job for them', when, as I say, other people cannot find jobs at the moment?

The Department also wants special advocacy groups to enter sheltered workshops and in effect take over this role from the Disabled Workers Union. Threats are even made that the $43,000 in Federal funding for salaries in the union will be withdrawn because it has committed the mortal sin of supposed lack of cooperation with the objectives of the Disability Services Act. All that the union is trying to do is serve its members in the best possible way. I thought that was the objective of the union movement-and this very small union is doing that very well.

Indeed, on 28 November, Mrs Cassidy received an angry letter from the Department because she had publicly opposed generic union membership for the disabled. I think it is very sad that such is the authoritarianism of the Disability Services Act. Such accusations by the Department have gained an Orwellian significance whenever the disabled and their parents are faced with de-funding of essential sheltered employment. This is of great concern to the parents, many of whom are very old. They are very concerned that they will not be around to look after their sons or daughters. They are also looking down the gun-barrel at their children losing their jobs.

There is also an ideological preference for normalising-if one can call it that-the employment of the disabled through conventional union coverage without thought as to whether those unions will act in the real interests of intellectually disabled people. There is no thought by these social engineers or by this Government of encouraging specialist unions similar to the Disabled Workers Union in other States where there may be real problems with sheltered workshops. Instead, Gloria Cassidy and her team are regarded as an inconvenient anomaly that should be quietly eliminated so that the Miscellaneous Workers Union can add to its empire and the disabled can be told what their rights should be, irrespective of the practicalities.

It is a very sad state of affairs when a big powerful union can send a log of claims to the providers of sheltered employment and tell them to respond within seven days or else. Now this matter has to go to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to be sorted out. Really, it is a case of unscrambling the egg. Why do we now have to go through this lengthy process when the Disabled Workers Union is already doing the job in the best interests of the disabled?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise an issue of importance that will have a major economic bearing on the future of this nation, not only in the near foreseeable future but also well into the future. I refer to the issue to be addressed today by the Cabinet relating to the mining of Coronation Hill in the Northern Territory. It is an issue that has attracted wide attention throughout Australia in recent months, if not years, from politicians, from judges, from Aboriginal leaders and even from Anglican bishops. I will comment on that a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: In raising this issue of major concern, I want to highlight a letter, dated 29 May 1991, written by the Deputy Chief Minister and the Minister for Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory, the Hon. Barry Coulter, to the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). It is so important that I would like to read it into the record:
Dear Minister

I have considered the report to the Minister under section 10 (4) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act (the Heritage Act) on the Kakadu Conservation Zone. In my opinion the whole report is seriously flawed. With respect to His Honour the report is plainly wrong in many respects especially those concerning Northern Territory and Commonwealth law. In view of recent media reports that Cabinet is to consider the issue of Coronation Hill tomorrow I consider it appropriate that I place on the record the Northern Territory Government's concerns about the report.

The first fundamental issue that the report fails to address is the role of the Commonwealth legislation. The second reading speech of the Heritage Act made it clear that the Act was one of last resort. No action can happen in the Conservation Zone unless the Commonwealth initiates it. Even if some action was proposed the person carrying out the activity in the zone would then be faced with the processes under Northern Territory law for the protection of sites. There is no role for the Commonwealth under this Act until these procedures under the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Act have been exhausted.

The second issue is the finding in the report that the Northern Territory law is in some way inadequate because sites are not protected by strict liability. Unless you wish to drastically reverse some of the basic principles of criminal law this finding cannot bear scrutiny. The Northern Territory law is also criticised because it allows an elected Minister some decision making power and because registration of a site is only prima facie evidence that it is a site for the purposes of prosecution. You will note that the Northern Territory law is practically identical to the Commonwealth law in respect of the discretion of the Minister in section 10 (1) and the effect of a declaration in section 24 (1).

The third fundamental flaw is the finding that the Minister may still make a declaration no matter how remote a threat of injury. Despite acceptance of the Minister's initial determination that there was currently no immediate threat of injury or desecration, His Honour appears to report that because there is a real chance or possibility of activity in the area there is currently a threat of injury or desecration. The definition used by His Honour bears no relationship to the circumstances of this matter and cannot be logically sustained. My earlier comments about the role of the Commonwealth Act also apply in this respect.

A further flaw is the finding that Northern Territory legislation can allow desecration of a site. The Constitutional position of the Northern Territory, its power to make laws in this area, section 73 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (NT) Act, and section 35 of the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Act clearly demonstrate that this conclusion cannot be correct.

In view of these flaws any reliance upon the conclusions of the report would be dangerous unless, when read with the evidence and submissions, those conclusions are clearly correct on the face of the material.
Yours sincerely,
Barry Coulter

The issues that have been raised by Mr Coulter are crucial to the decisions that must be addressed by Federal Cabinet tonight. A misinterpretation of the role of the Commonwealth Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, an incorrect finding by Mr Justice Stewart that the Commonwealth Minister could make a protection order over Coronation Hill, an incorrect finding that the Northern Territory Act could allow the desecration of a site, and the incorrect criticisms by Mr Justice Stewart of the Northern Territory Act, are important issues. They are fundamental and they are crucial. If Federal Cabinet does not take them seriously and if the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy does not pass them on as part of the decision-making process this evening, all Australians will be seriously disadvantaged.

I said at the beginning of my speech that a number of comments have been made by politicians. I accept that that letter from Mr Coulter to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is an exchange between politicians. It is also interesting to note the criticisms that have been levelled at judges, particularly Mr Justice Stewart, with regard to the report of the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC). There has been widespread criticism of that report in recent weeks.

This must also be read alongside the fact that it is well known that within the Resource Assessment Commission there is wide disenchantment with the Chairman, Mr Justice Stewart. This comes about because of his very inflexible and very legal way of running the RAC. He has obviously had trouble recruiting and attracting people to work in that organisation. It is well known that he hates Canberra and has a particular dislike of bureaucrats. Because of these fundamental flaws, perhaps in his own leadership of the Resource Assessment Commission, we need to be very cautious when looking at the final outcome of the report.

The third group of people who I said were important in this decision-making process are the Aboriginal people. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you have often pointed out in this chamber with regard to the Coronation Hill debate, it is well known that there is controversy in respect of the Aboriginal custodians of the site. This controversy has been alluded to by Mr Justice Stewart in his report. It has been alluded to by many spokesmen for Jawoyn Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory and the wider Aboriginal community.

I turn to another politician for a moment and refer to some of my own statements. I have always maintained that it is wrong to assume that Aboriginal culture is incapable of evolving and of accommodating the social consequences of change. We have seen many successful mines in the Northern Territory in the context of Aboriginal people. The ones that stand out and which are well-known are the bauxite mines at Gove, the manganese mines on Groote Eylandt and the uranium mine at Ranger within the Kakadu National Park. In all of these instances, the Aboriginal owners and people vitally connected with these projects have successfully reconciled mining with the various aspects of their spirituality. Moreover, mining has brought them a sense of financial independence which is so vital to maintaining the dignity of an individual and a community.

We must look to the future. We must not cocoon Aboriginal people in the nineteenth century. They must not be subject to the patterns of behaviour and expectations put forward by some wild and woolly-minded people, particularly anthropologists. I was very interested to note that in one of the submissions made to the Resource Assessment Commission and Mr Justice Stewart some very good sense was put forward by one anthropologist, Dr Ron Brunton. In his submission, Dr Brunton said:

. . . cultures are not . . . houses of cards . . . People and their cultures adapt to changing circumstances; they select, they reinterpret, they innovate. They cope with challenges, and they are usually stronger for having done so. There are many potential growing points in an Aboriginal culture . . . Whatever decision is taken regarding Coronation Hill, there will be impacts on Aboriginal religious beliefs, and not just among the Jawoyn . . . A decision to prohibit mining in order to protect Bula would probably strengthen the hands of traditionalists and provide an added impetus for greens to forge strategic alliances with their `totemic people': traditional Aborigines. A decision to allow mining is likely to encourage those of a more open and modernising bent, those who seek to accommodate the cultural and social development of their communities to contemporary circumstances. This accommodation may take many forms: it does not imply the `loss of culture', or Jawoyn-ness, or Aboriginality.
That is a most important point to bear in mind in terms of all the discussions that are currently being pursued.

The final group that I identified includes an Anglican bishop, the Rt Rev. Clyde Wood, the Bishop of the Diocese of the Northern Territory. Earlier this week, Bishop Wood was quoted in the Australian newspaper as warning that mining royalties can lead to alcoholism and acute social dysfunction in Aboriginal communities. I will quite readily accept the authority and the position of Bishop Wood as a Christian when it comes to matters of biblical exegesis or matters of my Christian faith. But when it comes to matters of politics-seeking to add fuel to a controversial political issue, such as the mining of Coronation Hill, and to influence the Government's decision-I will take issue with the bishop. I will thoroughly disagree with him and I will say that he is wrong. The tragedy of alcoholism, kava abuse, petrol sniffing and the use of analgesics-and the violent consequences and medical complications that this produces-is endemic in far too many communities. But to link these issues to mining royalties, which, after all, are an independent source of income to many Aborigines, defies normal logic.

From my experience in northern Australia, I could give the bishop many more examples of the same social and domestic problems existing in communities where the income sources are not mining related. In fact, I hold a very strong view that welfare dependency and the lack of work opportunities are the major factors contributing to many of these social issues in Aboriginal society today.

I recognise that in the past the Anglican Church played a very important missionary role at communities such as Oenpelli and Groote Eylandt in the Northern Territory. But I would turn the bishop's attention to what happened even under missionary control, when grog was then available in those communities, and to the consequences of that before mining royalties flowed to many of his flock and Aboriginal constituencies. I would have hoped that the bishop, because of his very extensive pastoral knowledge and activities throughout the Northern Territory, would have looked more widely and compassionately at this issue and not sought to get involved in a grubby political debate.

However grubby that debate might be in this place, the matter is for us as politicians to resolve because we are charged with the political responsibility of making the important economic decisions for this country. The mining of Coronation Hill is an important factor in the future of this country. The fact that the Labor Government wants to hide behind Aboriginal spirituality and Aboriginal issues and deny thousands of Territorians and many more thousands of Australian citizens wide and proper economic benefits from an appropriate mine is something that must bear heavily on the Federal Cabinet when it considers these issues this evening.
