TALK.START.PARA: — I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it not true that without the large 3.5 per cent increase in government spending, the March quarter national accounts would have shown negative growth? I also ask, given that the private sector has been subjected to this disastrous scorched earth policy, why did today's figures show that foreign debt grew by a further $3.3 billion in the March quarter to a record $133 billion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has asked a couple of questions which are somewhat unrelated, but I think they both flow from the figures released today and I understand what he is asking. The first question related to government spending. All I can say is that the question relates to total government spending and the figures indicate that Commonwealth spending has been very restrained. In terms of State government expenditure, the figures show that the State governments are continuing to spend significantly. As I understand it, there is no break-up of the figures for respective State governments, but in terms of a pattern of expenditure the spending comes from State governments.

ANSWER.PARA: Looking at the national accounts figures generally, I appreciate that Senator Short would ask me a question about government expenditure because in terms of net exports, inflation outlook and a range of other factors the national accounts figures, without being exciting, certainly show a trend which Government spokesmen have said is likely to be there at this time and show up later in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense.
—It is not nonsense at all. Senator Short should look at the net export figure, for example.
—Have you looked at profits and investment?

—On the question of profits, let me say first of all that profits are down to a figure which is, I think, 2 per cent below what was a record figure for corporate profits two years ago. I will give those precise figures. The profit to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio was 14 per cent, down from a record high of 16.5 per cent in June 1989-something that those opposite never achieved in their whole period in government.
—That is not true.

—It is true. For example, the corresponding figure in respect of the Fraser Government at this point in the cycle-in September 1982-showed that the profits to GDP ratio was 10.6 per cent; in June 1989, it was 16.5 per cent-a record high; and these figures just released show that it is 14 per cent.
—When are you going to get up with the times?

—These things have to be looked at in terms of the historical performance of the Australian economy. The fact that honourable senators opposite were then in government is just an unfortunate aberration for the Australian people. I would have given these figures irrespective of who was in government.
—We never planned a recession.

—No, it is like everything else the Opposition does-totally unplanned. The second question related to foreign debt. Of course, the March national accounts figures reinforce the Government's conviction that later this year and through 1992 we will see a durable economic recovery. That is the point that I was trying to make to Senator Short, unpalatable as it may be to him. Gross domestic product has not fallen since the September quarter last year.
—What about interest rates.
—Order! Senator Short, you have asked a question. This is developing into a debate.
—In terms of government policy in response to the economic downturn, we have reduced interest rates by 7 1/2 per cent since early 1990. Wage growth is being held in check.
—What about real rates?
—Real rates follow down inflation and nominal rates.
—They are still the highest in the Western world.

—I hope that Senator Short will get one of his colleagues to ask me a question about that later because that is not right. That is an assertion which is quite incorrect. Senator Short knows that, does he not? That is quite incorrect. Wages growth has been held in check by the accord framework and automatic fiscal stabilisers are operating with the structural integrity of the Budget, we believe, being maintained.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some signs of recovery in the national accounts figures. The March accounts show that the restructuring of the economy required to ensure sustained future growth is well under way. In the longer term that, together with major gains against inflation, the contribution of net exports and so on, will contribute to the reduction of foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister obviously had great trouble in dealing with that question the first time around. Let me ask again the first of my two questions which he failed completely to address. Is it not true that without the increase in government spending the March quarter national accounts would have shown negative growth? In the light of the Minister's attempted response to my questions I also ask: is it not a fact that when the national accounts figures are adjusted for the terms of trade-which is the correct way of looking at national accounts-they show a fall this quarter of a further one-half per cent, making five falls in the last six quarters?

—Senator Short could have asked the second part of the question on any previous occasion. He is only doing so on this occasion because the national accounts figures are a little better than he anticipated. In so far as the contribution of government expenditure to GDP is concerned, let me say that GDP reflects the economy as a whole and it always has. As I have already said in my answer to Senator Short, Commonwealth expenditure has been restrained; State government expenditure has not. The government contribution is an aggregate of all government expenditure.
—It is negative when you put it to one side.
—I do not retreat from the answer that government contribution to GDP has been important in these figures, but it always has been.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister will be aware of an unfortunate dispute between an officer of the Department of Community Services and Health and the Human Rights Commission about the validity of the women's health program within the terms of the Sex Discrimination Act. As this legal action is, I am aware, essentially a private matter, can the Minister reassure Australian women of the Government's ongoing commitment to the Federal-State women's health policy and outline progress of its current implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not very familiar with the legal proceedings to which Senator Reynolds refers and, of course, I make no comment on those in particular. It is a fact that Australian women are responsible for a large proportion of the informal and formal health care provided in the Australian community. I know that Senator Reynolds has a particular interest in the progress of the Federal and State governments in dealing with the question of health services for women, particularly arising out of the National Agenda for Women which led to a commitment to develop a health strategy to deal with women's health policy matters.

ANSWER.PARA: I am able to indicate several elements in that program which have been extremely helpful to women in the Australian community. For example, the women's community health services aim to improve women's health services through a strengthened primary health care network, as well as the access of disadvantaged women to health services. To be eligible for funding under the national women's health program, all such services must provide primary health care services at no cost to women and that network is being developed. In addition, a consumer information and education program which aims to develop a women's health information and education strategy, dealing in particular with the needs of disadvantaged women, is being put together. Of course, there is continuing education and training on women's health for health professionals.

The Senate would also be interested to note that, in addition to the national women's health program, the Government has established a number of other services to meet the specific health needs of women. First, the rural women's health package, which is targeting women in rural areas who are particularly disadvantaged by their isolation, was announced by the Prime Minister in his rural statement on 1 December 1989. The rural package provides $438,000 over three years to frontier services in conjunction with the Royal Flying Doctor Service to develop a program to improve women's access to health services in western New South Wales, south-west Queensland and north-west Western Australia.

Second, the alternative birthing service program assists the States to establish appropriate and safe midwife managed alternative birthing services for women who choose not to give birth in specialised hospital settings. Thirdly, there is the national program for the early detection of breast cancer. We know from many debates in this chamber about the premature deaths from the failure to detect breast cancer early enough. With $64m of Commonwealth funds set aside for a three-year budget for that program, it is anticipated that some 375 deaths a year will be averted which might have otherwise resulted from breast cancer.

These are only three of many programs that I could mention which are specifically dealing with the health problems of women and with the responsibility of governments to ensure that the questions which are specific to women in regard to health policy are dealt with in a practical fashion, such as I have outlined, or as part of the women's health policy which has evolved from a consideration of matters raised by women themselves in consultations held under the National Agenda for Women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister gain an assurance for the women of Australia that an officer who takes private legal action against the national women's health program would not be required to be directly involved in the implementation of something to which he obviously does not have any commitment?
—I think I will refer that question to the Minister for Community Services and Health.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given that a number of East Timorese soccer players have remained in Australia following the recent Arafura Games in Darwin, can the Minister please explain how many have sought asylum with Portuguese authorities or applied for Australian refugee status? Are the defections of concern to the Government in light of Australia's diplomatic relationship with Indonesia and Portugal's international court challenges over the Timor Gap? What was the role played by the Northern Territory Federal member and Labor left Parliamentary Secretary, Mr Snowdon, in the defections, particularly in light of his close association with the radical Lafaek and Fretilin groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously this is primarily an immigration matter. All I can say about those aspects, the subject of the brief in front of me, is as follows. An Indonesian soccer team from East Timor was participating in the Arafura festival in Darwin. Two members of this team travelled from Darwin to Canberra on 27 May where they made contact with the Portuguese Embassy. I understand that they were provided with Portuguese travel documents to allow them to travel to Portugal and they left Australia on 29 May.

ANSWER.PARA: Two other members of the team are reported to have contacted the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in Darwin to lodge applications to remain in Australia as refugees. That is, of course, a matter for my colleague the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I understand that any such applications would be dealt with on their merits through the established determination of refugee status procedures. The remaining members of the soccer team returned to Indonesia on 29 May.

I see no reason for these events to have any impact on Australia's bilateral relations with Indonesia. I note that the Indonesian charge d'affaires in his remarks to the media and during his call on my Department yesterday, 29 May, also made clear that the Indonesian Government does not want these events to harm the bilateral relationship.

Conditions in East Timor are obviously not perfect. We have made that clear often enough. Although the Embassy's assessment is that the human rights situation is now significantly better than during September-November 1990 when the Indonesian authorities were responding to what they perceived to be an increase in security problems, we continue to monitor very closely the human rights situation in East Timor. We continue to make representations to the Indonesian Government where there are credible grounds for concern. Our views on human rights are well known to the Indonesian Government and current events will be perceived in that light. As to the role played by Mr Snowdon in these matters, I have absolutely no idea but I am sure he behaved with his usual absolutely impeccable sense of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would it not be a normal function of the Australian Embassy in Indonesia, at the time of granting visa approvals to a group such as an Indonesian team visiting Australia, to acquaint members of that team with issues relating to any change of status that was likely to be envisaged in that area?
—No.

—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of concerns expressed by Australian companies about Australian industry participation in the development of the integrated air traffic control system which has been announced by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)? Will Australian companies be given an opportunity to participate in the project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes, they will. I announced to the Senate earlier this year that the Civil Aviation Authority board had moved to a two-centre air traffic control system which is proposed to be in place by the end of 1995. This system, which will include state of the art communications technology already proven overseas, is at this stage proposed to be located at both Brisbane and Melbourne. When it is established, for the first time in Australia the CAA will have in place a totally integrated air traffic services system.

ANSWER.PARA: The CAA has announced that six international companies have been invited to submit registrations of interest for the project as prime contractors. Registration of interest in the two-centre project will seek bids from the companies on the costs and benefits of retaining geographically distributed terminal control units. I am aware, because representations have been made to me directly, of Australian industry's concerns over being given the opportunity to be involved in the two-centre proposal. I would point out that the CAA's original list of prime contractors was drawn up on the ability of these companies to provide a proven totally integrated system.

I might add-and I absolutely support the CAA's view on this-that the need to get this new system in place is urgent and necessary. We simply cannot afford to waste time because of the substantial period that will be necessary in research and development to get a new system up off the ground and this would include the difficulties with having an unproven technology at the end of that extended time.

The CAA's decision to provide for contractors who will provide proven air traffic control technology is a decision that I support entirely. Although clearly it is too early to speculate over the exact amount of potential Australian involvement in a project in its formative stage, the Civil Aviation Authority, in conjunction with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, will be holding a workshop with Australian industry representatives next Wednesday to outline details of the two-centre project. This workshop will give Australian and New Zealand companies the opportunity to assess where they may be able to develop proposals to link in with the international companies which have been asked to provide expressions of interest. Australian industry has made a major contribution to the Australian aviation system in the past, and I have no doubt will continue to do so in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respectfully remind the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs of his previous advice to me in this place that clients should settle their disputes with banks in courts. Is the Minister aware of the plight of Mr Stan Aliprandi who has attempted, on 94 occasions, to take his dispute with Partnership Pacific Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation into the Supreme Court of New South Wales where the banks are represented by Allen Allen and Hemsley? Is the Minister aware that Allen Allen and Hemsley in its advice to Westpac in the now infamous Westpac letters proposed a strategy of litigation avoidance and delay at `any reasonable cost'? Does the Minister agree with Sir Ninian Stephen's recent assessment before the bank inquiry that the pursuit of justice in some jurisdictions is beyond ordinary Australians-an opinion endorsed by the Chief Justice of a Supreme Court who stated that he could not afford litigation in his own court? Can the Minister advise ordinary Australians, therefore, how they obtain justice when no legal aid is available to those pursuing banks in courts? Finally, can the Minister advise the Senate when and how the Government intends to rectify this extraordinary situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Mr Aliprandi has approached the New South Wales Supreme Court on a large number of occasions. Whether it is of the number that Senator McLean indicates in his question I do not know, but I certainly accept that, given his interest in these matters, that is an accurate indication of the difficulty that Mr Aliprandi has had in getting this matter resolved before a properly constituted court. Of course, I am aware of the Westpac letters and their contents, as I think all honourable senators are. But the broad thrust of Senator McLean's question deals with the problem of the cost of justice, the access to obtaining justice in our society.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that the Senate committee chaired by my friend and colleague Senator Barney Cooney which is looking into that matter is carrying out a large number of hearings on that very matter. It has received many submissions, including I have no doubt from Senator McLean, particularising the problem that customers and clients of banks and other financial institutions have when taking on the might of those institutions, bearing in mind the considerable resources available to those bodies, in engaging legal counsel and obtaining the best possible legal advice.

I must say though that the Government has not just stood aside awaiting the report from Senator Barney Cooney's committee in relation to persons getting access to justice in our community. We have been encouraging in many spheres the development of alternative dispute resolution processes-mediation and other processes. Particularly in the banking industry what has been a most notable achievement has been the way in which the Federal Government, through the then Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Nick Bolkus, and the banking industry and consumer groups came together to evolve what has become a most successful operation, namely that of the banking ombudsman, Mr Graham McDonald.

There, one has a method whereby those bank customers who are dissatisfied with a decision by the bank can get very speedy attention to their grievance. They can get a remedy from the Ombudsman, if he decides that a remedy is justified, of up to $100,000. If he makes a recommendation, the banks have agreed to be bound by his recommendation in that regard, and there are no costs in the service that the banking ombudsman provides. There we have a very clear instance of the evolution within our society of an alternative to the very costly legal system as a means of resolving disputes.

I understand that already the ombudsman's office in its first year of operation has received over 2,000 written complaints, a further 8,000 telephone inquiries, and that over $1m has been paid out by the banks following recommendations by the banking ombudsman. There is also my announcement that a group proceedings process would be evolved over the next several months to enable persons, where they had a matter in common, to approach the Federal Court so that they could group together to lower the costs which otherwise would have to be paid by individuals approaching the court in relation to similar or related disputes. I do not see why that initiative should not be available to those who are alleging against those who provide banking or other financial services that that bank has, for example, engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct. Clearly, the group proceedings procedure would be available in that case in appropriate circumstances.

As to legal aid itself, there will never be sufficient legal aid available to satisfy all those who wish, with the assistance of the community, to pursue their cases before the courts. Nevertheless, the Federal Government has provided well over $100m for that purpose this year throughout Australia, to be distributed by the legal aid commissions in all the States and Ter- ritories. I believe that this is a very substantial contribution by the taxpayers to assist their fellow Australians to have access to justice where the funds available to them are not sufficient. I believe that those scarce dollars are being put to very good use by the various legal aid commissions around Australia.

In summary, I understand the problem raised by Senator McLean using a particular case as an instance, but I believe that as a society we are attempting to provide alternatives to that very expensive resolution of conflicts before the courts in the traditional judicially supervised processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I still seek the Minister's comments on the assessment by Sir Ninian Stephen that the pursuit of justice in some jurisdictions is beyond ordinary Australians-a comment which, as I said, was endorsed by a Chief Justice who said that even on his salary he could not afford litigation in his own court. Finally, could I make the question more pointed by asking: is the Government prepared to make legal aid available to people who are pursuing banks in courts, not through the ombudsman?

—I think that I indicated my agreement with the general tenor of Sir Ninian Stephen's remarks. It would be unusual for him to say anything else, as he has the distinguished position of being chairman of the supervisory council which overlooks the ombudsman's activities in the banking industry. He understands better than most the need for a cheap alternative for the resolution of disputes and complaints in the banking industry.

ANSWER.PARA: As for the question of provision of legal aid for those who find themselves in a dispute with the bank which requires the judicial process of settlement, I have indicated that the Federal Government is providing over $100m a year to the various legal aid commissions around the Commonwealth of Australia for their assessment of the merits and the need to apportion funds in a way which enables those who are without sufficient money to approach the courts to be assisted. But it will always have to be rationed according to a process of assessment by the legal aid commissions, and I understand that no special provision is made by the various commissions around the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government's response to the announcement by President Bush of a comprehensive United States arms control initiative for the Middle East?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —President Bush announced last night, our time, an arms control initiative for the Middle East which in a very important way addresses conventional arms transfers and nuclear, chemical and biological weapons and missile proliferation. Action on and commitment to arms control is an essential follow-up to the Gulf war. This initiative, which we regard as bold and imaginative, is a very important step in the extraordinarily difficult process of achieving peace for the Middle East and certainly has our strong support.

ANSWER.PARA: The initiative envisages six broad elements coming together. The first is Iraq-specific measures, involving continuation of the current United Nations supervised destruction of Iraqi missiles and weapons of mass destruction, and the continuation of the UN embargo on arms transfers to Iraq. Secondly, as far as missiles are concerned, it involves the elimination of surface to surface missiles by the countries of the region with a first step of a freeze on acquisition, production and testing of missiles by regional states.

Thirdly, in relation to chemical weapons, it involves the resolution of all major outstanding issues relating to the chemical weapons convention by the end of this year, early adoption of relevant chemical weapons convention provisions by regional states as confidence-building measures and a commitment to become original parties to the convention when it is concluded. In relation to biological weapons, it goes to the enhancement of the global biological weapons convention. In relation to nuclear matters, it involves a ban on production of all weapons using nuc- lear material in the region and reiteration of the call for International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards on all regional nuclear facilities. Finally, as far as supplier constraints are concerned, it goes to the coverage of conventional arms transfers, weapons of mass destruction and missiles as agreed to by the five major suppliers of arms to the region, who are in fact the permanent five members of the UN.

The initiative in its practical implementation will focus on the five permanent members of the UN Security Council-the United States of America, the United Kingdom, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France and China, as being the major suppliers of arms to the Middle East. It will also focus on the regional countries themselves. It should be said that Australia is already pursuing, through multilateral forums, many if not most of the particular elements of this initiative in our own arms control activity, a role that has been acknowledged widely, not least by the invitation to me to be a keynote speaker earlier this week at the Japanese-UN sponsored disarmament con- ference. We do have a role, and we are seen as having a particular role to play, in the development and negotiation of global multilateral measures, including the chemical weapons negotiations and also the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty, the operation of the IAEA, and the biological weapons convention.

Finally, while the US Middle East initiative that I have described is important in so far as it tackles the major area of concern about the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and conventional weapons in that region, we should not lose sight of the same problems in other areas of the globe, including those of particular concern to Australia. The most obvious problem in that respect on the agenda at the moment is the potential proliferation of nuclear weapons in North Korea. Many of the elements in the Middle East initiative have an obvious application either world wide or in other specific regions. Australia, in cooperation with countries of the same view around the world, will continue to pursue our objective, which is a crucial one, of restraining the proliferation of missiles and weapons of mass destruction, and the excessive build-up of conventional arms.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is dir- ected to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the advice from the Federal Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, that the Government's Bill banning political advertising could prevent some documentary programs from being shown on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). Mr Burdekin said, and I quote for the Minister's edification:

QUESTION.PARA: I am aware, for example, of a number of programs produced for ABC television by or with the involvement of Aboriginal organisations which have clearly promoted what would indisputably be classified as `political' positions on issues of electoral contention such as land rights.
Mr Burdekin went on to say:

I can find nothing in the Bill which would clearly prevent such programs being regarded as advertisements in support of these political positions by the organisations involved and, therefore, at least potentially, being subject to prohibition.
Will the Minister explain the basis on which his views differ from those of Mr Burdekin? Secondly, why is the Minister putting freedom of the press at risk?

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming from a member of parliament who has not only opposed the establishment of the Human Rights Commission for a long time but also still seeks its abolition with a policy of possibly reviewing it--
—They are committed to its abolition.

—As Senator Collins says to me, if anyone is committed to doing away with the Human Rights Commission, it is Senator Kemp and the part of the Liberal Party that he represents. I refer the good Senator to the advice that was also made available to the Parliament at the time of Mr Burdekin's advice being made available, that advice being from Mr Burmester of the Attorney-General's Department. If the honourable senator were to look at that, he would find that the point he raises is one that, although Mr Burdekin raises it, is not sustainable. That is something he should have done before he jumped to a quick conclusion and asked a question such as he has asked today. In terms of the second part of the question, I just see that as one of those gratuitous comments the honourable senator seems to toss in from time to time, not worthy of an answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister to explain the basis on which his views, as a representative member of the Government, differ from those of Mr Burdekin. It would be greatly appreciated if the Minister could explain to us why Mr Burdekin's views are wrong. Secondly, it is no good the Minister's standing up day after day promoting the Human Rights Commissioner and refusing to accept his advice. Can he please answer the question that I put to him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the supplementary question is basically a restate- ment of the first one with some extra colouring. If it is not within the capacity of the Opposition to understand what I said, I will repeat it.
—Slowly.

—I will do so slowly. At the time Mr Burdekin's advice or comments on the legislation were made available, the Government also released advice that it had received from its advisers. Any fair and clear reading of the two respective pieces of advice would lead to a conclusion. It is our normal practice to look at the advice of our official advisers in the Attorney-General's Department, and in this case we have done so.

ANSWER.PARA: On the particular point that Senator Kemp raises, the advice from my recollection of it was that the point he raises is not sustainable. I have said that before and I have repeated it, this time slowly. Hopefully, the honourable senator has managed to listen to it this time with a bit more endeavour. Honourable senators opposite tend to make these points about freedom of expression and civil liberties and whatever without an understanding of the issues involved.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: the Minister is now debating the point.

INTERJECT.PARA: Government senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Minister to explain clearly why Mr Burdekin's advice was wrong. All the yahoos on the benches opposite laugh, but we have not heard from the Minister why Mr Burdekin's advice was wrong. If the Minister does not want to provide that advice to the Parliament, I suggest, Mr President, that you ask him to sit down.
—Order! There is no point of order. I am sure that the Minister is in the process of concluding his answer.
—I already have, Mr President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the recent statement by President Bush of his intention to recommend extension of most favoured nation (MFN) status to China. Does the Australian Government support such an extension?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —President Bush, in another very recent announcement in the past day or so, has indicated his clear intention to seek from Congress a renewal for one year of China's most favoured nation status. Under United States law, countries such as China which restrict emigration are ineligible for MFN status. However, under that same law, the US President has the authority-following the Jackson-Vanik amendment of 1974-subject to congressional agreement, to waive the application of this law on an annual basis if such a waiver is deemed to be in the national interest. In view of the difficulties in the US-China bilateral relationship going to the trade balance but, more importantly, the nonproliferation issues as well as concern about human rights, congressional debate on the renewal of MFN is expected to be very intense. Congress has until 1 September to respond to the President's recommendation.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's position is one of support for the continuation of MFN status for China. We take that position in support of the UN Administration for a number of reasons. Non-renewal of that status could be expected to have a very serious adverse effect not only upon US-China bilateral relations but also very specifically upon Hong Kong, and through Hong Kong for the region generally. There could be a number of serious flow-on effects for Australia.

It needs to be appreciated that some 30 per cent of Hong Kong's trade is with China and a very substantial proportion of that goes on to the US. It is estimated that something like 30 to 40 per cent of Hong Kong's re-exported goods to the United States would disappear if this particular status were not renewed. That would be a body blow, unquestionably, to the Hong Kong economy, resulting in the unemployment of tens of thousands of people and a significant impact on the growth of that territory.

Secondly, while we are very keen to see China more responsive to international concern on missile proliferation and human rights issues, there is a concern about the method chosen to pursue these goals if it does involve major economic repercussions for the country. It needs to be appreciated that the biggest impact of the MFN status issue would be on the economy of southern China-the Shenzhen economic zone and areas of that kind-where economic reform has been greatest and where the political environment tends to be the most relaxed. The consequences that would follow from removal of MFN status would have major repercussions in this sense internally for China. Inclination towards policies of self- reliance would tend to turn it even more inwardly than is the case at the moment and would be, from the perspective of encouraging reform, a rather unhappy result.

Thirdly, and finally, there is the consideration that MFN generally is, as President Bush said, not so much a special status or privilege as the ordinary basis for trade worldwide. At a time when we are trying to liberalise international trade and get restraints, conditions and barriers removed, that is another reason why the basic approach, we believe, should be to support the widespread application of MFN, not its selective removal. We hope that all those considerations will be taken into account by the US Congress in responding to the President's request.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to his answer to a question from Senator Faulkner on 8 May. In his comments, he claimed that 1,200 waterfront workers had left the industry. Is it true that the redundancy of 310 gangway watchmen was negotiated before the start of the Government's waterfront reform program; that 600 waterside workers exited under redundancy programs existing prior to the waterfront reform program; and that only 372 wharfies have left as a result of the program? Does the Minister therefore agree that, taking into account the 265 new recruits, the net reduction in the number of wharfies as a result of his significant waterfront reform program is indeed 107 at a time when trade on the waterfront is down by about 35 per cent? Finally, will the Minister tell the Parliament and the people of Australia the truth about how far behind schedule his waterfront redundancy program really is?
—Will you resign?

—No, I cannot be bothered, actually. Senator Campbell completely ignored the fact that the statement I made in the Senate was in specific rebuttal of just one more idiot press release put out by the shadow Minister for waterfront reform, Mr John Sharp. I pointed out that once again Mr Sharp had maintained his unbroken record for total inaccuracy in every public statement that he has issued on waterfront reform. The figures that I gave to the Senate previously in Question Time in rebuttal of Mr Sharp's press release are accurate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The point of the question is not the accuracy of the rebuttal; it is the accuracy of the press release. Does the Minister now admit that counting redundancies negotiated prior to the start of his waterfront reform process is really the same as setting up his own goalposts and then shifting them closer to the centre line instead of shifting the ball towards the real goalposts?
—For the third time, Mr Sharp's press release was wrong; my answer in Question Time was right.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by referring the Minister to the decreasing costs of funds enjoyed by banks with a cash rate near 10 per cent and passbook deposit rates as low as 3.75 per cent. Does the Minister agree that the banks have been tardy in passing on the benefits of lower interest rates to their borrowers, particularly for small business overdrafts, personal loans and credit cards? Secondly, does the Minister further agree that banks are attempting to cover their bad debt losses due to their irresponsible loan decisions by expanding their margins between the cost of loans and the rates they charge their borrowers? Thirdly, is the Treasurer prepared to place banks under the Prices Surveillance Authority to reduce the cost of money, to protect borrowers and to speed economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first two questions are of a generic type: they are different examples of the same issue. I have not consulted with the Treasurer about this, but I believe there is plenty of circumstantial evidence to at least allow one to draw the tentative conclusion that the answer to questions one and two is yes.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the third question-whether the Treasurer is prepared to place banks under the Prices Surveillance Authority-the Government's view is that the Reserve Bank of Australia has all the powers that are necessary to adequately and prudentially supervise the banks. There has been some discussion in economic journals by former senior officers of the Reserve Bank on whether those powers were in the past, at certain points, adequately exercised in the sense that discussions took place between the Reserve Bank and the various banks. Whether those discussions were sufficiently in-depth is debated in the economic journals. In terms of the powers that are available to the Reserve Bank, we believe those powers are adequate in order to fulfil this function.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, it would appear that the Reserve Bank is obviously not exercising its powers, since the Minister agrees with the propositions in questions one and two, yet the increasing margins exist to the detriment of the economy and borrowers. Does the Minister agree that the Reserve Bank is not exercising its powers? Will the Government take action to suggest that it should?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Spindler put it in the last part of his question, they are prudential powers; they are not powers which go to the question of whether a bank operating in a commercial market is tardy, for example, in passing on interest rate reductions. That is not an appropriate question for powers of the Reserve Bank.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as I answered the first part of the question by saying there was some academic discussion on whether the Reserve Bank's prudential powers had always been exercised in a totally appropriate way in the past, there is discussion about that. I cannot provide Senator Spindler with an answer to that; I have just observed that there have been various newspaper commentaries about that. So I do not think the answer to the first two questions really ties in with the answer which I have given Senator Spindler to the third one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to an answer he gave yesterday in response to a question asked by the Leader of the Opposition on wheat sales to Egypt. The Minister suggested that it would be the Government and not the wheat growers who `would be bearing the pain'. Can the Minister clarify this statement? Does he mean that the Government is to pay the uninsured portion of the loan amounting to some $25m? If he does not mean that, would he please apologise to the wheat growers for misleading them yesterday? Clearly, if they are to be responsible for the $25m, they will indeed bear the pain and at a time when they are least able to afford it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to clarify the record in this respect: I indicated yesterday that I would need to check that particular point. I was intending to do so after Question Time, if it had not taken Senator Brownhill as long as it has to ask the question. There is a slight lack of clarity in the note I had from Treasury in this respect yesterday which led me to be less clear than I should have been.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic situation is that Egypt's total debt to Australia is $760m, of which some $390m is subject to this debt forgiveness exercise. That $390m is, in turn, comprised of some $280m owed to the Commonwealth itself as a result of national interest insurance payments to the Australian Wheat Board (AWB). In respect of that bit of underwriting by the Australian Government, the Budget will bear the whole of the pain involved and no proportion of that will be borne by wheat growers.

The second component of the $390m is $60m owed to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) as part of Austrade on its commercial account. Again, that is just a commercial liability to be borne by EFIC. The final component is $48m to the Australian Wheat Board, which represents the uninsured portion of sales to Egypt. It is in respect of that proportion borne by the Australian Wheat Board that there will obviously have to be some pain borne by wheat growers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—That is the break-up of the debt that is involved-$390m worth of forgiveness. The breakdown in question-this has been discussed and it is well understood by all the players involved, even if it comes as news to some of those opposite--
—Yesterday you said the Government would bear it.

—Yesterday I said that I assumed, on the basis of the note in front of me, that the whole proportion was underwritten by the Government. That assumption was only correct so far as the $280m proportion borne by the Commonwealth directly under the national insurance account is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the remainder of it-the $60m that is owed to Austrade-EFIC and the $24m of the $48m worth of exposure that is borne by the AWB-the responsibility falls in different ways. I was talking about the total debt. The actual burden of the forgiveness is obviously half of that amount in each case. That breakdown reflects the risk-sharing arrangements for selling wheat to the Egyptian market, which have been discussed and agreed to by all relevant players over time. Of course, the Commonwealth has borne the lion's share of that risk, as is evident from what I have said, on its national interest account. All participants--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators opposite should calm their racing hormones. This angst that is being demonstrated is all totally artificial. All participants, including the Wheat Board, were fully aware of the risks involved and of the conditions under which the national interest cover was provided by the Commonwealth. The financial impact of the debt forgiveness will spread over a full 25 years. The precise details of that, including how the impact will be spread over those 25 years, remain to be worked out when data is available from the Paris Club. There is some prospect that the amounts might be less than those that I have suggested, but those are the figures in front of me at the moment.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it that all those figures that the Minister has just given us mean that some $30m will have to be paid by the wheat industry and the wheat growers? Is that the correct figure, or is the Minister trying to say that the correct figure is different? Could he be precise about what figure the wheat growers will have to pay, and would he like to apologise to those wheat growers who thought that the Commonwealth was going to pay the lot?
—Of the $390m worth of debt that is subject to forgiveness, some $24m will represent the amount forgone by the Australian Wheat Board.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Can the Minister tell the Senate what initiatives have recently occurred to provide consumers with improved complaint resolution procedures in respect of general and life insurance policies? In addition, would the Minister address the problem of fine print? I have received many complaints of insurance sales persons selling policies that are impossible for a lay person, or indeed any person except the insurance company, to understand. What action, if any, is proposed to have insurance companies produce policies that are in plain English and a simpler form?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly endorse Senator Jones's call for plainer English to be used in insurance contracts. It is very important that policyholders have a form that they can easily comprehend and understand. I am sure that some sections of the insurance industry are using plain English forms. That is to be encouraged, and I hope that it is regarded as a model for other insurance companies to follow.

ANSWER.PARA: I know that the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner is also promulgating new guidelines which will require greater disclosure by insurance companies of the actual terms into which a prospective policyholder would be entering. All relevant information has to be given in a comprehensible way, and I think that is to be encouraged too. But there is no doubt that the question of small print and the difficulty of understanding insurance contracts are only one part of the various complaints that are made about the life insurance and general insurance industry.

For that reason, the setting up by the life and general insurance industries of processes whereby complaints can be readily dealt with in a fair way under the supervision of panels comprised of representatives of consumers and industry, and chaired by persons appointed by an industry council, will lead to many of the complaints that are presently left either unresolved, or resolved in the insurance company's favour in a way which is not satisfactory to the policyholder, being dealt with in a much better way.

Of course, the process will depend on conciliation, as much as anything else, but the panels will be empowered to make binding decisions in relation to the industry up to certain amounts. Their activities in resolving these complaints will be under the supervision of a council chaired by Mr Lionel Bowen, the former Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General of the Commonwealth. I am sure that his chairmanship of that supervisory council will ensure the integrity and fairness of that process of resolving complaints.

I certainly take on board the matters which Senator Jones has referred to and hope that, together with many other matters, the sorts of worries that he has about fine print and the difficulty of comprehending insurance contracts can be overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President. It refers to a letter from you and Mr Speaker, Mr McLeay, dated 24 May relating to the ruling in the case of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations and the Tobacco Institute of Australia. I note that that decision does not change the legal status of tobacco, and I note that you have said that on advice `we could be seen as negligent if we do not totally ban smoking in Parliament House' which, in effect, is treating tobacco smoking as illegal. By whom was the advice sought? By whom was the advice given? Would you please table that advice? Would you explain under what authority the Usher of the Black Rod is acting to enrol honourable senators in behavioural courses to quit smoking? Indeed, what part of the building is included in the term `totally ban'? Does it include members' private offices and the Executive wing? What are the proposed penalties for breaching your orders?

—Order! I can answer some of Senator Bishop's question. I had a full brief on this matter yesterday because I expected it to be raised yesterday. The advice that the Speaker and I received was from the legal section of the Joint House Department. I am quite happy to table that advice. The Office of the Black Rod is offering these courses and they are purely optional. I will give Senator Bishop an answer to the rest of her question as soon as practicable.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. When we sight the advice that you have received and we see whether or not it is considered to be of sufficient, shall we say, authority to come to such a conclusion, if it is found wanting, could I ask that you seek a further advice which may be of better standing?

—I will table the advice. If you find it unsatisfactory, there will probably be a debate that will ensue after that. I am sure that the Speaker and I are open to getting other advice. I do not think that there would be any problem with that at all.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time, Senator Short asked me a question relating to government expenditure contributions to the aggregates of the March quarter national accounts. I indicated that, while government expenditure as a total is up, the largest contribution came from the State governments. I just want to give Senator Short the figures. As he knows, the total increase in government consumption expenditure was 3.5 per cent through the quarter. State and local government expenditure was up 5.6 per cent and Commonwealth expenditure was down 1.3 per cent on the last quarter.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as his interjection about real interest rates, let me say that, while we do not have the most favoured position in terms of real interest rates, the latest fall in real short term interest rates to 5.6 per cent is much more in line with the figures in other industrialised economies. For example, Germany has a real interest rate of 6.1 per cent; France, 5.8 per cent; United Kingdom, 5.2 per cent; Italy, 4.9 per cent; Japan, 3.5 per cent; Canada, 2.7 per cent; and the United States, 1.1 per cent. Those are figures from the Economist of 31 May. They compare with the figures which Senator Hill, I think, quoted from a previous edition of the Economist. Our real interest rates are about the middle of the range when compared to those countries.

With the trend lines revealed in inflation taken from the March quarter national accounts and declining interest rates, that position will improve. I will be happy to try to answer Senator Short's question next time the national accounts figures are published.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for that additional information, which I think will bear some careful scrutiny as to the basis for it. I move:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I undertook to consider a matter raised by Senator Lewis in relation to unparliamentary language. He referred to an incident during Question Time when I required Senator Knowles to withdraw a remark made about Senator Cook. Senator Lewis suggested that Senator Cook's remarks may also have been out of order.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have examined Senator Cook's remarks as recorded in Hansard, and it is clear to me that Senator Cook did not use any unparliamentary language. Senator Lewis's point is essentially that Senator Cook misrepresented the views of Senator Knowles. That is not a matter of order, but a matter for debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

With respect, I ask you, Mr President, to look again at the remarks of Senator Cook. Unfortunately, I do not have the Hansard with me but, if you examine the Hansard, you will see that Senator Cook was answering a question on industrial relations in the State of New South Wales. In the course of giving that answer, he made an aside about the views of Senator Knowles in relation to a goods and services tax. I do now see how, in answering Senator Childs's question about an industrial relations matter in New South Wales, an aside in relation to a goods and services tax, which is a totally different matter, and which attacks another honourable senator in relation to her alleged views on a goods and services tax, does not fall within standing order 193(3), which says that all personal reflections on senators, in effect, shall be considered highly disorderly.

I understand that there is some cut and thrust-and again, unfortunately I do not have the Hansard with me-but you will see that Senator Knowles's only response was immediately to call Senator Cook a liar-in fact, she said he was a born liar. That led to your requiring her to withdraw. She was placed in a position where she either responded immediately across the chamber to him because of his words or she had to leap up to seek that you make a ruling that it be withdrawn.

I am putting to you that you should have called Senator Cook to order under standing order 193. I regret that your ruling is that he did not use unparliamentary language and I ask you at some stage or other to review that in the light of precedents about the use of unparliamentary language.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Lewis, I will examine the remarks that you have made today. The Clerk and I had a good look at the question last night. We know that Senator Cook did not make any unparliamentary remarks. In fact, he was engaging in a debate. I will look again at the points that you have raised today.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Today I announce Government decisions on a series of significant defence reforms. These mark a further major step in the continuing process of refining Australian defence policy since this Government set the broad strategic direction for Defence with the 1987 White Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Defence planning, by its nature, must be dynamic and evolve with changing strategic and economic circumstances. We face considerable strategic uncertainties as we enter the 1990s. We are not in Europe, where we might benefit directly from the decline in superpower confrontation. We have regionally-based defence needs, and they have not diminished. There are tensions and pressures which could impact on our security, and which require us to maintain our military capacity to protect Australian interests, or to contribute to regional efforts to resolve problems.

3. Effective defence depends on a high level of commitment by service personnel and the broad support of the nation. It also depends on national economic strength over the long term. Our long term security interests will be better served if planning for defence and our national economic development are in harmony. This includes having appropriate sectors of the nation's economy more attuned to the support of our defence effort. As we enter the 1990s, the central challenge before us is to organise our defence better, so that we can obtain the maximum combat capability in the most efficient and affordable way.

4. It is easy to draw up lists of what can be done to improve our defence capacity, if there are no resource limits. More demanding is the task of deciding what we can do less of, or to find better ways of doing things so that we can release resources for new projects and activities. In Defence, as in all areas of government, there is always a need to strive to make more effective use of resources. It is only through being more innovative and creative in its approach to resource management that Defence will be able to acquire more surface combatants, improve Australian Army mobility, and acquire airborne early warning and control aircraft.

5. In the debate that follows about the force structure review, I am sure that we will hear reference to the recent Gulf war. There will be claims that the Gulf war proves that this or that equipment is obsolete, or that Australia must hurry to buy some specific piece of high technology-irrespective of our strategic circumstances or operating conditions.

6. I will not indulge in such speculation. It will take months of careful analysis by military specialists to reach considered conclusions about the practical military lessons of the Gulf war. Australian experts will participate in those studies, and we will examine the results carefully. We will not be distracted by the sensational claims of the instant experts, whose stridency is usually matched only by the shallowness of their knowledge of defence matters. Such so-called experts rarely acknowledge that Australia has no land borders with any country, and that distances in Australia's northern environment are mostly measured in hundreds or thousands of kilometres.

7. The only useful conclusions we might draw now about the Gulf war are broad strategic observations; that is, success in military undertakings is critically related to military professionalism backed by national will and economic strength. Saddam Hussein gambled on what he saw as the weakness of Western democracies-their pluralism, their commitment to human values and their distaste of conflict. He also grossly overestimated the military capacity and commitment of his own, largely conscript, armies.

8. There is an important lesson flowing from this. Militaristic and aggressive regimes run the risk of being met with concerted action, which will extend, if necessary, to military force. In particular, potential aggressors will need to be wary of the response of the United Nations and the United States.

9. The Gulf war also highlights the central obligation to provide for national defence. Australia will continue to receive support from alliances, including access to advanced technology and intelligence, and emergency re-supply, but we must plan on carrying out our primary combat tasks ourselves. The Gulf war has not changed these fundamental assessments, nor should it drive our force structure decisions. Australia must continue to structure its Defence Force around the tasks likely to arise in its area of direct military interest, and must not revert to the old and discredited forward defence policies of the 1960s.

10. This is not to neglect alliance and regional associations and cooperation with regional neighbours. They remain essential elements of Australia's overall defence approach. As the Gulf war showed, from a self-reliant Defence Force structured for the defence of this nation, Australia can make a contribution to operations further afield in support of friends and allies, and activities sanctioned by the United Nations. Today's decisions will ensure that Australia continues to have the capacity to contribute to wider global and regional security.
The Force Structure Review

11. The force structure review examined the current Defence Force structure and recommended adjustments up to the year 2000, taking account of strategic priorities and likely resources. It builds on 20 years of development towards defence self-reliance in Australia, applying the priorities set out in the Government's policy paper entitled The Defence of Australia 1987.
12. The force structure review adopted the following key principles:

(a) Firstly, to maximise the combat capabilities of the Defence Force, by reducing the number of service personnel involved in headquarters and base support functions; and, by commercial and civilian support and maintenance where this is operationally feasible, practicable and cost effective.

(b) Secondly, to meet the strategic focus on northern and western operations by extending western basing for the Royal Australian Navy and northern basing for further Army units, and by enhancing the forward deployment capacity of the Royal Australian Air Force.

(c) Thirdly, to make greater use of reserves, including a new form of reserve service to supplement the existing reserve forces of each service, while maintaining the required overall force readiness levels.

13. It is important to ensure that there is enough flexibility in funding to undertake new initiatives in the latter part of this decade, when expenditure on current major projects such as the Anzac ships and Collins class submarines reduces. This is because in the first decade next century there will be heavy demands to replace obsolete equipment such as the guided missile destroyers, Fremantle class patrol boats, M113 tracked armoured fighting vehicles and F-111C aircraft.

14. Within this framework, the review examined the capabilities which the Defence Force should possess as Australia moves into the twenty-first century. It found that current capabilities provide a generally adequate national defence capacity for the key roles identified in Government endorsed strategic guidance, although some should be given higher priority for enhancement.

15. There will be greater emphasis on the use of reserves. To give a new focus to the present reserves, an Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Reserves) will be appointed to advise the Chief of the Defence Force on ways to improve their effectiveness. This appointment will be held by a two-star Reserve officer.

16. Command, control and communications developments will emphasise joint operations, and we will be moving to collocate the joint force commanders as soon as practicable. Future communications projects will be directed away from costly, military specification programs to make more extensive use of the civil infrastructure and of commercially available equipment.

17. There will continue to be substantial investment in intelligence and surveillance, reflecting their high priority. An operational network of two over-the-horizon radars will be developed by the late 1990s. The need for a third radar will be reviewed then. By the mid-1990s, Defence Force operations will benefit from better integration of data from both military and civilian sources.

18. The P3C aircraft will be substantially upgraded to enhance their surface surveillance performance, and it is planned to introduce airborne early warning and control aircraft later in the decade, when more effective and affordable systems may be available.

19. The six Collins class submarines will be based in the west, but with one or two deployed continuously off the east coast. Defence will continue to monitor developments in air independent propulsion, but without commitment to fitting such systems.

20. A balance between aircraft, surface ships and submarines is needed to provide flexibility in maritime patrol and response. These are demanding tasks in the extensive ocean areas to our north and north-west. The present concept of three tiers of surface combatants will be replaced by a two-tier concept of destroyers or frigates and offshore patrol vessels.

21. By 2009, the number of major surface combatants will increase to 16, compared with the current 10. The new ships will be based on a modification of the Anzac frigate design, for delivery from 2006. The Fremantle class patrol boats will be replaced by 12 more-capable offshore patrol vessels, for delivery from 2004. Pending their introduction there will be a life extension for the Fremantles to maintain our patrol and intercept capabilities in the maritime approaches and fishing zone.

22. The increase in numbers of surface combatants will also improve the Defence Force's ability to protect shipping and offshore territories. There will be a change of direction for the mine counter-measures program: we will acquire larger coastal minehunters of proven design in place of the inshore minehunter program, which has not proved cost effective, and has performed poorly. The Government makes no apology for making the hard decision to end this program. Such decisions should be made as soon as it is clear that a new concept will not meet expectations, to limit further investment and to pursue more cost effective approaches.

23. The FA18 and F111C aircraft are central to the Defence Force's air defence and strategic strike capabilities. The fleets will be managed to extend their service life for a further 20 years. Completion of the chain of northern air bases this decade with the construction of RAAF Base Scherger, near Weipa, will enable the Defence Force to respond more effectively in the north.

24. We are developing an innovative scheme to provide a significant surge capability for the tactical fighter force and strike reconnaissance force. For the first time, former FA18 and F111C aircrew who have left permanent RAAF service may continue to fly them while on the reserve, thereby ensuring that their capability to bolster the permanent force is retained.

25. A number of changes will be made to the Army to enhance our ability to protect assets and to respond to incursions. Most importantly, Army will be restructured on the basis of independent brigades, better oriented to northern operations, with selected battalions having a higher level of tactical mobility through the permanent allocation of transport. A new infantry mobility vehicle will be acquired. We are negotiating with the United States for the reintroduction of four to six upgraded Chinook helicopters.

26. More Regular Army units will be based in the north. The Second Cavalry Regiment will move to Darwin in 1993. An armoured regiment with one regular tank squadron, and a composite aviation squadron will be deployed in Darwin by the mid-1990s, and an infantry battalion by the end of the decade. The regular tank squadron in Darwin will be able to be reinforced by the reserve tank squadron, which will remain at Puckapunyal.

27. The regular First Division headquarters in Brisbane will be restructured as a smaller, deployable joint force headquarters, while the reserve Second Division headquarters in Sydney will develop the skills and doctrine for conventional divisional operations.

28. The Regular Army of some 26,000 will continue to have a significant combat capability. There will be some 11,000 regular soldiers in that combat force, making up four regular infantry battalions, the Special Air Service Regiment, an armoured regiment with one regular tank squadron, a reconnaissance regiment, two aviation regiments and a balanced mix of combat and logistic support units.

29. The Army Reserve will maintain its present size of some 26,000 personnel, and the existing seven Army Reserve brigades will be retained. In addition, by 1996 a new form of more completely trained and equipped reserve will have replaced most regular combat and combat support units in south Queensland.

30. Twenty per cent of the strength of the new reserve brigade will be regulars. The reserve commando regiment and three northern surveillance units will continue to have significant numbers of regulars. Other regular service personnel will be involved in training and support, including for the 14 remaining conventional reserve battalions and the many other units which make up the reserve contribution to the support of land operations.

31. The Defence Force will retain the capability to respond to requests for support from regional nations, and this capability will be improved when the training ship Jervis Bay is replaced later in the decade by a new ship with the dual role of helicopter support ship.
Training and Support

32. Training will be rationalised on a joint service basis. Consistent with the Government's policy of micro-economic reform, there will be significantly greater use of commercial support and civilian staff in technical training areas. Navy's technical trade training will be consolidated at HMAS Cerberus. Motor vehicle trade training will be consolidated at the Army centre at Bonegilla-Bandiana, and the RAAF base at Wagga will handle all Defence Force aviation-related trade training, and possibly combined clerical training.

33. Facilities will also be rationalised. HMAS Nirimba will be closed as part of the rationalisation of training. It is also planned to close HMAS Platypus with the phasing out of the Oberon class submarines later in the decade. The RAAF airfields at Laverton and Point Cook will be closed and sold. No. 6 RAAF Hospital may be retained at Laverton, and the possibility of moving RAAF Logistics Command there from central Melbourne will also be investigated. The airfield at Point Cook could be zoned for public recreation purposes, but Headquarters Training Command, the RAAF College and RAAF Museum will remain there.

34. Changes to Army structure and rationalisation of training, together with extensive commercial support of Air Force and Army maintenance and support functions, provide additional opportunities for substantial rationalisation of facilities and concentration at a smaller number of bases and depots.
35. Opportunities will continue to be taken to expand combined training with the New Zealand Defence Force where it is mutually beneficial to do so.
Implementation

36. Since implementation of these proposals will incur some costs, particularly in early years when the defence program is under heavy pressure from commitments to major projects, it will be phased. In order to avoid overcommitment to unrealistic targets and expectations of savings which may not be met, only those estimated savings arising from functions which we are confident can be commercialised cost-effectively in the short term have been programmed. Similarly, no targets have been set for asset sales because of the difficulty in determining net proceeds. Funds from these activities will provide additional flexibility in the second half of the decade.

37. The personnel changes flowing from these Government decisions and internal defence efficiency measures will amount to almost 10,500 regular personnel-over 1,000 from Navy, 5,200 from Army, and 4,200 from Air Force-together with more than 3,800 defence civilians. More than 1,600 of these civilians will come from central elements of the Department, and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. DSTO will be given a more commercial orientation, so that it can make a larger contribution towards Australia's technology base.

38. In putting forward these proposals I am conscious that they will impact directly on the professional interests and career aspirations of staff at all levels. The changes will be managed to ensure that the needs of defence personnel, as the most important single resource, are recognised and given careful consideration, including appropriate consultation. Their high levels of skill and commitment are central to Australia's defence.

39. The changes will be introduced over a decade, and there will be no immediate or large-scale redundancies. However, to avoid distortions in rank and skill levels, some management initiated voluntary redundancies may be unavoidable. These will be kept to an absolute minimum. Many of the service personnel leaving the Defence Force in the future will find that their transition to civilian life will be eased by the greater availability of civilian jobs in areas where they have expertise. They will be able to continue their military careers on a part time basis through the new reserve scheme. The same scheme will provide opportunities for young people to have a year's full time training followed by a part time military career.
A New Form of Reserve Service

40. The Government has endorsed in principle this concept for a new form of reserve service, with implementation to begin next year. It will make greater use of former regular personnel and, in the case of Army, significant numbers of new recruits receiving about 12 months initial full time training. These personnel will allow appropriate parts of the Defence Force to operate at levels of operational readiness and cost below those for permanent elements, but higher than for the current reserves. They will significantly increase our capacity to deploy well trained personnel in shorter time scales than is practicable with the current reserves.

41. The new form of reserve service will form a part of, and build on, the existing reserve components in each service. While these personnel will primarily be recruited for the Army, they will also supplement permanent Navy and Air Force elements. The force structure review has planned initially for 3,200 in the Army and 450 each in the Navy and the Air Force, with possible future increases. As I said earlier, for the first time, we will be maintaining a reserve of significant numbers of former F111C and FA18 aircrew to provide a surge capability for those aircraft.

42. The Government decided not to adopt Mr Wrigley's specific proposal for a `militia' in his report The Defence Force and the Community largely because Mr Wrigley's proposal did not meet the Government's readiness requirements. Mr Wrigley's proposal is a high risk strategy which depends on retaining large numbers of reserve personnel. Nevertheless, the defence concept for the new form of reserve service is consistent with his emphasis on greater use of former regulars and improved training and resources for reserves to broaden the overall defence base.
Expansion

43. The new force structure, with its links to the wider community and the national infrastructure, will provide a better basis for expansion. I have directed that studies be undertaken to develop further defence planning for the remote contingency of substantial conflict. These studies will identify areas likely to cause difficulties during expansion, and identify action required to ensure that the Defence Force can meet any threats to the nation's interests.
The Wrigley Interdepartmental Committee

44. Mr Wrigley's proposals to open up defence support activities to competition, consistent with operational requirements, have been accepted by the Government. A substantial range of activities currently performed by service personnel can be carried out commercially or by Defence civilians, with no detriment to our defence posture and at lower cost.

45. There are many gains to be made. Reliance on the community will allow a more effective increase in the defence effort if needed. In some areas, such as communications, the civil infrastructure offers greater capabilities than Defence could provide on its own. Commercialisation and civilianisation will provide access to a wider range of skills. Importantly, commercialisation offers the prospect of substantial savings which can be redirected so as to improve the combat effectiveness of the Defence Force. A better level of understanding between Defence and the community should result.

46. Defence will start this program immediately, with progressive implementation across the decade. The central objective will be to transfer support activities to the civil sector where this is practicable and cost effective. Combat and combat-related activities within operational areas will not be commercialised nor, in general, will operational support functions. Rather, commercialisation will focus on areas such as catering, stores and transport, clerical support, non-military training, repair and maintenance, communications, health care and firefighting functions.
Defence Industry and Exports
47. The measures I have announced for a greater role for the private sector in Defence support functions represent a logical extension of previous Government initiatives for the Defence industry.

48. The Government has given practical effect to the White Paper objective of greater self-reliance. We have ensured that the major submarine and Anzac ship projects have Australian prime contractors and substantial industry programs which will last into the next century. Since the early 1980s, the Australian industry component of major equipment projects has risen substantially, with some $800m more being spent in Australia this year.

49. The challenge for Australian industry is to upgrade its ability to produce, support and maintain Defence equipment at competitive prices. Allowing much greater involvement by private industry in Defence support activities will ensure that the investments in industry capability we are making through our major new equipment strategies are properly utilised by Defence.

50. There has been considerable micro-economic reform in Defence already. The former government dockyards and Defence factories have been sold or corporatised, reducing their cost to the taxpayer by hundreds of millions of dollars. The process of reform is continuing. Aerospace Technologies of Australia has successfully restructured its business. The Government recently endorsed the company's five-year corporate plan as the basis for its future development. The board of Australian Defence Industries Ltd has recently announced a proposal to restructure and rationalise its activities, aimed at realising further efficiency gains, while meeting the requirements of the Defence Force into the next century.

51. I now turn to the matter of controls on the export of defence and defence-related goods.
