Australia's policy of defence self-reliance requires the involvement of Australian industry in the support and maintenance of the Defence Force. The Government remains strongly of the view that defence exports should be encouraged. The export efforts of defence-related industries will continue to receive active Government support. Australia is a substantial net importer of defence goods and services, and we should continue to support an increase in the level of exports from this sector of our economy.

52. As I undertook earlier this year, the guidelines on defence exports have been reviewed. This review was prompted in part by concerns about the practical utility of some aspects of the policy guidelines for defence exports. Ministers have now agreed to a number of changes to policy which have produced both a simplification and a tightening of the procedures for the consideration of defence exports.

53. Firstly, applications to export defence and defence-related equipment to sensitive destinations will be referred to the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports. Under previous arrangements, only lethal or destructive goods, or those determined to be of major military significance, were subject to the interdepartmental process. Internal procedures relating to the identification of sensitive destinations have also been streamlined.

54. Secondly, existing foreign policy criteria for considering applications have been strengthened in order to ensure that important strategic, external policy and human rights considerations are not prejudiced. The Committee, in making its recommendations to me, will take into account not only the political and military situation and policies of the country for which a particular export is intended but also the situation in the general region for which the goods are destined.

55. Thirdly, the guideline relating to goods of `major military significance' has been amended. Previously, such goods were so defined by reference only to their significance for Australia's defence. Now there will also be taken into account the significance of such goods for a country in the region of proposed export.

56. I must also emphasise that the significant majority of Australia's defence exports are non-lethal, and our major export markets do not give rise to any concerns on strategic or foreign policy grounds. In recognition of these facts, the process for consideration of applications of this nature will be streamlined. Certain parts and accessories will be able to be exported without individual permits. Licences for such parts and accessories will be issued for export to approved non-sensitive destinations. Being able to export such goods under licence will be of considerable advantage to industry in that companies will be able to respond more promptly to client's requests.

57. The recent events in the Gulf have further emphasised the need to strengthen international arms control measures. Australia is an active participant in international arms control forums such as the Coordinating Committee on Exports of Technology to Communist Countries; the Coordination Committee for Multilateral Strategic Export Controls; the Missile Technology Control Regime; the Australia Group concerned with chemical and biological weapons; and the Nuclear Suppliers Group concerned with nuclear proliferation in efforts to finalise the negotiations on a chemical weapons convention. Australia is recognised as a responsible member of the international community.
Conclusions

58. The plan that I have outlined today represents another major step in this Government's commitment to ensuring that Australian defence planning goes forward into the next century in a way that meets our national priorities and is consistent with our international obligations.

59. In the mid-1980s, with a rapidly growing economy, we were able to sustain significant real increases in defence spending. This allowed us to increase investment in new capabilities and update equipment significantly, and to improve living and working conditions for service personnel and their families.

60. For the 1990s, much of the defence agenda is about greater efficiency and effectiveness. This statement shows that, without expectations of major growth in the Defence budget, the Government can adjust the force structure in a considered and timely fashion, to deliver an even more effective Defence Force, with appropriate capabilities to take us into the twenty-first century. Nothing in this statement precludes future Government changes of emphasis, should this become necessary.

61. These decisions shape the Defence Force to maximise its capacity to draw on national resources as a whole to meet credible military threats. They will provide a force capable of overcoming the long distances and isolation of Australia's environment. Our strategy is designed to capitalise on Australia's geographic advantages and ensure that any aggressor would face major obstacles in an attack on this nation. It also ensures that we can make a contribution to operations further afield and, when required, support friends, allies and activities sanctioned by the United Nations.

62. Most importantly, while we do not now face a military threat, these decisions ensure that the Defence Force will be able to respond quickly to any threat that does emerge, and will be able to do so with the full support of the Australian community and the backing of all our national resources. They constitute a long term program to restructure and improve the effectiveness of the Defence Force.

I would like to table some accompanying documents. They are the Force Structure Review and the report of the Interdepartmental Committee on the Wrigley Report entitled The Defence Force and the Community. I would also like to table the Defence Communications Corporate Plan, which was not referred to, but I thought we would put it on the table and, finally, a document on the ready reserve program 1991. I also indicate that an executive summary of the two other reports, that is, the Defence Regional Support Review and the Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project, has been circulated to honourable senators. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On such an important subject as defence, I am sorry to say that the statement we have just heard from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is disappointing and a cop-out in a number of important areas. The statement is based on a great number of reviews, committees, reports, and reports on reports accompanied by a great deal of hype which has emanated from ministerial officers preceding the delivery of the statement today. I did really expect that we would have had something of greater note and significance than the statement we have just heard.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the work and attention that seems to have gone into this statement extending over many months, it is a seriously flawed statement in a number of respects. In the first place, perhaps the most serious criticism of all about this statement is the fact that it has not been based on any new up-to-date strategic assessment of Australia's situation in 1991, and that which we will face during this decade for which this statement and the Force Structure Review have been prepared.

It has been perfectly clear since the end of the Cold War that there has been a fundamental, major change in the strategic situation in which Australia is placed-indeed, in which the world is placed. This has had major implications for our own region. Then there was the Gulf war. There is instability in parts of our region which should be reassessed, and there have been new developments in arms acquisitions, transfer of technologies and so on. All of this has demanded a reassessment of the situation since the White Paper was prepared and delivered in 1987.

The Opposition has been calling for this reassessment for many months now. The Minister has steadfastly refused to make such a reassessment and has fallen back time and time again on the White Paper, finetuned, he says, by some secret strategic assessments of the Government. But he has refused to table even a sanitised version of that finetuning-and that is all it amounts to. The Minister has refused to have any prior public debate on this question of the fundamental basis of the Force Structure Review, and of the exercise which he and the Department of Defence have undertaken and which is now announced in the statement.

In itself, this approach has meant that the statement today has not been based upon any up-to-date consideration of these fundamental matters. The Minister's attitude is even more surprising in view of the recently expressed attitudes of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). As recently as last Friday, the Prime Minister told an Asia-Australia Institute function:
The last five years have seen the most profound changes in global strategic circumstances in nearly half a century.
He went on to say that this requires Australia to reassess our strategic relationship with Asia. On 24 February this year, Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, said:

There can be absolutely no doubt that the easing of superpower competition has had great effect in our own Asia-Pacific region; nor can there be doubt that new approaches to security now opening up have direct application in the region.

Therefore, this whole exercise has been going on, as I said, with committees, reviews and so forth, by the Defence Department and the Ministers-the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) has been much engaged in this-without the creation of any fundamental base which should be governing the direction of all of this work. On that ground alone, it is no wonder that there are serious flaws in this statement.

The second reason why this statement is so flawed is the simple fact that it has been driven simply by budgetary considerations. Again, this is a matter which the Opposition has emphasised time and time again over many years, particularly in defence debates in this chamber. This is not some new-found concern by the Opposition; it is something that has been reiterated over and over again. I have heard my colleagues Senator Newman and Senator MacGibbon in many defence debates, long before I became the shadow Minister for defence, emphasising this fact.

It is clear, from the record of the defence budget since the 1987 White Paper, that it has fallen well behind the financial requirements of the policy contained in the White Paper. We have this absurd situation where the Government has adopted the White Paper of 1987 and its force structure proposals, but has never been prepared to match its own acceptance with the financial requirements. As I said, it has been pointed out by the Opposition time and time again that this could not go on, and that there is a growing tension between the defence commitments that the Government has undertaken and the reality of the financial shortfall in the budgets year by year.
In the Force Structure Review is a complete acknowledgment of that major failing on the part of the Government in relation to Defence. Paragraph 3.5 on page 39 reads:
The funding of major White Paper initiatives has reduced the amount of discretionary expenditure available to Defence in the short term.
I might say that this short term is a matter of some years. The paragraph continues:

This commitment to major capital programs has also reduced much of the flexibility in Defence planning which enabled competing resource demands to be balanced. The short term problem is thus to develop a strategy to overcome these resource pressures over the next few years.

That is what this is all about. This is not a strategy for Australian defence over the next decade; it is a strategy, as this Force Structure Review report admits, to overcome the resource pressures over the next few years. That is a sorry indictment of this Government and, I regret to say, of the Ministers who have this responsibility, although it is much wider than the Ministers themselves because in the end it is the Government's responsibility to determine how much money it will give to Defence. I do not want to imply that responsibility is simply limited to the Ministers concerned.

It is a Government failure and, from this Force Structure Review, it will clearly be a Government failure in the years to come because the projections of this Force Structure Review would have to have been based on whether there will be no growth in expenditure, whether there will be a minus one per cent growth or maybe-maybe-a growth of one per cent. Over the last few years since the White Paper, the Government has not met a one per cent growth on average.

With the economic failures of this Government and the economic circumstances of the present day and age which will continue, unfortunately, for the next few years until the Opposition gets into government and turns it around, one can see no prospect for more resources being made available to Defence than have been available before. In fact, the probabilities are that under this Government there will be less. That is the second reason why this statement is fatally flawed.

Another reason for the flawed nature of this statement is the way in which the Government has gone about the savings which it clearly has to make in order to meet its capital equipment program and to also retain some semblance of Defence effort. We in the Opposition have been supporting the idea of saving money in the ways that Mr Wrigley pointed out in his report, which has also provided an opportunity for the Government because a major analysis was made by Mr Wrigley of ways in which savings could be made in Defence. The Government has, to its credit and to this extent, looked at that and sought to make some savings in that direction. But I am bound to say that the efforts of the Government to achieve savings by contracting out Defence support functions, by replacing more expensive service personnel by employment of civilians in this area and by cutting down and using better management practices so that there could be a reduction overall in manning in the Defence Department, have been somewhat half-hearted and somewhat ineffective.

The fatal flaw in this cost savings measure is that it has been directed towards and has fallen most harshly upon the regular combat areas of our defence forces. This combat area has taken the brunt of the cuts. I notice that we had a new euphemism by the Minister in his speech-cuts are personnel changes. That is what cuts are. The largest single cutting has been into the regular combat forces, particularly in the Army but also very significantly in the Air Force.

The Opposition has supported the Government in the opportunities for savings and in the way it saw that this could be done. The Government has taken these opportunities up to some extent, and we support what the Government has done to the extent it has, although I think it has been insufficient and a half-hearted effort. Nevertheless, the Government has seen its way to making its largest cuts in the totally wrong way, namely, cuts to the combat forces, and particularly vicious cuts in the Army, because its regular combat strength has been reduced from six battalions to two battalions.

A further weakness of this statement is its attempt to replace that clear weakening of our defence forces by the creation of a new Ready Reserve force, which is a new idea. No-one knows whether it will work. My colleague Senator Newman will have much more to say about that matter, so I will not deal with it further. But this is another clear weakness in that the Government has been prepared to exchange the certainty of our highly trained regular combat forces with something that could prove to be a pie in the sky. I hope it will not, but it is a risk. Nobody can doubt that it is a risk.

A final reason for this statement being so flawed is that the Government shows very little indication of the need to introduce a new management culture in the Defence Department generally. It indicates that there is no understanding of the need for management reforms, all of which were pointed out by the Opposition in our policy for the last election and which, of course, still stands. There are clearly a great many opportunities for management and particularly in the central areas of the Department. I note that the Minister is claiming that he is making cuts in numbers in what he calls the central elements of the Department. I do not know whether that is just at Russell Hill in Canberra or whether it is wider than that, but there is really no indication that there is to be any new management philosophy or structures adopted where further savings could be made.

There are a large number of matters dealt with in this very comprehensive statement. Although it is disappointing, nevertheless it certainly covers a great deal of ground. My colleagues in this debate, including Senator Newman, will no doubt deal with certain other aspects of it. There are some matters about the statement which the Opposition supports such as our support throughout this process for the approach of savings through civilianisation and contracting out. The Government has had our support all through on this. It must have been expected that the Government would make better use of that bipartisan support.

The Government will move further units to the north and there will be development of facilities there. It has reaffirmed its commitment to the two-ocean Navy with the building up of facilities at HMAS Stirling at Cockburn Sound, near Fremantle, and the decision to base all the new submarines there. These are matters that the Opposition supports. The collocation of the force structure command clearly is a sensible step, as is tri-service training. I am pleased to see that the Government has taken up the Opposition's strong recommendation that the ill-fated mine countermeasures be abandoned, and it now proposes to purchase some suitable coastal mine hunters, which it should have done a long time ago. I am also pleased to note that that can be done within a budget of no real growth. I do not know whether it can be done if there are cuts, and probably it will not be, but at least the Government is announcing this as a measure of some certainty.

This is unlike a number of the other equipment proposals, which in this statement only amount to a wish list. We have had a major force structure review and all the hype associated with it, but when we come to look for hard commitments as to what the Government proposes to do on the purchase of equipment-some of which will become necessary, as the Force Structure Review admits, in this decade but which certainly will become necessary in the early years of the next century-this document is very short on any commitments at all.

Even the major requirement of an airborne early warning and control capacity is left very much in limbo as to whether that can be managed at all within the life of this structure, which goes through for this whole decade. The review and ministerial statement are very ambivalent as to what the Government intends to do about that vital matter, as indeed is the statement on capital. It talks about what can be achieved with no real growth, with very limited measures indeed, and it says that it will require higher funding, if it can get it. Examples of high priority projects are helicopters for the Anzac frigates, reconnaissance and trooplift helicopters for the army and airborne early warning and control. Those very important matters are left entirely up to some later decisions, and this can only amount to a wish list in terms of this statement.

In regard to defence industry, I am pleased to see that the Government has repeated its review of its policy on export defence equipment and has reiterated its support for that policy. I think that this has been very much driven by the Opposition's initiatives in this area. From what I have seen of the statement, I am not by any means satisfied that the changes overall will be beneficial to assist more exports of defence equipment. I will have to reserve my judgment and comments about them until I study the new guidelines, but as they have been described in the statement it seems that further additional new problems may arise for exporters if they are having to negotiate some of the new provisions in the guidelines which have just been announced by the Minister.

For all those reasons, therefore, the Opposition finds little to commend in this statement. As I have said, the Opposition is disappointed on the whole by the statement. We certainly hope that the Government will be able to find greater savings and thereby direct the defence dollar to those areas where it is most required, namely, in the combat strength of the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that we have heard today from the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) could fairly be called the Robert Ray memorial lecture. I use this description because Senator Ray was handed a poisoned chalice from his predecessor, Mr Beazley. The problems that Senator Ray now faces as Defence Minister would not have needed a solution if `Bomber Beazley' had not handed him the bomb and dived for cover. Mr Beazley was also sometimes known as `the general', and Professor Stuart Woodman only recently told an audience in Brisbane at the defence and media conference that `a politician wants to be the general and the general wants to be a politician'.

SPEECH.PARA: Well, politician Beazley may well have been called the general, but he did not act like one. The duty of a general, apart from providing leadership, includes providing balanced judgment and direction for those under his command-the Australian Defence Force. Minister Beazley did just the opposite. He provided no balanced judgment, nor any lasting direction in his administration of his Department or in his administration of the Government's own White Paper.

Mr Beazley has wrongly been described, in my view, as a good Defence Minister. I have never believed that to be true, and in fact the evidence is here before us today. He was obsessed with capital procurement to the exclusion of the realities of long term financial management and the impact of his shopping trips on the remainder of his budget, and the budgets of his successors.

I welcome the fact that the Minister has recognised and acknowledged the lack of flexibility in the defence budget over the next few years, because Defence's forward commitment to capital expenditure is currently at its highest level ever at approximately 80 per cent of the capital expenditure component of the budget. This, when taken together with the salaries component of the budget, means that 80 per cent of the entire defence budget is already allocated well into the future-and thereby the problems with flexibility.

Mr Beazley's White Paper, as Senator Durack has already said, was prepared in different times, and there can hardly be any informed commentators left today who would believe that the strategic assessments on which the White Paper was based are still appropriate. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) only recently have acknowledged this. Yet, for some unaccountable reason, the Government apparently continues to rely on that same White Paper.

Not since the White Paper was produced in 1987 has the Labor Government provided the funds on which it was predicated and which were necessary to meet the tasks set out in the White Paper. Yet the capital procurement which was set in motion proceeded without apparent concern for the dislocation of the other priorities in that White Paper. Today we are debating a defence statement which, in essence, is an admission of the failure of the Labor Government to achieve its White Paper's objectives and, even worse, signals the inability to do so in the future.

One of the major priorities to be achieved for Australia, according to the White Paper, was a mine countermeasure capability. Yet after 15 years of the Mine Hunter Inshore having been accorded a high priority, we still today have little or no mine countermeasures capability. This is only one of the capabilities set out in the White Paper which we still lack. Others include, of course, the ability to maintain surveillance of our maritime and air approaches; the ability to rapidly deploy our forces by land, sea and air; and an amphibious capability for the Army.

Yet two years ago the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade made a number of recommendations about our mine countermeasures inadequacies, and today the Government has finally acknowledged the failure of the program. Not only is this serious for the defence of Australia but it is also a matter of great concern that nearly $109m has been wasted. I mention this because, to me, it is one of the more sizeable examples of poor management in the Department of Defence. The other examples are many and varied, and they have gone on for a very long time, ranging from the sublime to the ridiculous.

Only this week, when debating the Appropriation Bill, we heard several more examples of poor management by the Department. These included spending $350,000 recruiting engineers overseas before the necessary clearance had been given in Australia to allow the entry of those engineers into the country, and a trust fund of $100,000 which was given to the Department of Defence in 1983 and remained for four years without being invested, losing value each year: hardly good management of a trust fund bequeathed by a Polish Australian to be used in the interests of the defence of Australia.

On Tuesday Senator Ray and I debated the need for Defence to have good information systems so as to know how it is spending its money. Late last year, in a very important report, the Auditor-General revealed that it was almost impossible to get information on the cost of a soldier. He was not alone in having difficulty in getting financial information from the Department. Ever since I arrived at this place, I have had that difficulty, as have my predecessors. I recognise that the devolution of financial authority to commanders will go some way to improving the management of resources, and I welcome those moves, but there is still a need for senior management to know how that authority is being exercised.

Currently that seems to be too hard for Defence to manage, even though there are 24,000 civilians in the Department of Defence. The Defence Act provides that the Secretary to the Department of Defence is responsible to the Minister for financial planning and programs of all elements of Defence outlay and for financial administration and control of expenses, including the correct and proper use of public funds. One wonders what those 24,000 people are doing if this information is not available and cannot be made available cost effectively to the Parliament. Also, what are they doing in the mismanagement of the projects that we have seen over the years?

The Minister is proposing to reduce the size of the Public Service elements of his Department by 3,800 people. This immediately raises questions. If financial control is actually being handed to Defence Force personnel down the line, why are we still retaining 20,200 civilians who will no longer have their previous financial responsibilities? In addition, what confidence can we have that these 3,800 reductions are real? We have seen number shuffling with this Department in years gone by. I understand that 200 people in the Defence, Science and Technology Organisation in Adelaide are part of the 3,800, yet the phased restructuring of DSTO was announced by Minister Kelly on 18 November 1987. I believe that these people have been counted once already. How many of the remaining 3,600 are in the same boat?

We might also ask whether the DSTO reductions are of scientists and engineers in this clever country. I will be seeking details of the 3,800 positions, and I note that there has been no similar civilian structure review tabled here today as there has been with the force structure review. Even if the 3,800 positions are not being recycled, it would appear that the civilian reduction is 16 per cent when the people we actually recruit to defend us are being cut back by 15.4 per cent, almost the same amount. One would have expected the civilian cuts to be proportionately greater.

The Opposition has already stated on the public record its support for efficiency and improved management, both of which at the last election we claimed were possible and necessary in the Defence portfolio. We also support a changeover from military to civilian personnel in fulfilling base tasks provided it will not have a deleterious effect on our combat capability. We do not accept civilianisation measures which will reduce our combat capability. It goes without saying, therefore, that appropriate contracting out is supported by the Opposition. Indeed, I visited the Ministry of Defence in the United Kingdom two years ago to learn of the moves it had made in that direction, and I received warnings of the need to exercise great care not to impact on combat capability.

The two elements which give me most concern in this whole exercise are the impact on our readiness and, therefore, our ability to defend Australia, and the financial footing on which the whole exercise is based. The Opposition has made it very clear that it opposes any force structure cuts which impact on combat capability but, despite the Government's rhetoric to the tune of `our cuts will not affect combat capability', this is precisely what it is doing, as Senator Durack has already said. It is clear, despite the Minister's claims, that combat capability will suffer and the sharp end will be considerably blunted.

General Sir Ivan Mackay, the general responsible for this nation's territorial defence in 1942, said that he reckoned a garrison of not less than one division would be required to hold Townsville against a Japanese attack. He reported to the then Labor Government that it might be necessary to submit to the enemy occupation of certain areas of Australia should local resistance be overcome because, in effect, there were only enough troops in the country to defend an area bounded by Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. This was the origin of the notorious Brisbane line.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Labor initiative.

—A Labor initiative. I thank Senator MacGibbon. It was at a time when we had over 50 active battalions. In Vietnam we had nine battalions; currently we have only six undermanned battalions, and the Government proposes to remove two of those battalions and replace them with reserves, meaning that we will reduce our capability even further. To do this is surrendering Australia. How can the Government possibly be serious? Only yesterday Senator Maguire, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade, released that Committee's report on United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia and issued a press statement which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommended that `Australia should seek the command of any United Nations peacekeeping force in Cambodia to demonstrate our commitment to the region and our willingness to contribute to the peaceful resolution of the conflict there.'

That will not be as easy as it seems now, with the reductions that the Government is making. If two of our combat battalions are made ready reserves, not able to serve overseas, how can the other four sustain and maintain a rotation for a considerable duration in Cambodia, especially if it continues for some time, and do its job of protecting Australia at the same time if any threat or low level contingency should arise?

The Minister has been talking to journalists about our teeth to tail ratios being out of kilter, but what he has said has been misleading, because in prior wars Australia had the support of our friends and allies to provide logistical support. A change in ratio to meet our demand for self-reliance inevitably means that we have more logistics people, and rightly so. Wherever sensible reductions can be made which will not affect our combat capability, they should be made.

Another problem which compounds this loss of capability is our ability to actually recruit and retain the personnel to make up the two ready reserve battalions. The role of the Ready Reserve, as the Minister has indicated, is to boost Australia's overall expansion force with the capability to increase personnel in a short time to meet any credible contingencies. Those are admirable words, but how many ready reservists will be quickly released by their employers if they are needed? Even more basic, how many employers will be prepared to allow employees a year away with the reserves plus periods of six weeks a year thereafter? How many employees, especially in a time of recession, will be prepared to put their career on hold for 12 months while they go away for training, and then leave again for over one month's training in each subsequent year?

The financial inducements to employers will be costly to the taxpayer, and the absence of the employee for 10 weeks, about, of 52-including their four weeks annual leave-will have a significant effect on businesses, which should not be underrated.

Most importantly, what legislation does the Government propose to enforce these requirements? The Minister has made no mention of it and it is my understanding that there is none. How can we possibly be reducing our regular personnel component without any guarantees that those we are replacing them with will do the job if required?

The readiness of the Ready Reserve battalions inevitably will be less than that of the two regular battalions they are to replace. We are once again moving back to the situation we faced in 1939 where there were insufficient regulars ready to commit to combat and a long training period before the reserves were made combat ready.

The Ready Reserve program provides for a review with a prospect of expanding the Ready Reserve, especially for the Royal Australian Navy and Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF). These two services, in my view, have not made sufficient use of reservists in the past and thus the proposals in this area are welcomed. But the thought that the ready reserves in the Army will be expanded to replace even more regular units in the future is, however, one which fills me with alarm.

The two battalions of ready reserves will be provided with financial incentives, such as payment of tertiary education fees and commitment bonuses. What will be the costs of these incentives? The Minister has not spelt them out. If we look at the American experience we know that this can be very costly. In summary, the ready reserves will not be ready and any savings made by their introduction are uncertain.

The force structure review proposals substantially reduce flying hours for the RAAF F111 aircraft and for the Navy Sea King helicopters, the RAAF Caribou fleet is being reduced from 21 to 14 and operating costs for the RAAF 25 Squadron at Pearce are being reduced. These will significantly reduce the training and experience levels of yet more defence personnel.

Another problem we will face is a reduction in communications capability. The communications project cutbacks identified will make it difficult for our combat force signallers in the field to operate effectively. This has substantial significance for any peacekeeping forces we may send away in the future. The loss will mean that our combat forces will have only elementary manoeuvrability in the field. What is left of our communications may be suitable for vital asset protection, but this is hardly sufficient for our multi-roled soldiers.

Apart from the title of `ready reserves', I am concerned at the impact of the new proposals on the existing reserves. Already many reserve units cannot afford to pay the reserves that turn up for training or any new reserves recruited. One letter I received this week indicates that one reserve unit cannot afford any more training weekends until the end of this calendar year, weekly training nights have been restricted to 2 hours, and that it is carrying out some training on an unpaid basis. This is only the latest of several such reports from other units.

I believe one of the principal impacts will be to reinforce the existing reserves' perceptions of themselves as being neglected and at the bottom of the system. The result will be that many members of the reserves will be further discouraged and will drop out. This is likely to be especially so when the ready reservists undergo their part time training and inevitably have the advantage in promotional and career path opportunities over the existing reservists. One can only speculate on the impact on the existing reserves if some of these funds that the Minister has been announcing today had been invested in the existing reserves rather than in the new flashy model of ready reserves.

It is also likely that the Ready Reserve will have an impact on regular recruitment. There is every likelihood that the new one year option will be taken by potential regular recruits instead of the existing four-year commitment. I am concerned that this will have a serious effect on training costs and impact heavily on training facilities as well as reducing the total experience level of the regular force.

A high proportion of people going through the very short training cycle and then leaving not only is costly but also leaves little chance of the required experience levels being maintained. This is the same situation we faced in the 1950s when a small, demoralised regular force was tied up with an overwhelming national service and training commitment. It also means that the training costs blow out and the experience levels in the force go down. Both of these are very serious problems which may face us in the future as a result of today's announcement.

My further concern with the Ready Reserve is that many of the existing reserves come from essential services areas. That is, many reservists are farmers, farmhands, transport workers and Telecom Australia employees. The Minister obviously is aiming for farmers, amongst others, for the ready reserves. With a greater reliance on them, what will be the situation in an emergency? In the Second World War essential service workers were prevented from going to war in order to keep the country running.

How can the Government possibly deny that the ready reserves will mean a reduction in our total force combat capability? The experience levels and complex training achieved by regular personnel are vitally important to maintain these combat roles. As the American experience in the Gulf war demonstrated, crucial combat roles were only undertaken by regulars.

The sharp end will not be significantly `sharpened' as the Minister has constantly claimed; in fact, it will be blunted. A ceiling of 11,055 for the Army's combat force has been identified in the force structure review. At present, there are approximately 12,799 in the combined front-line combat and immediate support combat troops. The force structure review reduces the Australian Regular Army by 2,460. The other reviews have targeted other areas leading to a total reduction of 5,200 from the Army; this making a total of 10,500 from the whole Defence Force.

This leads me to the question of redundancy. The Minister has announced that cuts will take place over time, based on a percentage of voluntary redundancies together with some management initiated early retirement and natural attrition for the remainder. He says that redundancies will occur by negotiation where rank-trade imbalances exist, but it is my understanding that the extent of the redundancies is not known and neither are the terms and conditions of any packages.

The lowered morale that will be generated by this instability and uncertainty are very worrying, especially as defence personnel, unlike public servants, currently have no right to be considered for redeployment into the Public Service. I would hope the Minister will announce the extent and the terms and conditions of redundancies very soon.

The Minister stated in his speech that many of the service personnel leaving the Defence Force in the future will find that their transition to civilian life will be eased by the greater availability of civilian jobs in areas where they have expertise. That raised a hollow laugh on our side of the chamber, because the Minister appears not to recognise the difficulties of his Government's induced recession. Clearly, the Government is totally out of touch. No matter how well qualified many people are, they are still out of work.

He also said in his speech that those leaving the regular force will be able to continue their career on a part time basis. Perhaps the Minister is thinking of copying the British Government after the Napoleonic wars when the Army was put on to half pay.

The Committee for Employer Support of the Reserves Forces is properly to receive additional support. It is interesting that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been invited previously to provide a representative on both this Committee and on the Army Reserve Advisory Council. But it has not, however, chosen to provide a representative on either. This lack of support for the defence forces does not augur well for the future when Australia's defence will rely even more heavily on civilians. As is known only too well, the union movement has had a sorry record both in World War II, Korea and Vietnam and in peacetime, in its dealings with Australia's defence.

I turn now to the financial integrity of the statement. I have very serious reservations about the costing of the Ready Reserve. I referred earlier to the Auditor-General's report on the reserves. There were difficulties in getting reliable figures, but that report claimed that the cost per day of today's reserve soldier is more than 50 per cent higher than that of a regular soldier. Imagine my astonishment when I find that the Government has costed a ready reservist at only 42 per cent of a regular soldier and that the Army itself costs a ready reservist at 60 per cent of the cost of a regular soldier. They obviously cannot all be right.

I remind honourable senators that a ready reservist will inevitably cost considerably more than a reservist in the present Reserve. If 20 per cent of our reserve units are to be made up of regular members, and if regular reservists are to spend more time in uniform than the current reservist, then the training, pay and equipment for each of the ready reservists will be greater than for the current reserves. In addition, the incentives for recruitment and retention of the ready reservists and for their employers will be expenses which are not currently incurred for the existing reserves, and they will not come cheap.

I understand that the Auditor-General stands by his costs of last year for the existing Reserve and I understand that the Army figures were not wildly different from the Auditor-General's figures. It can only mean that the figures of 42 per cent and 60 per cent of a regular soldier do not include all the costs which should be included to arrive at the true cost of a ready reservist.

We have been waiting for the last couple of years to see the results of the previously announced assets sales. The continuing depression in the real estate market has meant that Defence has not received the benefit that these sales were predicted to bring to the Defence budget. I would not place too much reliance on any prediction of buckets of money from the sales of bases announced for closure today.

For example, the long term closure of HMAS Platypus may well result in a pretty small return for the Defence budget if, as appears likely, it ends up as a waterfront park rather than a valuable subdivision. Similarly, there is a question mark over the use to which land at RAAF Williams could be put and, therefore, to its value. Incidentally, one wonders in this context how effective the RAAF museum will be in the future if it is no longer to be attached to an airfield. This, I understand, was considered to be essential to the long term planning for the museum.

As I have pointed out, there are several internal uncertainties in the statement in the financial area. What is not spelt out by the Minister is the context in which these decisions have been taken. The announcements today are predicated upon no real growth in the Defence budget. However, the Defence Force structure review also looked at options based on an increase of one per cent and a decrease of one per cent in the Defence budget. It recognised that, even with one per cent real growth, the Government's White Paper was not affordable. It also recognised that only 70 per cent of the White Paper initiatives could be funded without any growth, and that if there was a reduction of even one per cent in the budget, less than half of the White Paper program could be funded.

I am most fearful that, taking together the suspect figures for the Army Reserve, the uncertain returns from the facilities sales and the bulge which will shortly hit us in the capital procurement inheritance from Mr Beazley in a year or so, the budget will once again be up for radical cuts. How much more can Australia's Defence Force be cut before we decide to lay down our arms and have no force at all? We are doing nothing short of surrendering Australia. How long must we wait before we see substantial and meaningful cuts to the dinosaur of the Defence bureaucracy? When will our combat capability truly take priority over the brown-suited bureaucracy? The mandarins appear to have won round one, and Australia is the loser.

The documentation released today will require more detailed study and time than has been available for this debate. A huge range of issues needs to be addressed, from the cuts to existing programs, to the sales of defence facilities to a close scrutiny of the areas detailed for contracting out and for civilianisation. This afternoon, however, I have concentrated on the personnel and financial aspects.

However, before concluding I would like to acknowledge my support for the decisions on the Chinooks and mobilisation planning. The cutbacks of the Chinooks was a decision which was roundly opposed by the Opposition at the time, and I welcome the maintenance of even some capability in this area. I also welcome the indication by the Minister for Defence that mobilisation planning will now be given some attention. Mr Wrigley was correct in pointing out our deficiencies in this area. However, I believe he was incorrect in suggesting that this could properly be laid at the door of Defence. Mobilisation planning covers much more than defence-it goes to other governmental responsibilities and the wider economy. The need for such planning must be a governmental decision.

In summary, although there are aspects of the Minister's announcement today with which the Opposition has no quarrel, there are serious and glaring faults. Firstly, the strategic basis for the White Paper has not been reviewed and cries out for reviewing. Secondly, the Government's past funding has gone nowhere near meeting the tasks established in the White Paper, and the financial measures taken today will only leave us further away from the targets set in that paper. Thirdly, the statement is purely budgetary driven, although it has been dressed up in public relations clothes to give it more clout.

Fourthly, the guts of it is that we are trading off readiness for dollars. Fifthly, our fears are that many of these dollar savings are illusory. Sixthly, the Ready Reserve program contains a `nudge nudge, wink wink' warning that this will be only the first step on the way to an even greater level of reserve forces. Seventhly, the Minister's shopping list for capital procurement into the next century is as illusory as the dollar savings he is claiming. They are simply a continuation of Mr Beazley's wish list of four years ago, the only difference being that they have been pushed further down the track.

The deployment during the Fiji crisis in 1987, the deployment to the Gulf in 1990 and the continuing instability amongst our neighbours, especially Papua New Guinea, makes it abundantly clear that we must retain highly specialised forces who are dedicated, have a high level of training and have the ability to react quickly in any of the contingencies established in the White Paper. The reductions in combat capability announced today by the Minister puts the defence of Australia in jeopardy. It is as serious as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, told the Senate the following:

SPEECH.PARA: I know Senator McLean wants to think laterally and to think in an exciting way about defence but I caution him on this point: one of the things in defence is never to adopt a high risk strategy. That is always the constraint on any Minister for Defence-he or she cannot always take the high risk strategies.

The theme of my response today to the Minister's statement on the Defence Force structure review is that Senator Ray has fundamentally misunderstood the point that I was making. The fact is that Australia already has a high risk defence strategy. For years the strategy has been designed to meet imaginary threats while real ones are largely ignored.

Our gigantic defence capital equipment budget is being lavished on inappropriate weapons systems while our real defence needs are starved of funds. Service families are being shunted around the country every two years and personnel are asked to perform tasks of declining relevance to the Australian community, yet our defence planners wring their hands and wonder why people are leaving the services.

We are at a watershed in our strategic and military history. If ever there was a time for a lateral and radical rethink of defence policy, that time has come. Vision and courage are needed to develop an affordable defence system which meets Australia's unique requirements, but this is not a high risk strategy. On the contrary, it is far less risky than the current approach. It is no exaggeration to say that the Australian Defence Force (ADF), notwithstanding the great dedication and skill of our service personnel, is in crisis. But crisis is opportunity, and the crisis in the Australian Defence Force is an opportunity for reform that presents itself only rarely.

Much of the publicity hype which preceded today's statement gave the impression that such a fundamental restructuring was under way. Nothing could be further from the truth. Beneath the hype is the reality that, as Peter Robinson wrote in the Australian Financial Review on 24 May, `The Ray approach is simply a camouflaged cost-cutting exercise by a veteran Labor numbers man'.

It must be said that Senator Ray did not create the mess from which today's statement is supposed to extricate him and the ADF. The Minister is between a financial rock and a hard place inherited from his predecessor in the Defence portfolio, Mr Beazley. The hard place, as David Lague wrote in the Financial Review on Wednesday last week, is the massive capital equipment program launched by Mr Beazley, which is now consuming 30 per cent of the Defence budget and putting enormous pressure on funds for personnel, training and operations. The rock is the pressure to stabilise the Defence budget, despite the 1986 recommendation of the Dibb report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities that annual real increases of 3 per cent were needed.

Given the Government's unwillingness to prune capital spending-indeed, this statement foreshadows the continuation of today's crippling level of investment for the next 20 years-the reductions must come from somewhere. It is for this reason and this reason alone that 10,450 regular service posts and 3,840 civilian posts will be axed over the next 10 years; that a Ready Reserve of some 4,100 personnel will be established; and that many of the non-combat service functions will be contracted out to civilian industry.

In his analysis of the Wrigley report, which was a major catalyst for today's statement, Dr Graeme Cheeseman of the Australian National University described it as an attempt to shift the deckchairs on the Titanic. The same could be said of Senator Ray's blueprint. The force cuts look radical, but the band on the deck is playing the same depressing old tune. The fact is that the changes do not alter the fundamental contradictions and absurdities on which Australia's defence planning is based.

There is an almost nonsensical quality to a defence strategy which assumes that a relatively small incursion into our northern zone will require the deployment of our entire Army to protect northern air bases. In the unlikely event of such an incursion, its very purpose will be to put pressure on Australia by exacting significant costs. The deployment of the full Army is certain to cost a great deal and the purpose of the incursion would have been achieved. We are investing billions of dollars on state of the art submarines, frigates and fighter bombers, and this statement foreshadows the possible purchase of six more frigates starting next decade. Yet any self-respecting military analyst would admit that they will play no useful role in the event of low level incursions and raids, which are the only feasible, albeit highly unlikely, threat that Australia faces.

The Minister in his address last week to the Melbourne Press Club acknowledged that we face no military threats. He said that Indonesia lacks the right military posture to threaten Australia and does not intend to acquire one in the future and has no aggressive intentions towards us. Any country beyond Indonesia which wanted to attack Australia would have to attack Indonesia first.

Only three years after Mr Beazley invented potential military threats from China, India and Japan in his attempt to sell ANZAC frigates to a sceptical New Zealand public, Senator Ray has disinvented these threats in order to sell his force cuts to the Australian public. The Minister is, of course, right. We face no existing or foreseeable military threat. Little wonder then that the past few years have seen defence policy drift back to the discredited doctrine of `forward defence' which has nothing to do with defence and everything to do with Australia's self-appointed role as the South Pacific policeman. The plan to buy a training vessel doubling as a helicopter and troop carrier, while having some merit, has the potential to be used for heavy-handed and unwelcome intervention. This proposal must be subjected to a full public and regional debate.

As I said before, we face no military threats, but we face substantial and potentially catastrophic threats from other sources. The greenhouse effect, for example, is predicated to claim large slabs of Australian territory as sea levels rise. Land degradation is putting significant amounts of farm land out of commission. By contrast, there is negligible risk that we will lose comparable areas of land, or indeed any land at all, to an invading force. Yet we pour $9 billion per year into meeting non-existent military threats while throwing a few million at the real security challenges of the 1990s.

No-one in this chamber would doubt that an important peacetime function to which defence can contribute, and does to some extent, is coastal zone surveillance. Yet the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar network, when operational, will only function from 9 to 5 during daylight hours, apparently to keep costs down. Australia's most powerful surveillance system of the future will be blind for 16 hours each day while drug smugglers and illegal fishing vessels operate undetected around our northern coastline.

It is crass madness that the coordinator of the State Emergency Service response to the Newcastle earthquake is forced to conduct chook raffles to fund the SES civil defence work. Just a few kilometres from Newcastle, 40 F/A-18 fighter-bombers worth $45m each sat idle in hangars with no pilots to fly them while the SES was forced to cope with the earthquake on a shoestring budget. This is not to suggest that ADF personnel live in glorious luxury. They come a poor second to weapons systems in the Government's defence investment priorities. One illustration of this is the Army hut at Ingleburn which I occupied in 1956 during my national service. That hut is still in use today and it is in somewhat similar condition to what it was in then.

The point I am making is that too much of our defence effort is irrelevant to our defence needs. This fact is never addressed by the other parties in their accusations and counter-accusations about wastage of service personnel. Why? Because the remedies lie in radical and lateral thinking which both sides refuse to admit is urgently needed.

This lack of relevance goes a long way towards explaining the public tradition of not being interested in defence. The Minister is now proposing to bridge this gap by following the Wrigley report recommendation that non-combat defence jobs be farmed out to civilians. Defence policy development will stay firmly in the hands of the small group of service chiefs and planners, bureaucrats and academics who have always set the agenda. The Minister should rest assured that this ivory tower practice will keep public interest in defence as low as ever.

This apathy may in turn hamper the Minister's ready reserve program. While the Democrats would generally support an improved reserves scheme, we have serious reservations about this one. Senator Newman has enumerated quite a number of quite legitimate reservations about the practicability of the program advanced today. We do not believe that it is sensible to artificially stimulate recruitment by using the reserves as an employment sponge to mop up struggling farmers and students, yet that appears to be the basis of this scheme.

We have particular reservations about the tax-exempt ready reserve education assistance scheme and the proposal to allow for more assured deferral of tertiary places for recruits undergoing their initial 12-month training. It is insidious and unjust to discriminate against the average students, many of whom have inadequate financial support, simply because they are unwilling to do military service.

It is a great disappointment to the Australian Democrats that, far from giving the public a role in defence planning, this Government continues to exclude even the Parliament. I remind the Minister that he has failed to honour an undertaking to me to table the Wrigley report for debate in this chamber. I also point out that the work of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, which has been conducting an inquiry into ADF reserves for some time now, was not asked to contribute to the development of today's statement. I endorse the conclusion of Peter Robinson in last Friday's Financial Review that today's statement:
will give Australia the worst of all possible worlds-a demoralised, inadequate, directionless defence establishment and a nervous, unconvinced public . . . .

The Democrats do not pretend that there are easy, overnight solutions to the crisis in our defence establishment. The longer the need for a truly fresh look at defence is put into the too hard basket, the deeper the crisis will become. Nor do the Democrats claim to offer a detailed, watertight alternative to the present system. We offer a model which clearly defines the directions in which defence planning must head if it is to become relevant to today's realities.

We propose that the Australian Defence Force become a multi-role civil-military organisation. Traditional defence tasks must take their place alongside peacetime coastal surveillance, search and rescue, bushfire fighting, environmental protection and rehabilitation, and other defence functions which require common skills and equipment to perform, and which therefore contribute to a capability for dealing with low level incursions in a cost-effective way. There is simply no justification for today's disproportionate emphasis on high level military threats when these are patently the least of our worries.

This multi-role organisation would encompass the existing civilian agencies which presently perform some of the civilian tasks I have mentioned. A Democrat Defence Force would have a core of professional, full time, regular military personnel; a larger pool of reserves providing routine part time service; and civilian personnel, some of whom would perform front-line non-military tasks, such as coastal surveillance and environmental protection.

The Democrats would encourage a respect for a new brand of national service-not national service by way of conscription to fight other people's wars, but voluntary national service in defence of Australia. We would begin to establish a conservation corps to undertake selected conservation tasks which build skills relevant to our wider defence needs, such as the rehabilitation of degraded lands and polluted waterways through major reafforestation programs.

Under our model, defence units should increasingly become regionally based, with the exception of capital city units which could supply reinforcements in the event of large scale emergencies in remote areas, and could contribute to United Nations peacekeeping activities. The units would operate in peacetime with light arms where necessary, using relatively small, medium-tech vehicles such as Canadair CL-215 multi-role amphibious aircraft, transport planes and helicopters, small trucks, four wheel drives, motor bikes, river craft, minehunters and fast ocean patrol boats. In this context the Democrats are in general agreement with the Minister's plan to acquire four coastal minehunters and 12 patrol boats.

Larger naval vessels and long-range maritime patrol aircraft would police the outer reaches of the fishing zone. Fast combat aircraft would provide air cover in the event of high level contingencies. Priority would be given to effective surveillance, combining technological means such as Jindalee with the eyes and ears of civil Australia-Aboriginal communities, farmers and pastoralists, truck drivers, fishermen, port officials and so on-linked to regional and national surveillance centres. In the event of an incursion, our strategy aims to evacuate threatened communities where possible and necessary and surround and await the raiding parties, whose supply lines will be extremely vulnerable or, more likely, non-existent. We would end the present nonsense of planning to deploy tens of thousands of personnel to deal with an incursion of perhaps 100 people.

The ADF's top-line military hardware is already of marginal relevance to Australia's defence and would have almost no role in the Democrat model. We propose to mothball tanks, artillery and armoured personnel carriers which are too cumbersome and destructive for remote defence tasks. Democrat policy also strongly supports a non-provocative defence posture and has no place for F111 land attack bombers, long range submarines or gold-plated long-range heavily armed frigates and destroyers. Expensive and irrelevant forward defence operations would be buried once and for all.

It is within this framework that the Democrats believe that Australia can construct an affordable, relevant and effective defence system which offers far greater vocational rewards and social stability and is in tune with the changes in community attitudes and our strategic environment. It is time, therefore, for real change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The defence statement that we have before us this afternoon has some of the hallmarks of a confidence trick. When we listen to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) we could be forgiven for believing that we had no problems in defence-that everything was fine-and that, even more importantly, it would get better still. Indeed, in the second sentence of the statement the Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: Today I announce Government decisions on a series of significant Defence reforms.

The word `reforms' means that there will be improvements. That is simply not true and I think it is less than honest to pretend that it is true. What we have before us today is a series of incorrect decisions which are quite dangerous, as Senator Durack and Senator Newman, who have preceded me on this side of the chamber, have said.

Nothing announced in this statement improves in any way the capabilities or readiness of the Australian Defence Force (ADF)-in fact, we have something that reduces significantly the readiness and capabilities of the Australian Defence Force which are, as the Gulf war showed, at a very low level already. What we have before us is a proposition to save money-the old Australian Labor Party trick of running down the defence forces. There is nothing more to it than that; it is a money-saving exercise by the Government. Put in its simplest terms, when we have a very small force structure of about 70,000 men and women-as Australia has in its Defence Force-to propose that 10,000-odd personnel can be taken out of it without affecting the capability, suitability and readiness of that force is absolute nonsense. When one adds to that the fact that this is coming after years and years of cuts to the defence budget, the situation then becomes very clear even to the slowest of minds.

Unlike the Americans, we are not coming from a well-funded background stretching over the last decade. We are coming from a persistent level of cuts-down, down, down every year. The consequence of taking 10,000 personnel out of the Australian Defence Force will be a serious degradation of our present capability and readiness. It will affect the Australian defence forces for at least 10 years because it will take five years before anyone in the Defence Force has the courage to tell the Minister of the day that there is a real problem here, and it will take another five years to come up with some system to fix it. In those 10 years we will have a great loss of institutional knowledge from the Australian Defence Force. Some of that knowledge, some of the skills and some of the capabilities of the Australian Defence Force will never be replaced; they will be gone forever-and they will be gone for no purpose whatsoever. This is particularly important at the present time because Australia has a need for increased readiness and increased capability in its defence forces. Australia's ability to look after itself is now at a higher premium than it has been for many years, purely because of the ending of the Cold War.

Paradoxically, while the American force structure has been reduced and is being reduced significantly and its degrees of readiness are coming down as a consequence of the relaxation of the tensions of the Cold War, that imposes upon Australia an obligation to increase its own capability. While the world was polarised into two blocs-the Western democratic nations and the Soviet Union-their military presence on the world stage meant that many countries of the world had to conform to one or other bloc. To be seen to be involving themselves in military adventurism or pursuing national interests in a dangerous way was really forbidden to them by the great power blocs that were astride the world stage at the time. With that gone, we will see lesser nations pursuing their national interests, and sometimes they will pursue their national interests in a military way. The consequence of that is that there will be increased unpredictability and instability in the world. Australia simply has to have a higher level of readiness and capability in its defence forces than it has at the present time.

The basic problem that we have at present is that the Defence Force is poorly structured. It has an incorrect balance and it does not have a high enough degree of readiness. The Government is proposing to reduce further-not enhance-that capability and readiness by getting rid of about 10,000 personnel to reduce our number of regular infantry battalions from six to four. I am ashamed that Australia has only six infantry battalions. I think for a country of 17 million people that is a very shameful admission; it shows that we are not really serious about defence at all. But to reduce our strength of regular infantry units-our principal land combat units-from six to four, by one-third, is absolutely indefensible.

At the same time in the Minister's statement we see that the essential equipment needed by the Australian defence forces will not be bought. A huge loss of morale has followed the Labor Government with its progressive cuts year after year. The way that the Sanderson report was handled, the way it was leaked and the way the uniformed services have known what was in it for the last three or four months, has had a crippling effect on morale. We will see resignations from key people in the Services because they feel that they do not have a future in the defence forces any more. There is now a general air in the Australian Defence Force that these people no longer have a career; they have a job for the time being but they do not have a career. An enormous difference in morale comes from that.

Like other speakers on this side, I express my disappointment at the way the Government has bungled this opportunity. There is a need to reform the Australian Defence Force but the opportunity has been missed. Not only has the opportunity been missed; we have had some regressive changes which I believe are quite dangerous. It is all unnecessary. Australia is the easiest country in the world to defend. There is not an easier country to defend and every day it gets easier with the introduction of new high technology weapons systems. I am not saying that the defence of Australia is easy-of course it is not. It is difficult and it is expensive. But it is the easiest country in the world to defend and we can defend it if we have high quality personnel with high quality training and high quality, appropriate weapons systems. None of those is addressed in the report we have before us today.

We have had four reports and a ministerial statement placed before us. I have not had time to read them all. In fact, I have only skimmed the ministerial statement, the Force Structure Review and the Ready Reserve Program paper. It is no accident that the Government has done this, as Senator McLean said. Though the Minister for Defence is a member of this chamber, we have had no formal debate on defence. The last large report that we had from the Department-the Wrigley report-has never been debated in the Senate. We have never had the opportunity for that. And now, in the closing stages of the session, we are overwhelmed by four significant reports dumped on us with inadequate debating time. We will rise for the winter recess, we will come back to the torrent of the Budget Bills and no-one will get around to analysing what the Government is proposing to do. As I said before, that is no accident when it comes from the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray). I will talk about those reports on the adjournment debate, even if it means keeping the President out of bed some nights and, hopefully, Senator Tate as the Minister on duty.

How did we ever get into our present position? It is all about money. We got into it because funds have been progressively cut. The Department of Defence, in the late 1970s and early 1980s, recognised quite clearly that as a consequence of the equipment purchases from the Vietnam era, with a life cycle of about 20 years, by the middle of the 1980s and through the decade after that there would be a high replacement bill. There are a whole range of papers published by the Department of Defence as to how the financial problem would be overcome. I have a number of them still in my files. I have been talking about this since the early 1980s. In precis form, what the Department said was that there had to be a real growth of 3 per cent per annum in the defence vote just to maintain the position we had-just to stay still-because we had to accommodate new capital expenses. It is very interesting to look at the graph at page 38 of the Force Structure Review presented today. I seek leave to incorporate the graph in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows-
[THE GRAPH IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE; PLEASE SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 3979]

TALK.START.PARA: —The graph shows how defence funding has run down. In the Labor years we have never achieved 3 per cent average growth. In fact, in the first couple of years of Labor Administration in this country, we achieved a little over 2.5 per cent growth purely because, under the FMS contracts, the Americans delivered equipment ahead of time. The graph shows that for three years the degree of funding has been actually less than what was required in the year before and in no case has it provided enough to accommodate the new purchases that had to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: Additionally, there was some very irresponsible spending by the Government. The Government used the Department of Defence as a means of distributing political largess. The speed with which the submarine program was run through and awarded to South Australia was purely a consequence of Mr Bannon's election at the time. The speed with which the Anzac ship proposal was picked up and run through for Victoria was to help the poor old failed government of Mr John Cain. I do not mind make-work programs from a Labor government but, for goodness sake, it should pay for them from the welfare program-out of Senator Richardson's department-not from the Department of Defence because that is a gross perversion and abuse of its responsibilities.

I will deal briefly with the salient points in the Force Structure Review paper. I will have to deal with the failings of the report more than anything else. I make three general comments before doing so. They relate to the scholarship of the report, the funding considerations in it and the discussion on the White Paper. The first thing to be said in relation to scholarship is that it is a very intellectually banal and pedestrian document. There is not one original idea or creative thought in it. It came from a narrow-based Army staff committee and, even worse, it was never discussed with the senior officers of the three Services. I find it astonishing in a profession of arms that matters of great importance which affect everyone are not put for discussion before brother officers of a suitable rank. It is quite astonishing to me that a profession can be run in such an authoritarian way as the Army and the ADF Headquarters ran this report. What we have is a collection of assertions, allegations and assumptions without any analysis and research and anything in the way of scholarship behind it to back it up. In one sense it takes defence planning back 20 or even 40 years.

There are sophisticated management tools available today for systems analysts. There are econometric models that can be developed. One can analyse in great detail and predict with great accuracy what the consequences of certain management schemes will be and what certain management actions will result in. In the early 1960s with Robert McNamara in the Kennedy Administration the use of systems analysts in the defence forces was highly developed. They got a bit of a bad name because it went a bit far- there was a degree of excess in what happened in Vietnam. But that does not deny the basic validity of systems analysts in the management scheme of things.

We had two bodies in Australia: the Central Studies Establishment (CSE) and, later, the Services Analysis Study Group-SASG. They reported on various programs with a very high degree of precision and fidelity. They are no longer with us because they were too good at their job. When service chiefs put pet projects to them, they would be analysed and would be found not to give the benefits that the father of the scheme thought, and that upset the general. When the secretaries in the Department put pet schemes up and they were analysed and did not work out, that upset the secretaries. When Ministers put up proposals and the same thing occurred, the CSE and SASG disappeared from the scene.

One simply cannot do a seat of the pants analysis of major projects such as the management of the Department of Defence. It is too large; it is too intellectually demanding; and, above all, the consequences of misdirection coming from mistaken ideas coming out are too intolerable to bear. The Minister, for the sake of his own protection, should demand the use of modern management tools such as this. While I am referring to the scholarship and the management of this report, I find it astonishing that a Cabinet could accept only one submission rather than having a range of serious options put to it before making a decision.

As I said before, we are in this trouble because defence has not had adequate funding. It is no secret that the Australian Labor Party cannot handle the economy, whether it is the general economy or the particular economy of the Department of Defence. Looking at the proposals in the report, I was reminded of the Scullin Government-another disastrous Labor government-that gave us the Great Depression. Like the Hawke Government, which gave us the second largest depression this century, Scullin gave us the greatest. I went back and looked at Mr Scullin's two defence budgets. While it was running at around #86m to #7m in the years preceding Mr Scullin coming in-in fact, in the year directly preceding it was #6.3m-when he went out of office after his second Budget it was down to #3.6m. I am more than a little concerned that we are going to see Scullin revisited by the Hawke-Keating crew. If that happens we want to stop spending any money on defence now because the money will be wasted.

I started out by saying that the Minister pretended that everything was fine and dandy. We on this side of the chamber know that that is not so. What we object to is the pretence that things are fine. We would be more than happy to work with the Minister if he came clean, laid it on the table and said, `We are in an enormous fix'. We would work to get our way out of the situation. We are not interested in pursuing any past vendettas; we are interested in the future of the Australian Defence Force and in providing an adequate defence system for the people of Australia.

The third general comment I want to make relates to the White Paper. White papers have an importance out of all bounds to the bureaucracy. It is quite reasonable to make an assessment of the strategic environment, the regional environment and what threats and influences might bear on Australia in the years ahead.
