The White Paper breaks down, though, when people believe it-and believe it they do. They believe that whatever is in the White Paper will happen, particularly in the Army. The Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy do not take any notice of it, except in a ritualistic way when they are in meetings.

White Papers have very great dangers because, as I say, people believe not only that what they say will actually happen but also that they dictate the force structure and capability and, even worse, that they get to the stage where they dictate force placements. That is what we are seeing in this paper.

There are three central points on the first page of the report: maximising combat capabilities by reducing numbers; meeting the strategic focus of the northern and western operations; and making greater use of the Reserve. I would just like to briefly touch on those points. Maximising combat capabilities is fine, but that cannot be done by reducing infantry battalions by one-third; that is an absolute nonsense. Cutting out people in base areas sounds simple-it is easy to say-but after 10 years of contraction there is not too much fat left. It is a fact of military life that more people are needed behind the lines than in the front line. An effective fighting force cannot be run without a logistic and training base to support it. There is no way that can be run down just willy-nilly with the grandiose gestures that the Minister makes in his paper.

The second point about combat capabilities refers to maintenance. We again have a structure that has to go into the field. Civilians cannot be taken into the field in a combat situation, because matters of discipline, training and many other issues are involved. Operational flexibility, which a defence force needs to operate on active service, cannot be removed.

There is quite a bit of discussion around that civil contractors in many cases can be more efficient than trained service personnel. That argument really has to be taken with a grain of salt. Civilian contractors work 37 or 38 hours a week. Most maintenance people in the Services are working between 40 to 50 hours per week. If there is a need to do more, they do it quite cheerfully without a cent of overtime. Not one civil contractor will perform five minutes of overtime without heavy penalty rates. If maintenance is intense-in other words, if a resource is used to 100 per cent of its capacity-one is better off owning it than hiring it through contract, just as people are better off owning their own homes over a lifetime than renting them for a short period.

It comes back to having a decent systems analyst in the scheme of things-of knowing with a degree of accuracy whether it will be cheaper before the maintenance units in the Navy, Army and Air Force are disbanded and turned over to civilian operations. If they are to be turned over to civilian operations, some no-strike clauses or voluntary employment agreements will have to be put in the contracts; otherwise the Services will be held to ransom.

The second point is meeting the strategic focus of northern and western operations. I do not think that anything in the whole report demonstrates the sheer amateurish approach taken by the authors than that strategy. That is armchair strategy at its very worst. Defence forces need flexibility; one does not put everything in the shop window. A consequence of the White Paper is that the Government thinks the threat is coming from the north-west. I do not know where the threat is coming from; the Government is smarter than me if it knows. But a government should not deploy forces in the front line until it has a real threat on its hands. The Government's approach is one of the most blatant displays of professional ignorance I have seen. In the north, we need a surveillance capability so that we know what is going on. We need the mobility, the flexibility and the firepower to cope with what happens after that. We need to hold those active elements in reserve until the threats develop.

We then come to the business of making greater use of the reserves. This really is the folie de grandeur of the whole report. The Government's proposal will not work and it never will. The Minister has been sold a real tar baby on this issue. I just do not know how he ever bought the scheme. We have a good reserve at present. The reason it is not better is that the Government does not give it enough resources.

If the Government wants a higher state of readiness and capability in the Australian reserves, it should give them the tools to do the job. They do not get them at the present time. Until that matter is fixed, coming in with a new system is a total waste of time because it will fail, and it will fail more dramatically than the present reserve system.

When it fails, it will fail at great cost to both the regulars and the reservists, because we will see the infantry battalions of the regulars reduced by one-third and the A Reserve even more starved of funds. They will go right to the bottom of the priority list. This major change was put in without any research, apart from Mr Bilney's glib assurance that Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd had done some surveys and found that the world was full of students and farmers who were ready to serve for 12 months and then for a period of 50 days for four years thereafter.

Let us look at what is involved in the recruitment side of the issue. The Government makes the point that some ex-Australian Regular Army personnel might want to join the Reserve. It would be good if they did, but the facts of life are that it would be a very small number. Most people who leave the Army before reaching retiring age have had enough; they do not want to be tied up giving six or seven weeks of their lives in the Reserve from thereon. There will be a percentage who do, but it will really be quite small. The other point about those who come from the regular forces is that they have rank-they are corporals, sergeants, warrant officers, captains, majors and lieutenant-colonels-and they cannot be accommodated in the new structure. The benefits of putting ex-regulars in is really quite limited.

Let us look at the students. I know a fair bit about students. I have taught in universities for quite a while and I have four children who have all graduated recently from university. Students are very competitive; they do not want to be a year behind their cohorts when they are graduating. They do not want to lose $50,000 in their professional lives through missing out on a year's professional practice. The proposition that they can be bought with pin money by the Government paying their higher education contribution fees or giving them a $1,500 bonus when they finish 12 months training just is not on. Students do not want that. The students who are going but not straight away to university are those who put on a haversack and go around the world travelling for a year before they settle down; they are not the sort of people who go into the discipline of a military unit.

Then we come to the business of training. Once the students have done their 12 months continuous training, what happens? They will not be available for overseas service and there is no way that the Government can compel them under the legislation we have at present. If anyone knows anything about university regiments, one knows that parades cannot be run in mid-term time at weekends. Yet this proposal rests very heavily on weekend training to make it work, and that will not succeed. Although the Government says it will compel members of the Ready Reserve to attend for training, at the end of the day there is no way that it can. Legislation will not do it. The Government will be faced with the problems of high resignation rates, a failure by students to attend for camps and the rest of the problems that the ordinary reserves have. So the problem is not evaded.

Then there is the problem of employers. I do not know any employers who would want to give up a good employee for 12 months training and see one go for 50 days a year afterwards. Things are too tough out there for that. The rather glib statement about reserves in the report entitled Force Structure Review about employers being instructed-or words to that effect-to make time available for members of the Ready Reserve to go to camps for training just shows how out of touch the people who wrote this report were.

I do not wish to go through the equipment changes that are mentioned in this document. I am more concerned with the principles of what is involved than with the equipment. I will come back to that later.

The Government really avoided the question of improving efficiency. I will give a few examples where efficiencies can be picked up, and literally hundreds of millions of dollars saved. First of all, as the defence committee recommended in its management study report several years ago, we ought to get rid of the diarchy between the civilian secretarial side and the uniformed service side. We are still running two management streams. Although it has improved a little in recent years, there are huge delays and there is competition, and that is costing us probably hundreds of millions of dollars a year.

The Australian Defence Force is over-ranked. Job for job, we are at least one rank higher than the Americans. We are overmanned. We have about two or three times the number of officers who hold a rank of one star and above in the Australia defence forces pro rata as have the Canadians and the Americans. We had the mine hunter program. Two years ago we recommended that that be cancelled. That probably represents $200m down the drain and only now has it been chopped. We have the two-ocean Navy and a cost, I estimate, of at least $50m a year for basing a fleet in Western Australia. We need a bare base there. We need to deploy ships as the need comes, not construct buildings. We have three air forces in this country. We have the nonsense of maintaining 34 Squadron, yet we are talking about cutting combat troops. We have to get rid of those inefficiencies and probably hundreds of millions of dollars will be picked up.

It is quite possible to have an adequate Defence Force for Australia, but it takes a lot more hard thinking than this Government has been prepared to do. It also takes money, and at the end of the day we do not put enough in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ministerial statement entitled Defence into the Twenty First Century bears all the hallmarks of a step backwards into the past instead of a look into the future. While some parts of it are to be commended as a move in the right direction, in many ways it is full of contradictions. I can agree with some of the Opposition speakers in that it is inadequate, and that defence options and plans for change, such as the Wrigley Report, should be debated by the Parliament, as Senator McLean said. One of Mr Wrigley's proposals for a militia was today dismissed as a high risk strategy in the statement of the Minister of Defence (Senator Robert Ray)-there was no discussion and no consideration of the options by the Parliament or the relevant defence committees of the Parliament. That is not good enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I can agree with some of the things that Senator MacGibbon and Senator McLean said in that respect. However, I must disagree with the amazing assertion from Senator MacGibbon that job creation schemes, as he called them, such as the submarine contract and the frigate project, should be funded by the Department of Social Security. He said, `Take the money out of Senator Richardson's Department'. This is almost unbelievable, but not quite. I did hear it with my own ears. I have to ask: does Senator MacGibbon not know or understand how people are hurting out there in the community? Does he not feel for them, or does he not care for them? He is a man, as I have observed over my few years here, who is bent on machines, especially high tech equipment. He relishes the hardware of the military and, judging by his report on his trip with Mr Ted Lindsay from the other place to visit the Gulf war in action, he has a great appreciation of, and even a reverence for, warfare. I find that really quite sad.

Going back to the Minister's statement, there is an observation in paragraph 57 reflecting the Minister's speech at the National Press Club on 6 February that the Gulf war has further emphasised the need to strengthen international arms control measures, but then it is recommended in paragraph 51 that Australia should continue to push military exports. There are many contradictions like that in this statement today. In paragraph 9, there is the important observation that we should not go back to the old and discredited forward defence policies of the 1960s, but then in paragraph 10 we have a version of forward defence revisited in the guise of overseas excursions to support the defence of Western interests, as was so tragically played out in the Gulf war recently.

Obviously this whole exercise is about cutting back on personnel and operability to pay for more hardware, an exercise hardly designed to soothe those who have been screaming about the run down of expenditure on military personnel and on day to day operating conditions for the Australian Defence Force (ADF). I do have considerable sympathy for people in the ADF who I think have had a raw deal over the past few years, especially during Mr Beazley's time as Minister for Defence when the whole emphasis was on hardware. Some of us had hoped for, and expected, a change with the new Minister. Obviously we were disappointed. I am sure that many people in the ADF will be extremely disappointed by this continuation of a hardware push at the expense of personnel.

The report fails abysmally on two counts. Firstly, because Australia does not need the kind of expensive hardware that we are told we can now afford through the savings mentioned in this report. Of course, this is despite the recession that the rest of the community is feeling only too closely that does not seem to affect defence whatsoever. Secondly, it fails because it still assumes that the world of the future will continue to rely on the use of military force to resolve conflicts.

In paragraph 26 the report acknowledges that there are no military threats to Australia, although Senator MacGibbon seemed to think that we should be armed and ready and practicing while the threats develop. That was the line that he took and that is the usual Opposition line, which is not really based on any logic whatsoever. In respect of there not being any military threats to Australia, we are very lucky. Given the involvement of a number of countries in the Asia-Pacific region in historical local conflicts such as those in Kashmir, East Timor, Indo-China, Korea and Sri Lanka, if every country were to act as Australia is and, even in the absence of threats, chose to arm itself with the sort of equipment that we intend to buy, then references to arms control would be laughable. How else can we visualise a world where every country wants FA18s, helicopter support ships, latest state of the art submarines and surface combatants such as the Anzac class frigates?

An article in the New Zealand Herald yesterday pointed out that critics of this review believe that Australia has become more dependent than ever on the United States of America (USA) through high technology weapons systems, such as the FA18s. The Gulf war certainly indicated our dependence on the United States for equipment. That is inevitable as long as we tie ourselves to the United States in a military alliance and depend on highly sophisticated, but irrelevant, military equipment for our national defence. Most of it is just not appropriate for our conditions.

I welcome the cut in the size of the ADF as this country never needed such a large military force, let alone such a bloated bureaucracy on Russell Hill-the largest in Canberra. Here again, I can agree with spokespeople from the Opposition.

Australia is a country of 17 million people in the south-west Pacific, generally removed from areas of conflict. A realistically appropriate strategy for the time being would be one that is non-offensive, based on diplomatic non-alignment and restricted to a small military force which would be available for disaster relief or service with the United Nations peace-keeping forces, but which would not otherwise serve beyond our shores. The money saved by the cutbacks referred to in the Minister's statement should be devoted to restoring health, education, social services and overseas aid programs, not to pay for the ADF wish list referred to in paragraph 4, or hinted at in paragraph 5 of the Minister's statement.

The peace dividend, elusive as it has proved to be, always required advance planning, just as it took some years to switch over from military production to civilian production after the Second World War. It is not something that can be done overnight as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has discovered, despite its efforts to convert factories designed for the manufacture of tanks and missiles to ones which can produce consumer goods such as refrigerators and washing machines. Obviously, a number of members of parliament will be unhappy with the proposals to cut down the number of military bases and other facilities in their electorates. I can understand that, especially in these days of recession when many people are unemployed already.

What worries me is that, if we spend the money saved by these cutbacks and closures on this wish list, it will hurt our balance of payments even further, because most of it will have to be purchased from the United States. As an example, when France acquired three AWACS from the United States in 1987 they cost $US550m, or $US942m if the ground support systems were included in the price. If we knew more about the helicopter support ship, or whatever roll on, roll off vessel the Navy has in mind, we could work out what that would cost, depending on whether it could be built in Australia.

The new helicopters referred to by the Minister will have to be purchased from the United States, like the FA18's, although I doubt whether the Government will admit that they are contributing further towards our balance of payments deficits. This is never acknowledged by the Government and it is rarely picked up on by the community, but defence purchases contribute significantly to the gross imbalance. Surface combatants will be expensive and, despite offset agreements, will require cooperation with a European or North American company, meaning a further balance of payments deficit.

We also learn from the statement that the Government is going to replace all kinds of expensive military equipment with even more expensive military equipment in the next couple of decades with an even more disastrous impact yet again on our balance of payments deficit. This indicates that either we are going to end up paying more for the military than the current 9.3 per cent Budget allocation, or 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product, or that equipment purchases will take up a greater proportion of the overall military budget than at present.

Equally disastrous is the admission in paragraph 51 that all these purchases mean that we are a net importer of military equipment so we have to offset these costs by exporting more military equipment. It is a real catch 22 situation. At this point it is worth recalling the words of Bill Hayden, in his previous incarnation as Minister for Foreign Affairs, when he addressed the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in 1988:

It is clear that arms exports should not be turned to as a way of solving domestic economic problems . . . Arms transfers must not become a new cash crop . . . It should also be recognised, especially by those whose development needs are great, that the purchase of arms is at the cost of the purchase of the investment goods essential to the creation of employment and economic growth.
They are strong words which we should heed, but obviously not taken into account by the Minister in his speech today.

It is worth recalling several news items that appeared within a few days of the end of the Gulf war to the effect that the arms race was well under way again in the Middle East with orders of up to $US30 billion already received by the Pentagon from Arab states, along with Israel and Turkey. As a defence lobbyist at a conference in Virginia told a Newsweek reporter in February:
The next big push in the defence industry will be to exploit the Middle East. This is not arms control. This is an arms opportunity.

His words might have been echoed here in Australia as we hear all the weak excuses trotted out by the Minister for why Australia is going to host the biggest arms bazaar in the southern hemisphere in Canberra this November; why we are going to push our military exports in a notoriously unstable and conflict-ridden part of the world; and why our exports are all right while other countries' exports are not.

There is no mention of the fact that half the other nations in the Asia-Pacific region are following a similar path, including South and North Korea, China, Taiwan, Singapore, India and Pakistan. At least Ken Harris, the Managing Director of Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI), was aware of this when he warned in his company's first annual report:
South East Asia is likely to become a much sought after market for European and American defence contracting companies.
Also reflecting on the Beazley military export strategy since 1988 was Greg Sheridan, a conservative reporter for Rupert Murdoch's flagship, the Australian, when he wrote on 3 March:
What is absolutely clear is that the attempt to develop a defence export industry has been a failure.
Thank goodness for small mercies, but it is not for want of trying on the Government's part.

The Minister can protest all he likes about our exports being different from other irresponsible nations selling offensive high tech military equipment to the volatile Middle East, but ADI has already booked its display into one of the world's biggest arms fairs, the International Aerospace and Defence Exhibition at Dubai in the Persian Gulf. We are going to be right in there with the best or the worst of them. This exhibition was originally scheduled to be held in January but it was postponed until after the Gulf war was over and then, of course, it was back to business as usual. How cynical can one get! All the testing was done, all the weapons were proven to be extremely effective and now more orders are called for. A huge arms bazaar in Dubai is coming up and Australia is participating in it. I think it is absolutely disgraceful.

Most military equipment is not offensive-this is the line, of course-but it is vital for the armed forces of any country to prosecute a war. If one country sells high tech defensive equipment, it is an incentive to other countries in the region to acquire equipment to evade it, such as quieter submarines, cruise missiles that fly under enemy radar, stealth technology and so on. It is all part of the arms race.

If we want to export in this climate, the temptation will be to cut standards of control, not to tighten them up. I notice that in the Minister's statement he talks about streamlining the export guidelines-simplification-but he also mentions a tightening up. Simplification and some items being able to be exported without individual permits will make it easier for industry. Companies will be able to respond more promptly to clients' requests. I can see that that will be the temptation. Even if it is not the intention of the Minister himself, the temptation will be there to cut standards of control to get around regulations which are in place, particularly in the unfortunately very competitive business that arms sales are in the world today.

This is what the changes to export controls were really about a couple of years ago. I welcome the Senate committee inquiry initiated by the Australian Democrats, to which many community groups will be presenting submissions through the months ahead. International arms control measures referred to by the Minister are a waste of time while Australia justifies its own military exports and blames other countries for weapons proliferation. It is highly hypocritical.

The ministerial statement reflects confused and muddled thinking. The coalition also offers no improvement when it wants, on the one hand, overall cuts in government expenditure-but not in Defence of course-and, on the other hand, lots more money for personnel in the ADF and the new hardware. As Senator Newman pointed out, this is a continuation of Mr Beazley's wish list. I would add that it is also the Department's wish list and, to a certain extent, the Opposition's wish list as well.

Senator Durack reflected on instability in the Asia-Pacific region in his contribution to this debate but, like the Minister, he still opts for a military response instead of exploring the options for non-military models for conflict resolution. Unfortunately, in that there is bipartisanship in the Parliament and I think that is the tragedy. We are still fixed onto a military model rather than looking creatively at non-military options.

It is clear that we need radical new thinking about the nature of war and conflict resolution in the twenty-first century; not a reiteration of gunboat diplomacy at a time when the proliferation of ballistic missiles, nuclear, chemical and biological weapons will make national defence obsolete as we understand it today. The glaring hypocrisy of world leaders is stunning as they talk about international arms control measures now directed at the Middle East region-the stable door being closed a fraction, maybe, well after the horse has bolted. These limitations on others are based on the premise that it is all right for `us' in the West, that is, to have all manner of weapons systems including those of mass destruction, while it is not all right for `them' to have such systems because they might not be used responsibly. I believe that all nations, including those who believe themselves responsible, should be scaling down and deploying their massive military budgets towards more socially and environmentally useful ends. That is certainly the position of the Greens Western Australia whom I represent here.

As I have said before, any military risks to Australia are imaginary rather than real. Successive defence Ministers have admitted that. Yet, present problems remain unacknowledged or at least inadequately funded. I refer to illegal fishing and drug smuggling on our north coast. Even the new high tech Jindalee system will not be able to monitor those niggling problems, as Senator McLean pointed out.

These long range high tech, offensive, offshore, directed weapon systems suit the United States military desire for burden sharing and interoperability-burden sharing because the US says it cannot afford to keep up with its huge military expenditure right around the globe and neither should it. It should not be its role to see itself as the international police power, but the Australian burden sharing and interoperability suit the United States military very well indeed. What we need, instead of all of those systems to suit the United States military, are lots of patrol boats and aircraft watching our northern coastlines to deter illegal fishing vessels and drug smugglers. I have said that often before but it needs to be repeated.

That is where we need the readiness, which the Opposition is so fond of promoting. If ever we needed readiness, it was to deal with the real and niggling threats to Australia's security right now. Assessment of real security risks, not only to Australia but also to the world, must be broadened to include environmental threats to our very existence. A redefinition of security is required and, if we had the courage to remove ourselves from the myth of dependence on militarisation as a guarantee of our safety, then we might be able to address some of the present risks to our security from which no military forces will be able to save us. No military forces can deal with the greenhouse effect; no military forces can deal with other environmental problems which are facing us on a global scale. There are others, of course, like ozone depletion, overpopulation, increasing soil degradation and desertification, and pollution of the earth's waterways. No military forces can deal with those real risks to our security. They are the real problems which the international community should be addressing together and cooperatively. They could do that if we were transfer-funding from militarisation towards ensuring that humanity has a future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement under discussion today is the ministerial statement by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, entitled Defence into the Twenty First Century. I am concerned that we are not proceeding very far into the twenty-first century with the detail that has been presented to us this afternoon. In fact, I believe that the assessment that has been given by the Minister is really only very short term and will require substantial revision and review, if not within the term of this Parliament, then certainly after the change of government at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned to have to follow a speaker such as Senator Vallentine on this issue. With her motivations and reasons for commenting on defence, one would think that the only priorities and preferences in northern Australia would be that it should be developed for greenies, green ants and green slime rather than looking after the major issues that must address the proper protection of northern Australia, and at the same time look at the strategic and proper interests of Australia as a whole.

The ministerial statement and accompanying documents that have been distributed this afternoon are very bare bones. They do not go into sufficient detail in so many areas that are necessary. The fact that the Government has not had the courage to develop a proper White Paper which would have addressed most of the issues must be one of concern. I am also concerned from discussions with friends I have in various military bases throughout Australia that the Government has not yet concluded the review process that it put in place several months ago. In fact, the major statement by the Minister today is a very ad hoc statement that has picked up some of the Russell Hill work and obviously some of the political budgetary priorities that the Government has had to address.

There is concern with regard to the cutting of regular Defence Force personnel numbers in combat areas and a range of other issues that my colleagues Senator Durack, Senator Newman and Senator MacGibbon have already outlined in this afternoon's debate. I would, however, comment on the move of more regular army units to northern Australia. It is pleasing to note that there will be changes in advancing this area. The Second Cavalry Regiment will move to Darwin in 1993, and along with this the Government has committed the movement north of an armoured regiment with one regular tank squadron and a composite aviation-infantry battalion by the end of the decade. The regular tank squadron in Darwin will be able to be reinforced by the reserve tank squadron which will remain at Puckapunyal.

Along with the move of 330 personnel plus dependants in the Second Cavalry Regiment, there will possibly be the movement of the 5/7 Battalion whose strength at the end of April 1991 was in the order of 468 personnel, plus their dependants. This population increase to the Northern Territory will be welcomed, and in particular to the community of Darwin, because of the economic impacts, and the very welcome and special social relationships that have built up between the civilian and defence personnel throughout northern Australia.

As many in the Senate will know, I have been an advocate for the northern move of the Australian Defence Force both in my terms in the House of Representatives when the initial decisions on the Tindal Royal Australian Air Force base were taken by the then Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, and more recently here in the Senate since 1987. The isolation, unique society and relations with our northern neighbours play an important role for people living in northern Australia and their perceptions and concerns as to the threat from the north and so many other associated issues.

Many of my constituents when moving to the Northern Territory become increasingly aware just how close our proximity is to Asia and the volatile trouble spots of Cambodia, Burma, Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea. This was brought home to me this week when attending, along with Senator Collins, the North Australian Development Conference in Cairns, where the focus of the conference was on the proximity and special arrangements that we must have in place with Asia. The isolation of northern Australia and the threat from the north are brought home to anyone who takes the time to read Douglas Lockwood's account in the book Australia's Pearl Harbour. Let me quote:
Destruction came to Darwin mid-morning on February 19, 1942, when war in the Pacific was but ten weeks old.
Destruction came while the sun shone, with a gentle breeze smudging a few white caps on blue waves rolling in from Beagle Gulf and the Clarence Strait.

Destruction by an enemy was brought that day for the first time to Australian soil. It came violently though not unexpectedly, with bombs and bullets and cannon shells scything through life as they splintered a fleet and a town and almost a human spirit.

Destruction and terror were such as to lead to a panic of people. Hundreds fled. They left half-smoked cigarettes, half-finished drinks, unopened mail, unmade beds, incomplete jobs, open doors and caged pets.

They walked and they ran. They rode on bicycles and they rode in cars, in garbage trucks, ice cream carts, sanitary carts and road graders. Women and children, the aged, infirm and those able-bodied men who could escape detection rode in an evacuee train of cattle trucks and flattops that left them exposed to the tropical heat.

The men who fled were not all civilians. Among them were many subject to a military discipline that was in tatters. Those who did not flee included nearly 250 men and women, Australian, British and American, black and white, near-black and near-white, whose bodies were at the bottom of the harbour, or soaking in oil-drenched mud on the beaches, or lying shattered in inadequate shelters.

Darwin that day became Australia's Pearl Harbour, centre of debacle in the tragedy of war without equal on Australian soil. Appropriately to the analogy, the Japanese task force which wrought this havoc was part of the same force, with identical leaders, which started the Pacific war.

I remind the Senate that the fiftieth anniversary of the bombing of Darwin will be on 19 February next year. That important event will be recognised by many civilian families and many service-related people throughout Australia. The account that I have just read describes just one of the 60 bombing raids on Darwin that occurred during World War II. I have used this quotation on a few occasions as it vividly describes the need for Australia to protect our northern coast.
I was therefore very disappointed to read the speech given by the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, to the Melbourne Press Club on 22 May 1991-just a week ago-when he said:

The north of Australia is the only place we can be attacked with air cover and no-one will attack without air cover, and it's an extremely inhospitable and difficult place in which to attack. Your first problem if you landed five divisions in the north of Australia and went a thousand miles is half your equipment would be down, you've extended your logistic and supply lines by a thousand miles and with all due respect to people of the north of Australia, I'm not advocating a Brisbane line incidentally, you really achieve nothing in strategic aims.

There seems to be some dichotomy of opinion between what Senator Ray was saying a week ago and the initiatives and moves announced this afternoon. I might add that over 2,000 miles separates Darwin from the major cities in the south, and that Jakarta in Indonesia is closer than most of these. Half of this continent is 1,000 miles south of the north coastline. I am sure that many will agree with me when I say that is not just the way in which we should be defending our northern shores which is important.

The north of Australia has for some time provided a major proportion of Australia's overall economic wealth. In return, the north traditionally has not had the same amount of revenue spent in the region, especially when the population centres remain on the southern and eastern seaboards of Australia. The numbers moving north are an encouragement in that the Government is at last looking to the north as an important area and an important initiative. We need always to be aware that moving large numbers of people by any forced change in their social environment and natural habitat will produce sociological and many other costs, not only to individual families but to governments, and I believe that there needs to be a much greater emphasis in the cooperation between the Australian defence forces and, therefore, the Commonwealth Government and the governments of Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australia. It is important that these changes are totally integrated within the social system, but I do not get the impression from the statements made today that sufficient priority has been given in this area.

I turn to some of the answers I received during the recent 1990-91 Senate Estimates Committee hearing from the Department of Defence. I refer to the completion dates for housing works of the Second Cavalry Regiment. I note that the original scheduled project completion date was September 1992 and that that has now been extended until December 1992. I certainly hope that there will be no further slippage to the construction program as this infrastructure will be necessary to accommodate the personnel and their families in 1993.

It is of concern to me that the figures in this statement by the Minister, and some of the associated documents, do not stack up. As the Australian economy dips further into the Labor Government's induced recession, we need to be sure that we are not just being given pious promises and convenient words that seek to change a defence statement without the backup and commitment particularly in those areas of finances. As I said earlier, I am pleased with the Government's proposal for troop movements and the emphasis to the north, and I am sure that my constituency in the Northern Territory will welcome this particular move, fraught with many problems.

I hope that the Minister will address those issues that are much more national in their perspective and that the other areas highlighted by Senator Durack and other senators will be addressed. I look forward to what I am sure will be many continuing debates on this topic in the near future, not in the twenty-first century for which Senator Ray seems to think he has cast the die.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cook, I present the Government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare on Intensive Livestock Production. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE
SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ANIMAL WELFARE
ON INTENSIVE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION
PREAMBLE

1. The Report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on Intensive Livestock Production, tabled on 21 August 1990, has been considered by the Government. This report is the sixth by the Committee and addresses questions of husbandry practices and housing standards which have caused concern and debate within the community in recent years. The Government is now in a position to respond to the report.

2. The Report contains forty one (41) recommendations. The Committee's recommendations form the basis for improvement in welfare aspects of the relevant industries and generally take account of the interests of animal welfarists and producers.

3. The Commonwealth Government will move quickly to implement those recommendations which it supports and which fall within its responsibilities. However, the matters considered by the Committee in this Report relate primarily to areas which are outside the control of the Commonwealth Government, which has brought these recommendations to the attention of State and Territory Ministers through the Australian Agriculture Council. While recognising that responsibility for deciding whether or not to implement these recommendations rests primarily with the industries and the State and Territory Governments concerned, the Commonwealth Government urges that a nationally consistent approach be adopted.

4. The Australian Agricultural Council provides a mechanism for monitoring the implementation of the Report at a national level and achieving as consistent an approach as possible. The Standing Committee on Agriculture reports to the Council. There is a Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare which reports to the Animal Health Committee of the Standing Committee on Agriculture. This Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare (SCAW) develops and reviews Model Codes of Practice for animal welfare.

5. The Senate Committee has generally supported the need to examine alternative or modified housing systems for intensive industries and the Government believes that these should be adopted as soon as evidence of their welfare advantages can be confirmed under Australian conditions. The report itself makes recommendations for further research and review on improving the welfare of pigs and poultry. I will be requesting the Chairpersons of the Pig Research and Development Corporation, the Egg Industry Research and Development Council and the Chicken Meat Research and Development Council to ensure that the required research is carried out. This research will be a vital underpinning of the development and review of Codes of Practice by SCAW.

6. Funding of the Commonwealth rural industry research and development bodies is from industry levies matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government up to 0.5% of the gross value of production of the relevant industry. Therefore, the greater the industry funding, the greater is the Commonwealth matching of research and development expenditure. It is to be hoped that the relevant industries will see the benefits of welfare research under Australian conditions and raise their contributions accordingly, unless the additional research can be accommodated from reserves or a reordering of research priorities. While the Government does not determine which individual projects are funded I would expect the annual operational plans and five year research and development plans, to be submitted by these research and development bodies for my approval, to include an appropriate level of research devoted to the welfare of the animals on which the industry is based.

7. It must also be recognised that these Commonwealth research and development bodies are not the sole research funding organisations and that the States and private sector also have a role and responsibility. Clearly there is a place for a co-ordinated research effort and in this respect the Commonwealth research and development bodies are well positioned to ensure there is an effective network of welfare-related research into intensive animal production.

8. Public attitudes have been instrumental in driving the welfare debate in relation to such matters as intensive livestock production methods. The public also bears some of the cost of change in welfare practices. Part of this cost comes from the involvement of Governments in funding welfare research. Other costs will appear in the market. Some of the Committee's recommendations such as those on poultry housing could be expected to increase the cost of production, and therefore the retail price of eggs. There is little evidence yet of a substantial willingness in the community to pay the extra cost.

9. The Government considers that poultry and pig producer organisations, research and development bodies, State and Territory government extension officers, and educational institutions all have an important role to play in spreading awareness of developments in available housing techniques and in public attitudes. In particular they can prepare producers for changes in production systems made necessary by changing welfare standards. State governments and producer organisations have a particular role in ensuring adherence to Codes of Practice.

10. An aspect of the Report which has caused some confusion is a lack of distinction between types of laying cages. The Government's response is based on the understanding that the term ``laying cage'' refers to the conventional laying cages, rather than to modified cages incorporating design features such as perches, nesting or dusting boxes or get-away areas.

11. Chapters eight (8) and thirteen (13) of the Report address the welfare problems encountered during the transport of poultry and pigs. The Government notes that the Senate Select Committee is conducting inquiries into the transport of livestock and expects that these issues will be given further consideration in that forum.

12. Chapter fourteen (14) of the Report focuses on the need for improved stockmanship as a means of improving the welfare of intensively produced animals. The Government notes that research has shown that poor stockmanship can lead to animals experiencing chronic stress and the possibility of negative effects on production. It is recognised that the way in which stock are handled, not just their physical environment, is crucial to their well-being. The importance of a comfortable working environment for stockpeople is also recognised as important in achieving effective stockmanship.

13. The Government notes the Senate Select Committee's commendation for establishing the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare (NCCAW) and the hope that it will continue to be enabled to perform its functions effectively.
14. I am now in a position to provide the Government's response to each of the Senate Select Committee's individual recommendations.
INTRODUCTION
RECOMMENDATION

1. The Committee recommends that research funding bodies ensure that all intensive livestock production studies and specific animal welfare related research methodologies take an integrated approach to problems addressed so that findings contain elements of matters relating to housing environment, animal reaction to it, specific management issues, and animal/human interaction.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Government will approach the Pig Research and Development Corporation (PRDC), the Egg Industry Research and Development Council (EIRDC) and the Chicken Meat Research and Development Council (CMRDC) regarding implementation of this recommendation.
THE DOMESTIC FOWL
RECOMMENDATION
2. The Committee recommends that as an initial step the maximum stocking density for cages with three or more birds be reduced from 52 kilograms per square metre to 46 kilograms per square metre.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government supports the principle of decreasing the stocking density for poultry housed in laying cages and notes that the stocking density recommended has been incorporated in the revised Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Poultry which has been reviewed by SCAW, under the auspices of the Australian Agricultural Council. At the same time the Government recognises that further research and review of existing information is required. The Government will request the EIRDC to assess the available research, identify any further work required and arrange for the required research to be carried out under Australian conditions. The Government will also request SCAW to review stocking densities in the context of its commitment to review the model code of practice regularly to take account of advances in knowledge.
RECOMMENDATION

3. The Committee favours a shift away from the current practice of calculating floor space per hen by kilogram of live-weight per unit of floor area and recommends that in future, the space allowance for hens be expressed in terms of square centimetres of floor area per bird.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Not supported.
The Government believes that recommended stocking densities could not be completely adequately expressed in terms of floor area per bird alone nor in terms of live-weight per unit floor area alone.

The former (floor area per bird) does not allow for the differing space requirements of birds of different breeds and ages and therefore size. The latter (live-weight per unit floor area) must be adjusted to make allowance for the number of birds involved (more birds per cage will require comparatively less space because they ``pack'' more efficiently, a fact being taken into account in the revision of the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Poultry). Ideally it should also be adjusted for the fact that a bird which is a good deal lighter than another will not be proportionally smaller in its linear dimensions, and is likely to require almost as much space for some of its behaviours as the larger bird (its wings may be nearly as long, for example).
The ideal is probably a table of acceptable live-weights per floor area taking into account both the numbers of birds in the cage and the weight of the birds.

The revised Model Code of Practice gives recommended live-weights per area taking into account the number of birds in the cage but not the weight of the birds. The Government will be continuing to liaise with SCAW on this matter.
RECOMMENDATION
4. To give effect to the Committee's objective of addressing the need for further reductions in stocking densities for hens the Committee recommends the following reforms:
(a) that each cage have a minimum area for each bird of:
1000 square centimetres where one hen is kept in a cage;
750 square centimetres where two hens are kept in a cage;
600 square centimetres where three hens are kept in a cage; and
(b) that an early date of effect be introduced for new cages with a phasing-in period to apply for existing systems.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
As noted in relation to Recommendation 2, the Government believes that research will be necessary to refine recommendations for appropriate stocking densities under Australian conditions.
RECOMMENDATION

5. The Committee recommends that the stocking densities for laying hens be regularly reviewed by the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare of the Animal Health Committee within the Australian Agricultural Council.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals-Poultry is currently under revision and SCAW has delayed finalisation of the Code in order to include considerations raised in the Senate Committee report.

Regular review of stocking density is recommended in the Code of Practice, and the Government will encourage SCAW to take into account such factors as the type and weight of birds, new cage designs, results of new research, levels of investment in cages and the economic life of cages.
RECOMMENDATION

6. The Committee recommends that more regular inspections of commercial establishments be undertaken by the appropriate authorities to monitor husbandry practices generally and to ensure that stocking densities do not exceed those specified in the Code of Practice for the domestic fowl.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
This recommendation will be referred to the States and Territories for implementation as considered appropriate.
RECOMMENDATION

7. The Committee, recognising the significant welfare benefits that may derive from the introduction of innovative cage design, recommends that the Commonwealth Government provide tax incentives to encourage farmers to invest in cages incorporating improved design features.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Not supported.

The Government is of the opinion that tax incentives would be unlikely to achieve significant desired results, ie welfare improvements, and is concerned that any such move would result in distorted investment decisions by producers to the detriment of overall farm management.
RECOMMENDATION

8. The Committee recommends that the banning of laying cages be considered when it can be demonstrated that viable alternative systems can be developed suitable to Australian conditions and that these alternative systems have positive welfare advantages.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government would expect that an economically realistic phasing-in period would be allowed should an alternative system be developed which is viable from a technical, economic and welfare viewpoint.
RECOMMENDATION
9. The Committee recommends that a combination of cage and non-cage production systems be continued with market forces dictating the relative market share of the different systems.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government feels that it is desirable that the relative market share be determined in the context of public and producer sectors well informed about the available alternatives. The public should also be able to feel confident that product is described accurately. For example consumers need to have confidence in the legitimacy of eggs marketed as ``free range''.
RECOMMENDATION

10. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government fund a research project in Australia to examine and evaluate alternative housing systems that may be suitable to Australian conditions and that this review:
(a) examine overseas research findings into alternative housing systems;
(b) assess the welfare benefits and any welfare disadvantages of such systems;
(c) evaluate the economic viability of alternative systems; and
(d) consult with poultry producers, State Governments, the veterinary profession and specialist ethnologists, both in the initial and subsequent stages of the project.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government supports the concept of further research on these matters but expects that such projects will be funded from existing sources. This would include the Commonwealth research and development program jointly funded by an egg industry levy on laying chickens and matching Commonwealth contributions. The Government will approach the EIRDC, State and Territory Governments and the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee (AVCC) regarding funding and implementation of this recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION

11. The Committee believes that beak trimming should only be performed by competent operators and recommends that more formal training and supervision be introduced by the poultry industry for beak trimmers so that improved standards of practice may be achieved.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
The Code of Practice states that beak trimming should be carried out by a competent operator.

It is possible that training schemes could be run through the Technical and Further Education system, or in-house schemes could be run by producers themselves. State and Territory Governments, education institutions and producers would be responsible for implementation of this recommendation, as they consider appropriate.

The Government is concerned at the evidence which suggests that the beak trimming practice causes nerve anomalies in the beak stump and possible chronic pain. Accordingly, the Government wishes to see efforts continue to reduce the need for the operation, through the breeding of less aggressive strains for example.
RECOMMENDATION
12. The Committee recommends that only humane methods of induced moulting be utilised and notes, with approval, the preferred method of feeding barley ad libitum.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government encourages further research into humane methods of inducing moulting.
RECOMMENDATION

13. The Committee believes that moulting practices that deprive birds of food or water for excessive periods cannot be justified on welfare grounds and recommends that the starvation method of induced moulting be prohibited.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Government supports the prohibition of deprivation of food and water and notes that this recommendation has been included in the current revision of the Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Poultry by SCAW.
RECOMMENDATION

14. The Committee recommends that the information contained in the Codes of Practice for road transport of livestock be more widely disseminated by government extension services, poultry companies, transport operators and the veterinarian profession.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government notes that the Code of Practice for road and rail transport is currently being revised. Once the new version is prepared copies should be made available and applied as soon as possible. The Government recognises that declining resources in the extension area have made dissemination of codes generally a more difficult process and has been investigating ways of promulgating their contents via the media in particular.
RECOMMENDATION

15. The Committee believes that sufficient resources should be provided to ensure that the provisions of the Code are enforced and recommends that additional manpower resources be provided to each State and Territory Department of Agriculture to ensure compliance with the provisions of the Codes of Practice for road transport of livestock.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
Implementation of this recommendation would be a matter for the individual State and Territory Governments.
BROILER CHICKENS
RECOMMENDATION

16. The Committee recommends that the maximum stocking densities for broilers in sheds be set at a rate consistent with the live-weight of the birds immediately prior to processing to ensure that overcrowding does not occur.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Not supported.

The Government notes that stocking rates will be higher during the growth period and that numbers of birds are regularly thinned at different stages of development to maintain optimum stocking rates. Consequently it would be inappropriate to base stocking rates throughout the growth period on the live-weight immediately before processing. However the Government appreciates the Senate Committee's concern and will ask the CMRDC to evaluate the existing research into optimal pre-processing stocking densities and if necessary arrange for further research.
RECOMMENDATION

17. The Committee recommends that the stocking densities for broiler chickens be regularly reviewed by the Sub-Committee on Animal Welfare of the Animal Health Committee within the Australian Agricultural Council.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals-Poultry is currently under revision. Mechanisms for regular revision are being incorporated in the Code. SCAW has recognised the need for regular revisions of all the Codes of Practice based on developing research.
RECOMMENDATION

18. The Committee believes that all slaughtering practices should ensure a humane death and that as to the methods of slaughter, other than by decapitation, the Committee recommends that in all instances broiler chickens be stunned prior to slaughter in accordance with the guidelines laid down in the Code of Practice for poultry at slaughtering establishments.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government believes, however, that excluding decapitation from the general requirement to stun birds before slaughter may not be warranted as decapitation does not necessarily mean instantaneous loss of consciousness nor absence of trauma. The Government will ask SCAW to consider this question in its current review of the Code of Practice in relation to slaughter.
RECOMMENDATION
19. The Committee recommends that research be conducted into effective means of stunning in an effort to overcome the problems associated with the current methods.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government will refer this recommendation to the CMRDC for action.
PIGS
RECOMMENDATION

20. The Committee recommends that the Pig Research Council actively encourage research to address the cost equation associated with capital costs of pig housing and loss of production with a view to clarifying some welfare stress issues.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
This recommendation will be passed on to the PRDC.
RECOMMENDATION

21. The Committee recommends that the maximum recommended stocking densities for growing and adult pigs in groups be reviewed to take account of the advances in understanding of physiology and behaviour and the welfare consequences of pen space, stocking rates and group sizes.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Code of Practice for the Welfare of the Pig is currently being revised to take into account such advances since the Code was initially produced.
RECOMMENDATION

22. The Committee recommends that future trends in housing the dry sow should be away from individually-confined stall systems and that this be reflected in the Codes of Practice for the welfare of the pig.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government supports the principle of reviewing housing for pigs as further information on the welfare implications of different systems becomes available. The Pig Research and Development Corporation is currently funding research to determine the feasibility of such change. The Government is concerned that research must confirm any net welfare advantages of abandoning individual stall systems. Research suggests that individual systems, properly implemented without overcrowding, can have welfare advantages in reducing aggression and ensuring that each pig receives the appropriate amount of feed for its individual circumstances. There are greater demands in terms of stockmanship in group systems than in individual systems, especially in attending to the health and feeding of individual pigs.
RECOMMENDATION
23. The Committee recommends that the tethering of sows be banned.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

Acceptance and implementation will be a matter for the States and Territories. The Government supports the principle of allowing pigs the maximum opportunity for free movement and behaviour. Problems have been reported with neck tether systems when animals are forced to lie with their heads close together and less dominant animals cannot withdraw as they usually do. However stalls can be designed so that they can withdraw if they wish. Also it is possible to have a system of tether housing in which physical and social contact and range of movement is quite adequate. The advantages of individual attention, already noted above, can also be obtained.
RECOMMENDATION

24. The Committee, noting that sow size has increased over the years, recommends that immediate attention be given to ensure that stall and farrowing crates currently in use do not cause suffering due to cramping.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

Acceptance and implementation will be a matter for the States and Territories. The Government notes in this respect that manufacturers have been producing stalls and crates that reflect the increased size of sows.
RECOMMENDATION
25. The Committee recommends that the Codes of Practice for the pig be revised to ensure stalls and crates reflect the body dimensions of large sows.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals-the Pig is currently being revised by SCAW, and issues such as this will be considered.
RECOMMENDATION

26. On the issue of farrowing crates, noting that piglet mortality due to sow overlay is a major welfare consideration, the Committee recommends the encouragement of some producer pilot systems to test the ability of designs which allow sows more freedom of movement and access to a separate exercise area at least some time each day.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government understands that some such designs are currently being tested in research institutions and some commercial enterprises. Interaction between producers and producer organisations and researchers will help address the substance of this recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION

27. The Committee recommends that governments and the industry encourage the adoption of alternative approaches to accommodating sows through their various stages and the improvement in husbandry skills needed to avoid welfare problems.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
Implementation of this recommendation is largely a matter for State and Territory governments, and possibly producer organisations.
RECOMMENDATION
28. The Committee questions the management practice of birth induction and recommends that the welfare implications of prostaglandin use be investigated.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government will encourage research into the welfare implications of the use of prostaglandin through the PRDC.

The Government recognises that there may be welfare advantages for both the sow and piglets in using prostaglandin for birth induction, in that this may facilitate the involvement of stockpeople in the farrowing process.
RECOMMENDATION

29. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government fund a research project in Australia to examine and evaluate housing systems that may be suitable to Australian conditions and that this review:
(a) examine overseas research findings into alternative housing systems;
(b) assess the welfare benefits and any welfare disadvantages of such systems;
(c) evaluate the economic viability of alternative systems; and
(d) take account of the views of producers, industry service providers, design engineers and specialist ethnologists.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government supports the concept of further research on these matters but expects that such projects will be funded from existing sources. The Government will approach the PRDC as well as the State and Territory Governments and the AVCC regarding funding and implementation of this recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION
30. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government provide tax incentives to encourage producers to upgrade their systems to incorporate improved design features to improve pig welfare.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Not supported.

The Government is of the opinion that tax incentives would be unlikely to achieve significant desired results, ie welfare improvements, and is concerned that any such move would result in distorted investment decisions by producers to the detriment of overall farm management.
RECOMMENDATION

31. The Committee recommends that the appropriate authorities ensure that regular inspections of intensive pig production units be undertaken to monitor husbandry practices generally and to ensure that stocking densities do not exceed those specified in the Code of Practice for the welfare of the pig.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
This recommendation will be referred to the States and Territories for implementation as considered appropriate by the relevant authorities.
RECOMMENDATION

32. The Committee, noting that taildocking involves some pain and stress, recommends that stockpersons are properly trained in the procedure, so that the task is undertaken with dexterity and with as little trauma to the pig as possible.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
State and Territory Governments, education institutions and producers would be responsible for implementation of this recommendation, as they consider appropriate.
RECOMMENDATION

33. The Committee recommends that further research into the causal factors of tailbiting be undertaken as the issue is so closely linked to overall aspects of pig welfare in close confinement production.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
This recommendation will be passed on to the PRDC and to the States and Territories for consideration.
RECOMMENDATION

34. The Committee is surprised at the high susceptibility to infection which apparently occurs in intensive systems and noting the emphasis placed on health benefits of intensive production recommends that further research be conducted into the underlying reasons for infection that necessitates teeth clipping.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
This recommendation will be passed on to the PRDC and to the States and Territories for consideration.
RECOMMENDATION

35. The Committee, noting the importance of a multi-sector approach to strategies to minimise stress, deaths, and decrease yield and quality losses during post-farm handling of pigs, recommends a State and Territory-wide multi-sectoral review of off-farm handling of pigs with a view to upgrading existing codes of practice and disseminating information to service providers, producers, transporters, abattoirs and other interested parties. The review process should take account of the views of animal welfare organisations and specialist ethnologists.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Government is aware that the Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals-the Pig is currently being reviewed by SCAW and will draw this recommendation to the attention of the working group responsible for that review.
RECOMMENDATION

36. The Committee recommends that in addition to ensuring that information is widely disseminated on the proper handling of pigs from farm loading to slaughter, adequate monitoring should also be undertaken to ensure compliance with the provisions of the Codes of Practice associated with the transport and slaughter of livestock.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government notes, however, that ensuring the effective dissemination of and compliance with animal welfare requirements is largely a matter for State and Territory authorities.
THE WAY FORWARD
RECOMMENDATION
37. The Committee recommends:
(a) that the subject of animal behaviour be recognised as an integral component of the curriculum in agricultural and veterinary colleges in Australia, especially as a component of welfare;
(b) the development of certificate training courses for stockpersons in the pig and poultry industries by Technical and Further Education and agricultural college courses;
(c) funding initiatives be developed to support skills training of stockpersons unable to gain access to formal training courses; and
(d) the Pig Industry Research Council, the Chicken Meat Research Council and the Egg Industry Research Council give greater priority to welfare-related stockmanship research.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government will encourage the research councils and corporations to address the issue of welfare-related research on stockmanship.
The States and Territories, and the producers themselves, are primarily responsible for the implementation of educational aspects of this recommendation.
RECOMMENDATION

38. The Committee also recommends that the Codes of Practice be revised to take account of advances in the understanding of the importance of stockmanship in the welfare of animals in intensive systems.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.

The Government is aware that the relationship between stockperson and livestock is vital to welfare and productivity. It will draw the importance of this point to the attention of SCAW, which is currently reviewing the relevant Codes of Practice.
RECOMMENDATION

39. The Committee recommends that to ensure that the Codes of Practice remain relevant there should be continuing revisions as appropriate and major reviews every five years to take account of technological changes in husbandry practices, including advances in the understanding of domestic fowl and pig physiology and behaviour, and to reflect prevailing community attitudes. Codes should include statements on the importance of suitable education and training in maximum welfare in intensive systems. The review process should take account of the views of the industries, industry service providers, consumer and animal welfare organisations, and specialist ethnologists.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported.
The Government understands that SCAW has undertaken to review all the Codes of Practice for the Welfare of Animals on a regular basis.
RECOMMENDATION

40. Noting that each State and Territory Government has the responsibility to implement policies and enact and upgrade existing legislation which it thinks will best enhance animal welfare within its jurisdiction the Committee recommends:
(a) legislation for the prevention of cruelty to animals and other relevant Acts specify that Codes of Practice for the welfare of animals must be followed; and
(b) that State and Territory Governments around Australia develop a complementary legislative and regulatory approach to animal welfare.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.

The Government recognises that there are both positive and negative aspects of including Codes of Practice in legislation and the question is under consideration by the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare. Areas of concern include the possibility of pressure to lower the standards in the Codes to the lowest common denominator; the risk of making standards inflexible; the problem of encouraging compliance with the letter rather than the spirit of the law and the added cost of administration. As noted in the recommendation the issue of legislation and regulation to embody and ensure compliance with Codes of Practice is a matter for State and Territory governments. However the Government would welcome a consistent, standardised approach to animal welfare regulation.
RECOMMENDATION

41. Noting that standards are set for a range of commodities which are released onto the market the Committee recommends that governments with responsibility in this area develop standards for new and modified animal husbandry systems.
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
Supported in principle.
The Government will consult further with the States and Territories with regard to implementation of this recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of this document because it is a response to a report that took a lot of time and effort on behalf of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. The Committee issued this report to the Government in June last year, so it has taken almost one year for the Government to respond to it. However, in reading the Government's response, I believe that it has been worth the wait. If success is rated by how many recommendations are accepted by the Government, it would seem that the Committee has done very well, because 37 out of the 41 recommendations have been accepted, either totally or in principle, by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This report evolved over a number of years. During that time the Committee's membership changed several times, necessitating the retaking of evidence and the re-examination of some of the issues. The basic question the Committee was faced with in this inquiry was whether we should continue to allow intensive production of poultry-the so-called battery production-and internal concentrated housing for pigs. Both issues have aroused considerable hostility and public demonstrations over the years. Additionally, legislation has been passed in some other countries, notably Switzerland and the Netherlands, to phase out or totally ban intensive poultry production and revert to the free range situation. However, despite some obvious visible problems associated with intensive housing for poultry, the Committee found that, in many instances, free range situations were far worse than the intensive system with animals in cages. Scientific evidence actually supported this view.

Therefore, the Committee came out in favour of a continuation of the present situation, with modifications, until, at such time as is viable, less intensive systems can be developed. I note that researchers in Britain now support our view. A recent article headed `Battery cages are ``better for hens'' ' in the British magazine This Week states:

Britain was warned against banning battery cages for chickens at a conference in London last week. Veterinarians and experts from the poultry industry said that alternatives for housing laying hens caused more suffering than the cages.
Further on the article stated that chickens kept in new-style barns or percheries suffer greater hardship than in the battery-type situation.

Rather than outlining what the Government agrees with in the report, I will concentrate on those areas with which it disagrees. For both the pig and poultry industries, it has rejected recommendations to provide tax incentives to encourage producers to upgrade their systems. I am not surprised that it has refused to provide any form of assistance to the rural industry. It would be totally outside the character of this Government to do that, and I accept that it has refused to consider it. However, its rationale that it might provide distorted investment decisions could be applied to any industry where tax incentives are provided. I believe that its argument is weak, but I have to accept that that is the view of the Department.

On stocking densities, we recommended a shift away from the current practice of calculating floor space per hen by kilogram of live weight per unit of floor area. We recommended that in future the space allowance for hens be expressed in square centimetres of floor area per bird. The Government did not accept this recommendation. The Committee adopted that recommendation after much discussion with the industry on a feasible and affordable alternative to the present system. It is not for me to say whether the industry has now changed its mind because of cost considerations or whether the Department came to that view.

Nevertheless, while economic considerations cannot be ignored by the Committee, it is important that welfare considerations take precedence, as with this particular recommendation. In any event, it will cost producers to upgrade their facilities. That is no reason, however, to suggest that producers should not do it. That is why the Committee thought a tax incentive might encourage producers to upgrade facilities faster than they might otherwise have done.

I notice that Mr Acting Deputy President is leaving the chair. I take this opportunity to commend Senator Burns on the job he is doing as Chairman of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. He has at heart the interests of what he is doing on that Committee.

The opinion of the Committee was that much greater use should be made of tax incentives to upgrade facilities faster than might otherwise have occurred. On the question of stocking densities for broiler production, I am not personally convinced that stocking rates at the late stages of production are appropriate.
