To my inexpert eye, some sheds we inspected looked crowded. I would have thought a stocking density based on weight would be an appropriate method of reducing numbers.

I am pleased at least that the Government has asked the Chicken Meat Research and Development Council to look at the situation and that it has also supported our recommendation that the relevant committees within the Australian Agricultural Council examine the question. I note that the annual report of the Agricultural Council that was tabled yesterday also referred to that matter.

As an overview of the report, I believe the relevant industries have accepted the general thrust of the report, although with some criticisms, while some of the more extreme animal activist groups have rejected it outright.

The issue of battery hen versus free-range egg production has raged for some time. It always intrigues me that those who support free-range production never acknowledge that free-range is hardly ideal either. In fact, on an inspection of free-range facilities in Sydney, the hens looked nowhere near as happy as the ones in good housing conditions in their properly constructed cages.

Man's use of animals must and does, of necessity, involve compromise. Animal welfare is the parameter by which we try to determine how best these animals can be utilised. In the pig industry, for example, some recommendations received some acknowledgment from the Government. One recommendation was on the issue of farrowing crates. We said that piglet mortality due to sow overlay is a major welfare consideration.

The Committee recommended the encouragement of some producer pilot systems to test the ability of designs which allow sows more freedom of movement and access to a separate exercise area at least some time each day. It is pleasing to note that the Government actually supported that in principle. The Committee understands that some designs are currently being tested in research institutions and some commercial enterprises.

An interaction between producers and producer organisations and researchers will help address the substance of these recommendations. That is something the Committee has been pushing in all its inquiries for a long time. Interaction is basically about people, research and education coming together for the betterment of animal welfare. We have attempted to do that in this report.

On balance, I believe we have produced an appropriate plan for improved conditions for both the pig and poultry industries. As I have said in this place and elsewhere before, we can make all the rules, we can write all the recommendations and the codes of practice, we can do all that we like, State governments can legislate all that they like, but at the end of the day it comes down to the individual and stockmanship, which is still the most important and paramount issue in any animal industry.

One cannot legislate for good husbandry; one can only educate for good husbandry. One cannot ensure that animals are treated properly by everyone at all times. The reason that we have institutions like the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is to ensure that people do the right thing in different places. All I can hope for is to educate people on what animal welfare encompasses and why it is important.

I should like to thank my staff for the help they have given me in compiling some of the work that we have done on this report. Our staffs do a lot of work at different times in helping us behind the scenes. I pay particular tribute to Sue Carney in my office for the work she has done in helping me in all my work on the animal welfare issues in my role as Deputy Chairman of the Animal Welfare Committee. I commend this report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the report of the Committee on Gungahlin's transport links and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I commend to the Senate as warranting attention the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory relating to the proposed transport system between the new town of Gungahlin and Canberra. I shall not speak in detail. Every report that I have been associated with emanating from this Committee in the 10 years that I have been here has come at a time of year when we have been pressed for time. But I want to refer briefly to some of the matters within it and say why this report is important.

In the next 10 years, a lot of people will be living in Gungahlin. There will be considerable traffic movement between Gungahlin and Canberra. The proposals and expectations are set out in the report. Out of an expected population of 85,000 living in the area, approximately 40,000 will be in paid employment. It is clearly important that they have easy access to Canberra.

The proposals for roads put before us by the National Capital Planning Authority were looked at bearing in mind that Canberra had to be retained as the bush capital, which most people enjoy and want retained, with a transport system that moved people reasonably to and from Gungahlin. The Committee made nine recommendations, some of which with substantial subdivisions. We hope the Government of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will examine those recommendations when it makes its decisions on this matter.

The report sets out the principals used in coming to these recommendations. In addition, chapter five contains summaries and priorities, in which we refer to the need for a public transport system of a high standard. The report also recommends looking into the possibility of a rapid transit system. We also referred to the report that was issued in Canberra recently dealing with the benefit of a rapid transit system, which we hope will be built early enough to attract people to it.

We refer to the use of private cars, the routes which people are likely to want, the impact on north Canberra of there not being an adequate peripheral system and, in particular, to the John Dedman corridor and Monash Drive. We recognise the need for residents in Gungahlin to have access to Canberra via the John Dedman corridor. We rejected, though, the route which would take John Dedman Drive to the east of Black Mountain because of the impact that we believe it would have on the woodland areas on the edge of the city, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and, in particular, the Botanic Gardens. We recommend that it proceed on the other side of Black Mountain, and we have dealt with the two options on that side of the mountain.

As I said, I shall not go through the report in detail. It is a report which is easy to read and which sets out clearly the principles we used in coming to our decision. The report reflects the unanimous view of the Committee. I commend it to those involved with planning in the ACT and those who will be making the decisions as to the future transport needs of Canberra when this part of the city is developed.

We were greatly helped by the work of the secretary of the Committee, Mr Grant Harrison, and the administrative officer, Mrs Marlene Lyons. As they do not work full time with our Committee, they have to balance their other commitments as well. I am pleased that we have been able to produce this report and present it within this time frame.
Debate (on motion by Senator Parer) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works I present the fifty-fourth general report of the Committee and seek leave to move a motion in relation to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Thursday 30 May 1991
Mr President, the Committee's fifty-fourth general report covers the activities of two Public Works Committees during 1990-the 29th Committee and the 30th Committee.

Twelve reports were tabled during the year dealing with a diversity of projects ranging from the over the horizon radar to the refurbishment of the Reserve Bank of Australia in Sydney. The estimated cost of proposals reported on by the Committee was 559 million dollars, down from 1.1 billion dollars in 1989, but that was a record year.
In all, the Committees met on 44 occasions during the year to conduct public hearings, carry out inspections, consider reports and other matters.
The report raises a number of matters of concern to the Committee. The first matter concerns overseas works.

The Committee conducted a public hearing in Canberra into the proposed construction of Australian High Commission and Defence Housing in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. The Committee is concerned that it is precluded by the Public Works Committee Act from travelling overseas to inspect locations and sites of proposed facilities and to have informal discussions with local staff and authorities.
Instead, very often local embassy staff and design and construction personnel are required to travel to Canberra from overseas to appear at the Committee's public hearings.

The Committee suggests that it may be more cost-effective for it to be permitted to travel to countries where new Australian embassy and high commission projects are proposed. Adequate local knowledge is important to the Committee, and very often this cannot be simply gleaned from video productions and written submissions.

Accordingly, the Committee has written to the Minister for Administrative Services requesting that the Act be amended. The second matter concerns what are called urgent works. In May the House of Representatives agreed to exempt the proposed construction of the Australian Pavilion at Expo 92 in Seville, Spain from Committee scrutiny on the grounds of urgency. The motion was made under the provisions of section 18(8) (b) of the Public Works Committee Act. There was apparently uncertainty amongst agencies responsible for planning the proposed work about the applicability of the Public Works Committee Act to this proposal.

Following the exemption of the work the Committee received an assurance from the Minister for Administrative Services that in future situations where doubt exists regarding the applicability of the Act, the Committee would be consulted at the earliest opportunity to ensure that possible parliamentary action is not precluded.

The third matter concerns energy targets and energy audits. The Committee has requested that sponsoring departments and design and construction authorities set achievable energy targets and thereby not design buildings requiring unusually large and unjustifiable amounts of energy for lighting and climate control.
Finally, I would like to make a few remarks about a number of changes in the Committee's membership and secretariat staffing.

The Committee was saddened to learn of the death in January 1990 of a former Secretary, Dick Fenton. Dick Fenton was secretary to the Committee from October 1972 until his retirement in July 1986. During this period he was involved in more than 150 inquiries and attended the Committee at public hearings and private meetings on more than 500 occasions. He served five Chairmen and eight Committees. This, his record of achievement and service to the Parliament, speaks for itself.

During 1990 a number of Members left the Committee. Clarrie Millar, the former Member for Wide Bay retired from Parliament after a long and distinguished career, first as Deputy Speaker and then as Vice-Chairman of the Committee. The Committee notes with pleasure that Clarrie was created a Member in the General Division of the Order of Australia on Australia Day 1991. The award was made for services to Parliament. I would like to think that this to some extent included his service to the Committee.

John Mountford and Senator Glen Sheil retired from Parliament in 1990 and George Gear and Bob Halverson left the Committee upon their elevation to the positions of Government and Opposition whips. Ali made substantial contributions to the work of the Committee and I thank them for it.

Work on the Committee for both Members and staff is demanding. The Public Works Committee has been exceptionally well served by the dedication and professional approach of the secretariat under the leadership of Peter Roberts. Other members of the staff are Patrick Regan and Michael Fetter, Assistant Secretaries, Sally Dunn and Jackie McConnell and Di Singleton, Secretarial Support. I thank them all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Deputy Clerk-A return to order relating to details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation, is tabled pursuant to order of the Senate of 29 November 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I take this opportunity to speak on this unproclaimed legislation dated 29 May 1991. One of the reasons why I would like to speak on this is that it is a symbol and a constant reminder to us-the last time we had something like this was, I think, in the middle of November last year-of the role that the Senate can play and has played in bringing the Executive to heel and to task about its responsibilities. On 27 September 1988, the Senate agreed to the following motion without debate:

That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 25 November 1988, details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, together with a statement of reasons for their non-proclamation and a timetable for their operation.

Honourable senators had become concerned at what seemed to be an increasing tendency for the Parliament to pass legislation with a provision delegating the right to bring such legislation into operation to the Executive without any limitation being imposed on the Executive's powers to delay the implementation of the legislation indefinitely. The order of the Senate, therefore, sought details of all legislation enacted by the Parliament since 1901, the reasons why the legislation had not come into operation and a timetable for its coming into force. The Government complied with that on 24 November 1988.

Honourable senators at the time were quite surprised at what they found. In fact, some 60 Acts, or sections thereof, were unproclaimed at the time the paper was tabled. We have seen quite a significant change since that time. Tonight we have before us 14 A4 pages with not 60, but still a considerable number of, unproclaimed Acts. There have been some changes. Some Acts have been added and some have gone off the list since last November. One innovation in this document that I have noted is that most of the Acts that are listed give a date of royal assent, which is quite useful and I would like to see that continued.

One thing that concerns me is the rather strange comments from various departments about why their Acts have not been proclaimed. There are a number that I would like to raise, but I do not want to hold up the Senate and I will just give one example which seemed to me to be quite gobbledegookish. Regarding the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act 1986, the document states:

The unproclaimed provisions are intended to enable Government nursing homes to be listed in a Gazette notice subject to Parliamentary disallowance rather than in regulations. However, section 139b of the National Health Act, which was to be amended by proclamation of section 22, was subsequently amended by another, separate provision, which rendered section 22 inoperable. A new amendment to section 139b to achieve the original purpose, along with a proposal to repeal the inoperable section 22, is expected to be introduced in the Parliament shortly. If this amendment is passed it will be possible to proclaim the above outstanding provisions of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Act.

People trying to follow that legislation could understandably be a little confused as to why that particular section had not been proclaimed. Even that description leaves me a little confused. It seems to me that there is no clear thinking and planning ahead on the part of the Department, and we end up with that sort of confused statement.

One of the other things that I thought was interesting and is of concern to me is that a couple of departments explained that they were not going to proclaim these Acts because they were out of date or because something else had happened and they would at some time in the future repeal or amend them. It seems to me that it would be very simple for a Minister to organise a short omnibus Bill to tidy up such things. In relation to the Health Legislation Amendment Act 1982 again, page 4 states:
Section 10 and 11 had not been proclaimed at that time and are redundant. It is intended to repeal these provisions as soon as space is made available in the Government's legislation program.
At the beginning of this session, when we did not have any business, we had hours to spare and the Ministers could at least have tidied up the legislation. On the same Act, page 5 states:
It is intended to repeal this provision as soon as space is made available in the Government's legislation program.

There are a couple of other examples where it is said that the legislation will be amended or repealed when the Government has time. I suggest that Ministers co-operate with each other and go through this document and, in an omnibus Bill, tie up the legislation so that we can deal with it very quickly at the beginning of the Budget session. It would be a very easy thing to do. I am sure-because I heard Senator Powell speak on this issue the last time the report came out-that we would be quite cooperative in assisting the Government in doing that.
Another thing that concerned me in the report was that under the heading `Health Legislation Amendment Act 1986-section 5' on page 5, we see:
The Government expects to introduce legislation to amend this and related provisions in such a way that either the amended definition can be proclaimed or the existing provision can be repealed.
I think the Government should get on and do that. I hope it knew whether it was going to amend it or repeal it.

As I was saying, this document is testimony to the work that was done by former senators, particularly Senator Macklin and Senator Puplick who took a particular interest in unproclaimed legislation. Whereas we had 60 Acts that were not proclaimed, we now have a much smaller number and I think it is even a slightly smaller number than we had in November. Honourable senators should diligently look at them, and I recommend that, particularly in areas in which they have an interest, they address those particular ones and, if there is any chance of their bringing in amendments to tidy up that legislation, they could do so quite easily. That would be quite an interesting exercise for a backbencher or a midbencher, like myself. I will probably be doing that and looking at the areas that I could influence. I think this document is a credit and is another example of the role the Senate plays in reviewing and scrutinising legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes amendments to a range of Acts dealing with Commonwealth criminal law. The most significant amendments are:

those which amend the Passports Act 1938 and the Crimes Act 1914 to introduce an effective procedure to ensure that the existing scheme under which the passports of persons charged with, or convicted of, certain serious offences, particularly drug offences, may be surrendered; and

those which amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 to enable information obtained under that Act to be provided to a foreign law enforcement agency to which the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 applies.
I shall briefly discuss each group of amendments proposed in the Bill.

Part 2 contains several amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (AFP Act). The first of these will considerably widen the scope of the witness protection scheme. It is in line with the Government's concern to provide the maximum protection possible to people who are under threat as a consequence of witnessing or being present at an event, or because of their relationship with such witnesses.

The amendment will remove any suggestion that witness protection arrangements apply only to people who have actually witnessed an event and are called to give evidence and not to their families who may be used as tools by the criminal element to orchestrate the witness's silence.

The second amendment will adapt the management initiated retirement scheme to overcome some practical difficulties. It allows compensation to be calculated after appointment where a determination was not validly made at the time of appointment to the AFP. Currently, a determination may only be made on appointment. It will also allow the Commissioner to end a person's appointment before the expiry of his or her term. Previously, the appointment could only be ended by the person who made the original appointment. This could create practical problems as the AFP employs over 3,000 people on terms of appointment from 5 to 10 years. It might therefore happen that the person making the original appointment was unavailable.

Parts 3 and 7 of the Bill amend the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 (The CTR Act) and make related amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. Part 3 of the Bill contains a number of amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988. Many of these are of a minor nature and are intended to assist the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency (the CTRA) in the performance of his functions under the Act and clarify the position of cash dealers in relation to certain matters. For example, subsection 16(1) of the CTR Act requires cash dealers to report to the CTRA those transactions which the cash dealer has reasonable grounds to suspect may be relevant to tax evasion, a Commonwealth offence or the enforcement of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. Subsection 16(5) provides protection against legal proceedings for cash dealers and their employees in relation to any action taken pursuant to section 16.

Concern has been expressed that, unless all the requisite preconditions set out in subsection 16(1) are strictly met, the cash dealer will not be able to claim the benefit of the protection against legal action contained in subsection 16(5). For example if a teller reports a particular transaction in the mistaken belief that it is relevant to tax evasion or to a Commonwealth offence, and after investigation, it is found to be relevant only to a State offence or to have an innocent explanation no action should lie against the teller.

Subsection 16 (5) is expressed as a bar to any proceedings against a cash dealer. This bar would preclude any action, even where the action is based on a report filed before commencement of the amendment and even if a court were to take the view that the existing provision did not bar such action.

Other amendments implement the recommendations of the Group of 7 industrialised nations (G7) Financial Action Task Force on Money-Laundering. Although not a member of the G7, Australia was invited to participate in the task force when it was established in July 1989, because of the comprehensive nature of our anti-money laundering measures. The task force made 40 recommendations on anti-money laundering initiatives which relate to greater vigilance by financial institutions and increased cooperation with law enforcement agencies through initiatives such as suspect transaction reporting and consideration of import/export reporting and significant cash transaction reporting together with law enforcement initiatives such as confiscation of proceeds of crime and mutual assistance at all levels.

Australia meets most of the requirements of the G7 recommendations because of the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and associated changes in the practices and procedures of our financial institutions. There are, however, a number of recommendations which Australia must implement before achieving full compliance with the G7 recommendations. These include prohibiting cash dealers from disclosing the making of suspect transaction reports and permitting the international exchange of information concerning suspicious financial activity subject to appropriate confidentiality undertakings. These matters are addressed in the Bill.

As the Financial Action Task Force now includes participants from the OECD, and most have endorsed the recommendations, there is a growing body of information available internationally which will significantly assist in providing evidence of the true nature and extent of criminal activity in Australia and render both prosecution and confiscation more effective.

The Bill, therefore amends the CTR Act to provide that the Attorney-General is entitled to have access to CTR information for the purpose of transmission to a foreign country to which the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 (``the MA Act'') applies. Where the AttorneyGeneral is given access to CTR information for this purpose, and he is satisfied that the foreign country has given appropriate undertakings as to confidentiality and control of the information, the Attorney-General may communicate that information to the foreign country.

Proposed amendments to the MA Act in Part 7 of the Bill permit regulations to be made, specifying a foreign country as a country to which the MA Act applies for the purpose of obtaining access to CTR information. Where such a country asks for such information the Attorney-General can direct the CTRA to give him access to that information for the purpose of complying with the request.

The Bill also amends the CTR Act to enable the Director of the CTRA to give access to CTR information to a wider range of domestic law enforcement agencies. These are the Independent Commission Against Corruption of NSW and the Criminal Justice Commission of Queensland. The ability to conduct financial investigations is central to the investigation of corruption, and the investigative functions of these bodies will be greatly assisted by access to CTR information.

The Bill contains a provision requiring the Director to provide the Attorney-General with an annual report on the operation of the CTRA. The availability of annual reports will be of particular assistance to parliament when the operations of the CTR Act are reviewed in 1993 in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

The Bill also contains several amendments to clarify the intention underlying the new federal sentencing legislation, which was enacted in the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1989 and came into force on 17 July 1990. The amendments are required to clarify the circumstances in which non-parole periods and recognizance releases should be fixed. It is the intention of the legislation that, where the total federal sentence is less than 3 years and the court wishes the person to be released under supervision, the court can only make an order for the release of the person on recognizance. Where the aggregate sentence is greater than 3 years the intention of the legislation is that the courts be able to make either a recognizance release order or fix a non-parole period. Because there have been doubts expressed about the operation of the relevant sections, namely, sections l9AB, l9AC, l9AD and l9AE, these sections have been repealed and replaced. In addition, the opportunity has been taken to make a small number of minor technical amendments.

Several Parts of the Bill amend provisions of the various Commonwealth Acts dealing with confiscation of assets. The Proceeds of Crime Act was enacted in 1987 and was a major new weapon for law enforcement in Australia. It is encouraging to note the increasing success of the new procedures introduced by the Act. Until 30 June 1990, recoveries and forfeiture under the Proceeds of Crime Act (and the related provisions of the Customs Act) have totalled nearly $7 million. In addition, the net value of property restrained to meet future orders was nearly $47 million as at 30 June 1990.

Since 1987 a number of decisions by courts exercising jurisdiction under the Act have shown that there is a need for minor modification of the Act. This Bill proposes those changes, and also proposes amendment of the corresponding provisions of the Customs Act and the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act. The amendments are all of a minor policy nature and are discussed fully in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to Honourable Senators.

The Bill will make amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to give the A.C.T. Government the same status as the State and Northern Territory Governments and to allow it to participate in the activities of the Inter-Governmental Committee. This is appropriate now that the A.C.T. has responsibility for its own criminal matters.

The participation and co-operation of the A.C.T. in the activities of the NCA is essential to the national focus and scope of the authority's investigations. It is only the issuing of references by State and Territory Governments that provides the NCA with the powers necessary to investigate offences across State/Territory boundaries. The NCA operates as a co-operative national law enforcement agency. The inclusion of the A.C.T. in this process reflects the Territory's status within the Commonwealth.

The A.C.T. is currently drafting its own underpinning legislation and the amendments to the Commonwealth legislation will not commence until the A.C.T. legislation is passed. If, however, the amendments are not proclaimed after 6 months they will be automatically repealed. This is to ensure that important NCA operations in the A.C.T. are not prejudiced by delays in the passage of the A.C.T. law.

As a result of an initiative of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Bill contains amendments to the Crimes Act and Passports Act which are designed to render more effective the existing power of the Minister under the Passports Act 1938 to cancel or refuse to issue a passport to persons charged with, or convicted of, a serious narcotics offence or other prescribed offence against a Commonwealth or Territory law.

Section 7b of the Passports Act already prevents an authorised passport officer from issuing a passport to a person if the officer has reason to believe that the person is, by order of a court or under a condition of parole, recognizance, surety or bail bond, to remain in Australia or to refrain from obtaining an Australian passport. The Act also provides that a passport, whether in the possession of the person to whom it was issued or not, can be cancelled by the Minister.

The proposed amendments empower a court, when imposing bail or recognizance conditions or sentencing a person for such an offence, to order the person to remain in Australia, refrain from applying for an Australian passport, or to surrender any Australian passport. The order may be varied or revoked as the court sees fit. A copy of any order made by the court must be given to the department administering the Passports Act and the registrar must retain any passport surrendered until the order ceases to have effect or the passport is cancelled or expires.

As the proposed scheme was the subject of a reference to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Bill inserts a new section in the Crimes Act designed to complement any state law empowering courts to make orders in relation to passport surrender.

The only change to the Passports Act contained in this Bill is to amend section 7b to provide additional grounds for the refusal of a passport where the requirement to remain in Australia is a condition of release by licence or any similar instrument of early release granted under State or Territory law.

The totality of these relatively minor amendments is in my view a significant strengthening of our legislation to ensure that persons charged with serious offences cannot evade detection and prosecution nor reap the benefits of their illegal activities. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief remarks on this report which was presented in the last session by Senator Aulich. As Senator Tate is in the chamber, my comments will be particularly relevant. I refer to a section in the report which deals with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Education Office (PEO) and the work that this body does. The report goes into some detail about the many programs that the PEO undertakes. From my experience with the PEO and its programs, I am pleased that this report gives very strong endorsement to its work.

SPEECH.PARA: The report draws our attention to the fact that there are many things that can be done to make students and adults more aware of their role as citizens. I believe it is very important that more people understand and know about the Commonwealth Constitution. A number of surveys have been done and it is very worrying to see that only a small proportion of Australians have any knowledge at all of the written Constitution of this country, which has carried us through for over 90 years.

I was very pleased that recently Senator Tate made a speech-it was reported in the newspapers-in which he said that the Commonwealth Constitution had served this country well. I thought that that was a very important statement from Senator Tate. It is certainly a statement which I fully endorse.

In the follow through to this report and any considerations the Government might give to it, I would like to see what we can do to make sure that not only the 100,000 or so students who visit this Parliament House every year but the wider community are made more aware of the Constitution and its importance, and the massive achievement of our constitutional history.

David Smith, the former Secretary to the Governor-General, drew our attention to the fact that there are only five other countries in this world that have a longer continuous constitutional history of democracy than Australia. As there are probably more than 150 countries in the world, that is quite an astonishing achievement. I think that it would be very worth while if the PEO, through its work, was able to bring to community attention the basic facts regarding our Constitution-how it was developed, the work that went into it, and the constitutional achievement of the past 91 years.

I strongly commend this part of the report to the Parliament and to the Government. I hope that, in the months and years to come, more emphasis will be given to informing students about the great constitutional achievement of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now consider the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department.

—As the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), particularly as he is a Tasmanian, would be aware, the appointment of a replacement for Justice Wood, the Family Court judge, will be coming up shortly. Is Justice Wood being replaced and can the Minister give me an assurance that Tasmania will have a replacement for Justice Wood?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Mr Justice Wood has recently delivered his resignation to the Governor-General, effective, as I understand it, from 30 June 1991, but I am not absolutely certain on that point. As a consequence, of course, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has been holding discussions principally with Chief Justice Nicholson of the Family Court of Australia, me and others about the needs of the Family Court in what is called the southern region, which includes the Court's registries in Melbourne, Dandenong, Adelaide, Hobart and Launceston. No firm decision has been made about the replacement of Mr Justice Wood, but I can assure Senator Walters that the most vigorous and sustained entreaties and pleas have been made to the Attorney-General to recognise the need for a judge of the Family Court to be based in Hobart. I believe that that representation has had a sympathetic hearing from the Attorney-General.

—I add my pleas to the Minister's. I think the Minister would be well aware of the problems that we already face and the backlog of cases that has occurred in Tasmania. Even though we may get a presence in Hobart, I believe that we need a replacement for Justice Wood, and I would be very disappointed if that did not occur. The Minister says that the Attorney-General has not yet made a decision on this. Can he tell me when he will know because, as he has already indicated, Justice Wood leaves us very soon? I believe that we should be made aware before his retirement whether he is to be replaced.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the decision will be made in good time to meet the needs of the Family Court of Australia as it operates in Tasmania, particularly in Hobart. Although I cannot give a particular time, I know that the Attorney-General is very well aware of the need for the southern region of the Family Court to be well served and I believe he is sympathetic to the argument that that service could well be provided by a judge based in Hobart. Senator Walters will appreciate, nevertheless, that the process of selection is very delicate. Some discreet inquiries have to be made. That is taking place, and an announcement will be made in good time for the service of the people who need to avail themselves of the jurisdiction of that court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has listed as the first matter that it believes should get some further discussion the security of the Family Court buildings in Adelaide which, as the Minister knows, has been something of a long running saga. As the Minister will no doubt remember, I asked some questions in the Senate Estimates Committee because I was told at the last Estimates Committee, and it was reaffirmed at the recent one, that the Government's current plan is to build a dedicated Federal courts building in Melbourne prior to building one in Adelaide-albeit, as I understand it, that was not originally the case. The questions I asked followed on from what I will now refer to as the first Estimates but which were the real Estimates of 1990, where it was indicated that workload was primarily the basis of the decision. It was not surprising to be told that the decision was made on the basis of workload when one realises that Victoria has more people and therefore there will be greater use of the courts. I wanted more information than that and sought it at the recent Additional Estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The information I received included some select statistics for a number of matters in Melbourne as opposed to Adelaide, particularly for divorces, files opened, ancillary applications, orders sought, first directions hearings, contested issues that were determined and counselling cases. Those statistics did not provide an indication of the number of courts in which those matters were dealt with. If Melbourne has 10,000 matters and Adelaide has 5,000, who cares? If Melbourne has double the number of courts, the workload per court-and per judge for that matter-cannot be assessed to be greater than that of Adelaide. I say this on the preliminary understanding that we all share, including the Minister, that the court buildings in Adelaide are manifestly inadequate. On that basis I ask whether the Department can provide the chamber with some indication that the workload in Melbourne, on a per court and a per judge basis, is greater. My dog could wink `yes' to the notion that there would be more cases heard in Melbourne. That is just a little too simplistic. I wonder whether we can deal with that matter first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officials with me are unable to provide the breakdown that Senator Vanstone requires. They understood the question at Estimates was in terms of volume of work rather than the way in which the honourable senator now wishes to have the matter presented. In order to make a valid judgment as to the different workloads that might be required to be discharged by a number of judges or in a number of courts, we will undertake to provide that information to the honourable senator, but it cannot be provided tonight. It will be provided later.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that Senator Vanstone is particularly concerned about the security arrangements in the present Adelaide court. I have had a bit more work done on that by officials who tell me, as Senator Vanstone perhaps knows from her personal observation, that the aspect of security-of course, the court was acquired in 1976 before security loomed as something of great concern to judges and indeed to the staff in registries and so on-which is of most concern is that circulation paths cannot be segregated, chiefly because all the lifts are grouped together and the public toilets are accessible from the stairwell. I do not know whether Senator Vanstone has noticed that, but it is the case. In most courts the judges cannot get from chambers to the courtroom without passing through public space and the size of the floors does not allow alternative circulation arrangements.

I am advised that if additional floors were provided to the court, some security problems would be eased but there would remain fundamental difficulties. The additional floors have been sought in the new works technical policy submission for the coming Budget. That is as much as I can say as, obviously, decisions have not been made. However, it is the intention of the Department, out of the amount of money that is set aside for certain works to be undertaken, to apply to acquire and fit out extra floors in the currently occupied building. That should ease some of the security concerns. But of course that requires that in the Budget process the particular proposal receives assent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not checked, and will not bother to do so, the Hansard of the recent Additional Estimates. I expect that what the Minister has been told is correct, that I did ask for workload figures. But let me put that in context. The reason offered for Melbourne proceeding above Adelaide was workload. Therefore, when one asks for workload statistics, one assumes one is going to be given relevant ones. If what that means is that every time one asks a question one has to spell it out in the context it needs to be put in, next time I ask for workload statistics-because workload was given to me as the reason Melbourne is proceeding ahead of Adelaide-I will spell out every inch and detail. However, that will take a lot longer in Estimates than the good understanding I believe we have had thus far in the Estimates Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: One could have expected that I was after some useful statistics. Therefore, having some indication of the number of courts and the number of judges, I would not assume for a minute that what the Minister is saying-he can correct me if I am wrong-is that Melbourne is going ahead of Adelaide because there are simply more Family Court cases there. He cannot be saying that. I am sure the decision has not been made in ignorance of the relative workload per court and per judge. Perhaps the Minister will respond to that. I would be interested to hear what the Minister can say as to the reason offered. I understand that the reason offered was workload and that one of the officers mentioned there were additional matters that one might take into account. As I understand it, many factors are taken into account, and last but not least listed is the Commonwealth making some sort of judicial statement. I quote from the reply I was given:
These are major buildings which make a major symbolic statement about the Commonwealth's judicial presence.

So all those elements go into it. The Minister understands, as I do and as anyone who uses the court does, that the buildings are inadequate not only in terms of the security aspect but particularly in terms of the security aspect. What kind of Commonwealth judicial statement does it make for the buildings to be left in that condition and for the lives of judges, litigants, staff and counsel to be put at risk because of that? Presumably, we do not need to go through a recitation here of the problems that Adelaide has had in this respect.

I think the last time I raised this matter with the Minister in this chamber there had been a gentleman who had stabbed his wife or former wife-I am not sure what status she bore at that stage-in one of the public areas, not long after one of the judges had moved out of the public area, I think into the stairwell; but it does not matter where he went. It is a disaster waiting to happen, which is what I told the Minister last time. Nothing has changed. The addition of more space does not necessarily solve the security problem. The essence of my point is that it is not enough to say, `We're going ahead with Melbourne' when Melbourne does not have such security problems. I would have thought that of all the factors the Minister would want to take into account, including whatever symbolic statement he wants to make about the Commonwealth's judicial presence, and the fundamental statement he would want to make about the Commonwealth's judicial presence is that Commonwealth judges will be safe.

As I understand it, there is no allegation that the premises in Melbourne are anywhere near as unsafe for the judges as they are in Adelaide. That would seem to me to be the priority. I do not say that a judge's life is worth more than anyone else's-not at all; everyone's life is worth the same-but if we are going to talk about judicial statements being made on the location of buildings, I would appreciate the Minister's comments on what sort of judicial statement leaves judges in Adelaide at risk so that a dedicated court building can be built in Melbourne ahead of a building in Adelaide for reasons that are really not explained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made it clear that I, along with Senator Vanstone, do not regard one life as being more valuable than another. She is quite right to point to the question of risk. There is no doubt that the threat factor and then, given all the circumstances, the real risk factor are issues which anybody concerned with the security of Family Court judges and personnel-and indeed those appearing in the jurisdiction-would know needs to be taken into proper account. I have indicated that the Commonwealth is very conscious of the matters. No little raising of that consciousness has been undertaken by Senator Vanstone to good effect.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, the fact is that, even without a decision as to the priority of one building over another, the question of the addition of floors to the present building in order to overcome some of the more severe security problems is being looked at in the Budget context. One would hope that that could, if assented to, alleviate a major part of the security concern.

As to the choice between Adelaide and Melbourne for a new court building-which is where I think the expression `symbolic statement' really came from; it really relates to the building of a purpose-built court rather than the renting of premises dating back some years-I do not say, and I do not think the Attorney-General would say, that a statement in Melbourne is more important than a statement in Adelaide. I believe that the decision has not yet been made as to either their relative priority or whether they both go ahead at once, which I know would be an extreme but is a possibility because a decision has not been made, as I am advised by the officers tonight.

I simply say that, as decisions are made as to the status of the new buildings to be erected for the purpose of housing courts exercising the judicial power of the Commonwealth, the matters that Senator Vanstone draws attention to will be taken into account. Security is one issue. The question of the workload, in the way in which Senator Vanstone has asked it to be analysed, as I have indicated, will be taken into account. The answer which is provided will be put together in a way which will be of interest not only to the Attorney but also, I am sure, to Senator Vanstone. I have given Senator Vanstone an undertaking that it will be provided. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the information that he has just given. I did not appreciate that a decision as to the priority between the two had not yet been made; that pleases me. I also wonder whether both buildings will be built together. I wonder whether the Minister could tell me, in a relatively simple form, how far advanced planning for the Adelaide building was.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the legal profession have been very concerned about this not just because of the security matters and the total inadequacy of the court but because, as I understand it, in the past they have been consulted about the adequacy of some of the plans, even to the point of saying, `Look, what about if the public toilets are here, the stairwells are here, the photocopy room is here and the counsel room is here?'. I am not talking about quite narrow and specific detail but, generally, the layout and outline of floors.

When members of the profession are told about the acquisition of a block of land and are asked about the layout of the building and the floors, they naturally think the plans are pretty far down the line. Can the Minister tell me whether the plans for Adelaide are or have been at that level of consultation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that some plans were prepared in anticipation of being taken to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, if the Government decided that that were the proper course to adopt. If a decision were now made to proceed with giving the Adelaide court building a prior program status, quite clearly those plans would have to be dusted off and looked at again. That was a process undertaken in order to enable the Government, if it took a decision, to take the matter before the Public Works Committee as soon as possible. I guess that that process would have to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the expression `dusted off and looked at again' does not mean that that money has been wasted and that something else will simply be done. I hope it means that the ground work has been done in Adelaide.
—It is the same site.

—It is the same site, but I hope that some of that ground work has not been wasted not only in terms of taxpayers' money but also in terms of time to get the building done. In relation to this matter, I wonder whether the Minister has seen the Law Society Bulletin for April this year and the message by the President of the Law Society, Mr Brian Withers. Johnston Withers McCusker-I do not think it is called that any more-or whatever it is now called is not known to be a rabidly conservative firm designed to advance the most conservative or even `Liberal' causes. In his report on the Family Court, the President says that in February he attended the Family Court in the company of two vice-presidents of the society to be entertained by the judges of the court. He says that that was a pleasant occasion; I am pleased for him in that respect. He goes on and says:

SPEECH.PARA: However, what the visit did highlight for us was the very inadequate facilities that are provided to that Court. As we all remember there were plans for a significant Federal Court Building to be built at the corner of King William and Wright Streets. The plans were at an advanced stage prior to the project being cancelled some 18 months ago.
I am sure that Mr Withers would be pleased to know that we would not refer to the project as being cancelled. The Minister might help me in that respect. Mr Withers goes on to say:

The Family Court is a most important jurisdiction. It is a jurisdiction which is subject to constant public scrutiny and which has a high volume of contact with the public. It is a Court of high emotion.
The Minister and I have canvassed these matters before. The article continues as follows:

It is simply intolerable for so grossly inadequate facilities to be provided to such a body and the Law Society will continue to urge the Federal Government to take steps to more appropriately house this important Court.

That cannot be called a partisan remark from the President of the Law Society. I just wonder whether the Minister is aware of this and how seriously he treats the complaints coming not from an Opposition senator whom the Minister might perceive as having, apart from the Court's interest, some other interest in pursuing this matter. I picked Mr Withers as the President of the Law Society, from a firm that has a high reputation and a totally bipartisan approach, shall I say. I wonder what weight the Minister is prepared to put on Mr Withers's remarks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would only give it a little more weight than I have already given to Senator Vanstone's remarks. I never thought that they were offered in a partisan spirit, but because Senator Vanstone had the best interests of the Family Court of Australia and those who come within its jurisdiction at heart, as it is experienced in Adelaide. Nevertheless, I do note the segment in that particular Law Society Bulletin. I had not had it drawn to my attention prior to this evening, but I am sure that it will now become part of the considerations which the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the Expenditure Review Committee and others take into account when deciding on the question of expenditure on this building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is getting on and the Minister has probably told me as much as he can in this respect, but I draw to his attention a paper put out by the Australian Bar Association entitled The Independence of The Judiciary in March 1991. Page 8 quotes an article by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of South Australia entitled `Minimum Standards of Judicial Independence', published in 1984 in the Australian Law Journal in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that control of court buildings and facilities be vested exclusively in the judiciary. The court must have the right to exclusive possession of the building-
which the Adelaide Court does not have-
or part of the building in which it operates-
and it does not even have that-
and must have power to exercise control over ingress and egress, to and from the building or part thereof.
The article goes on to indicate what the judge thinks about the control which should be exercised within that space, and that is not a matter that I want to raise with the Minister tonight.

I do want to raise with him the point that the Chief Justice has said that a court should have control of its buildings or the portions thereof, and remind the Minister that the Family Court of Australia does not have that control. Even if the Minister and I would not be prepared to go as far as the Chief Justice does and say to the judiciary in each court, `Yes, you can have whatever money you like', which I am reasonably sure that neither the Minister nor I would be prepared to do, the point is that the Bar Association raises this in the context of the independence of the judiciary.

The Bar Association's article raises the question of judicial salaries and the premises in which the judiciary is kept. It makes the point that if the judiciary is beholden to a government-has to go kowtowing and scraping to a government-then the question of its independence is very seriously called into risk. That is the whole focus of this paper which the Minister has probably seen.

I want to stress, in case it is misinterpreted by anyone, that I am not saying for a minute that the Government is deliberately keeping the judges in the Family Court in Adelaide in these intolerable conditions as a means of gaining some sort of dependence from them. That would be a ludicrous notion. I am saying that if the conditions are left in an intolerable situation for much longer, the question can be raised about the independence of the judiciary and what it has to do to get itself housed, not in Hotel Inter-Continental or Hyatt Hotel standards, but in adequate buildings. I would be grateful if the Minister could comment on that.

Lastly, I ask whether the Minister's attention been drawn to some remarks made by, I think, Mr Justice Brennan in the recent Family Court matter. The title of it escapes me, but it was the one that was decided during the Additional Estimates hearings, on the use of judicial registrars and the notoriously inadequate supply of funds to the Family Court. I will not go so far as to say that it referred to premises-I am not sure it did-but it referred to the general funding to the Court. I make those two references and invite the Minister to consider how they apply to the Adelaide situation and to respond to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Mr Justice Brennan's comment was made in the course of a particular case. I expect it has been given due weight, given the judicial lips from which it fell. I imagine that it would be part of a more widespread sense of the need to ensure the independence of the judiciary that Mr Justice Brennan has expressed more eloquently and at greater length in certain addresses and speeches which he has delivered.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Vanstone's general point, it is quite true that the independence of the judiciary could be affected by the Executive in various ways. In particular, I think that the security of tenure of judges is recognised in our constitutional arrangements as being the best protection, and the one required by history as being the almost absolutely essential guarantor, of the independence of the judiciary. Other matters, including their salaries and the premises in which they are housed, assume an importance but, to my mind, would not loom as significantly as the question of security of tenure. Nevertheless, I take the point that Senator Vanstone is making.

I think she also acknowledged the need for the Parliament in appropriating moneys, and the Executive in recommending the appropriation of moneys for the Family Court, amongst all other expenditure, to take into account the fact that the moneys are provided by the Australian community at large and cannot be made available simply on request. I am not suggesting that the Chief Justice thinks that they ought to be, any more than Senator Vanstone does, but we are very conscious of the need to make priorities in the allocation of resources, including to buildings to house those who exercise the judicial power of the Commonwealth.

I can give Senator Vanstone the assurance, simply because it has been asked for and not that there is any real need to, that no decision about the allocation of moneys to provide for those premises will be made with any thought in mind of either punishing or, if they are provided, trying to provide some sort of inducement or expression of favour towards a particular area where new premises might be provided. It will be done simply on the basis of the availability of funds in the Budget process.

I think it needs to be said that if judges, who exercise such an important function in our community and exercise a power vested in them by the Constitution very deliberately, are housed in premises which are not able to come up to that symbolic expression which is considered to be important, then every effort has to be made to ensure that that symbolic statement of the importance and the status of the judiciary in our society is made adequately.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably inappropriate for this vicious rumour to have been in the profession for the last couple of years, given the inadequacy of the buildings to house the judges, but there has been a rumour that Adelaide might get another one. Since I am complaining about the inadequacy of the housing, can I attach a question in that respect? Is there any suggestion from the Government that there will be another Family Court judge in Adelaide? Given that the Minister is aware, no doubt, that four of the Family Court judges had to trot down to another court to give evidence of a threat being made against them by someone with experience in bomb disposal-I know nothing about bombs, but I would have a pretty good idea that, if one knows how to take it apart, one probably knows how to put it together-is the reason that we have not got another judge that there is no-one to take the job with the lousy conditions?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the rumour, nor are the officers, so I cannot say whether it is well founded or not. Certainly, the question of the appointment of another judge will be made on the basis of the work that has to be undertaken in the region and would not be influenced by the security considerations, although I imagine that the question of adequate chambers and courts from which to operate would be a factor to be taken into account. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple more questions on other matters. Without being rude, I invite the Minister to be as brief as he can in the answers because I have given an undertaking to finish at a certain time.
—You stop calling quorums and I will finish within the time.
—No. I have given an undertaking of time with quorums cut out. I am not that silly.
—You are that silly.

—That might be sweetie pie's estimate; his day will come. I raise the question of the Australian Securities Commission properly defining those activities which amount to dealing in securities for the purpose of identifying those persons who consequently need to be licensed. I notice in the Hansard that I did not actually ask specifically for an answer. I think that I misunderstood the flow of conversation and was under the impression that I would get more information on that but, when it did not arrive, I checked the Hansard and found that I had not actually asked for the matter to be pursued and reported back on.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am really seeking tonight-I do not believe that the Minister will be able to tell me any more because the Hansard does not give the slightest hint that I would be asking about it-is whether the Minister knows what has happened as a consequence of this reservation being put in. Is someone looking at this matter? I raise it quite seriously. People who give their money to land agents or other bodies to pool into mortgages have lost an enormous amount of money.

It is a bit like unemployment. It does not matter how low the percentage is, the person unemployed is 100 per cent unemployed. In this matter, the person who lost his or her money to one of these people might not have lost it had these people been properly licensed. It is the person's money and it has all been lost. The fact that the person is 0.02 or 0.1 of one per cent of the population is irrelevant; it is all of that person's dough down the drain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information from the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) which attempts to respond in a somewhat fragmented way to Senator Vanstone's question because, as the honourable senator said, there was not enough detail to permit a very clear answer to be put together. Can I say that the Australian Securities Commission is not aware of specific instances of land or stock agents carrying out dealing or investment activities without being appropriately licensed or authorised. However, this is the type of activity which the ASC expects to pick up as part of its scan and complaints program within the overall licensing, compliance and surveillance program.

SPEECH.PARA: This program covers scanning newspapers, including country newspapers and magazines, for advertisements relating to securities investment from unauthorised persons. It will also have a system in place for dealing with personal complaints. Whilst the Commission had not specifically mentioned land agents as targets in its compliance program, Senator Vanstone's comment will be drawn to the attention of regional officers of the Australian Securities Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last, but certainly not least, I wanted to get some further understanding of the cost of transcripts in Federal jurisdictions. As was pointed out at the Estimates Committee hearing, no person in his right mind would expect counsel to remember every word that was said in a two-day matter that was held over for a couple of months, so it is likely that transcripts would be sought.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Minister provided some information, but unfortunately I do not have it with me. I do recall that the Minister has asked for some of it to be just taken as information provided to senators and not publicly dealt with. Actually, as I recall it, whatever the Minister was referring to in that remark I could not find amongst the papers. So perhaps I will get back to the Minister about that later. However, I want to ask this simple question: if I were a counsel in the Family Court acting for someone and I wanted a transcript of the day's proceedings, what would be the cost per page? If the officers can give the answer for another Federal jurisdiction that the Australian Transcript Service provides transcript for, that will do, but what would the cost per page be?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that all Family Court transcripts are treated as transcript-in-confidence and are only sold to court and/or parties involved in the litigation. The Family Court is charged at $9.50 per page and the parties involved at $6.50 per page. That is the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I understand then that, for a day's proceedings involving a couple of hundred pages of transcript, the court will be charged $9.50 per page, or $1,900 for the day, or let us round it up to $2,000 because they are quick talkers? Also, irrespective of the fact that most people earn less than average weekly earnings, it is going to cost the litigant in that matter $1,400 to obtain the transcript.

SPEECH.PARA: One can get a senior junior at the Sydney Bar to do a day's work at the rate of $1,400, and that is the up-front cost to continue with proceedings if one wants to know what one has said in a one-day matter. If it is a two-day matter, it will cost the litigant $2,800 for the benefit of counsel to have a transcript of what happened. This chamber, as the Minister well knows, is conducting an inquiry into the cost of justice. With due respect, we have certain members on the Minister's side of the chamber who think that the cost of justice can be sheeted home very firmly to the fees charged by lawyers. I do not notice any Labor members sheeting home the cost of justice-the enormous cost of running a matter in the Family Court where there might be some delay-to government charges.

I do not mean to pick on the Federal jurisdiction, it is just as bad in the State jurisdictions, but to take the example of 100 pages or 200 pages of transcript a day and a two-day hearing, someone will be paying about $3,000 to the Australian transcript service, or whatever it is called-that crowd. The litigant would be paying $3,000, and in a two-day hearing the court would be paying $4,000, making a total of $7,000. If the other litigant wanted to get a set, they would be paying the same $3,000, so that is a figure of $10,000. Are we honestly at the stage where three parties, all entitled to these things, who have had a two-day hearing with 200 pages of transcript a day-that is a total of 400 pages of transcript-will have to pay $10,000? Is that really where we are at?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The cost of the provision of transcript at the request of a court or a party is, as has been outlined, charged at a per page rate which, given the volume of work transacted in any one day, could lead to the sorts of accumulated costs which Senator Vanstone mentions.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the court itself is concerned, when the decision was made to commercialise the Commonwealth Reporting Service in the provision of this service to various courts, authorities and commissions and so on, certain money was transferred into the budget of those courts, tribunals, authorities and commissions, representing a best guess as to what up until then had been provided as `a free service' by the Commonwealth Reporting Service, so that people would become more aware of the costs in the succeeding years. That has been the case, and Senator Vanstone has highlighted how that has become the case. But the total cost to the Family Court of Australia for the provision of transcripts is about 0.59 per cent, just over half of one per cent, of the total running costs of that court. In terms of the court itself I do not think that it can be regarded as a major factor. Obviously it is a factor, but it is related to the cost of the provision of the service. I agree with Senator Vanstone that that does not help the parties concerned for whom the costs are quite burdensome.

In making the decision to commercialise the Commonwealth Reporting Service, the Cabinet set the target date of 1= July 1993 as being the date on which clients such as the Family Court of Australia would be `untied' so that the Family Court could shop around for a cheaper provision of that particular service. Of course, the Commonwealth Reporting Service is very aware of that and would be entering into contractual arrangements with major clients on a commercial basis in order to undercut any competition that might emerge. But I would agree with Senator Vanstone that the cost per page to clients must be regarded as a burden to them in the conduct of the case. I simply say that it is part of the process of requiring that people pay for the costs of the services provided to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister mentioned the cost of transcript services to the Family Court. I presume he picked the Family Court because that was the information he had. There are other Federal jurisdictions for which I assume the charges are not much different, and if they are I suppose I would want to know why. But I will not worry about that now; I will save that until April of next year. The Minister referred to a total of 0.59 per cent. If I were running BHP, I would be very pleased to increase profit by 0.59 per cent of costs. It sounds small as a figure, but it is still a lot of money that could be applied in some other way.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Minister says that the costs to Family Court judges are not necessarily that high. Perhaps the reason that the 0.59 per cent is down is because Family Court judges are doing what I understand judges in another Federal jurisdiction do. They ring up the litigants and say, `Hey, what about a bootleg copy of the transcript?'. The Minister's own judges cannot afford the Government's fees. I am not saying that judges are doing the wrong thing. I give full credit to them if they are sensible enough to get a copy from someone without paying the Government's exorbitant charges. I hope that the Family Court judges are as smart as these other judges I have heard about and are doing this. I hope that there is a bit of sharing going around because the Government's charges are so outrageous.

My final question to the Minister is: what is the charge per page in the High Court? Is not the charge in the High Court significantly lower because it does not run through the Minister's system? The High Court spotted how hopeless the system was a long time ago and set up its own system. I understand that the charges for transcripts in the High Court are significantly lower. To save my asking another question, perhaps the Minister will give me a nod if his officers agree with what I have said and can give me some assistance in that respect.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the High Court of Australia runs its own system, and that would account for its ability to set a schedule in relation to the cost of provision of transcript, which is different from that which is charged by the Commonwealth Reporting Service to the other tribunals, courts, commissions and authorities that I have mentioned.
—How can the charges be so different?

—I do not know; I think that it is a very good question. It is a matter that the Commonwealth Reporting Service will have to be conscious of. Once it is the case that these various authorities do not have to go to the Commonwealth Reporting Service from 1 July 1993, clearly more competitive entrants into the field will be able to offer a service which will be such that the Commonwealth Reporting Service will be ousted from the field. The marketplace will take control.

—Will the Minister ascertain the costs per page in the High Court of Australia and provide the chamber at some later stage with a comparison of those costs? Will he also provide details of the delay as between the Commonwealth Service and the High Court service? I understand that one can obtain a transcript from the High Court the following day, if not later on the day of hearing, but one has not a hope in hell of getting that from the Minister's other system. If the Minister would be so good as to provide later a comparison between the two systems-which may, for all I know, indicate some good and proper reason why the High Court transcripts are so much cheaper-I will leave the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give an absolute undertaking because of the judicial independence of which Senator Vanstone speaks. I will make a request and see whether the High Court will provide the information.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise with the Minister questions about which I put a reservation into the report. There were several of those, but the one I want particularly to pursue for a couple of minutes tonight is the lease by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) of the Kindersley House premises in Sydney and the subsequent lease of the City Centre. On 7 May I requested by telephone some more information that would have assisted my understanding and hopefully would have lessened the time that it would take me to elucidate the information I need tonight. I have not received it. I might also say that, in the second reading debate on this Bill on 14 May, I canvassed at some length the matters that disturbed me about these leases. Much of what I said there could be proved to be incorrect if some of the assumptions I had to make were not correct. I had to make those assumptions because I had not been given the material for which I had previously asked.
—Whom did you phone?

—Helene Hallahan in the Minister's Department at 4.15 p.m. on 7 May 1990. I subsequently spoke with the Secretary to the Committee and he was going to approach the relevant department-and I am sure that he did-through more formal channels for this information. I sought a copy of the deed of surrender dated 5 December 1989 and a copy of the deed of amendment, as it has been called, dated 20 June 1990. Even if those messages did not reach the Minister, although I am sure they did, I raised these matters in my speech in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also asked for some advice on the minimum amount of a Government contract that must go to tender-up to what amount the Government can award contracts without going to an open and public tender. I also asked whether someone could tell me whether Ozton Pty Ltd was in receivership, liquidation or just having a tough time. If I could get the answers to those questions, that would assist me in asking the rest of the questions that I wish to ask about this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this the reservation that commences, `By reservation, I recommend that matters in the Attorney-General's Department relating to the lease at Kindersley House . . . '?
—Yes, that is the one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess to Senator Macdonald that there has been a complete stuff-up, if I may use that expression, and I apologise to him most sincerely. On 14 May, in response no doubt to the honourable senator's questions, my office received a list of documents about which it was understood in the office-and there is no notification on the papers to indicate otherwise-that this was a copy of the information that had been supplied to the Committee secretariat for transmission to the honourable senator.
