That is what I thought. I am told by my officers that it was their unstated intention that I should approve the transmission of this material to the honourable senator via the Committee secretariat.

SPEECH.PARA: There was certainly no intention on the part of the Department nor of my office to deny the honourable senator a considerable amount of information. For example, attachment A is the information explaining why the decision was made to proceed with a single select tender to complete the fit-out of the City Centre for the AAT. Attachment B is advice as to why the Department made the decision to re-engage Desaro Design Interiors Pty Ltd. Attachment C is the deed of surrender, dated 5 December 1989, between the Commonwealth and Ozton Pty Ltd. Attachment D is the deed of amendment, dated 20 June 1990, between the Commonwealth and Ozton Pty Ltd. Attachment E is the deed of guarantee and indemnity between the Commonwealth and Essington Developments Ltd, dated 20 June 1990. Attachment F is the certificate of exemption, approved on 8 April 1991 by the State Manager, Projects Services, Australian Construction Services. Attachment G is advice on Ozton being in receivership or liquidation. Attachment H is details of shareholders and directors in Ozton Pty Ltd and Desaro Design Interiors Pty Ltd, Desaro Properties Pty Ltd and Desaro Developments Pty Ltd.

There is a great bundle of information there which no doubt is precisely what the honourable senator was seeking. I apologise very sincerely for its not being provided to him in time for this evening's debate. I am not blaming him, but I am only sorry that he did not give my office a call to see what was possibly happening, as some other senators do when confronted with this apparent lack of response. However, I can make it available to him now and I indicate that I am happy to enter into further discussion with him. I think the estimates have to be approved if possible tonight, but I am very happy to enter into discussions with him on the basis of his reading of the documents and to answer any questions that he wants to put tonight in a way which could help provide him with as much information as is possible. So, perhaps at another stage in the Senate proceedings, we could find some means of his expressing his conclusions having read all the documentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I probably should have rung his office. After having asked in effect three times and making what I thought was a fairly telling speech about it all-obviously no-one in his Department thought it was-that would have encouraged him, when the information was not forthcoming, I thought there must have been something to hide, which made me all the more keen to pursue the matter tonight. But obviously that is not the case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will table the documents which were to be transmitted to Senator Macdonald.
—Is it possible for me to get copies of those documents while I am talking so that at least I can browse through them?
—As soon as they have a stamp on them. I am not quite sure what it is, but certain bureaucratic steps have to be taken.

—I will not pursue the matter to the extent that I intended because obviously a lot of the questions that I was going to ask are there. I do not want to take up the time of the Committee on a night like tonight when there are so many other important things happening that we are all very interested in.
—We have to work here.
—We have to work here. We do not want to sit until after 5 a.m. We might have a new Prime Minister by then.
—You might have a new Chairman by then.
—Could the Minister indicate whether there is an upper limit of Government expenditure which can be contracted without going to open public tender?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The decisions are made by officers in the Australian Construction Services on the principle of securing best value for money. Guidelines are issued on the limits within which decisions can be made on the purchase of stores, equipment and one thing or another. There is no definite monetary limit put on the exercise of the judgment of the officers in these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister saying that the Government can spend $100m on a contract and not be required to go to open public tender? As I said in my speech, I do not hold the Burdekin Shire Council up as an example of what the Commonwealth should do, although our tendering process seems to be much better than the Commonwealth when one thinks of the Nashua Australia Pty Ltd deal and others. In Queensland, local authorities are required to go to open public tender over a certain amount, the reason being that it takes away at any time any suspicion or suggestion of corruption, collusion or favouritism.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for going to open public tender where everyone gets a crack at the same set of rules is so that public officials and Ministers cannot be accused of getting some gold bars because they gave contracts to the right place or obtained some better stamps than others as a result of awarding contracts to particular places. That is why I thought in most government instrumentalities there was this absolute necessity that over a certain amount one had to go to open public tender. That is the fair way to choose contractors, is it not? The same set of plans and rules is given to everyone and they are asked, `How much can you do that for?'. In our free enterprise society where competition gives the best result, people cut their margins to the bone to get the job so that we as taxpayers get the best result. Surely, there must be something like that which binds even this Government to follow those sorts of norms.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in something of a difficulty because the decisions in this matter are made in another portfolio, that is, in the Department of Administrative Services. I am advised that the general guidelines issued on whether a matter should be put out to general tender indicate that in this particular instance, prima facie, that should have occurred, except that exemption can be granted by the person delegated to grant such exemptions by the Secretary to the Department. That exemption was granted in this particular case.

—Does the Minister agree that if there were a $100m contract to fit out this particular building or other buildings the Secretary to the Department could say, `You do not have to go to open public tender'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The overriding consideration is to obtain best value for money. That is the key criterion used. If a judgment were made that the best value for money could be obtained without going by that general tender route, then there is capacity to make that decision in the interests of getting best value for money, and that was the case here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister not accept that that really opens the door for suspicion, which is quite unfair, to fall on officers, public officials and even Ministers if contracts can be let without having to go to public tender? I find it incredible that that is the case. I also find it incredible that nobody seems to have worried about it before in this particular instance.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the departmental Secretary thinks that he is getting the best deal. Really, the contract was let by a company whose ability to make the correct deal or to run its finances, to do its financial calculations, has been shown to be sadly lacking because the company is in liquidation, receivership or whatever it is. That company in either receivership or liquidation could not manage its own affairs, but it has this contract with someone that the Commonwealth is now adopting.

I accept the Minister's statement that the under-secretary has looked at it and thought it is the best deal, but how is the under-secretary qualified to say that? I would be suspicious. I would have thought that in a situation such as that the proprietary way to go about doing that would be to say, `Let us go to open public tenders'.

I know, as the Minister would, that in these tough economic times-in the recession that the Government thought we needed-all of these outfitters, these contractors, who deal with these sort of things are really cutting their margins to the bone. There are some steals of deals to be obtained at the moment. I would have thought that the Commonwealth would have been better going to the open market now and saying, `We can possibly do this for a bit less than $3.7m; we might get it for $3m'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a better position now to answer Senator Macdonald both as to the guidelines that are used and as to their application in this particular case. Guidelines issued by the Department of Administrative Services on government purchasing require compliance with the following criteria, irrespective of the monetary amount involved: best value for money and fair and open competition. In addition, finance regulation 44b requires that persons entering into financial commitments should be satisfied after reasonable inquiry that in all the circumstances the Commonwealth could not obtain better value for the expenditure. The need for tenders to be called is assessed against this regulatory background.

SPEECH.PARA: In the particular instance of the proposed fit-out of the City Centre, the authority to go to a select tender situation was exercised by the State Manager of Project Services, Australian Construction Services (ACS). This authority provides for delegated officers to issue a certificate of exemption certifying that it would be impractical or inexpedient to invite public tenders by reason of the urgency with which the works and services are required, the source of the particular works or other circumstances.

Desaro Design Interiors Pty Ltd, the fit-out contractor for Ozton Pty Ltd, was given the opportunity to quote for the completion of the project. Australian Construction Services ensured that Desaro was aware that Australian Construction Services would go to open tender if its price was not competitive. The quote of $2.348m subsequently received was well within range, and there were obvious benefits in contracting with the company familiar with the job. The Department and Australian Construction Services agreed that the seeking of further quotes would be futile, as prices in excess of $2.5m would be expected due to the higher risk incurred by others.

The decision was made on the basis of a judgment that savings in cost and time would result if Desaro was contracted for the work. Given the fact that Desaro was obviously familiar with the work and had been a good performer, it was decided to seek that single select tender from Desaro and the quote, as I say, was well within the range-in fact, $402,000 less than the estimate made by ACS, which was the amount included in the Additional Estimates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that information. I still dispute the judgment, but maybe the people who made it are better qualified than I. However, I do point out that there seems to be little in the way of urgency. The work stopped, as I understand it, on 31 May 1990. It only recommenced on 29 April 1991, some 11 months later. I would have thought that in that time the Commonwealth could have called for tenders and let the open tender market prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: To save me trying to wade through this information while I am on my feet, can the Minister indicate to me whether Ozton is in receivership, liquidation or just having a tough time? Perhaps the Minister can tell me at the same time what legal proceedings have been instituted against Ozton or Essington to recover the money. If I had had this information before I could have answered my own questions. I ask the Minister whether the agreements are with Ozton or Essington.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the first set of questions first. This information is dated, of course, at the time that its transmission to Senator Macdonald's office ought to have occurred, that is, the second week of this month. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The following information is provided in relation to Mr MacDonald's question to the Department as to whether or not Ozton Pty Ltd is in receivership/liquidation.
As at 1 May 1991 there is no evidence of a liquidator having been appointed to either Ozton Pty Ltd or Essington Developments Ltd.
However, an application for the making of a winding up order in relation to Ozton Pty Ltd was made on 2 November 1990.
In relation to Essington Developments Limited, applications for winding up orders were made on 5 October 1990.
It would appear from information provided by the Australian Securities Commission that the winding up applications in respect of both companies are still pending.

Senator Macdonald asked about the contract for the fit-out and I can tell him that it is between the Commonwealth and Desaro for the completion of the work, and that is a building contract. Therefore, of course--

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked who the surrender of lease agreement was with, and it was with Ozton.
—Yes, the surrender of lease agreement was with Ozton.

—I was told in the written response that I did receive that the lease of Kindersley House was with Essington. I do not have a date for it, but the written response gave details of the lease saying that the premises that were occupied by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal were sold to Essington. Essington then became the landlord, I would have thought, and yet the deed of surrender of the lease seems to be with Ozton. Just skimming through this information, the lease suggests that Ozton is the lessor and not Essington. Can the Minister elaborate on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —According to my information, in August 1988 the premises currently occupied by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT)-Kindersley House-were sold to Essington Pty Ltd. That is clear. In October of the same year a request was received to surrender the lease on Kindersley House to allow Essington to redevelop the site. Agreement to this request would see Essington funding and providing an equivalent fit-out at an alternative building of AAT's choice.

SPEECH.PARA: The request from Essington was approved, and in November 1989 a lease was signed for new premises at the City Centre building in Market Street. In December 1989 a deed of surrender of the Kindersley House lease was signed between Ozton, the registered proprietor of Kindersley House and a subsidiary of Essington, and the Commonwealth.

That deed of surrender made provisions for Ozton to meet the fit-out costs at the City Centre building together with any extra rental expenses incurred by the Commonwealth. It also allowed the Commonwealth to cease payment of rental at Kindersley House and commence payment of rental at the new premises. Under the deed, Essington was nominated as guarantor in the event that Ozton could not comply with its part of the agreement. I think that that is the connection between the parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is certainly the information I have been seeking. So Ozton owned Kindersley House--
—The registered proprietor.
—Now I can understand why Ozton signed the deed of surrender. I assume that Ozton also owns the City Centre building and the new lease.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the information as to who is the proprietor or owner of that City Centre building. The agreement with Ozton is as to the fit-out of that building and is not concerned with Ozton as the owner of that building.

—We are not going to get far. It is obvious that the Minister is not briefed on the subject and is being briefed on the run. From the information I have been given, I understood that the new lease was from Ozton or Essington.
—That is not the case.

—The Commonwealth is paying much more rent now than it was, as have I pointed out, and Ozton was going to meet the difference in rent. The Minister says that that has been guaranteed by Essington. I asked the Minister before, but he did not get around to answering it, what legal proceedings have been taken against Ozton. Now that I find out that there is a guarantee, what proceedings have been taken against Essington to recover the almost $4m of taxpayers' money which has gone west because either the Minister's Department or the Department of the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus-and that would not surprise me-has bungled this deal? We had a lease, it was not costing us anything-we were paying cheap rent-and suddenly this deal was put to us whereby we could move over to this more expensive place. We would get $4m worth of fit-out for free, but we ended up paying the $4m, so we did not get anything for free. We are paying the higher rent and we are now also paying for the fit-out. We seem to have lost out all around.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Appeals Tribunal wishes to move from the cramped quarters that it presently occupies to a larger space, which is the simple reason the rent is more expensive. As to the taking of legal action, I am advised that, until expenditure has been incurred and a loss has been suffered, legal proceedings cannot be instituted. In other words, legal proceedings have to be instituted in relation to damage or loss that can actually be pointed to. Once the expenditure is incurred, the legal proceedings can be undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contract has been signed, I assume. The Minister is a much better qualified barrister than I am but, if the agreement has been signed, I would have thought that that was an indication of the amount that we fix the losses by. The Minister might make a comment about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I also put to the Minister the proposition I made in my speech-and hopefully his advisers have considered this-that, when he negotiated the lease for the new premises, he obviously did so on the basis that he was getting a $4m capital fit-out thrown in for free. In normal commercial practice, that would have been added on to the rent and he would have been paying for that, but he would have been paying for it over the term of the lease.

I am saying that the rental that was negotiated would have taken into account that the landlord was providing him with $4m worth of free fit-out. That would seem to be a commercial proposition. Now that we are not getting the $4m free fit-out, now that we are actually paying for that, of course we are overpaying the rent. I would like to know whether we have gone back to renegotiate the higher rental that we are obviously paying because we are supposedly getting $4m worth of free fit-out.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I get this right. I think that they are two separate matters. The lease and the rent are determined by way of a relationship between the Commonwealth and the owner of the City Centre Building, which is quite different from and has nothing to do with the fit-out costs, which are part of the deal to vacate the Kindersley House premises. So in fact those are two different matters which have no relationship if, as I am advised, the owner of the City Centre Building is not Essington or Ozton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I was under the impression that either Essington or Ozton owned the new building and that that was why we have been shifted. What the Minister has said puts a new element and dimension into the matter. I will pursue it further now that I have this material that has at last been supplied. I ask that the Minister provide me with a copy of the old lease and a copy of the new lease so that I can find out who the parties are. That would overcome a lot of this fairly elementary questioning.

SPEECH.PARA: I will conclude now because we are obviously not going to be able to pursue this matter much further until I am able to look at all these things. I particularly note and I will record the Minister's offer to allow me to pursue this matter further. Probably a good time to do this would be at Estimates Committee in a couple of months time. Even if that is not a good time, I have the Minister's undertaking that he will not take the point at next year's Estimates Committee if I pursue this matter then.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — I apologise to Senator Macdonald for the way in which this matter has developed. It has not helped the consideration of this matter in the Committee of the Whole. I will certainly provide such further documentary information as he has requested. Further, I will make available for him-of course, without prejudice to his rights as a senator to come in and do whatever he wishes-all the officials from the Attorney-General's Department who may be able to sit around a table and go through the documents with him and explain their understanding of the situation. I will ask my officers to use their best endeavours to secure the attendance of the officials from the Department of Administrative Services at such a round table meeting so that he can get the most complete understanding of the matter. If he is still dissatisfied with that, he is free to use whatever opportunities arise in the Senate program.
—I thank the Minister. I have nothing further.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further questions on the Estimates for the Attorney-General's Department? That being the case, the Committee will move to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

INTERJECT.PARA: (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a few questions relating to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. At the Estimates Committee hearing the Director indicated that a meeting was to be held shortly with the National President of the Returned Services League and ex-service organisations to discuss a number of matters, including sponsorship assistance. Has that meeting taken place? If so, what was the outcome of the meeting and what follow-up is planned?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the meeting has been held. It is intended that further meetings should be held with the heads of the various national service associations, as they are described, with a view to securing more sponsorship. As I understand it, a constructive meeting was held.
—I thank the Minister. I did ask what the outcome of the meeting was, so I would appreciate more detail.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have indicated, it was the first meeting of what is hoped to be a series. The outcome simply was that it is intended to get together again with a group of people who can assist in the development of programs to go out and secure the sort of sponsorship which was mentioned and examples of which were given at the Estimates Committee.

—I thank the Minister. In an answer to a question taken on notice regarding the Australian War Memorial bookshop, it was stated that the sale of all items through the shop and the sale of the Memorial's own publications through whatever means were all reported together and on a cash accounting basis. Can the Minister explain to me how a mail order service operates on a cash accounting basis? What was meant by that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that a cash accounting basis is precisely that: a method of dealing with the cash as it is paid in relation to the mail order business, which is a simple, normal and quite usual mail order business-it has no special features which would lead to one's description of the payments as they are made as being accounted for on an accrual basis.
—I thank the Minister. Apart from the mail order service, what were the other means referred to in that answer in relation to the selling of publications?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that that refers to the possibility of making sales through arrangements with a publishing house where there is a joint publication. That is a description of one of the means by which revenue is raised from the sale of books and such items as are published through those joint arrangements.

—I thank the Minister. So that simply means joint promotion and joint sales of jointly published works; is that correct? Have I missed something there? Does the reference to the sale of all items through the shop and the sale of the Memorial's own publications through whatever means indicate only one means? They all reported together on a cash accounting basis. So there were the shop sales and joint publications, some of which were done on a mail order basis. Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there were three methods of sale: one was the bookshop, the second was the mail order business, and the third was joint publications. Some of the joint publications might have also been on the mail order list, but I am not sure of that.
—Would the Minister agree that the criteria for hiring a bookshop manager ought to include a knowledge of selling publications through the shop and by the other means referred to above?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would be an element to take into account. Exactly what weight is given to it in relation to other attributes, skills or potential for development of the business, I am unable to say. But it seems to be a sensible criterion to use.
—I thank the Minister. I agree with him. I ask: why, then, was the mail order service dropped-because of the lack of a qualified shop manager?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the person in charge of the mail order service resigned or retired. A process of advertising took place which led to the eventual appointment of another person. But in the meantime a decision was made not to operate the mail order service.

—Am I to take it from that that the position of bookshop manager is an Australian Public Service position that has to go through the normal Public Service hiring and firing arrangements? I assume from the Minister's nodding that that is correct. What, then, does that mean in terms of the delay in that case? There was no permanent qualified shop manager and shop activities slowed down during that period in 1989-90. How long did we wait for a qualified shop manager?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —An exact period has not been given to me, but it is suggested that it could have been in the region of 10 weeks. That was not thought to be an undue period. But, as I have said, I do not have a firm answer.
—Why is it that, despite nearly comparable gross takings with the previous year, in 1989-90 net operating profits fell by more than 67 per cent?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to ask the officers to provide a considered answer to the honourable senator on that. There are obviously many factors to take into account, as well as how we weight them. We will endeavour to provide a reason for the figure which the honourable senator has suggested indicates the turnover-or was it the profitability?-of the shop.
—The net operating profit in 1989-90 fell by more than 67 per cent from the previous year's profit, as I understand it. Can we get an explanation of that? Is that not possible tonight?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is possible tonight but, if the honourable senator is talking about net profitability, that is different from turnover and other matters which could be looked at. But we will try to give Senator Newman a comprehensive picture of the shop's operations.

—I would appreciate that. The answer to another question which was taken on notice gave me the staffing levels for the Memorial. I notice that a staffing level of 2.81 is listed for the public relations section. What sort of activities are undertaken by those staff, and do they have public relations or marketing experience?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that, in trying to project the profile-as it is called these days-of the War Memorial, the institution has employed people with public relations experience, not marketing experience, which enables them to put out press releases and do all of those things which are necessary to keep the Memorial before the public.
—A commercial operations section is also listed. Does that refer only to the bookshop? What other duties do staff in this section undertake?
—I understand it is restricted to the bookshop, Senator.
—Would it be possible for the Minister to take on notice a request to get a section-by-section staff breakdown for the four years prior to that that has already been provided?
—That can be done. I do not know how much work it involves and how long it will take, but we will certainly attempt to provide it, Senator.

—If it is not an unreasonable request; I am not in a position to know. But it does not look like a very big list. I ask why the Memorial does not have a distinct policy document as opposed to guidelines or minutes from a council meeting for its display, restoration and acquisition roles.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the short answer-I recall this being dealt with somewhat, at least, at the Estimates Committee-is that, even though it is an accumulated set of guidelines and so on, this is thought to be sufficient for the operation of the War Memorial. Certainly, they are known to those who require to be guided by them.

—I would have thought that an organisation such as the Memorial would have had them brought together and produced for the benefit of employees. Do all employees involved in restoration, acquisition, display or whatever have a copy of the requisite guidelines produced to them when they start employment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As employees take up duties in a particular area they are made aware of the guidelines and the directions and undertake their task in accordance with those guidelines. They are certainly aware of them in so far as it is required knowledge for them to discharge the responsibilities of the post to which they are appointed.
—I thank the Minister. Can he tell me when the display policy guidelines were last altered and what alterations were made?
—I will have to get the date on which they were last amended and provide the honourable senator with information as to what amendments were considered necessary at that time.
—I particularly want to know for how long the newly approved mission statement has been incorporated into the guidelines.

—As the honourable senator would know, the mission statement is to become a guiding principle of the operations and undertakings and various tasks of the War Memorial in this calender year. Therefore, it will have to be incorporated by a reference in the guidelines as they exist at the moment without that mission statement-in other words, it is an addition to the existing guidelines in relation to the various areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to a question at the Estimates Committee hearing regarding the mission statement, the Director said:

SPEECH.PARA: Everything that we say, everything in all the documents, indeed in this document in relation to program 5, is stated to be to commemorate Australian war dead and to preserve the nations military history. It has been used in all our documents . . .

I have in front of me the first page of a performance management agreement form for the Senior Executive Service (SES). At the top of the form is the Australian War Memorial mission statement. Nowhere is there a reference to the purpose. How can that be reconciled with the Director's comments, which I have quoted?

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment we are not aware of the SES formal document to which the honourable senator is referring. So we are at a bit of a loss to respond.

—The form I am referring to is headed `Staff-in-Confidence'. It has a logo of the War Memorial on the top and is entitled `Performance Management Agreement-Senior Officer Structure'. In smaller print on the statement it says:

SPEECH.PARA: A major criterion in assessment of an Appraisee's performance is how his or her efforts assisted the Memorial to achieve its mission;
Here again there is an explicit reference to the mission as opposed to the purpose. We had this exercise in semantics during the Committee hearing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that what the honourable senator has is a discussion document put out for that very purpose-to generate comment and discussion. It has no formal status and does not represent the type of legal agreement that might be entered into by an SES officer, or for the foundation for a contract of employment of an SES officer.

—I will send the form across to the Minister when I have finished with it. It does not look like a discussion document. It looks like something that is ready to be completed by an appraisee and an appraiser and a document which is in ready use. I would have thought that the piece I just read out seems to indicate that the purpose of the War Memorial has been usurped by the mission statement, despite the earlier assurances of the Director.
—I have nothing further to add.
—I take it from that that the Minister does not choose to answer the question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to be put on the defensive in the Hansard. The honourable senator said that she would send over a document. I have indicated that we do not know the document to which she is referring. If she cares to send it over we will have a look at it and assess whether her indication of its status is correct. After being given an opportunity to look at the document, I am told that it is simply a discussion document.

—It may be pushing the point on the question of words, but words became extremely important-as the Minister will remember from the Committee hearing-as to what was the mission and what was the purpose. One referred to the commemoration of the war dead; one left them out of the documentation. We established at the Estimates Committee hearing that the corporate plan was taken to the Council without the purpose of commemorating the war dead being included. Then we discovered that later on, at the Council, that was included. I ask the Minister: at whose direction was it decided that the purpose should be included; when was it decided; when was it approved; and why was it decided that the purpose should be included given that initially it had not been necessary to include it?
—I am advised that the decision was taken by the Council in November last year.
—On what basis was it included by the Council, although it had not been seen as necessary by the staff of the War Memorial to include it? It was being submitted for approval to the Council.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to recall, as is the officer. I understand that this was all dealt with in our discussions at the Estimates Committee. The purpose was never, in a real sense, deleted. It was always intended to be--
—It wasn't included.

—That may have been in a draft or something; I do not know. The fact is that the Australian War Memorial corporate plan for 1991-94 does have the purpose of mission clearly stated as decided upon by the Council in November last year. That is the key matter.

—I thank the Minister, but I think he is missing the point. In the corporate plan that was submitted in draft form for the approval of the council, which was pretty well ready to go to the printers, as we can see, it was excluded. In addition, I have just passed to the Minister another document designed for working use by Memorial staff which also excluded the purpose. I suggest to the Minister that a tendency has now developed within the War Memorial to exclude the purpose of the War Memorial and substitute for it a lesser mission. That is the cause of my concern and, if you like, my overemphasis, as the Minister might see it, on the words in question. I am not satisfied as to the explanation given about why the corporate plan went to the Council without the purpose included in it and why we have confirmation that yet another document from the War Memorial has been given to the printer without the main purpose, the whole and sole reason for its existence, being included in the statement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that it was never intended that there be any change in the purpose and that what the Council may have had in a document before it was perhaps the bare bones. It was never ever intended that there should be a refusal or an explicit decision to put up to Council, as an expression of the corporate plan, a statement which would merely emphasise the mission and exclude the purpose. I am advised that it has always been the case that the purpose looms very significantly in the understanding of the officers as to the whole function and reason for being of the War Memorial. Senator Newman cannot take any comfort in constructing her argument from the document she has sent over because that does not represent a final formal document. It is a draft that somebody has put together. It does not represent a formal basis for an agreement or a document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the answer. I do not intend to labour the point any further, but I do point out to him that that is two documents which, in the last year, have emanated in draft form from the staff of the War Memorial in which the main sole purpose of the Memorial is excluded.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for assuring the Committee that the purpose of the War Memorial is basic to everything that was undertaken there. I hope that means that in future no such drafts will again eventuate. The document I just sent across to the Minister is one upon which an employee at the Memorial confirms that staff are prepared to base their work in relation to the mission of the Memorial. I hope that we would ask all staff to base their work on the purpose, that any document in future has the purpose and that it is given due prominence and attention. If it has to have the mission as well, so be it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give an undertaking on behalf of the Minister and the War Memorial that that will be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move (Quorum formed) Before I was rudely interrupted, I was saying that, pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to the struggle for power within the Government at a time of economic crisis.

I am seeking the suspension of Standing Orders tonight because of what is occurring in this building at a time of economic crisis. It is important that this chamber tonight has the opportunity to move a motion that will condemn the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for engaging in an acrimonious and destabilising feud over the spoils of office in the midst of a desperate economic crisis induced by the Labor Government's incompetent economic management and calls on the Prime Minister either to immediately sack the Treasurer or to resign himself.

The background to this situation tonight is the appalling economic situation in which this country finds itself. Unemployment is now at 10 per cent; youth unemployment is at 25 per cent, and in some cities it is 33 per cent. Foreign debt is $170 billion, the top of the scale among Western developed nations. Our balance of payments is about $1.4 billion in the red every month. Bankruptcies are at a record level. It is the worst situation since the Great Depression. What is the Government doing in this hour of need? It is squabbling over the question of leadership. One leader is clinging to power and another is desperately lunging for power.

What have we learnt tonight? What has happened tonight? We have found out that in November 1988 Bob Hawke pledged to stand aside after the 1990 election. What did he tell the Australian people after the 1990 election? He said that he would serve the full term. He has misled the Australian people again. Why was the Prime Minister going to stand aside? Why did he give this pledge? He gave the pledge in order that Mr Keating might have his turn as Prime Minister. What is his right to have his turn as Prime Minister? The Prime Minister had to get out early enough to give Paul Keating a chance to settle into the job.

Did they trust each other? No, they needed to call witnesses. Who were the witnesses? They were Bob Hawke's friend, Sir Peter Abeles, and Mr Keating's friend, Mr Kelty. Not one witness was sufficient; each had to call an independent witness to verify the truth of the other. The mates of the Australian Labor Party, in the environment of what has occurred in Western Australia, will stand by each other, no matter what the consequences or the national interest might be.

What went wrong with the plan? After Mr Keating's press gallery dinner late last year when he decided to put the pressure on, Prime Minister Hawke apparently changed his mind. Mr Hawke described it as an act of treachery. He has called it an act of treachery again tonight. All bets were off. No longer would he stand aside for Mr Keating. Despite the fact that the deal had been verified by the mates, Mr Hawke decided that he had grounds to breach it.

We know that the pressure has been put on in recent times. The faction meetings have been taking place. What would have given us a better guide to what was about to happen than the headline in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, `Hawke: nothing to fear but his mate, Rock'. It became relevant today because today Mr Keating has gone to the Prime Minister, reminded him of his deal and said, `It's now my turn, I've got the numbers, you've got to get out'. What happened after that no doubt pleasant discussion? Senator Richardson went to see Bob Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, use the proper forms of address, please.

—Senator Richardson went to see the Prime Minister, reminded the now Prime Minister of his 1988 pledge and suggested that he should honour it. The truth was in the article yesterday-Mr Hawke had nothing to fear but his mate Rock. I ask whether honourable senators remember the Prime Minister's statement in December that followed the meeting at the National Press Club. He put out a joint statement with Mr Keating in which they said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have today had a long and constructive conversation in which Paul conveyed to me that he had intended no offence nor implied any challenge to me in his remarks last Friday night. He apologised for any harm that his remarks might cause.

The important thing, in this moment of national economic crisis, is that this leadership question is settled. Either the Prime Minister has to sack Mr Keating and get rid of him once and for all so that he, as Prime Minister, can concentrate on the job or, alternatively, the Prime Minister has to get out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, Senator Hill has engaged in a rather hysterical display of interest in the internal operations of the Australian Labor Party parliamentary Caucus. He has tried to justify this by saying that the nation is in such a state of economic crisis, and that this ought to be a matter of such concern to this chamber that we suspend the consideration of the Supplementary Estimates in order to indulge in a bit of cheap politicking of the sort that Senator Hill wishes to put forward to the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, if his proposition is to be given any weight, the question really is whether this chamber should be distracted from its duty to the economic well-being of Australia in a way which would enable it to put to one side the consideration of the Additional Estimates. If Senator Hill is correct in saying that the state of the economy is the crucial matter facing all Australians, and is so vital to their well-being, I would have thought that as a consequence he should say that this chamber should, at this moment, be continuing its deliberations on the Additional Estimates.

That is the task on which we are engaged as a parliament which has the duty to scrutinise the expenditure proposed by the Executive Government. That is the primary function of this chamber and, in fact, it is the function which normally is said to be one of the primary reasons for the Senate's existence. I would have thought that if we had a true obligation to the economic well-being of Australia-which seems to be the primary criterion for the assessment of correct and proper political behaviour in this country-we ought to be getting on with the task which is the Senate's primary role at this moment, and that is to consider the Estimates.

At the moment we are only half way through Estimates Committee E deliberations. We should continue with that particular project as the true and proper business of the Senate. I would have thought that it was quite distracting from that proper, primary role of the Senate for Senator Hill to be proposing that we hold some sort of discussion on what he is retailing as the state of certain questions in the parliamentary Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The matter before the Chair is an important one. I ask honourable senators on my left to be silent.

—Mr Deputy President, I think you have hit the nail on the head because what is portrayed as a matter of great importance is no more than a bit of cheap political grandstanding by the Opposition in order to make some capital out of certain rumours that are circulating in Parliament House at the moment. That is not the primary concern of this chamber. The primary concern of the Senate chamber is to do the business which it has been asked to do by the people of Australia, and that is to scrutinise the expenditure which this Executive Government is putting to the Parliament by way of certain appropriations by various departments. That is our primary task. That is what we should be undertaking to do at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. This is the result--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable senators on my left will be quiet.
—This is an exercise in political opportunism which has been- Opposition senators interjecting-
—Order!

—It has been set in train by a personal power play between people in the other place. This motion proposes, as the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) has said, to take the Senate away from the consideration of the Additional Estimates. As a Victorian, I cannot help seeing shades of Jeff Kennett in this exercise. This is not what this chamber should be doing now. There is a very long list of very important legislation before this Parliament, without the passage of which we will all not be doing our proper work. I think it is worth noting that in the long list of legislation which will be delayed--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order on both sides of the chamber!

—In the long list of legislation before us, apart from the Additional Estimates which have yet to be passed, there is a major package of Bills on telecommunications on which the Opposition no doubt will support the Government in any case. There are very important social security Bills before this chamber-again, Bills on which the Opposition will support the Government. The wool industry is dependent on legislation that is yet to come forward. There is taxation legislation. Of course, I can quite understand why the Opposition would want to waste time and not get to the political disclosure legislation, not to mention the Australian Capital Territory which labours under its own political difficulties at the moment and is awaiting legislation from this chamber. We have an enormously long list, we have a long way to go and the last thing we need is hours and hours--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Panizza interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Panizza.

—The last thing we need is this chamber being filled up with political hot air from either side simply, as I say, because there is a personal power play going on between people in the other place. I can quite understand why the Opposition would want to do this. After all, this is a parliament composed of people from political parties. All I am saying is that for the Democrats in this place, at this time, this power play simply does not have, and cannot be expected to have, the same sort of priority that it has for the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: A similar motion to that which Senator Hill wishes to introduce into this place-it may be the same motion for all I know-is, I think, at this moment being debated in the other place, and perhaps it is more appropriate for that to happen there. The Democrats do not believe that it is appropriate for it to happen here.

At this stage it is quite clear that the vote at the end of this motion will not allow a suspension of standing orders. Therefore, the motion that Senator Hill wishes to move will not go ahead. If the Opposition decides to take the rest of the 30 minutes which is available to this chamber, it will be quite clear that it has decided that 30 minutes of head kicking is better than none at all. All that means is that we will all be here for 30 minutes longer than we would otherwise have been, at which point we will all go home and members of the Opposition can please themselves what they do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the next five minutes I wish to put aside the sort of sanctimonious nonsense that we have just heard from the Australian Democrats who would not know an appropriation if they fell over one. I would have thought that they would be interested in the crisis which is in front of this country at the moment. Does anyone doubt for a moment that this country is paralysed by inaction? The Cabinet meeting has just had to be adjourned because no-one can keep an eye on the ball. No-one is interested in the fact that unemployment is at record levels and that several days ago, when the destabilisers talked about Keating's resignation, the dollar fell. No-one gives a damn in this country, apparently, about anything to do with the state of the economy and the state of the nation.
—Senator Alston, it would help if you directed your remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, I thought that I had attempted to do that several times. This country is paralysed by what is going on at the present time. There is obviously no ability, no comprehension and no willingness to confront the real issues. Instead, what we are seeing is a very sordid and grubby display between aspirants who have forfeited any claim to the throne.

SPEECH.PARA: After eight years of government we have seen the record of disaster and the litany of broken promises. The Senate should remember one classical broken promise when Senator Button had the temerity to suggest that perhaps a deal might have been done on the leadership. Do honourable senators remember that and all the vigorous denials that no such thing had ever happened? Now, of course, we have quite the contrary coming out. The truth emerges when desperate men play desperate games.

It is perhaps fitting that Australian Associated Press should have Mr Hawke's political obituary given high priority tonight in proclaiming that undoubtedly Mr Hawke, who tonight becomes the longest serving leader of the longest serving Federal Labor Government in Australian history, will go down in history as the Australian Labor Party's most successful leader. What a disaster to preside over and what a claim to fame!

The most successful leader to take a country to record levels of unemployment. Who says that they are record levels of unemployment? We have been-we had been-told that they have not quite got over 10 per cent, but of course the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tonight is reported as saying that he predicts that the dole queues will reach a record post-war high of 10.75 per cent this year and that the country is facing a $4 billion deficit. Mr Willis, the Minister for Finance, said, `Maybe just under' whereas Mr Keating has been pretending that we will stay in surplus. All this comes from people who aspire to lead the country to even greater disaster and who are not concerned for a moment about the true welfare of the nation.

The nation is driven by people that Senator Hill rightly described from Peter Hartcher's article as `those entirely without honour, those who are not concerned about anything other than deal making and those who would not know what the economic and national interest was all about'. The great tragedy of tonight is that no-one on the other side of this chamber is concerned or interested in anything other than simply the spoils of office. They know the sands are running out but are determined to go for broke. They want to get as much as they can out of the system and whether it costs $130,000 to go overseas or whether it involves having $630 worth of dinner on the taxpayer, they will go for broke.
It is fascinating that Mr Kelty was there as a witness. Where was Warren Anderson? Surely they could have come up with a few more witnesses to vouch for the witnesses?

TALK.START.PARA: —Tom Domican wasn't available.

—Yes, Tom Domican apparently was not available. No doubt what stopped him from attending was that he could not get out on bail. Does anyone have any doubt about the desperation of those who are ignoring the desperation of the country and who are desperate to make the most for themselves? Senator Loosley is over there no doubt priding himself on his great ability to get to the front bench quicker than he had hoped. There are all sorts of deals, all for the wrong reasons and all because of the lack of interest in the true welfare of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very sad day for this country. The very least that ought to happen is that this Senate should try to bring the Government to its senses and get this issue resolved once and for all so that we can simply preside over the dying days of a desperate government. It does not really matter who wins tonight. Labor is the loser. The country is losing and there is only one side of politics that is interested in resurrecting it. I do not think it matters ultimately which one of tonight's prophets without honour prevails.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have the extraordinary spectacle of these boneheads from the Liberal Party and National Party coming into this chamber and talking about leadership-with their track record. With their track record they have come into the Senate tonight to talk about leadership. They are the same people who gave the coalition Johnny Howard; the same people who knocked him off with Andrew Peacock. The coalition had an endless rondo.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: you asked that I refer to people in their proper terms and I ask that you apply it to Senator Faulkner as well.
—I must admit, Senator Hill, that I did not notice it because I was distracted by the noise on my left. I shall take more care.

—This is the group of people that gave the coalition the Mr Andrew Peacock leadership; that organised Andrew Peacock's demise and gave them the Mr John Howard leadership; that had a look at the opinion polls and then gave them the Mr Andrew Peacock leadership again.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The continual interjecting from my left is disgraceful.
—These are the same people who gave Mr Charles Blunt the leadership of the National Party.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Panizza should laugh because it is a real joke. I think we will hear a lot more of Mr Charles Blunt in the not too far distant future. These are the same people that give you Mr superannuation, Jeff Kennett in Victoria.

—On a point of order. I remind you, Mr Deputy President, that this is a suspension of Standing Orders debate and this speaker is supposed to be speaking to urgency. I cannot see what Mr Howard or Mr Peacock has to do with the urgency of tonight.
—I have given wide rein to other speakers. I am sure that Senator Faulkner is developing an argument.

—These are the same people who came into this chamber, as glum as one likes, on Tuesday this week because they got an absolute trouncing at the New South Wales State election. These are the same people who are responsible for the divided leadership of the coalition in New South Wales. These are the same people, in the National Party over there, who at the moment are trying to stave off a leadership challenge to Mr Wal Murray in New South Wales. These are the same people to whom this week Mr Greiner offered his resignation.
—On the same point of order: this has got nothing to do with the question of urgency or otherwise.
—There are two minutes to go. I think he is still developing the argument.

—These are the same people who just saw a Liberal-led coalition in the Australian Capital Territory Assembly fall to pieces this week. These are the same parliamentary performers that gave the coalition the worst deputy leader in the history of Australian politics, Mr Peter Reith. These are the same people who gave the coalition Mr Wilson Tuckey. Yet they have the hide to come in here and argue urgency about the leadership of the Australian Labor Party. They are nothing more than the greatest group of sanctimonious hypocrites that Australian politics has ever seen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Opposition, I would remind you, Mr Deputy President, that this is a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Neither Senator Alston nor the previous speaker addressed that question. It seems to me quite clear that whether this matter is debated tonight or not will make not one jot or one tittle of difference to the outcome of the leadership battle.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

Senator Hill-I rise on a point of order. I seek clarification of a matter of practice, Mr Deputy President. Would you please clarify why the Australian Democrats now get the call, whereas I understand that, according to normal practice, the call would come back to this side of the chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I was explaining, neither of the two previous speakers--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Hill did raise a serious matter with the Chair. I would have thought that the Chair therefore would feel the obligation to respond to it rather than simply pretend that it did not happen. This is a matter that all of us on this side regard as an important issue and an important debate, and we want to play a proper role in it. Therefore, we invite you to indicate the basis on which you gave the Australian Democrats the call when, by force of numbers, it should have been at this end of our side.
—It has nothing to do with force of numbers. The last speaker was on my right; the next speaker will be on my left. The first speaker I noticed was Senator Coulter, and I gave him the call.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I was on my feet before Senator Coulter was on his feet. I rose well before him, and I believe that I should have had the call.
—Senator Coulter.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I was explaining, neither of the previous speakers addressed the question of the urgency of this motion. It is quite clear that what goes on here tonight by way of debate will make not one jot or tittle of difference to the selection of the new leader of the Government. For that reason it is ridiculous to occupy time at 10.30 at night, when there are probably 30 people out there on time and a half or double time, waiting to continue with the Appropriations debate. There is no urgency whatever in this matter; any debate that is held tonight will make no difference to the outcome. It is for that reason that we will therefore not support the suspension of Standing Orders.

—I thank you for giving me the call, Mr Deputy President. There is a reason why this matter is urgent tonight. The Australian Democrats do not seem to understand. They say that there are 30 people out there on time and a half. What they do not appreciate--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I would like your ruling on the question of whether urgency has to be shown. There seems to me to be a confusion on the other side. Given the sort of motion that Senator Hill has put to the chamber with notice, there is no need to demonstrate urgency. Certainly I did not mention it in my response, and I believe that Senator Powell did not do so either. It is not a question of urgency needing to be demonstrated.
—Normally one would point out the matter of urgency in the five-minute speech, but I have been quite liberal in allowing people to speak for five minutes on the particular subject.

—There is one very simple reason. Apart from the devastation that is being foisted on this country by this Government and the fact that, while that devastation is going on, the two would-be leaders are having this destabilising and acrimonious feud, the reason that this is so important is, in the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), `If you can't run your party, you can't run the country'. What is clear, what has been clear over the last couple of months and has become crystal clear today, is that the people on that side cannot run their Party. Therefore, according to their own rules, they cannot run the country. That means that, while they are spending all this time trying to run their Party, they are not running the country. That is why this matter has to be brought to a head. That is why the Prime Minister either has to resign or sack the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to resolve this matter, so that they can get back to trying to do what they should be doing, which is running the country properly.

—There is one reason why this motion is on tonight, and it is very simple. It is to slow down the progress of legislation in this Parliament. The one Bill that those on the other side are frightened of is the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, because that is the Bill that will make them honest. It will finish, for example, Community Polling in New South Wales, the Concerned Citizens in Tasmania and all those cranky organisations--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of this debate has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE E

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has concluded its examination of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It will now proceed to an examination of the estimates of the Department of Community Services and Health.

—The Minister probably knows the Launceston Students Workshop, a group of workers who educate Launceston students into competitive employment training and placement. I do not think they come under the Disability Services Act. As at March 1991 there were 26 students aged 14 to 15 and 35 students aged 16 to 22-there is a large number of very young disabled students who are trained very successfully for full and competitive employment. Can the Minister indicate from where that group should be funded? It fits entirely within the Government's aim of getting the disabled out into full time employment. Because of the age group, I believe that they do not come particularly under the Disability Services Act. Under which legislation does the Department believe that age group should come?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is no threshold age at which the programs are made available for people. As they leave school, at whatever age, and are legally available for training, the relevant departmental program can be made available to them.

—Some of these young people are still at school and present for training for three days per week and do their studies on the two remaining days. It is because they are still students at the various schools in Launceston that they do not, I believe, come under the Disability Services Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The officers do not know the details of this particular service but indicate that it is the case in some States the education departments regard this sort of training as part of the responsibilities which they can undertake on behalf of students who are part time within the education system and part time undertaking the sort of specialist preparation for the competitive workplace that this group is assisting them with. Whether that is the case in Tasmania or whether some sort of scheme could be undertaken by the State Education Department, as occurs in some other States, is a matter for further inquiry.
—Can the Minister tell me whether those in these age groups who leave school and approach such a service will be funded?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot go any further on this particular service. I know that it is a good service and that Mrs Knox does an extraordinarily good job in supervising this scheme. I am afraid I cannot take the matter much further without knowledge of the ability or capacity of the State education department to respond to this particular situation. In some other States, it is regarded as something which the State education authorities can help with.

—Mr Chairman, I put it under the reservation I made-assistance for people with disabilities. In February, 19 clients were placed in competitive employment on full award conditions; so there could be no doubt about the job Mrs Knox does. Unfortunately, the Department does not see her coming within its guidelines. The State department does not give her any assistance. At the moment she is getting temporary assistance, but it needs to be better than that because, as one can well imagine, she needs to plan. I should like some assurance that she will be funded from now on.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Walters knows, it is impossible for me to give that assurance. Certain programs are available from both governments on which there are guidelines and necessary parameters. I hope that there is a program that can serve the organisation, which does such a good job in the Launceston area. But I cannot give an assurance that funding will be made available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the Committee to raise one small issue that will only take a few moments.
—Are you saying you want to raise an issue on which--

—On which I have not put a reservation. I was given an answer at the Estimates Committee which I found satisfactory, but in the interim I have been contacted by a number of services which are still a little concerned and I seek to raise that issue of concern. The Minister has nodded.
—I know the Mini- ster has nodded, but earlier this week I said that I would not give leave for any extraneous matter. You said it would only take a few moments, so let us give it a try.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. In the questions on Estimates I asked about the linkage programs that are currently undertaken in Victoria in the home and community care program and asked whether those current linkage programs that were being funded would be extended for a further 12 months. The answer I received from Ms Murnane was yes, they would be extended. I asked about indexation and the answer was a little equivocal. Ms Murnane said, `Yes, except in Victoria'. The reason for that is that in Victoria the linkage projects, as they are called there, with the exception of two, have not spent up to their approved limits on purchase of service.

SPEECH.PARA: Although they were not given a precise amount for indexation, they were able in effect to take account of increased expenses because they had that extra money. The Victorian department is now suggesting to us that money should be made available to index all linkages projects and we are discussing this with it. But with the exception of two projects that have now reached their approved limits, the situation is that there is money to enable them to take account of increased costs this financial year.

There are two questions that concern me. One is that the projects had not been advised as at the beginning of this week on whether they would be funded for a further 12 months. I actually sent them copies of Hansard to try to allay their fears. I received a copy of one of the letters the Minister sent. I think it was sent to me by the Minister's office. I really could not tell from that letter whether those programs would be funded for a further 12 months or whether they would be indexed. That is why I am expressing a concern. I was told that in the Estimates Committee; it has been confirmed that that is the case. I want to know whether those linkages programs will get their funding and whether it will be indexed.

Those programs mainly involve older people-people with disabilities-being cared for at home, who are in projects and who are feeling very vulnerable. Councils are making decisions about next financial year and their budgets. If they are not assured that they will get their money, then those programs are in jeopardy because the councils will not be able to support them. I would appreciate it if the Department could confirm that and tell me when those councils and linkages programs will be told in writing, in a clear way, that they will receive their funding and indexation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson has raised the continuation of linkage projects at the conclusion of the four-year unmatched program on 30 June 1991. The Commonwealth and all State governments have agreed to extend the linkages projects for 12 months to allow evaluations to play a role in determining the future of this approach to care.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, the Hon. Peter Staples, will confirm ongoing funding for projects in the near future. I cannot say whether that includes an indexation undertaking. I will get an answer to that question and ensure that, when the Hon. Peter Staples confirms the funding for the projects in accordance with the information I have given, the various projects are given very clear information not only as to the ongoing funding, which will be apparent, but also as to whether it is indexed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Minister understands the urgency and importance of it. I ask the Minister to appeal to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services to advise them as soon as possible.

—During the Estimates Committee, I asked some questions on financial support for individual midwives. I was told during the Estimates Committee that the idea of paying midwives $500 for delivery came from a report of the working party on homebirths in Australia. Could the Minister tell me where the reference to payment of midwives came from in that report?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, we do not have a copy of the report with us and officers cannot point to that particular item in the report. I am sorry to take up the time of the Committee but, unfortunately, we do not have the report with us. It is understood that the report made a recommendation as to the way in which a package of money would be made available for the delivery of this alternative birthing service, engaging the skills of midwives, and included in the options open to a State receiving that package of money is the capacity to pay a sum to a midwife. A contribution is made to the State which can be channelled by that State to the midwife as a payment for her services in that particular alternative birthing environment.
—Could the Minister tell me the exact title of the report that he was referring to?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Walters mentioned the name of the report in the first question.

—The reason I asked that question is that I have a copy of the report here and there is certainly no recommendation along those lines. I thought I must have got the wrong report, so I was asking whether the Minister could give me the exact title of the report which made the recommendations that we have been given.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the report to which Senator Walters is referring is that which was mentioned at the first meeting we had of the Estimates Committee. I am not saying that in that report there was a recommendation that midwives be directly paid that sum of money. I understand from the officers this evening that there was a recommendation that States be provided with a sum-or package-of money which could be used to support the alternative birthing centres, including the provision of midwifery assistance, and that the States can choose to make part of that money available to the midwife.
—Is the name of that report Home Births in Australia 1985-1987?
—If it was said in the Estimates Committee that that report recommended that a sum of money be made payable to a midwife--
—It didn't say that in the Committee.
—In that case I ask what the difficulty is. I thought that Senator Walters was saying that that was said in the Committee and she could not find the reference in the report.

—There is obviously some misunderstanding. When I asked where the idea for the decision came from, I was told that that idea came from the Home Births in Australia report. I did not go into the detail of the exact name of the report. I am now asking where that idea came from because the report I have, Home Births in Australia 1985-1987, certainly does not have any recommendation in it for payment of midwives by the Government, and I was wondering where that recommendation came from.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The need for alternative birthing services was identified by the national women's health policy, the Medicare Benefits Review Committee of 1986, the National Health and Medical Research Council working party on homebirths and alternative birthing centres and a number of State-based reviews of maternity and birthing services. Many of these reports involved extensive consultations with consumers and professional groups. After consideration of those reports it was concluded that large numbers of women and many professionals saw alternative birthing services as a matter which should be given some priority.
—The Minister told me a little earlier that the suggestion of a package came from a report. Obviously, he has been given misinformation somewhere along the line.
—I think we were at cross-purposes.

—There was a lot of confusion. Certainly, none of those reports had any recommendation that the Government should set up a package of payments for midwives. I ask where the idea of the package came from.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter obviously has been determined as an appropriate way for the Commonwealth to respond in financial assistance terms to the States, giving the States as much flexibility as possible. In other words, once the decision was made that homebirthing services had a certain priority which should attract Government support the actual mechanism, it appears, was worked out in accordance with consultation with the States rather than being generated by a particular report.

—I thank the Minister. That is what I imagined must have happened because I could not find anything at all in any of the reports that referred to the fact that it would be a good idea for the Government to pay midwives any amount-far less an amount greater than that paid to the general practitioner doing the same delivery. The Minister also said `large numbers of women'. I am not quite sure whether he knows that the number of women who have planned homebirths is 0.5 per cent, according to the report that the Department was referring to.
