I am not quite sure what the figure is-but I am sure the Department could tell me-for women who choose birthing centres around Australia with midwives delivering babies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Birthing centres are being established under this program. It is by no means a complete setting up or establishing of these centres around Australia. I imagine that the numbers of those who have at this stage availed themselves of the service could be obtained through consultation with the States or by receiving reports from the States and that could be undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the support from women for this alternative birthing service is not necessarily measured in the numbers of those who avail themselves of the service or those for whom it is considered to be safe that they avail themselves of this particular alternative birthing service with the assistance of a midwife. There is a larger number of women who would, if they could-if Senator Walters can understand me-or who simply support the availability of this service for other women.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister how he comes to his `would if they could' statistics.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not offer any. I simply note the fact that this service obviously is not simply a matter of the choice of the women concerned. It has to be undertaken as a matter of proper medical judgment that the birth could be conducted safely. Therefore, it is quite impossible to indicate precisely those numbers of women who, having thought of the alternative birthing service, then find that their pregnancies develop in a way that makes that an unsafe or less safe alternative. I cannot put a number on it, but it stands to reason that there must be some.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what I mean. It stands to reason that there must be some. I agree with the Minister entirely that those women who choose to have midwives deliver their babies have every right to seek that type of delivery, but the number is very small. The Minister cannot tell me tonight the number of birthing centres we already have around Australia, and his Department cannot tell me how many women avail themselves of the birthing centres using midwives-some of the birthing centres, of course, are used by women who would prefer the medical practitioner to deliver their babies. I am sure that the numbers to date are very small.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to know whether the Department can tell me here and now how many women in Australia availed themselves last year of midwives to do their delivery. I am sure the Department must know. It has put forward this plan that taxpayers should pay midwives more than the individual person pays a doctor for a delivery. The patient does not pay the midwife. The taxpayers of Australia pay the total amount to the midwife. The patient does not pay anything at all and does not get anything from Medicare. The taxpayers foot the bill. I am quite sure that the Department must know that there is a large cry from women in Australia for this service if that is what it recommends. The Department would know the figures. I ask the Minister to give me the number of women who last year chose to have their deliveries done by midwives?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have those figures available. The point is that it would not matter whether the amount was $200, $300 or $400. The fact is that the Government has determined that this particular alternative birthing service ought to be available to women in Australia. It is prepared to pay an amount to the States to facilitate the provision of such a service. The package of care which the midwife offers over a period of many hours is, we think, such that we ought to help the States by a contribution of $500 per birthing service. The States would then make a decision as to whether they would apply the money directly to a midwife or to a centre which employs midwives or whatever. It is not a payment necessarily direct to a midwife.
—It can be.
—It can be. But basically, it is a payment for the service of delivery in an alternative birthing fashion.
—Or at home.
—Yes. It can include independent midwives operating in a private home or at a birth centre or, as Senator Walters says, an approved home birth setting could qualify.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have in my hand a statement on homebirths put out by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) following the original report which recommends participation in data collection and quality assurance programs which it says should be an integral part of an accreditation process. It is emphasised that homebirth practitioners should notify State peri-natal data collection units of all planned homebirths to allow proper collection of data, accurate recording of peri-natal statistics and publications of data nationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that the Department would think that that was very helpful because then it may have some data to go on when making its recommendations to the Government. At least then, the Government, which has come out with such extraordinary decisions, would have some data. Will midwives be required to facilitate such data collection and quality assurance programs before they are paid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As is noted, the Commonwealth is at present developing an evaluation framework and methodology for an evaluation of the program. It needs to be worked out in detail in consultation with the States, as they will be collecting the information in the first instance. As the States establish their alternative birthing programs, they will also be considering how best to monitor the outcomes in relation to maternal and infant morbidity and mortality. States already maintain extensive maternal and peri-natal statistical collections.

SPEECH.PARA: The NHMRC has recently funded the national peri-natal statistics unit to analyse the statistics from homebirths in Australia for the years 1988 to 1990. This will start in a few weeks time and will carry on from the report on home births in Australia from 1985 to 1987. That is obviously not the full range of statistics to which Senator Walters referred, but I am sure that the States would be undertaking the collection of those statistics from midwives or at least from the alternative birthing service, however it is provided.

As one of the conditions of receiving the payments from the Commonwealth there will be an obligation on the States to keep an adequate record of the morbidity rates, the mortality rates, the peri-natal care and so on that is offered. In that way, the picture that Senator Walters wishes to see built up will be assembled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a few more questions. Could the Minister tell me who was consulted prior to this arrangement being finalised?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned that there was an identification of the need for this particular service under the national women's health policy consultations, the Medicare Benefits Review Committee 1986, the NHMRC working party on homebirths and alternative birthing centres and a number of State-based reviews of maternity and birthing services. It was on the basis of the consultations which have gone into those reports and reliance on those reports that it was concluded that the consultations indicated that this particular alternative birthing service was a matter of proper concern to the Commonwealth which should lead the Government to encourage it in the light of giving of financial support.

—Am I correct when I say-this is how I interpreted what the Minister said-that there were consultations with the National Health and Medical Research Council working group? Was it the case that this information was not just taken from its report, but that consultations went on with that group? That is what the Minister said.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I indicated that the need for alternative birthing services was identified by the national women's health policy, the Medicare Benefits Review Committee, et cetera.

—If the Minister reads Hansard, he will see that just then he said that consultation occurred between these bodies. That is why I particularly asked whether I understood the Minister correctly. I did not think those consultations had occurred. The Minister did say earlier that they used those reports, but when he was asked what consultations went on, he said that consultations went on between them. I query that because I do not believe it did.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that consultation did not take place with the working party on homebirths and alternative birthing centres.
—So there was no consultation with the College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and there was no consultation with the Australian College of Midwives?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Consultation is certainly occurring now, as the honourable senator would expect, but the actual commencement of those consultations in relation to the delivery of this particular program is something on which I do not have immediate information.
—There was no consultation, Minister.

—It appears that there was no direct consultation by the departmental officers with the groups that the honourable senator has mentioned, although they themselves were part of the consultative process undertaken under the aegis of the national women's health policy. In so far as there was indirect consultation in that sense, I suppose one could point to a reliance on the input of those organisations; but one has to say that there was no direct consultation.

—I thank the Minister. So there was no consultation with anyone. Can the Minister tell me whether the midwife gets paid if she does not do the delivery? As the Minister knows, many midwives, when they get into trouble, call in the general practitioner or the obstetrician to do the delivery. If she does not do the delivery, does she get paid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth contribution is for a particular package of services coordinated by a midwife, covering pregnancy, labour and the postnatal period. The maximum contribution is $500 per birth. Under the program, States and Territories are expected to put in place appropriate guidelines and protocols to cover the transfer of the birthing woman to a labour ward or theatre during labour should this be required.

SPEECH.PARA: In most instances, the midwife will still have provided a substantial range of services covering the antinatal and postnatal periods. In some cases, the midwife will also have attended the woman for a considerable period of her labour before it becomes clear that medical intervention is necessary. The payment to the midwife would be a matter for the States to decide and would not necessarily be tied to the level of the Commonwealth contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the midwife, who according to the Commonwealth is entitled to be paid $500 for the care of a woman and the delivery, has to call in a general practitioner to do the delivery for her, she still gets paid, even though the general practitioner is paid less than she is-or she can be paid if the State so desires-because the Commonwealth has made arrangements for that to occur. She will get paid more than the general practitioner is entitled to be paid in recompense under the schedule of fees for his patients. I thank the Minister.
—I do not accept that.
—I am sorry; I thought the Minister said that it was up to the States.
—Let me say what I said.
—Fine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated that a payment was able to be made to the midwife but one would expect, in the protocol and guidelines developed by the State, that it would take into account the amount of prenatal care, attendance during labour to the point where medical intervention was thought to be essential, and perhaps postnatal care provided by the midwife. It is in relation to the provision of those services that a payment could properly be made if the State was operating on the provision of a fee to a midwife, as opposed to employing the midwife in a birthing centre, for example.

—I understood that, and that is why I said that the State could-because the Government has made provision-pay the midwife the full amount. There is nothing in the guidelines that would stop it. The State could still pay her the full $500 whether or not she did the delivery. How does the Department normally assess payments to doctors? How did it assess the schedule fee to a general practitioner for the prenatal, delivery and antinatal care of a woman?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable senator knows, the schedule of fees is compiled with the benefit of very extensive consultation with the profession and, no doubt, other consultants. But I think the construction of the schedule by consultation with various committees, or a committee, is something which has been commented on before and is reasonably well known.
—Can the Minister tell me how the midwife's $500 fee was assessed?

—The $500 is a notional amount which represents the approximate average saving to the Commonwealth in Medicare benefits compared with the cost in benefits if the birth had been managed by a private medical practitioner. These savings would include the benefits paid for the services provided by the supervising medical practitioner and for a range of diagnostic tests. It is not appropriate, therefore, to characterise this funding as a fee for midwives and any comparison of it with the Medicare schedule of fees for obstetric services provided by medical practitioners must take into account all of the factors which contribute to the different cost structures.

—I fail to really understand that. The Minister has said tonight that it is up to the State whether it gives the midwife $500. The Government has made this available. That answer was given to us during the Estimates hearings as well. How is the midwife's fee, which has been determined by the Commonwealth Department, assessed? Why on earth would the Department assess it to be a greater fee than that which is given to general practitioners? We know that it is $70 more than general practitioners are entitled to under the schedule fee. Why would a midwife be assessed to receive a greater amount? Her skills are not as great and, as I have pointed out to the Minister on so many occasions, when she gets into trouble she calls the general practitioner to get her out of the trouble that she is in. But we will leave that matter because obviously there is no assessment able to be justified on this occasion. But if the Minister has an answer-it appears that the officers are trying to justify it-I would be grateful to hear it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Government is doing is enabling the provision of the alternative birthing service to be provided with the assistance of a midwife. That involves encouraging, if you like, the States to enable the provision of this service either through a birthing centre or through some other arrangement. It is assessed that the Commonwealth could make a maximum contribution of $500 for each birth managed by that independent midwife. I have indicated how that $500 was arrived at. It is not put together as a fee for a midwife's service so much as a way of expressing the encouragement of the Commonwealth Government to enable the provision of this alternative birthing service. It is based on the notional amount which represents the approximate average saving to the Commonwealth in Medicare benefits compared with the cost in benefits if the birth had been managed by a private medical practitioner.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many ways in which this can be assessed. For example, one has to be aware that medically managed births generally involve a hospital stay of about five or six days at a cost of about $450 per day, while women having midwife assisted births either deliver at home or spend 24 hours or less in a birthing centre. The hidden costs of hospital births are substantial and must be acknowledged in any comparison with the Commonwealth's contribution towards services provided by midwives. That is one of the factors, no doubt, that were taken into account.

The type of care which is provided by the midwife involves the provision of routine antenatal care, the preparation for childbirth, advice on nutrition and so on. The midwife attends the woman for the duration of labour and for a minimum of three hours after the birth, an average time of 12 hours. Postnatally, the midwife performs routine screening tests and visits the home daily for seven to 10 days, providing advice and support on infant feeding, postnatal exercises and parent craft skills and substantial emotional help within the family setting. That is one of the factors that has also been taken into account in the provision of that funding.

Evidence given to the Medical Benefits Review Committee by the two professions-generally speaking, midwives and doctors-indicates that, on average, midwives spend about 45 hours with their clients throughout the pregnancy, birth and after-care, and medical practitioners spend about five hours on average. These were matters which were taken into account in the setting of that particular amount of money to be paid to the States to enable the provision of the service. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I correctly understand the Minister to say that a patient was in a birthing centre for only 24 hours? What happens to that great assessment if she is in longer because, as far as I know, patients are often in birthing centres for more than 24 hours or are moved from the birthing centre to a normal ward, which is what happens with the normal method of delivery? Perhaps I misunderstood the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was only giving a description of what has been supplied to me as the general pattern of time spent in birthing centres, which is apparently 24 hours or less. There will be occasions where further medical intervention is sought or required and there will be a transfer to a hospital.
—If the Department could supply me with the name of the place where they get those statistics, I would be very grateful.
—An attempt will be made to provide Senator Walters with that information.
—What is the cost of indemnity for the midwife?
—The officers understand that that information was supplied to the Committee as a follow-up to the meeting of Estimates Committee E. At page 61 it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian College of Midwives advises that they have negotiated a package for midwives which would provide indemnity insurance at a cost of $250 per midwife per annum for a cover of up to $1m. The package also covers home birthing work.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Medical Defence Association has made noises that future medical insurance cover may not be available if medical practitioners do not have direct and complete responsibility for patient care. What happens if that occurs? This is what the Medical Defence Association is threatening at this moment. Who will cover the patient and the medical practitioner who takes over halfway through the delivery of a baby when the midwife bows out? If that medical practitioner's medical defence does not cover him or her, will the Government cover the medical practitioner?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If a medical practitioner takes over the care of a patient and provides that patient with service and care based on the professional skills that the medical practitioner has acquired through training and experience, I assume that the insurance cover that the doctor has would cover that doctor in relation to the services which the medical practitioner provides. Obviously, the doctor cannot be responsible for an injury or complication brought on by the attentions of others to his or her present patient.

—Let me explain the process. On many occasions when a midwife gets into trouble, she calls a general practitioner or her specialist. That call is often pretty late-and on occasions too late. On those occasions, the Medical Defence Association has said already that it is looking at whether that medical practitioner would be covered because he or she has not been in to `direct and complete responsibility for the patient's care during the whole term'. If that is the case, who will cover the doctor that has been called in by the midwife?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give a definitive response. Quite clearly, there is some analogy with a doctor taking up the care of a patient after a paramedic perhaps-a Red Cross officer or somebody like that-has dealt with a patient who suffered some injury. If the State accepts Commonwealth funding for the establishment of these alternative homebirthing services, there would need to be consideration by the State of the sorts of issues Senator Walters has raised, such as the transfer of the midwife's care, supervision and responsibility to the practitioner or specialist. I will seek information as to whether the States are developing as part of their assurance that service of the best care can be provided to the woman concerned and her child in a way which protects the doctor or the midwife concerned from the consequences of a suit relating to the alleged bad delivery of that care. Quite frankly, I would need to follow it up.

—I will be interested in the response. I thank the Minister for his answer, although his analogy with the paramedics is not one that is sustainable because they are only used in crisis under emergency situations when no medical practitioner is available. My final question is: will the Government be funding through the States freestanding birthing centres, or must those birthing centres be attached to the hospitals?
—That is a matter for the States to determine. It is not a predetermined or absolute requirement that one type or category of birthing centre be established.

—Would it not be a good idea for the Department to consult with the medical profession, particularly the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, which has already indicated that its members would not be interested in giving the service to freestanding birthing centres-certainly birthing centres within a hospital where they would be available? Would it not be a good idea-before the Government leaves it open to the States-seeing that it is Commonwealth taxpayers' money, to see that it is established whether the profession is willing to work in the freestanding centres?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly see that there would be advantages in the States consulting with those particular bodies as to the decisions that the States make as to the sorts of services that they provide.
—It is Commonwealth money.

—The Commonwealth makes a contribution; it does not determine the way in which the States might facilitate the provision of the alternative birthing service. As I say, it can be a matter for consultation, as Senator Walters has quite rightly indicated. The States will certainly be undertaking that.

—I asked at the Estimates Committee-and did not get satisfactory response-whether the Government had set in place a record of any alteration in maternal or foetal morbidity and mortality with the changes being brought in with birthing centres. Has the Government been given assurances that there would be no deleterious effect in this regard?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can offer is the study reported upon by the United States national birth centre which has reported its findings on the outcomes of care and birth centres in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine of December 1989. I suppose I am only relating something that Senator Herron is already aware of. Does he want me to detail some of those findings?

—No, I do not. I am talking about Australian children and Australian mothers. Surveys done in the United States of America are completely immaterial as a justification to trot out that information. As it is Commonwealth money that is being put into this, I would like to know what mechanisms have been put in place to check whether there are any alterations in maternal morbidity, and foetal morbidity and mortality as a result of this new determination by the Government. Is there a check to see whether there is an increase, a decrease or no alteration in maternal and foetal morbidity and mortality?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot accept that the American study is entirely irrelevant to the situation that would obtain in Australia. No doubt those who are interested can find quite interesting information in that particular New England Journal of Medicine. It is worth noting in the Australian context that an extensive review undertaken by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) failed to support claims that homebirths are less safe than hospital births or that there are substantially greater risks to mother or child. I guess that is some indication of the view of the National Health and Medical Research Council in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, the program will have an evaluation component. Maternal and infant outcomes will also be monitored through the usual State collections of maternal and peri-natal statistics. Through that method a picture will be able to be built up of the results of access to these services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister tell me what the current evaluation procedure is?

—It is still being developed in consultation with the States. I think I answered this in response to a question from Senator Walters. Obviously, the States will be collecting the information in the first instance. It is intended that the evaluation will examine issues of cost effectiveness and health outcomes for mothers and babies. As I say, I believe that the NHMRC has recently funded the National Peri-natal Statistics Unit to analyse the statistics for homebirths in Australia for the years 1988 to 1990. That does not cover all the alternative birthing centres that will be covered by the methodology to be developed in consultation with the States.

—I ask whether that means that these figures will be collated separately within the statistics, and that those figures from the homebirthing centres can be identified within the overall maternal and foetal morbidity and mortality statistics.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is intended that that should be the case.
—I ask the Minister to repeat what he said to Senator Herron. I missed his answer when he quoted the information from the report relating to homebirths in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I was saying that the NHMRC has recently funded the National Peri-natal Statistics Unit to put together the figures for the homebirths in Australia for the years 1988 to 1990. (Quorum formed) I believe that Senator Walters may have been recalling something that I said some moments ago when I said that it is worth noting that an extensive review undertaken by the NHMRC failed to support claims that homebirths are less safe than hospital births, or that there are substantially greater risks to mother or child. If that is the statement that Senator Walters heard me say, I will anticipate her next question and provide the review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the review; I have the lot. I am just wondering whether the Minister has the subsequent statement on homebirths which puts it slightly differently. Following the fuss-for that is all I can call it-that that working party's report engendered, the National Health and Medical Research Council downgraded that a little. The statement on homebirths says:

SPEECH.PARA: As stated in the report of the working party, it has not been possible to determine the safety or otherwise of homebirths in the Australian context.

That could not be done because there were no statistics. We do know that there were many more morbidity cases in that group of homebirths and when we take into account that they are the ones which should have no complications at all-they are supposed to be the ones where everything goes naturally-it is an area of great concern.
I ask whether there will there be, or can the Minister assure me that there will be, a requirement in line with the recommendation from the National Health and Medical Research Council that:

All those planning to have a homebirth should be provisionally `booked in' to an appropriate hospital and should be encouraged at some time during the pregnancy to consult with a hospital obstetrics services.
And these are the recommendations:

All newborn infants should be examined in the first week of life by a medical practitioner. The midwife should undertake a routine newborn screening or refer the infant to the appropriate child health services.
Can the Minister give me an assurance that that will be undertaken?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that those matters should quite properly form part of the consideration of other States as to the protocols and guidelines that they require to be observed by the homebirthing or the birth centre services. I would imagine that the weight of those recommendations by the NHMRC would carry quite a bit of force with the States in establishing those protocols and the procedures that they should encourage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister may think it is being slightly painful in here, but I am sure that the labour pains being suffered outside are worse than those of any homebirth. I have been waiting for an hour to make that joke. I want to ask some questions about the vocational register. In the Estimates committee hearings, I asked a series of questions about the new vocational registration arrangements which were introduced on 1 December 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a significant number of problems with the register from the beginning, including the criteria of registration being loose and ill-defined and the list itself being poorly constructed and extremely inaccurate. However, overall, the most important issue is that there has been very little evidence provided to indicate that vocational registration is working in terms of either better patient care or improvements in the standard of general practice. The legislation provides that for general practitioners (GPs) to be eligible for vocational registration they have to be predominantly in general practice and have appropriate training in general practice.

The criteria used for vocational registration is determined by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). I actually asked for a copy of the criteria during the Estimates committee meetings but it has not been forthcoming from the Department as yet. I would appreciate it if the Minister could supply me with this information.

One matter I raised in the Estimates committee meeting was the requirement of GPs on the vocational register to provide home visits. The Committee was told that there is no legal requirement to provide home visits. The criterion is that, with full vocational registration, GPs have to give an undertaking that they will be available for home visits.

One of the indicators of compliance as to whether or not the GP is in general practice is whether or not he provides home visits. However, in practice, there is nothing to compel the general practitioner to do this. The point I am trying to make is that a higher rebate is being paid and the GP is being advertised as being a better doctor, which implies that one is getting a better service from these doctors.

In the Estimates hearing I asked to be provided with an update of figures of what percentage of vocationally registered GPs provide at least one home visit. My office has not yet been provided with that. The last figures that I have available to me are from the March 1990 quarter when 91.3 per cent of vocationally registered GPs undertook at least one home visit. Therefore, 8.7 per cent of vocationally registered GPs failed to undertake at least one home visit.

There are a significant number of GPs on the register who are failing to meet the criteria. I do not believe that the system, which has been held out to the public as one that provides a better quality GP, is working. The vocational register has been in operation for over 12 months. What is of concern is that there appears to have been no evaluation or check to ensure that people who are vocationally registered are adhering to the conditions of vocational registration.

A number of revised arrangements were outlined in the Estimates hearing, including a new application form and a letter being sent to all vocationally registered GPs reminding them of their obligations. However, the Department, the Health Insurance Commission and the RACGP have yet to decide on the matter of whether the HIC should make information available to the RACGP in order to assist it in monitoring the compliance with vocational registration criteria.

It is hoped that in the future an agreement is reached whereby evidence given to the HIC that a GP is not acting in compliance with vocational registration criteria is provided to the RACGP for investigation. I hope that the protocols for passing on this information are completed soon and that the vocational register is tightened up. I go back to the two questions that I have asked about the criteria for registration as a vocationally registered general practitioner, and also about the figures regarding the number of home visits undertaken by vocationally registered GPs.
Friday, 31 May 1991

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will certainly undertake to provide the criteria for registration. I do not know why that has not been provided but I imagine that it can be fairly readily provided. They are called guidelines, apparently, and they can be provided. As to the question of up to date figures on the percentage of vocationally registered doctors providing at least one home visit compared with other general practitioners, at the Estimates hearing Senator Patterson asked for an update of those figures. The Health Insurance Commission is currently extracting information to answer the honourable senator's question and detailed data will be provided when available. It is expected that the analysis would be able to be provided very shortly, but the extracting of the information is taking a little longer than had been thought. It is being undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I will be able to receive that before the end of this sitting. One of the other issues I wanted to address was the accuracy of the vocational register. In the Estimates hearing I raised the matter of the accuracy of this register. There were 7,561 GPs on the register as at 15 April. The Government's target, I believe, is 10,000 to 12,000. At the rate of 40 additions to the register a week, which were the figures supplied in Estimates, it will take over 12 months to reach even the lower limit of the Government's target.

SPEECH.PARA: I have received many complaints about the accuracy of the vocational register. Copies of parts of the register that I have obtained have been riddled with mistakes. Many of the problems with the register have been with practice locations listed. Many of the practice locations provided by the Health Insurance Commission are open but not active.

In the five to six weeks prior to Estimates, the Committee was told that there had been a process of analysis of activity location so that information given out now relates only to the most active of GP practices. I just wanted to check because the answer given in Estimates was that only the most active of the doctors' practices are listed. Does that mean that two or three practices can be listed on the vocational practice or the one at which the doctor is most active?

TALK.START.PARA: —The one practice location.

—I just confirm that it is the one practice at which the doctor is most active. When I was told during the hearing that if I were to obtain a list in two weeks I would find it more up to date I was quite sceptical and my scepticism proved justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a list here obtained from an HIC office about two weeks after the Estimates hearing which clearly shows that the Health Insurance Commission is still publishing multiple addresses when I have just been told that it gives people the one most active practice. It is still giving multiple addresses, many of which are not active premises. I could not see any improvement on the last list.

Another related matter I wish to raise is the method by which the public is informed of the GPs who are on the register. The Estimates Committee was clearly told that if a person requests a list of vocationally registered GPs, that list is forwarded in the mail if the list is too long to provide over the counter, that is, if there are more than five doctors in that post code.

From reading the Hansard, I think that both the Minister and I thought that, if there were more than five doctors in the list, one would receive the list by post. I gathered also from that Estimates hearing that one would not get a list of five doctors written by hand. But I have here a list received when somebody asked for a list of vocationally registered doctors which is written in the most appalling handwriting. It has something like the doctor's name, 253 and the address but with no name of the suburb. There is another one I can hardly read-I think it is Minchinbury-and then two other suburbs that are almost illegible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that received in the mail?

—No, it was not received in the mail, but over the counter-five handwritten scribbled addresses. It is also of great interest, but not much use to a person who is supposedly getting one of these vocationally registered doctors, most of whom got in under the grandfather clause anyway. Apparently one does get a handwritten list, but that is not what I believe I was told in Estimates. How a sick person or someone who is elderly is supposed to utilise this list, I will never know.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that begs to be asked is: why was this list provided when there appear to be over five doctors-in fact, 20 or more doctors-in this particular postcode? In Estimates the Committee was told that a list is not supplied over the counter if it is too long. The truth is that the public is only offered an illegible handwritten list of five GPs. How can the Minister reconcile this statement by the Health Insurance Commission officials as to the method of providing vocational register information with what actually happens in practice?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to recall what was said in the Estimates Committee. I thought that the five related to the number of postcode areas for which one could get a list of general practitioners. It was not five vocationally registered medical practitioners. The five related to the number of postcodes which would be searched to provide a list, as I recall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall what was said on page 144 of the Estimates Committee proceedings. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I would walk out with a handwritten list of five doctors.
Then Senator Tate said:
No, of the doctors of five postcode areas.
Then I asked:
One doctor in each of five postcode areas.
Then Senator Tate said:
No, all the doctors.
The Chairman-and I forget who it was at that time-said:
The concept is postcodes, not doctors.
Then I said:
But the thing is that I am going to have a handwritten list.
Mr Hazell then said:

We would give you a list of the vocationally registered doctors in the postcodes that you were interested in for up to five postcodes. If the list were too long we would send that list out to you. If it is just a short list of two, or three, or four names, we will conclude the transaction there.
That presumably would be in handwriting. We have here a list of five names, not the full list of all the doctors, and I want to know how that can be explained.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how the person approached the counter in relation to his inquiry; the handwritten illegible list of some five names was given to the person. But I am informed that what was intended to be said at the Estimates Committee, and what was understood, was that, if the person required all the doctors within a five postcode area, that would be provided. If it looked as though it would be too many to give in a simple, straightforward fashion across the counter to the satisfaction of the person making the inquiry, then a computer list of all the doctors in those five postcodes would be sent out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would advise the Minister that is not what is happening. I think that the Department needs to do something about its training program to advise its officers at the counter that that is the system, rather than that somebody should get a handwritten scribbled list that cannot be read. That does not conform with what I have been told here. I ask the Minister to ask the Department to ensure that the officers in the Medicare offices know what the requirements are for vocational registration.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been provided with a costing of a vocational register. The total cost to the Health Insurance Commission of getting the vocational register in its present form was estimated to be $2.12m. A sum of $1.62m has been spent on advertising and promotional costs-$1.62m spent on promoting and advertising a register that has multiple listings, incorrect addresses, and the names of GPs who are not meeting the criteria set down by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). I suggest to the Minister that the money would have been better spent if it had been directed at getting the register in a more accurate form than is the current one. I think I should put out for a contract. I would quite like to have $2.12m, and no doubt the Minister and I probably could go into business and set up an accurate vocational register very easily.

There seemed to be some problem in the Estimates in obtaining a full list of vocationally registered GPs. Health Insurance Commission officers have consistently argued during Estimates that secrecy provisions prevent the full disclosure of the list. As a member of the public, I can have access to a page or two, or even more. If I ask for five postcodes, the list will have in it a lot of general practitioners. It is given to assist the public. Well, I do not know whether it does assist the public. Presumably it is felt that it does assist the public to have access to vocationally registered GPs. This list contains, or is supposed to contain, the names, addresses and phone numbers of GPs, or anyway their names and addresses, supplied by the GPs to the RACGP and they are then passed on to the Health Insurance Commission. There is no-I repeat, `no'-secret information on the register, nor any information on the register that is not already obtainable by the public. I have been told in the Estimates Committee that it cannot have a list because of so-called secrecy provisions. Let me tell the Department-and I think Minister Tate questioned that advice at one stage-that I have received advice that this is not so. It would have been appropriate for the Committee to have been provided with that information since the Act does not prevent the Parliament receiving that information, and only when the Act specifies that the Parliament is not to have that information is that the case.
This morning Senator Crichton-Browne tabled documents on parliamentary privilege and secrecy provisions. The advice I had was as follows, and I shall read it into Hansard:

At first sight it might be thought that this matter raises the question of whether statutory general secrecy provisions, provisions which in general terms prevent officers disclosing information acquired under statutes or in the course of their work, have any application to the provision of information to parliamentary committees. The question was raised in relation to the National Crime Authority Act and the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, and is disputed in the advices to that committee which are attached to the explanatory memorandum accompanying the National Crime Authority (Powers of Parliament Joint Committee) Amendment Bill 1990, introduced by Senator Crichton-Browne on 8 November 1990. The Solicitor-General appears to think that the secrecy provision contained in that Act in some circumstances operates to prevent the provision of information to that Committee.
The advice goes on to say that:

. . . the person giving the advice maintains that the terms of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 make it utterly clear that the general statutory secrecy provisions cannot operate to prevent the provision of information to a parliamentary committee, such provision of information being explicitly declared to be a proceeding in Parliament by that Act.

And so the advice goes on. It leads me to believe that there is absolutely no reason why the Parliament is not able to be provided with that information. If any of the advisers shake their heads in the advisers box, let me say-and I think I will be backed up by Senator Herron-that in regard to the Medical Registration Board in Queensland one can go and buy a copy of the list of registered doctors for a dollar or two, containing their names, addresses, and all the information that is here on the vocational register. The Minister did achieve what seemed to me to be the impossible in that I could look at the vocational register. I received a letter that says that I was not to use it or to publish it:

At the recent Estimates Committee you made a request for the Committee to be supplied with a copy of the vocational register. The Commission has declined to do this on the basis that in supplying the list to the Committee it will become a public document.

I say to the Minister that there is nothing in here that is secret. If the Department argues that it has got commercial value, I can find out from some of the commercial operators more about the doctors who are on this list than is available there, and they are more accurate lists. The letter continues:
The General Manager has agreed that this be released to you personally and I would request that it not be published in any way.

I will abide by that, but I will challenge in this place the right of a department to say that to me-to say that to parliament. There is nowhere in the Act that precludes this Parliament from demanding and asking for that to be tabled and from receiving that document. I will not do that in good faith with the Minister, but I will continue to insist that this Parliament has access to that document in order to evaluate it.

It is appalling. I have the document here. I refer to the Canberra section of the document, and the Minister has just told me that the list would be brought fairly much up to date, with improvements that would take about two weeks from 18 April. This document is dated 10 May 1991, and it lists doctors with multiple entries, doctors who have retired, doctors who have moved to Sydney, doctors who are not at the address, doctors who have moved and doctors who have not been known in the area-all on this up to date vocational register which will be given to sick, elderly people when they go into the Medicare office to get information about these wonderful vocationally registered doctors from whom they will get a very special service, many of whom, as I said, qualified under the grandfather clause.

As I said in that debate over and over again, the Opposition had no objection at all to improving the level of knowledge of general practitioners, but this is a farce-an absolute farce. How many million dollars have been spent on this absolutely appalling list? I will be going through this list and asking continually for updated lists because I want to see the situation improve. I expect this list to be presented to the Parliament. I do not believe that there can be an argument that this document should not be tabled in Parliament. I will be seeking further advice, but I am telling the Health Insurance Commission that I will be hounding it until it gets this list right.

I know that there are changes and that doctors move, but it is not good enough. It is messy. There are duplications and it does not help people who are seeking assistance from doctors who, according to the Government, will provide a better service. What is the Minister's advice on whether he believes that it is appropriate for this document not to be tabled in the Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the advice from the Attorney-General's Department reveals that the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission may exercise his discretion to release the register in full, and that such a release would not contravene the secrecy provisions of the Act. It had been thought that the details of the register could be revealed only under the public interest clause of the secrecy provisions of the Act. Apparently that is not the case, as I am advised tonight. Indeed, the General Manager does have a discretion to permit the release of the register in full without contravening the secrecy provisions of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: However, privacy principle No. 10 which, as honourable senators know, is contained in the Privacy Act passed by this Parliament, talks about the use of data for purposes unrelated to the purpose for which the information was collected, and the General Manager of the Commission has decided to maintain the policy of limiting the release of data from the vocational register. So, while I cannot say that the secrecy provisions of the Act in themselves preclude the provision of the information to the honourable senator, the General Manager has exercised his discretion in a way that is somewhat limited. The information has been provided to the honourable senator for her analysis and commentary, for the purposes which she has in mind in order to improve the standard of the register, to enable her to question officials as vigorously as she has and, as I say, to goad them into the proper construction of that important register document, which apparently is not in complete harmony with the precise information which ought to be on it and available to those who seek to have the benefit of a list of doctors who are on the register. As I say, the General Manager has adopted that policy and has made the information available to the honourable senator. I hope that its having been made available to her enables her to undertake the sort of questioning that is appropriate in order to ensure that this vocational register is properly assembled.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the vocational register, it is a recognition that the person so certified is providing a service of a higher calibre than someone who is not on the register. It seems an absurdity to me that that is not published. It is in the interests of the person on the register to have that available. It is an added benefit to a person to be on that register, yet the Minister is saying to us that it is a private matter. It is absurd.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that lists of other specialists, if I can put them in that category, are not published either. It is something that is just not undertaken by the Commission.

—For the Department's purposes, I will provide it with a list of specialists in Queensland. It is published every year. There is a specialist register of every specialist in Queensland, broken down according to speciality, name and address, year of graduation and qualifications. If this list is categorised as a specialist register, I see no difference between that and the lists that are published in my own State and, I would expect, in every State of Australia, because there are medical registration boards in every State of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of force in what both Senator Patterson and Senator Herron have put to the Committee. I will undertake to convey the strength and sense of their view to the General Manager and see whether the discretion can be exercised in a way that is not as circumscribed as has been the case to this point.

—I want for a moment to pursue the question that first inhibited the capacity of Senator Patterson to obtain the information. It was originally denied on the basis of the secrecy provisions. Presumably, if the information had been provided, an offence would have been committed, according to the Attorney-General. Is the Minister saying that an offence could be established, that a prosecution could succeed in a court on the basis of evidence given to a committee of the Parliament which is covered by section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act, the source and reason for which the Minister is well familiar with?
—The Minister is a well renowned legal expert, but I am not sure whether we should be asking him questions of a legal nature in this Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the original stance depended on a distinction between the Estimates committees and other committees of the Parliament and, indeed, the Senate itself, in that Senate Estimates committees are not possessed of the same powers to compel production of documents and so on that is vested in other committees. It was on the basis of that distinction that an argument was constructed that it was not possible to provide to Senate Estimates committees the information that was sought. Since that opinion was given, it has been thought that section 3f of the Health Insurance Act, which refers to the vocational register, does vest in the General Manager of the Commission the unfettered discretion to release names and addresses from the register. It is on that specific provision in the Act that I was relying in making the suggestion that I did to Senator Patterson and Senator Herron.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that, but I do not understand the distinction the Minister is drawing between an Estimates committee and an ordinary committee of the Senate. The distinction the Minister appears to be presuming to draw is that there are no coercive powers for Estimates committees but there are for other committees. If the information is provided as a result of a demand by the committee, privilege attaches; but if the information is simply asked for and is provided by the witness, an offence occurs.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought, with the greatest respect, that is nonsense. Privilege attaches whether the information is provided either to an Estimates committee or any other committee, however it is given, whether the witness or documents have been subpoenaed or the witness has simply been invited to provide certain information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis of the advice that was given was section 135a (1) of the National Health Act, which is the secrecy provision.
—The standard secrecy provision, which you will find in all sorts of Acts.

—Maybe. The power to compel the attendance of witnesses and to require them to answer questions is one of the express powers conferred on the Senate and the House of Representatives by section 49 of the Constitution-as Senator Crichton-Browne would be aware-it being one of the privileges of the House of Commons as at 1 January 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 49 of the Constitution, such powers may only be abrogated or modified by an expressed declaration of the Parliament. It follows that section 135a (1) of the Act does not affect the Senate's power to require disclosure of information specified in that provision and no breach of section 135a (1) would result from such disclosure.

In other words, there is no express declaration in section 135a (1) to abrogate the powers of the Parliament to compel the attendance of witnesses to answer questions or whatever. Senate Estimates committees, however, do not enjoy the Senate's powers in relation to the disclosure of information. The functions, powers and procedures of a Senate Estimates committee are prescribed in Senate standing order 26. Standing order 26 (13) provides:
The Committees may ask for explanations from Ministers of State in the Senate, or officers, relating to the items of proposed expenditure.

That is, the standing order does not confer on the committee the power to compel witnesses to answer questions or produce documents. Given this, the question arises whether section 135a (1) prohibits the disclosure of the prescribed information to Estimates committees. The conclusion was that information could not be divulged. I will make this particular opinion available to Senator Crichton-Browne, having the concurrence of the department to which it was provided. It may be that he will find it very useful in his deliberations on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that we will be able to chase this issue to a conclusion. To put it bluntly, I understood the Minister to be saying that, unless the words of an Act particularly exclude privilege, the Parliamentary Privileges Act prevails, notwithstanding the secrecy provisions, unless the secrecy provisions say to the contrary. In this case they do not, and they are the words I thought the Minister read out. Therefore, the secrecy provisions the Minister read out are the standard secrecy provisions. It does not matter whether coercive powers are available to an Estimates committee. That seems to be totally irrelevant. The committee can simply invite a witness who was quarantined by the Parliamentary Privileges Act from any offence under the secrecy provisions, save where the Act says particularly to the contrary. Surely, that is the point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The argument is that the secrecy provision prevails against an Estimates committee because the Estimates committee is not exercising the powers of the Senate as conferred on it by section 49 of the Constitution.
—But you are only talking about one part. The power to coerce and the power to call by compulsion is just one of the powers. That does not visit the privilege.

—To be quite frank, I cannot deal with this argument at this time of night with other things happening. I am a little distracted. I would like to make this available to Senator Crichton-Browne. Perhaps we can have some discussion about it, or the Standing Committee of Privileges might have a look at it, to see whether it is consistent with that Committee's understanding of the matter.
—Do you wish to table that, Minister?
—Yes, I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue it any further. For a moment I thought I saw an indication from Senator Tate that he was understanding the thrust of what I was saying. Perhaps it is a matter that ought to be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges or to an appropriate committee. Not only has this matter been raised in recent times but also the Solicitor-General has been giving legal opinions roughly along the lines that you have proffered tonight. On each occasion they do not seem to stand up to a logical conclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: To the extent that there are so many Acts with standard secrecy provisions, it is inevitable that the Senate itself and its committees will be confronted with this on an increasing number of occasions because of this new-found interpretation the Solicitor-General has given for the purpose of the National Crime Authority. The Minister is quite right: it ought to be cleared up so that we have a better understanding of what the Solicitor-General is trying to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure where that leaves me now with the suggestion the Minister made before that he would review the possibility of the Senate receiving the vocational register. Could the Minister clarify that? We have had an intervention in between what the Minister told me. If it is to be available for the purpose of ensuring that this list is as accurate as possible to provide constituents with appropriate information about vocationally registered doctors, we would need to receive it on a reasonably regular basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The request was made on 10 May. I do not want my office flooded, but when we ask for that vocational register it should be available if the requests are reasonable. I hope the Minister will also address that issue. If I were to examine one suburb, or a number of suburbs, I hope I would not then be told, `Of course, the list you have is out of date, and it is no wonder you are not getting the same list from the Medicare office'.

It is appropriate that we have `the list' and that we have access to reasonably regular updated lists. I would like the Minister to comment on whether what he said to me earlier now holds, given that we now seem to be looking at the whole of the secrecy provisions, and whether he feels it would be appropriate for the Senate to have, at least every three months, an updated list of the vocational register.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I was saying was that in relation to the sections of the statute dealing with the vocational register there is a capacity vested in the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission to comply with Senator Patterson's request. I will ask the General Manager to consider whether he might exercise his discretion in order to make that register available in a more general way than simply providing it to Senator Patterson for the purposes of enabling her to ask the questions which she has put tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be conveying that request to him. Obviously, I agree with Senator Patterson that, even if she were the only person to be provided-also if others are to be provided-she ought to be provided with a list which is certainly accurate and reasonably up to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record my appreciation of the Minister because it has been a long, drawn-out battle to get access to the list. In all my dealings with him on this issue, he has understood the purpose for which I have wanted this list. I appreciate that he has come as far as he has this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue I would like to raise is the reissuing of the Medicare card. I draw to the Minister's attention an advertisement in the Age entitled `How to get your new Medicare card'. At least the people shown in the advertisement have hats on, unlike the photographs that the Health Insurance Commission decked its annual report with last year. I hope that those people have factor 15-plus suntan lotion on. In the advertisement we have two people sunning themselves. They are told in the advertisement:

How to get your new Medicare card . . . A new Medicare card is being introduced, so we can more efficiently validate and process claims, and because many of the old cards are wearing out or contain particulars which have changed. So how do you get one? By doing absolutely nothing. Most cards will be automatically sent within the next six months. If you don't receive one this time, it probably means your card particulars need to be confirmed. But you still need do nothing.
That is wonderful! That is actually what is written here. It continues:
We'll contact you if we need more information. Naturally, your old card remains valid while you're waiting for the new one. So sit back, relax and let Medicare do all the work.

I hope the Minister feels confident that he is going to get his new Medicare card. If this advertisement is accurate, can the Minister tell me why the Assistant General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission told the Estimates Committee that, firstly, the Health Insurance Commission would not reissue cards without making contact with people-I presume that its officers are going to stroll along the beach giving them to people-and, secondly, that for the first six months Medicare cards will be reissued when claims are made at Medicare offices? It seems to me that the information I was given in Estimates and the information in this advertisement, which appeared just a few weeks later, do not correlate. Could the Minister, or the Department through the Minister, explain?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what was attempted to be conveyed by that advertisement was that no special steps have to be undertaken by a person presently holding a Medicare card, for example, by making a special application, writing a letter or visiting a branch office specifically for that purpose. It is envisaged that, in making contact with a branch office in order to secure a Medicare payment, then at that time the opportunity will be taken by the Medicare office to do whatever is necessary to enable that person to receive a new card. But it is quite clear that some contact will have to be made in order to enable the process to take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advertisement says:

SPEECH.PARA: By doing absolutely nothing. Most cards will be automatically sent within the next six months.
It does not say anything about going to a Medicare office. I have not used my Medicare card for so long that I do not know where it is. It is said:
Most cards will be automatically sent within the next six months.

It seems to me odd that the advertisement says, `By doing absolutely nothing'. Either it means that people do not do anything and the card comes in the mail or it means that the Health Insurance Commission needs a new advertising agency, because what is in here is not what was said at Estimates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what was attempted to be created was the correct perception for people-that is, they do not have to take a positive initiative themselves to secure a new Medicare card; the Medicare card will come to them principally through the contact they make with the Medicare branch office when they seek to submit some sort of patient claim. In other words, that will be the occasion whereby a new card will be issued rather than the Medicare cardholder having to take a particular step to get one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister or the Department advise me: obviously, the Minister's advice is that the person will have to have had some contact with the Medicare office in order to get a new card-that is, by making a claim or by, for some other reason, being in a Medicare office when someone will ask if he or she has a Medicare card on them so that it can be updated. A little brochure that the Health Insurance Commission has put out also seems to indicate that nothing needs to be done. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: There's a new Medicare card. But don't worry, we'll keep you posted . . . How do I get one? Each Australian will be posted a new card. Most will be sent automatically over a six months period . . . The remainder will be sent after card particulars are confirmed.
I presume that this is saying that the new card will be sent automatically after I have made a Medicare claim.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that there is a strategy whereby, for the first six months, the reissue of cards will depend on the person's coming in and presenting a claim at the Medicare branch office. That will be the trigger. After that initial six-month period, which should cover a tremendous number of Medicare card holders, for those who are left there will be an advertising campaign to get them to fill out something which will initiate the process of obtaining a new Medicare card.

—The Health Insurance Commission admitted that there were some 300,000 ineligible and deceased people currently enrolled in Medicare. How can the Health Insurance Commission ensure the integrity of the new Medicare card when the advertisement seems to indicate that it is being issued straight from the Medicare enrolment file?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be compiled exclusively from the Medicare enrolment file. The thrust of the advertisement was simply designed to prevent panic running through the Medicare card holder community or to counter the suggestion that this proposal was something like the old Australia Card proposal, where one had to present oneself or something like that. The thrust of the advertisement was to allay fears or worries about the process, to indicate that the introduction will take a gradual and discreet course and to indicate that people did not have to rush in to their Medicare office especially in order to get a new Medicare card to secure their future entitlements.
—The Minister still has not allayed my concerns that we are not going to have a Medicare card which does not have reasonable integrity.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am assured by officials that the Health Insurance Commission has a process of checking the integrity of the system which will lead to the reissuing of the Medicare card. I am told that the Commission has designed a replacement strategy which is intended to detect most of the abuses of card systems commonly thought to exist by not making procedures too onerous for the vast number of honest citizens. I believe that the honourable senator could imagine that there are certain procedures available to the Commission to enable it to detect those abuses. They will be put in place, and one hopes that the Commission will be able to weed out such abuses as might be attempted.

—I hope so, too. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner has agreed to changes to the Medicare card. Has the Privacy Commissioner given his blessing to the extended use of the Medicare card in the on-line eligibility checking? What uses has he yet not approved?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that extensive discussions are still taking place with the Privacy Commissioner and it would not be proper to prejudge the final outcome of those discussions. I am told that, subject to some conditions, the Privacy Commissioner has indicated his concurrence with the procedures for the reissue of the Medicare card and its use for eligibility checking, but that he has indicated that in the future it is his intention to issue guidelines in relation to those matters.

—I thank the Minister. As my colleague behind me said, that seemed fairly quick; we seemed to not have them and then have them. Will the compulsory computerised claims transmission system (CTS) still be introduced on 1 June 1991?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been deferred by one month; it will commence on 1 July 1991.
—Can the Minister give the Committee any reason why this extension has occurred?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that representations from the Pharmacy Guild of Australia have been the primary factor in this decision.

—In the Estimates hearings, the Department told the Committee that there are a significant number of pharmacists yet to move to the computerised claims transmission system; I think it was 700 of them. How many pharmacists are still to move to the computerised CTS and what assistance has been given to aid the transition of these pharmacists to the computerised claims transmission systems? (Quorum formed)

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the numbers, but they can be provided. The assistance package comprises $1,000. People who are going to close their pharmacies are exempted; the very few people who do not have a continuous electricity supply are exempted; and people who are isolated are exempted. That is the package that is offered.

—I ask for the indulgence of the Committee. I have two more topics I want to deal with. Will a dedicated line from the eligibility checking device in the pharmacy to the Health Insurance Commission be open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be open seven days a week but there will be several hours-maybe two hours each day-when it is closed down for what I am told is referred to as maintenance. I am not quite sure what that involves. It will be in the early hours of the morning, obviously-like this morning.

—I will take note of that last remark by the Minister-`like this'. I presume that that will take into account that sometimes we have a three-hour daylight saving change with Western Australia. If the line is shut down, is the pharmacist exposed to the risk of not receiving payment for claims that he has been unable to check eligibility for? I am thinking of some of the 24-hour pharmacies around Melbourne and Sydney that I know of.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In those few instances, as I say, it will probably be closed down in the very early hours of the morning. But I can see that there are 24-hour pharmacies that may have customers presenting and claiming to qualify for a benefit. It has been made clear that, if an incorrect assessment is made as a result of the line being down, the pharmacist will not be penalised. Apparently that has been notified to the Guild.
—Has the Health Insurance Commission undertaken any studies to check the accuracy of the Auditor-General's figures regarding incorrect pensioner concession numbers in pharmacy claims?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that about 18 months ago the Health Insurance Commission undertook an internal study which indicated a 3.5 per cent error. The Auditor-General has said that there might be a margin of error above that, but no more recent work has been done within the Commission to clarify that matter.

—Is this error caused by pharmacists making incorrect numbers, or the fact that the information received from the Department of Social Security is inaccurate, or is it because of errors on the part of the Health Insurance Commission? Do we have any proportioning of those errors?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no further analysis of the reasons why that error was made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have four questions about that percentage of incorrect pensioner concession numbers in pharmacy claims. Perhaps it would be appropriate for me to put those questions on notice and let the Department try to answer them as quickly as possible rather than hold up the Committee for something that is of general interest to me and most probably not to many other people. So I will put those four questions on notice next week.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise one other issue about the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. Senator Walters and I asked a number of questions regarding one pharmacy approval in Port Macquarie but questioning was difficult, given the lack of certain relevant information. I have been provided with an opinion which states that there is no reason why the information I asked for could not have been supplied. The issue of new pharmacy approvals is a matter for concern because the whole idea behind the pharmacy restructuring process was to reduce pharmacy numbers.

The Government has stated that there are too many pharmacies servicing our population. Answers to questions about the desired pharmacy population ratio have been unsatisfactory. But, given the premise that there are too many pharmacies, it is a concern that here we have an example of an area identified by the Department as being overserviced and a new pharmacy having been approved and subsequently opened. I will not go into all of the details.

Another thing that concerned me when I read the new monthly journal Retail Pharmacy-there is not only that publication, which we mentioned in Estimates, but also I have been told about another one in Victoria and another in another State-was the article which stated:
Rorts are already being reported-and don't forget, you are paying for them.
I suppose it was reminding pharmacists and the taxpayers that they were paying for them. The article continues:

At least one pharmacist is known to have closed a pharmacy within 500 metres of his long established business and handed in the oldest approval number.
