Meanwhile, he actually closed the newer business and simultaneously ``relocated'' into the older premises. Given that the authority had to approve the ``relocation'' one can only ask whose money do they think they are handing out?

In one very large town two nearly adjacent pharmacists were considering amalgamating with the younger pharmacist buying out the older partner. They then found that after getting $80,000 from the authority and several hundred thousand dollars goodwill changing hands between the two, that a third pharmacist just under 500 metres away could move into the vacated building. No sterilisation of the site as it was in the 500 metres allowed even if that site was the subject of money paid out for amalgamation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson, can you help me in relation to which reservation you are referring to?
—It is a reservation about the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority.
—Yes, but I cannot find it.
— It is in the report.
—Perhaps I could be helpful, Mr Chairman. You will find it under my reservation `Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme'. You will find that under my name.
—As long as it is there that is all right, although I am not quite sure that it is there.
—We were assured that it does apply to the whole of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
—The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The chairman of the authority was questioned on this and his reply was: ``We are only interested in the handing in of approval numbers.''

That is a direct quote. One should not always assume that this journal would be any more accurate than some of our newspapers, but at least it is an issue that has been raised by someone in the field. Another issue which is pointed out in another article by another author in that same journal makes me very concerned about the Restructuring Authority. The article points out an example and states:
This situation has highlighted how easy it is to take advantage of the amalgamation and closure system.
The article goes on to say:
Consider those pharmacies in major hotel complexes and inner city shopping centres.

It goes on to refer to pharmacies which do not give out many subsidised scripts. The article asks what is to stop these operators from applying for the closure package, getting a golden handshake and the next day reopening the pharmacy's doors, albeit minus an approval number. The overall effect on its business might be minimal, given the fact that it has not dispensed many subsidised scripts. As the article says:

After all, the odd Amoxil or KH3 can be dispensed without the customer noticing the lack of approval number. And as long as they conform with all the requirements of the pharmacy board, the board would have no power to stop these pharmacies operating.
Another problem which has surfaced involves partnerships which own several pharmacies in close proximity.
They can elect to close one that attracts the highest overhead, directing all business to their remaining outlets.
The pharmacy they decide to close may well be the most convenient for the customers.
I thought this was what we were on about. I continue:
And what happens when that landlord wishes to find another pharmacy tenant and is prepared to challenge the guild/government agreement in his efforts to do so?
The article goes on to say:
Unlikely to happen-or already occurring in at least one suburb in Sydney?

A number of other issues which have been raised concern that. In fact, sufficient concern has been expressed to me that I have discussed it with my colleagues. Senator Walters is also very concerned and because of that concern I have circulated an amendment to the motion that the report of the Estimates Committee be adopted. I move:
At end of motion, add ``, and that the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 9 September 1991:
The implementation of the pharmaceutical restructuring measures including:
(a) the operation of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority, including the objectives, guidelines and methods used when dealing with the matters placed before it;

(b) the relationship between the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority and the Health Insurance Commission and the degree of co-operation between both organisations concerning the operation of the Pharmacy Restructuring Scheme; and
(c) the operation of the Health Insurance Commission in approving applications for new pharmacies subsequent and prior to the setting up of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has tried to assist Senator Patterson in relation to her queries concerning the operations of the pharmacy restructuring scheme, but particularly in relation to a certain case, and certain documentation has been made available. However, in relation to the more general matters that Senator Patterson is concerned about, the Government is not disposed to support the reference of matters to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. It believes that, as the Authority was established only in February 1991 and works totally within guidelines determined by the Minister which determine the criteria for approval of a new pharmacy for closure payments and for amalgamation payments, and as the Authority makes recommendations to the Secretary of the Department and the Secretary's decisions are reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), we have a system of review which ought to enable the occasions when the Authority-or the Secretary acting on the advice of the Authority-might be acting in a way which was not in accordance with the guidelines to be reviewed quite adequately.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the Authority intends to recommend to the Minister shortly that a committee be established to review the outcomes of its operations from the standpoint of the achievement of the objectives of the pharmacy restructuring program. As far as individual applicants are concerned, there is an AAT review of outcomes. As I say, there are very clear ministerial guidelines or criteria for Authority recommendations.

As for the program as a whole and a review of its operation, the Authority-and we have to remember that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia has two members on the Authority-is able to carry out an evaluation of itself. In addition, it will be seeking from the Minister a review committee to examine its operations with regard to the objectives set for it.

I believe that the sorts of matters which the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs might inquire into under Senator Patterson's particular reference are matters that are perhaps a little premature and unnecessary, given the only very recent establishment and operation of the Authority.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just seek from the Minister an assurance that the supported accommodation assistance programs will not be devolved to the States.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the support accommodation assistance programs are part of the matters which will be considered by the Special Premiers Conference and, indeed, it is scheduled for consideration by that Special Premiers Conference in November. I believe that it would be premature for me to pre-empt the decisions of that Premiers Conference.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the report of Estimates Committee E, together with Senator Patterson's amendment, be adopted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.
Senate adjourned at 1.18 a.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 15 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to a proposal for a protocol to import raw salmonid flesh from New Zealand:
(1) Have all possible tests been undertaken to ensure that imported raw salmonid flesh does not, and cannot, contain viruses or diseases which could affect Australia's aquaculture fish population.

(2) Will the Minister give an unqualified assurance that the signing of this protocol will be delayed until such time as irrefutable proof can be given by the New Zealand Government and the salmonid flesh producer that it is impossible to contaminate the Australian fish population.
(3) Would existing salmonid flesh export arrangements with other nations, such as the United States or Japan, be affected if the proposed protocol with New Zealand is signed.
(4) Does New Zealand permit the import of raw salmonid or trout flesh from Australia; if not, why not.
(5) Has this protocol already been signed; if not, when is it likely to be signed.
(6) Will the protocol be a disallowable document under the terms of s.46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 &2) The finalised protocol will contain stringent conditions to ensure that the risk of disease entry into Australia is negligible. The risk of an exotic organism establishing in Australian fish populations from imports of New Zealand salmonid meat must be considered very remote. This is especially so as the material is being imported for human consumption and the likelihood that any product containing infective material will come into contact with fish must be very small. The principal practical issue in regard to trade relates to the cost of measures which will give the desired level of confidence.
(3) I am advised that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is unaware of any such effects.

(4) No. The New Zealand position on access for salmonid products is very closely aligned to that of Australia. Like Australia, New Zealand allows access to heat treated product, but does not allow the importation of uncooked product. New Zealand is presently assessing the importation of uncooked salmonid meat from Australia, just as Australia is assessing the importation of uncooked salmonid meat from New Zealand. New Zealand claims to have a higher health status for salmonids than Australia as epizootic haemorrhagic necrosis virus, Aeromonas salmonicida, and some Streptococcus and amoeba species which cause or have the potential to cause salmonid diseases are present in Australia but not in New Zealand.

(5) The protocol has not been signed at this time. The exact timing of finalisation will depend on satisfactory resolution of the outstanding technical issues-this is not expected to occur before July 1991.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Prime Minister and Cabinet: Direct Marketing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funding spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Taking direct marketing to mean an interactive system of marketing which uses one or more advertising media to effect a measurable response and/or transaction at any location, the response is as follows.
Direct marketing is utilised by the Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA), the Aboriginal Reconciliation Unit (ARU) and the Office of the Status of Women (OSW).
(a) in instances where the Office wishes to provide detailed information on programs or activities to the general public and defined target groups.
(b) to achieve a greater awareness of multicultural issues and relevant Commonwealth Government programs and services.
(c) distribution of printed material through direct mail.

(2) No. Because direct marketing is only a small part of OMA's community information activities and overlaps several functional areas these costs are incorporated into individual program/project costs.

(3) Yes. OMA has a mailing list of around 23,000 names and addresses in various categories, including organisations and individuals who have asked to be included on the list. Telephone numbers are not listed.

(4) Yes. OMA publishes a quarterly newsletter, Focus, which provides information and articles on a range of topics and is distributed to all those organisations and individuals on the mailing list. In 1990-91, issues of the newsletter included special fliers advertising the availability of Office publications and survey forms seeking comments on OMA's posters and the newsletter itself.

In addition, guidelines for the Community Initiatives Grants Program, part of the Commonwealth Government's Community Relations Strategy, were sent to approximately 3,500 community groups in April 1991. Letters were also sent to over 2,000 people in February 1991 inviting them to have their names included on a register of individuals with expertise in multicultural affairs for use by Commonwealth agencies in recommending names for appointment to statutory and other bodies.
OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN
(a) in particular instances where the Office wishes to provide information on Government policies and programs to improve the status of women.
(b) a greater awareness of women's issues and Government policies and programs to improve the status of women.
(c) OSW uses a mailing list to distribute a quarterly newsletter, OSWomen. A coupon has been placed in the OSWomen newsletter to allow new readers to add their names to the mailing list.
(2) No, direct marketing is a minor element in the OSW publications program and is not a significant expenditure item.

(3) Yes, OSW maintains a data base for the publications mailing list. The information on the mailing list is limited to name, address and area of interest and is not used for telemarketing. In addition, the Office maintains a mailing list of major women's organisations.

(4) Yes, OSW includes in the OSWomen newsletter notices advising of the availability of particular publications. A coupon for self-nomination to the mailing list was placed in a women's supplement of the Sydney newsletter St George Leader in March 1991. A mailout of guidelines and application forms for the National Agenda for Women Grants Program took place in July 1990 to organisations and individuals who had previously expressed interest in applying for a grant.

(a) The ARU believes that direct marketing will be of assistance in providing information and reports on progress with the Aboriginal reconciliation process to various groups in the community, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal.
(b) The use of direct marketing would help ensure that the reconciliation process has a successful outcome.
(2) No. As these activities overlap several functional areas the costs are incorporated into program costs.

(3) The ARU is in the process of developing a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing. The final format of the database will not be determined until the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has been established.
(4) The ARU has not undertaken any direct mailing this financial year.
(1) &(2) These questions are not applicable to the Division.

(3) The Social Justice Secretariat, a Branch of Social Policy Division, has a mailing list of welfare organisations, academics, librarians, etc. It also has a list of SES officers and a list of relevant organisations from the Office of Multicultural Affairs.
(4) The Social Justice Secretariat mailed out its Social Justice Strategy Statement 1990-91 immediately after the last Budget to everyone on its general list and its SES list.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 19 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department considered the effectiveness of direct marketing; if so, please provide details of: (a) the areas in which the department believes direct marketing will be of most use to it; (b) the results it would hope to achieve from direct marketing; and (c) the types of direct marketing methods considered most relevant and effective for the department's purposes, for example, direct mail, telephone canvassing or other forms of direct marketing.

(2) Has the department separated direct marketing as a budget item in Budget expenditure terms; if so, please provide details of the level of funds spent since 1 July 1990, the anticipated level to 30 June 1991 and the purposes for which the direct marketing will be used; if not, does the department anticipate separating direct marketing as a budget item in its expenditure details; if not, why not.
(3) Does the department have, or is it in the process of developing, a database from which it can operate its own direct mailing or telephone canvassing projects; if so, please provide details.
(4) Has the department undertaken any direct mailing activities for this financial year; if so, please include details of the subject of the project, timing and to whom it was directed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Bureau of Immigration Research (BIR) and the Office of Local Government (OLG) have considered the effectiveness of direct marketing.
(a) The BIR believes direct marketing will be of greatest use to it in promoting its conferences and publications.
The OLG has developed a communication strategy which includes marketing OLG's products and activities. The OLG has a number of target audiences including:
* local governing bodies, both elected members and officers;
* Local Government representatives bodies-Australian Local Government Association (ALGA), State Local Government associations, Local Government unions and Local Government professional bodies;
* State government departments and agencies-as relevant;.
* other interest groups-Australian Council of Trade Unions, Australian Council of Social Services, Housing Industry Association, etc;

* Local Government education and training bodies-industry training network, Australian Centre for Local Government studies, Charles Sturt University, Institute of Municipal Management, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology, etc;
(b) The BIR would hope to achieve wide interest and attendance at the conferences and increased sales of its reports through the Australian Government Publishing Service.
The OLG to contribute to and implement Federal Government strategies on matters concerning Local Government and local communities, and promote local achievement of national objectives.
(c) The BIR considers that direct mail is the most relevant and effective means.
At the OLG, marketing is carried out through:
* OLG providing copies free of charge of newsletters and comprehensive publication;
* Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) Mail Order sales and Commonwealth Government Bookshops;
* speeches by the Minister and OLG officers;
* publications of other agencies and regional newspapers; and
* photocopy service by Local Government Development Program grant recipients.
(2) No. Direct marketing will not be separated as a budget item because it does not represent a significant cost.
(3) The BIR has a database of approximately 2500 names for distributing its quarterly BIR Bulletin magazine, publications catalogue and conference promotion inserts.
The OLG has developed a mailing database comprising Local Government, State Authorities, industry, relevant professional associations, unions, media and consumer groups.

(4) The BIR mailed out copies of the BIR Bulletin, publications catalogue and insert about its Social Impact of Immigration Conference, in February. Expression of interest forms for the Conference have since been mailed to State and Territory Ethnic Affairs Commissions and Ethnic Communities' Councils, all registrants for the inaugural National Immigration Outlook Conference held last November, and heads of selected state and federal departments.
